Title: Marion Hecht
Comment: I am a licensed LPC and would like to see LPC's added to the list of eligible providers to conduct SAP assessments. MFT's have been added. Licensed professional counselors are licensed in all 50 states, have a minimum of a masters degree in psychology or counseling or a related field, and meet educational and experiential requirements. I conduct non-DOT assessments currently, and would like to be able to join the SAP provider pool.I have extensive experience treating clients with substance abuse issues.

Title: Comment from Greg Gayden
Comment: I urge the Department to deny this request for EAS operations. The EAS program is a gross waste of taxpayer money, one that subsidizes flights to far flung rural communities at tremendous cost to the greater population as a whole. In many cases, EAS flights operate with just a handful of passengers, while the government pays carriers to operate flights with empty seats. There is no good reason that people who choose to live in rural areas cannot drive a few hours to the nearest large commercial airport if they want to fly somewhere. Tens of millions of dollars are wasted each year on EAS service, and the routes contained within this application are no exception.

Title: Comment from Harriet Petrulio
Comment: Because of a tragedy, the FAA, United States legislature and the American public decided that it was time to increase the required experience and training levels of pilots flying commercial aircraft.  It is not appropriate to start back-tracking and lessening these requirements to simply to accommodate  a business which is not an appealing employer.  Allowing Great Lakes to not comply with these regulations would open the floodgates to other airlines wanting the same relaxations as well as putting those flying on Great Lakes at decreased levels of safety.  There is a transition happening and Great Lakes must learn to adapt to the new levels of safety.

Title: York College Learning Center - Recommendations for Title II, Adult Education - Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act
Comment: These are the recommendations for the WIOA j Title II RIN1830- AA22..

Title: Comment on FR Doc # N/A
Government Agency: California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation
Comment:
RIN 1830-AA22

Comments on the Notice of Proposed Rulemaking NPRM RIN 1830-AA22 (Docket No. ED-2015-OCTAE-0003), implementing programs and activities authorized under Title II of WIOA.


For performance accountability (Proposed 677.175) collecting participant Social Security Numbers and matching them with quarterly wage rate data is effective.  However, California Adult Education programs do not uniformly collect Social Security Numbers and some of our students do not have a Social Security Number. There are other data matching mechanisms by which to track employment outcomes.    

Many places in the proposed regulations require greater clarification, including content standards for English Language Acquisition programs (Proposed 463.32), and the definition of Integrated Education and Training (Proposed 463.35).  Also, make clear that Title I funds can support Title II as the definition of Training (WIOA Section 134 (c)(3) includes  (x) adult education and literacy activities, including activities of English language acquisition and integrated education and training programs, when they are provided concurrently and in combination with other training services.

Funding for Adult Education national programs has declined by 25 percent since 2002.  WIOA provides higher authorization levels each year from fiscal year 2015 through fiscal year 2020, but even if fully funded, agencies would still be below the level at which Adult Education was funded a decade ago. With the implantation of WIOA and the focus on integrated education and training, the need for additional funding has never been greater.

Title: Comment from Diane Frank
Comment:
Regarding Great Lakes serving Riverton, Wyoming, it is imperative that the FAA Regulation mandating two very experienced pilots on board each flight, be relaxed to allow one very experienced pilot and the other pilot with the minimum of 250 hours experience.  

Any pilot that has invested that much time in piloting can and does work for a larger airline which can afford to pay him or her more.  Who wants to work for less with those qualifications?  Our small markets are being squeezed out and we the clients are on the losing side with no way to improve our situation.  Perhaps these comments will help those making decisions to see this situation from the Wyoming point of view.

When  I travel by air, I must drive to Casper, Rock Spings, Cody, or Jackson to get a reliable flight.  These drives are minimum of 2 1/2 hours away and over mountain passes!  This is a huge waste of travel time, fuel and a motel room and cost in time and money is in both directions!

Thank you for the opportunity to be of some help by sending comments.

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment: Please look closely at this proposal.  This company has no presence in Colorado or any of the states surrounding Watertown.  They have no baggage agreements with any serious airline.  Watertown people would have to leave security to claim their bags and then re-check them.  This company has no code-share with any serious airline so Watertown residents would have to check in every time with their connecting airline, then pay bag fees, despite the claim by this company that there would be no bag fees.  And all that is just so Watertown people can fly to Denver with a stop in Pierre to get anywhere.  This is colossal folly.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Sun Air has requested to replace or supplement current EAS from LNS to IAD with service from LNS to PIT, 
however, its fares to PIT are substantially more than its fares to IAD.
Sun Air clearly wants to replace the IAD service with PIT service for its own purposes, not the public good.
Additionally, Sun Air has not proven that it has overcome problems with cold weather operations with its decades old
aircraft.  Such problems were indicated by a LNS authority submission to DOT.
How does LNS continue its eligibility for EAS when similarly situated RDG has not qualified?
Would not ground transportation to MDT, ABE or PHL be a less costly alternative than continued EAS subsidies?
Current EAS is due to expire the end of this month (Sep 2015).  What action, if any has been taken to discontinue the waiver
and the service, or alternatively to extend it?

Title: Fire Stream
Comment: Why is Baltia Airline being held up in the Part 121 Certification process with the FAA on an issue that is Industry wide? Why has the last Mini Evacuation Test results not been decided on after more then 3 months? Many other airlines have these exact slide issues and are still allowed to fly daily. Why is it okay for other airlines to fly with a 37% slide failure rate industry wide yet Baltia has had a few of these same issues and penalized for it?  If this issue is such a big problem that certification process is held up by these slide issues then all airlines with these slides should be grounded by the DOT and the FAA. Why once Certified does this issue seem to be a non issue and no random test preformed to assure compliance by all airlines in regards to 100% pass rate on these slides? I hope this is not a political thing and Baltia is being given a fair chance in the certification process? Thanks for hear my comments and I hope our government agencies do the right thing! I also hope to hear the DOT's comment to mine and others concerns regarding this.

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment: What's the follow up on this application?  It has been over a month since the submission.

Title: Comment from Cassondra
Comment:
As a disabled individual I would like to say I believe the DOT should follow rules similar to the ADA.  I do not believe that documentation should be required for Psychiatric Service Dogs (PSDs) as they perform a critical function in keeping the handler stable and safe on a flight.  

Emotional Support Animals (ESAs) should still require medical documentation however I feel a doctors note dated within the year should be more than sufficient instead of jumping through hoops on what the letter has to say specifically if it says something along the lines of "(insert name here) has a disability and requires his/her ESA to accompany him/her" that should be sufficient.  The wording shouldn't hold up a passenger as ESAs can also provide a critical function in keeping the handler calm.

Finally I also believe those accompanied by Service Animals, PSDs, and/or ESAs should be allotted extra leg room or a free seat next to them (if the plane isn't full) to maximize the use of their Service Animal, PSD, or ESA.

Title: Jason Lee
Comment: Amway (short for American Way) is an American company using a multi-level marketing model to sell a variety of products, primarily in the health, beauty, and home care markets. Amway was founded in 1959 by Jay Van Andel and Richard DeVos. Based in Ada, Michigan, the company and family of companies under Alticor reported sales of $11.3 billion for 2012, the seventh consecutive year of growth for the company.[6] Its product lines include home care products, personal care products, jewelry, electronics, Nutrilite dietary supplements, water purifiers, air purifiers, insurance, and cosmetics. Amway conducts business through a number of affiliated companies in more than a hundred countries and territories around the world. Amway was ranked No.114 among the largest global retailers by Deloitte in 2006, and No.25 among the largest private companies in the United States by Forbes in 2012, but has been frequently subject to investigation as a pyramid scheme or fraud. For a more thorough Amway review visit http://www.jasonleehq.com/amway-review/

Title: Rick Hanton
Comment: I wholeheartedly believe that it would make some sense to penalize carriers for their inability to deliver a bag to its destination properly and on-time. I just got back from a flight where we waited in Denver for 3 hours on a layover, and rather than sending our bag to Omaha with us, it sounds like United sent it to the east coast. It makes no sense for me to pay a $25 fee if they aren't going to get my bag on the plane with me. I might as well Fedex the damn thing for less trouble. If we have to regulate to force the airlines to move bags properly, then so be it.

Title: Mike Silver
Comment: I think that this on-line complaint form is a very good idea. Many people have issues with air transportation, but the burden of filing a complaint to one of the airlines drives people away from voicing their opinions on what needs to be improved or changed. By having and implementing an on-line complaint form, the ease of filing a complaint or something of that matter will become easier to access, and submit. By using this form, I believe the quality and overall ease of air transportation will improve, because the people that actually experience these issues can now voice them, thus making air transportation better.

Title: Dianne Coleman
Comment: I do not want e-cigarettes allowed on airplanes. The public has accepted that there is no smoking allowed on planes and to permit e-cigarettes would be confusing for them as well as the airline staff. There is still the risk to the person using an e-cigarette as well as to those around them.

Title: Emily Steer
Comment:
Please ban/prohibit the use of e-cigarettes and any other type of vapor products on airplanes. 
 
Planes are an indoor environment with shared air, and one person smoking an e-cigarette means an entire cabin of people breathing polluted air. 

E-smoking is a public health issue: workers and the public should not be exposed to secondhand aerosol from other peoples e-cigarettes.

E-cigs emit more than harmless water vapor such as: 
o	Nicotine
o	Hazardous ultra-fine particles
o	Carcinogens

At least 10 chemicals identified in e-cig aerosol are on Californias Proposition 65 list of carcinogens and reproductive toxins

Title: Samuel Spencer
Comment: The smoking of e-cigarettes aboard aircraft should be prohibited. As a frequent flyer I do not wish to be a guinea pig for finding out the consequences of such close quarters exposure to this slightly different form of secondhand smoke and aerosol. E-cigarettes do not just emit water vapor, as is the common misconception. E-cigarette aerosol contains nicotine, ultra fine particles, volatile organic compounds, and other harmful substances such as formaldehyde, cadmium, lead, nickel, and nitrosamines. As a long-time resident of CA, I will add that at least 10 chemicals identified in e-cigarette aerosol are on Californias Proposition 65 list of carcinogens and reproductive toxins.

Title: Rhonda Williams
Comment:
Dear DOT,

I ask that you ban across all flights the use of e-cigarettes or other vaping devices. There is sufficient evidence pointing toward the contents of the aerosol that they are not harmless. Nor is it healthy for kids to be exposed to seeing adults vape or smoke products that look a lot like cigarettes. They may ultimately be safer than conventional cigarettes, but the information available on them is showing that they aren't safe. Nor regulated. Deaths among children have occurred from exposure to the nicotine in the cartridges. Airline carriers do not allow other potentially harmful products on board, nor should they allow e-cigarettes.

Thank you for considering a comprehensive ban that helps families, regular flyers, and other members of the public feel safe when on a flight - and not have to wonder if this or that flight will be treating e-cigarettes differently. 

Thank you,

Rhonda Williams

Title: Joyce Adkins
Comment:
Hello:
 I am a health educator who has worked in tobacco control and prevention for many years.  While the long term effects of using e-cigarettes and/or being exposed to the vapor from others' e-cigarettes have not been sufficiently studied at this time, we do already know that there are carcinogens and ultra-fine particles in the vapor, along with, of course, nicotine. I believe this knowledge should be enough to warrant regulations prohibiting the use of e-cigarettes, or any vaping device, on aircraft where the air is circulated and shared by everyone on the plane. After the disastrous effects on airline personnel's health due to second hand smoke in the past, surely we do not want to wait until they are ill and dying in large numbers before we regulate yet another source of air pollution. Further, I have a heart condition and my grandson has asthma.  I do not think either of us should be subjected to other people's vapor in an enclosed space, certainly not when we have to pay for being in this enclosed space and have no way of escaping it until the aircraft lands. Thank you.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I propose a complete ban on all electronic smoking devices in all chartered and commercial airplane settings, even if electronic smoking devices are not tobacco products. See Sottera, Inc. v. Food & Drug Administration, 627 F.3d 891 (D.C. Cir. 2010)(stating electronic cigarettes are often tobacco products). As an asthmatic child, even the smallest toxin in the air could have triggered an asthma attack requiring use of a prescription inhaler. This was a constant struggle growing up. What if an electronic smoking device causes pollution in an airplane cabin triggering an asthma attack in an asthmatic child or adult? Where would the asthmatic individual retreat in a pressurized airplane cabin at high altitudes to breathe in clean air?
	The Department has provided research on non-asthmatic individuals stating exposure to propylene glycol mist from artificial smoke generators may cause acute ocular and upper airway irritation, and in a few cases people reacted with cough and slight airway obstruction. See G Wieslander, D Norbck, and T Lindgren, Experimental exposure to propylene glycol mist in aviation emergency training: Acute ocular and respiratory effects, Occupational and Environmental Medicine2001; 58:649-655. If non-asthmatic individuals reacted with slight airway obstruction from artificial smoke generators, then an asthmatic individual will likely have greater than slight airway obstruction causing a severe health risk. 
	According to Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, one in twelve people had asthma in 2009. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Vital Signs, May 2011. Additionally, more than half of the individuals diagnosed with asthma in 2008 had an asthma attack within that year. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Vital Signs, May 2011. Clearly, asthma is one of many valid concerns for the Department in the broadening of Part 252. 
	The purpose of the proposed rule is to prevent introduction of a new potential source of contamination to the cabin environment that could potentially endanger the welfare of nonsmokers who are now protected from all such exposure. The only way to prevent endangering the welfare of nonsmokers is a complete ban against any type of nonprescription inhalation device that may produce toxins into an airplane cabin. Amtrak and the U.S. Navy set the standard for banned use of electronic smoking devices in all areas and the Department must follow by banning all use of electronic smoking devices in all flights. 
	The Department should extend the ban on smoking to all charter flights of air carriers and foreign air carriers between points in the U.S. and between the U.S. and any foreign point with aircraft that have a designed seating capacity of nineteen or more passenger seats. It is estimated that the number of people with asthma will grow by more than 100 million by 2025. World Health Organization. Global surveillance, prevention and control of chronic respiratory diseases: a comprehensive approach, 2007. Asthma is a global concern. The only way to prevent pollution of unclean air into an airplane cabin is a complete ban on all electronic smoking devices in all chartered and commercial flights.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Good Evening,
  I have been dealing with asthma since I was a little girl.  Even the scent of perfumes impacts my breathing and at times causes me to reach for my inhaler.  The thought of being on an aircraft with someone who is puffing an e-cigarette causes me great alarm.  Although the e-cigarette is SUPPOSE to be healthier, pollutants (nicotine, formaldehyde) are yet spread in the air, particularly, within the enclosed space of an aircraft carrier leaving all within its cavity to breathe in the harmful toxins...especially, me!   It would be a step backward if Department of Transportation is not proactive in banning e-cigarettes from aircraft carriers, as we all have the right to breathe clean air.

Respectfully Submitted.
Anonymous

Title: Janet Williams
Comment: It has been 25 years of smoke free skies that protected workers and passengers.  We need to continue this protection by eliminating electronic cigarettes from our airline travel. These contain toxic chemicals and these pollutants are exhaled in the vapor from these devices.

Title: Maria Iriti
Comment: Please do not allow electronic cigarettes to be used on airplanes!

Title: Lee Fremault
Comment: Please ban any and all forms of cigarettes on planes, electronic ones as well, please!  Check with the National Cancer Institute and the American Lung Association for information about them.

Title: Beverly Voller
Comment:
I am writing to encourage you to adopt policies that would prohibit all tobacco products, including electronic cigarettes and vaping devices from all air traffic.  There is no evidence that these products are safe and can indeed be a fire hazard.  There are other products available, such as nicotine gum, lozenges, and patches  for those tobacco users who cannot be without nicotine for an extended period of time.  There is no reason for all of us to be exposed to these products that are unsafe and potentially hazardous while traveling.

Thank You.

Title: Cathy Ball
Comment: Ban all types of electronic cigarettes on flights. They ARE harmful, not only to the user but also to others. We have deliberately avoided flying on holidays because of them. I would not like to have to been oxygen to breathe on a flight.

Title: D. Levitt
Comment:
I can't believe this is even an issue.

Please prohibit the use of e-cigarettes on airplanes. 

That is not only dangerous, but offensive.

Title: Judy Martinson
Comment:
Yes, please keep electronic cigarettes off the planes as well as cigarettes. Matter of fact, all tobacco products. I can't stand the smell of secondhand smoke and for many people they are allergic to it as well. 
The electronic cigarettes shouldn't be allowed on the planes because there is no control over the amount of nicotine in each of the cartridges, they e-cigarettes are not FDA approved and the lithium batteries have been known to explode in people's faces. Why allow them on the plane? Also the vaping (what comes off the end of the cigarettes is not safe nor healthy and no one else should have to breathe that in either.
Please ban all electronic  cigarettes and tobacco of anykind in planes and airports.
Thank you. greatly appreciate it

Title: Allen Kost
Comment: Please treat e-cigarettes, along with any other such item, as tobacco products by banning the use of such products from airplanes.

Title: Katherine Donald
Comment: In light of the growing body of research that show that there are cancer casing chemicals in the aerosol  emitted into the air from electronic cigarettes, and for the sake of the public's health and safety; I strongly urge the DOT to adopt  very strong regulations that prohibits the use of any electronic cigarettes or similar smoking devices on planes and other modes of public transportation.

Title: Annamay Olsen
Comment: Thank you for this opportunity -- I always have lots to say on this matter.  I recall my first flight, which was from NYC to Mexico, in the mid 1950's, when during which, free packages of cigarettes with women in mind, were handed out.  They were oval shaped and in a variety of pastel colors.  I was in my early 30's and never put a cigarette to my lips before -- thank goodness, it didn't take.  In my 40's I began to suffer greatly from second-hand smoke on jobs.  In the hospital for hysterectomy, I was being pushed back from surgery into my room filled with visitors' tobacco smoke, I yelled, "get me out of here!" and so my hospital bed was pushed into some huge dark cavernous room -- while the smokers were free to continue!  I got into a great deal of debt from inability to stay on a job.  I was frequently on unemployment insurance from sickness.  I was verbally abused, told by smokers, "Why don't you work in a church!" and "Why don't you smoke so it won't bother you!"  Post Offices and banks as well as restaurants were off limits, all the while, the smokers claimed their "Rights."  Until we changed the laws -- and now we victims of their "rights" have ours!

Title: Aaron Grossman
Comment: e-cigarettes are cigarettes - they emit second hand smoke that is harmful to others and should be prohibited in airplanes and other public places. Please take action.

Title: Paul
Comment: The fact this is even being proposed to allow e-cigarettes on Airlines is frightful. Why would anyone want to turn back the clock on this issue.  I'll never forget being on an airplane right behind the "smoking section", and the torment I experienced just trying to breathe.  I've been in close proximity to an e-cigarette user, and I can smell and FEEL the effects of breathing in their vapor.  It contains nicotine, sometimes in high amounts, it is unregulated, it is ghastly to look at. What a nightmare for airline personnel who have to work in that environment. Why are we looking to reward and accommodate nicotine addiction?  As a society we should be looking at better ways to rid people of this awful addiction.  Not find ways to roll back public health advances to the detriment of all.

That had to die because someone wanted to smoke a cigarett 300 to 1 lives lost not counting the ones after the plane crashes to the
ground.

Title: Lin Glen
Comment:
Our California State Health Officer has issued a Health Advisory against electronic cigarettes. The advisory states that the chemical aerosol emitted from electronic cigarettes is somewhat less dangerous than secondhand tobacco smoke but still contains at last 10 chemicals known to the state of California to cause cancer and reproductive harm.

As an airline passenger, I ask that the Department of Transportation use its authority to regulate electronic cigarette usage the same way the DOT regulates tobacco cigarette usage. Ban electronic cigarette usage on airplanes and inside airports. Airline passengers should not be forced to breathe toxic substances.

Title: Carl Stein
Comment: For the health of all people on airplanes, it's important that DOT prohibit the use of electronic cigarettes and all electronic smoking devices in airplanes. No one should have to breathe the toxic gases and chemicals that are part of the aerosol emitted by electronic smoking devices.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: The Department of Transportation (DOT) should get off their high horses and do something presently to prevent smokers from continuing to harm the health of others on aircrafts. Many people try to maintain good health and take healthy measures to do so. It's so not fair for someone who craves nicotine at any given time to disturb those efforts. When I converse with cigarette smokers, they always make clear statements of how they wished that they had never started the nasty little habit. But now, because they are hooked, their addiction purpose a health risk not only to themselves but to others as well.  America has progressed over the years with tobacco issues in baby steps which is good.  So, even though the numbers are down, tobacco- nicotine addiction is still around, going no where fast. Taking action means, going all the way in to destroy the root of the problem, understanding that there is more than one way to skin a cat. Tobacco is nothing to play around with, it requires demands to prevent it from starting and demands to drop it where it stands. Let do this NOW!

Title: Michaeline Hade
Comment: Please enact the proposed rule prohibiting the use of e-cigarettes on airplanes.

Title: Carolyn Martin
Comment: Prohibing the use of electronic nicotine devices will protect the health of every passenger and airline employees.

Title: John Ward
Comment: I am opposed to allowing use of e cigarettes on commercial airplanes.

Title: Steven A. Zilber
Comment: Please forbid use of e-cigarettes aboard aircraft; their emissions contaminate the cabin air.

Title: Patricia Haight
Comment: Please ban e-cigarettes on airlines.  Why should I breathe carcinogens when I have paid to fly in a plane?  It's deadly and annoying.

Title: Constance Hameloth
Comment: Please ban the use of e-cigarettes on all aircraft.   There is now evidence that the vapor contains carcinogens which not only affects the user but anyone close to them.  It will also leave third hand smoke residue on walls,seats and even in the air system.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Any form of smoke or e-cigarette is an unhealthy distraction...its bad enough being crammed into a tiny airplane with all the confined air getting u sick we dont need e-cigarettes too

Title: Frederick Barnewold
Comment: Why are you procrastinating? This is a no-brainer. There is nothing good about electronic cigarettes for those not using them. And no one really knows what is in these things anyway.

Title: Misty Jensen
Comment:
It is imperative that all forms of nicotine delivery devices be banned from air travel. While we do not yet know the long term effects of e-cigarettes, we do know that they pose a health risk. The use of these products on airplanes also re-normalizes the use of cigarettes, and after 25 years of being smoke-free, do we really want to negate all of the tremendous progress in the health rights of passengers? I urge you to immediately ban the use of all nicotine delivery devices on air travel, thus ensuring passenger safety. 
Thank you,
Misty Jensen
Tobacco Prevention and Control
Anchorage/Mat-Su, Alaska

Title: Walt Bilofsky
Comment:
This rule has been pending long enough.  Please adopt it now.

In addition to the health issues, the flying public is against e-cigarette use in flight.  See for example this thread on FlyerTalk.com, where a large majority of commenters oppose nicotine vapor in cabin air:

http://www.flyertalk.com/forum/travelbuzz/1391249-electronic-cigarettes-airline-policy-decisions.html

Title: Elizabeth Smith
Comment: Please act quickly to prohibit the use of electronic cigarettes on aircraft. We simply do not know what exposure to the vapors produced by these products might do to the health of users, other passengers, and flight attendants, and since they are completely unregulated at the  moment it seems unlikely that we will know in the foreseeable future. Smokers have become accustomed to smokefree flights; preventing the use of electronic cigarettes will not place any additional burden on them, and will ensure clean air on flights for everyone.

Title: Mike Speciner
Comment: Use of e-cigarettes should be prohibited on airplanes. While e-cigarette vapors may be less harmful than cigarette smoke, there are still dangerous substances present in the vapors. Further, the chemicals present can vary dramatically between different brands and there is as yet no regulation of the ingredients being vaped.

Title: John Hess
Comment: An aircraft cabin is a closed environment which already is quite stressful.  I don't want to breath anything that someone has smoked.  Electronic Cigarettes release a chemical gas that is forced upon all other flyers.  Please act quickly to make these cigarettes illegal in all airlines.  Thank you

Title: Robert Hutchison
Comment:
Please prohibit the use of ENDS of other nicotine delivery systems on aircraft.  The vapor from these devices has hazardous chemicals in them as do tobacco products and no one should be forced to deal with these in any public settings.
Thank you

Title: Penelope Quintana
Comment: As a researcher, I know that nicotine from e-cigarettes can deposit on surfaces, where it can react with air pollutants to form very toxic and carcinogenic tobacco-specific nitrosamines (TSNAs). These can persist even after cleaning. Please keep our aircraft safe for workers and vulnerable passengers such as infants and children, and ban e-cigarettes!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am requesting the removal of any smoking of  electronic cigarettes on aircraft  due to the many toxic chemicals that these cigarettes have been proven to contain. It is  the respect for the health of other travelers that the electronic cigarettes are not smoked on the aircraft.  Thank you for your consideration in this regard.

Title: Steve Neithercott
Comment: Please ban email cigarette on flights

Title: J. Gary Wheeler
Comment:
As the medical director of our state health department's tobacco control program in Arkansas, I have spent an extensive amount of time reviewing the literature on e-cigarettes and conclude that there is no information suggesting these products are safe for second hand exposure. Documents prepared by the American Academy of Pediatrics and the World Health Organization support this opinion. In fact, there are limited data suggesting the contrary. In addition, these products can malfunction and ignite or explode.
Until the manufacturers or the FDA proves they are safe, I strongly recommend that the products be banned for use on all flights.

Title: Janet Schwarz
Comment:
Pass public policy that fully enacts the proposed rule prohibiting the use of e-cigarettes on airplanes.

This action would protect public health.

Nicotine is a drug, also a known pesticide.  

I don't want a pesticide entering my lungs, which is inevitable when confined to a small area such as an airplane.

Title: Barbara Segal
Comment: PLEASE ban e-cigarettes from airplanes...and the waiting areas in the airports.  I still have vivid memories of flying on planes with smoke being circulated for all passengers to breathe.  It was disgusting, sickening, poisonous...and we do NOT want to have today's passengers subjected to these conditions.  PLEASE make sure that there is NO SMOKING allowed!

Title: Rudy Breteler
Comment:
I am doubtful that the vapor from e-cigarettes is as harmless as the industry would like to have us believe.  Even if it were, however, sitting in confined quarters with somebody who is puffing on an e-cigarette is obnoxious and unsettling.  As a traveler, I would be very uncomfortable if somebody near me was exhaling e-cigarette vapor that I was forced to breath.  I do not want a situation where taking air travel (which is a quasi-necessity in the modern world) requires me to consent to exposing myself to second-hand e-cigarette vapor.  The federal government has an interest in combating nicotine addiction of all kinds.  The government also has an interest in the health and safety of air travelers, and in fostering business, commerce, and tourism by making air travel comfortable. For these reasons, the government should extend its current prohibitions against smoking on aircraft to cover e-cigarette use.

Rudy Breteler
Boston, Massachusetts

Title: Cynthia Chew
Comment: Second hand smoke and e-cig smoke should not be permitted on airplanes.  Thank you.

Title: Charlene Henley
Comment:
Do not allow e-cigarettes on planes!

Charlene Henley
5275 Country Oak Court
San Jose, CA 95136

Title: Justin Frye
Comment: Smoking is still smoking, regardless if it is an electronic cigarette. If we were to make an exception for electronic cigarettes, there would most certainly be outcry from tobacco lobbyists. It still creates a vapor, and it can still both cloud the air in the cabin/the fuselage. Ban this and do not make exceptions.f

Title: Pamela Granger
Comment:
Emotionally, I never want to see my grandchildren exposed to secondhand electronic smoking device emissions in a plane or any other location.  Heck - I don't want to be exposed.  The ventilation systems ensure that everyone has an equal opportunity to breath harmful chemicals. 

Logically, studies confirm that emissions from secondhand electronic cigarette aerosol can be measured in the systems of non-smokers.  There are over 450 manufacturers with an equal number of manufacturing techniques and no regulations. How can that be good?

Please let's not have a repeat of the unhealthy situation for passengers and crew that we had with combustible cigarettes prior to 1990's regulations.

Title: Peter Pesic
Comment: Please ban all use of electronic cigarettes on aircraft, as per the current ban on smoking. From all indications, secondhand smoke is still just as dangerous, not to speak of the obnoxious intrusion smoking makes on all around it. Thank you.

Title: Ssu Weng
Comment:
Please keep flights smokefree from electronic cigarettes.
The devices pose risks to both health and safety.
Thank you very much, Ssu Weng MD

Title: Nathan Edel
Comment:
Please enact the proposed ban on "e-cigarettes" use in commercial aircraft.

There is now ample evidence that electronic smoking devices expose those around them to second-hand aerosol chemicals, just as traditional smoking exposes non-smokers to second hand smoke.  As a person with asthma, I have enough respiratory trouble without having to inhale someone else's recreational inhalants -- especially in an enclosed space where I have no option to go away.

All the major US-based mainline airlines already have their own ban in place.  It's time for public policy to match.  Aircraft (or any other sort of enclosed public transit) are not an appropriate place for "vaping" (or for smoking, although that is already banned.)

Title: Amberlyn Storey
Comment: I find it remarkable that there is no law in place to prevent Ecigarettes the same way cigarettes are now regulated. There is much scientific evidence that smoking is dangerous to everyone near so even though there is not the same amount of data regarding Ecigs, it stands to reason the potential for danger is there and we should err on the side of caution while awaiting study results. Those studies that are in are showing that it is harmful. I have only noticed my own personal affects and that is a burning sensation and then sometimes coughing. I would not fly ever if there was smoking on board airlines. If ecigs become okay to smoke then I will not be traveling via plane anymore. I believe in everyone's freedom to do as they choose but the line stops when it crosses into someone else's rights. I have the right to breathe clean air and not be poisoned by someone else's choice to poison themselves. Please do not delay any longer in passing a law protecting the many people such as myself who can be very ill from smoking I.e. children, elderly, disabled, pregnant women etc. All people who utilize airlines!

Title: Mary Chace
Comment:
The jury is still out on ecigs - we in public health have individual studies, but not enough weight yet with evidence to say that second hand exposure is detrimental or not.  So until we know, we need to be respectful of those who may be at higher risk for respiratory issues - We have a significant proportion of our public who has asthma, or compromised immune systems - and what about pregnant women and the workers who may exposed to this potential health hazard all day long?

Until the science tells us unequivocacly that inhaling second hand smoke from e-cigs (and ecigs are regulated so we have some assurance what exactly is in them), we must enact the proposed rule prohibiting use of e-cigs on airplanes!

Mary Chace, Ph.D. Professor of Public Health, wright state university, Dayton, OH

Title: Lorraine Waldau
Comment:
Please enact the same regulations on Electronic Cigarettes, E-Hookahs, and all new electronic forms of smoke.  The side stream smoke contains many of the same ingredients as do regular cigarettes and are not proven to be anything but another form of smoking or vapping.

I remember flying in the days prior to current regulations with my mother who did smoke.  It was horrendous.  Continue to protect the workers and passengers on these aircraft.
Thank You,

Lorraine Waldau

Title: Charles Hartjen
Comment: A big step toward protecting the health of passengers and employees was achieved when smoking was prohibited on airlines. It is time to continue that by including ecigarettes in the prohibition.

Title: Olivia Powers
Comment:
Please ban electronic cigarettes on airplanes and in airports and environs. All research shows that the vapor created by these devices is just as dangerous as cigarette smoke. 
As a Respiratory Therapist, I am concerned for my fellow citizens and patients with pulmonary impairments who travel by air. There is no good reason to allow these dangerous electronic vapor devices to be used around others who wish to protect their pulmonary health.
Again, please ban the use of electronic cigarettes or vapor producing devices and tobacco products of any kind from airplanes and airports.
Sincerely,
Olivia Powers BA RRT LRCP

Title: Elaine Wangler
Comment: I have much admiration for all those who helped get tobacco banned from flights and from workplaces, restaurants, etc.  I am opposed to the use of electronic cigarettes in ALL places that ban cigarettes and cigars.  Thank you!

Title: Lori Burns
Comment: Please fully enact the proposed rule prohibiting the use of e-cigarettes on airplanes.

Title: Karen Woods
Comment: I urge you to get off the fence and take action to protect our flights from e-cigarettes!!!

Title: Rishi Batra
Comment: make it illegal

Title: Andrew Kalukin
Comment: Please prohibit electronic cigarettes on aircraft.  Thank you.

Title: Kris Williams
Comment: As a passenger of air travel, I strongly encourage prohibiting e-cigarette use on airplanes.  With the close quarters and re-circulated air I am very concerned about inhaling secondhand vapor and the chemicals contained therein.  I am also deeply concerned about the safety and "explosive" capabilities of the devices.   Use of the devices in public also gives the impression that smoking is allowed.

Title: Michaeline Fedder
Comment: Every day we are seeing more and more documentation about the dangers of using e-cigarettes and of being in the presence of someone using them.  How long do we have to wait for the DOT to step up to the plate and act to make it illegal to use them on any aircraft?

Title: Randall Russell
Comment: This rule is thorough and covers all the necessary aspects related to the smoking of electronic cigarettes on aircraft. Smoking these electronic cigarettes on aircrafts pose more than just health concerns for other passengers. Ever since smoking was banned on all U.S. airlines in 2000, smoking anything containing nicotine should also be banned as well. Coming in the form of a vapor isn't enough to necessitate legal action and fight back against a ban against smoking these on aircraft. Smoking with designated seating capacities over the amount of 19 is against the law, the includes U.S. carriers and foreign carriers. I agree with this amendment to the law regarding aircraft smoking, although I believe the rule should be extended to all public aircraft. Smaller airports have planes with under 19 designated seats and they, as well, should have to obey by the proposed rule. If any plane complies with the Federal Aviation Administration, then they should comply with a rule eliminating smoking on said aircraft. Aside from this slight change, I support this proposed rule to be fair and just.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: This should be immediately implemented and apply to airports  as well as airplanes. When in ONT airport gate area I first experienced the effects of a e-cigarette. Within 15-20 minutes exposure (she was sitting 6' from me) I was physically feeling the effects of a lady "I am not smoking, vaping" a e-cigarette. It took an hour or more for the effects to wear off. E-cigraettes should be regulated at the same or higher level as smoking traditional cigarettes. As a exhaled vapor it is inhaled by others (2nd hand)  and is instantly absorbed, in some ways likely worse than traditional smoke. We would not stand for people sneezing directly on us with TB and should not allow e cigarette smoking (vaping) in any enclosed area either.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
The Food and Drug Administration should treat Electronic Cigarettes in the following manner as soon as possible:

1.  Before more people die, or are injured from Nicotine overdose, Nicotine should be labeled as a drug and be subject to regulation just as other dangerous drugs.  

2.  Electronic Cigarettes should not be treated as if they are safer than Tobacco Cigarettes and other Tobacco Products.

3.  Electronic Cigarettes should be treated the same as all Cigarettes and other Tobacco Products - as dangerous to the health of smokers and nonsmokers alike.  

4.  Electronic Cigarettes should be banned from being Advertised on TV, Billboards, or on any other type of Media where Tobacco Cigarettes and other Tobacco Products are banned.

5.  Electronic Cigarettes should be banned in workplaces and in all buildings and public places where Tobacco Cigarettes and other Tobacco Products are banned.

6.  Electronic Cigarettes should not be allowed on Aircraft, or on Busses, in Cabs, Ferry's, or in or on any other Public Transportation.

Title: Meir Libersohn
Comment:
I request that the US Government refuse this application due to the egregious attitude of this company on fellow customers.

As the US DOT have in file, the level of complaints against the United Airlines have raised up notoriously, and their refusal to make good, including for damaged luggage and goods, delayed luggage and the necessity of purchase of goods till arrival of such.  When actively the consumer complaints either customer care refuse to make good, or the customer is threatened with a potential lawsuit for insisting the airline to make good, they get corporate security involved, who the say that they will involve law enforcement, the customer frequent flier account is shut down and miles confiscated as well, at times they may allege that miles were bartered or sold.

Title: Comment from Greg Gayden
Comment: I urge the Department to deny this request for EAS operations. The EAS program is a gross waste of taxpayer money, one that subsidizes flights to far flung rural communities at tremendous cost to the greater population as a whole. In many cases, EAS flights operate with just a handful of passengers, while the government pays carriers to operate flights with empty seats. There is no good reason that people who choose to live in rural areas cannot drive a few hours to the nearest large commercial airport if they want to fly somewhere. Tens of millions of dollars are wasted each year on EAS service, and the routes contained within this application are no exception.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Good bye American -- Welcome United.  American has made limited efforts on trying to develop itself off EAS -- not seen much marketing -- doesn't except cargo-  No Dallas service -- basically was all smoke when they took on the contract originally.  Americans bid is out of line --we don't need to support corporate greed.

Title: Comment from Greg Gayden
Comment: I urge the Department to deny this request for EAS operations. The EAS program is a gross waste of taxpayer money, one that subsidizes flights to far flung rural communities at tremendous cost to the greater population as a whole. In many cases, EAS flights operate with just a handful of passengers, while the government pays carriers to operate flights with empty seats. Title: Comment from N. Smith
Comment: Real "Shady" on American --- how can you go from asking more than double than you have been receiving on an established market because you thought you were the only bidder to zero?    Hmmm...????

Title: Comment from Greg Gayden
Comment: I urge the Department to deny this request for EAS operations. The EAS program is a gross waste of taxpayer money, one that subsidizes flights to far flung rural communities at tremendous cost to the greater population as a whole. In many cases, EAS flights operate with just a handful of passengers, while the government pays carriers to operate flights with empty seats. There is no good reason that people who choose to live in rural areas cannot drive a few hours to the nearest large commercial airport if they want to fly somewhere. Tens of millions of dollars are wasted each year on EAS service, and the routes contained within this application are no exception.

Title: Comment from Greg Gayden
Comment: Once again, another proposal to waste significant taxpayer funds for EAS flights. The City of Bemidji mentions less than 200 workers who seem to benefit from these flights. Why on earth should U.S. taxpayers be forced to pay millions for a flight that will benefit such a small number of people. Surely these folks can drive the 200 miles down to Minneapolis if they need to. I understand inclement weather, but that is not my issue. This proposal should be denied as it an egregious waste of taxpayer money.

Title: Comment from Greg Gayden
Comment: I urge the Department to deny this request for EAS operations. The EAS program is a gross waste of taxpayer money, one that subsidizes flights to far flung rural communities at tremendous cost to the greater population as a whole. In many cases, EAS flights operate with just a handful of passengers, while the government pays carriers to operate flights with empty seats. There is no good reason that people who choose to live in rural areas cannot drive a few hours to the nearest large commercial airport if they want to fly somewhere. Tens of millions of dollars are wasted each year on EAS service, and the routes contained within this application are no exception.

Title: William Moyes
Comment: A recent story from USAToday.com (http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2015/07/02/tsa-damage-tops-3m/29353815/) confirms the suggestion I sent to TSA a couple of months ago. Because TSA officers have free rein to open any luggage at will, they should be held accountable for that action. Ive had multiple cases where my suitcase was not latched completely shut after an inspection and anther time when a piece of clothing was left dangling outside the suitcase.  Inside the suitcase each time, I found an anonymous note saying that my luggage had been inspected.  However, it was impossible to complain about the sloppy work, because there was no way to know which agent at which airport had done the inspection.  It would be very simple for each agent to have an individually identifiable stamp that could be placed on that paper notice that would hold that agent responsible for his/her actions. The clothing industry does something similar with their Inspected by #22 slips of paper, and theres A LOT LESS at stake with inspecting a mens shirt than breaking into a persons luggage. I dont trust TSA and this article gives me good reason to reaffirm that distrust.

Title: Beverly, Steven and Sophie Galarza
Comment:
Our family very much appreciates the opportunity to share our concerns regarding  "space allocation per passenger on aircraft"   with each member of this Advisory Committee.

Our family travels by air every three months and over the course of doing this for six (6) years,  we have noticed significant changes in the amount of space provided for passengers, or not provided as the case may be, in the way of legroom for certain passengers with disabilities.  Our travel is from Texas to Hawai'i, so flights which are long in duration, but impacts persons with certain disabilities and/or service animals whether it's a 7 hour flight or 2 hour flight.

Under the Air Carrier Access Act (ACAA) certain passengers, and it's very specific as to who qualifies,  may request bulkhead or other seating which provides more legroom due to the qualifying disability.   This rule was put in place so that passengers with certain qualifying disabilities may have an opportunity for equal access to travel, i.e.  a person with an immobilized leg, braces, crutches, and service animals.

Recently, some of the major airlines have sent certain aircraft for re-configuration.   The end result is space is being taken from bulkhead and added elsewhere in the aircraft to generate more revenue.  By doing this, whether intentional or not, by design, if a qualifying passenger with immobilized leg, cast, braces, or service animals cannot fit, there is exclusion and no longer have equal access to air travel, unless the passenger has money to fly first class.  In certain aircraft we travel on, even the first class bulkhead has had legroom reduced to the point of almost no access.   In the main cabin, the space is typically reduced  by one to three more inches.

I'm asking this Advisory Committee to also take the following into account as an example of why we are even more concerned. 

Last summer, Hawaiian Airlines sent a fleet of their Airbus aircraft for re-configuration.   This fleet primarily services the West Coast to the Hawaiian Islands.
Hawaiian Airlines elected not to include bulkhead seating in the "main cabin", where most passengers pay to sit.
So rather than keep standard bulkhead seating in what Hawaiian Airlines calls its main cabin,   Hawaiian Airlines created what they call a "separate class of service" and they advise passengers this is where the bulkhead seating is now situated.
They advise there is no longer a bulkhead row in the main cabin.    As a result, if you require the bulhead or other seating which will accommodate a qualifying disability under the ACAA, then you must pay more to sit in the new "separate class of service", or pay even more and fly first class, or worse, not be able to go at all if you cannot afford to upgrade seating and you are excluded from the main cabin where most passengers fly.

We ask this Advisory Committee to keep in mind airlines customers who have qualifying disabilities under the ACAA and in particular, those who qualify for the bulkhead seats as you consider passenger space issues.

We would ask this Advisory Committee to help ensure that airlines be required to provide equal access to each class of service it offers customers, including providing a bulkhead or space which would not exclude those passengers the Air Carrier Access specifically went into detail to ensure access was provided, i.e. those passengers with immobilized legs, braces, service animals, etc.   Ironically, the very narrow qualifying passengers the ACAA intended to protect, are in jeopardy of being completely excluded.

On behalf of my son, Steven and his service dog, Sophie, (a Labrador Retriever, 80 pounds, not the standard 100 pound Lab),   we thank you in advance for allowing us this opportunity to voice our concerns.    

Respectfully submitted,
Beverly, Steven and Sophie Galarza

Title: Geroge Demchak
Comment:
These resort fees are a clear money grab.  On a recent stay in Las Vegas the fee was more than 50% of the mid-week rate of the room.  Resort fee for things that I did not even use such as fitness room, wi-fi and local calls.  Why does the FTC allow this obvious scam to continue?  In what other business can a merchant charge a customer for services not rendered?

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Title: Daniel Koebel
Comment: I am 6'6" and cannot taking any coach flight without experiencing some pain in my legs and back.  There should be a minimum distance between seats and the CDC should look into the dangerous health effects of the current distance between seats.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I would like to express my serious concern about the significant decrease in the size of airline seats that has been occurring over the last few years. For individuals such as me and others who are tall the feeling is that the space shrinkage is intended to pile up passengers like sardines in a can. I cannot think of any other reason for this than to increase the airlines' profits which have reached incredibly high levels in the last couple of years.

The shrinkage is unhealthy since it can lead to the very dangerous and life threatening formation of clots in the deep veins of the legs. These can cause death. Also, in the event of an emergency evacuation where quick and effective movement is expected, the increased number of passengers in more cramped spaces would substantially raise the number of casualties.

I believe that eventually the airlines shrinking their seating spaces will end up losing customers. I and, others I know, seek to fly uniquely in airlines with more comfortable spaces. Sadly, most of those airlines are not American. My travel abroad in the last few years has been uniquely limited to foreign airlines where the seats are more comfortable and, incidentally, the in-flight service and amenities are much better. I would much rather fly in American airlines but long flights in small seats, mostly fit for middle school size passengers, has become an experience to avoid.

I hope the Advisory Committee for Aviation Consumer Protection seeks the advice from safety and medical experts to comment on the shrinking seat size in many of the American airlines in particular.

Title: Alan Clayton
Comment: I have a friend who couldn't get health insurance before Obamacare.  He now has insurance.

Title: Ron Dodge
Comment: Please DO NOT ALLOW CELL PHONE USE ON AIRCRAFT! Flying is already very difficult and uncomfortable resulting in much stress among passengers and increased demands on flight crews. Our safety and peace of mind will be further compromised by use of cell phones. Also, the matter of interference of aircraft instruments is still unsettled and many passengers believe this is a problem, adding to their stress while flying.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Keep Cell Phone conversations OFF our airplanes.  It is extremely upsetting to listen to someone else talking in a large room.  I can not even contemplate how awful it would be in the confined space of a 26 inch wide seat to have to listen to the stranger sitting next to you talking on a cell phone.
It is unnecessary and will cause great frustration and potentially significant conflict on our airplanes that are already crowded, with inadequate storage,  many crying babies and other distractions.  
Keep cell phone conversations off airplanes PLEASE.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I have been following this complaint and the related complaint by Mr. Samstein.

I am dismayed that the Department of Transportation has failed to address this matter.  Both Mr. Martin and Mr. Samstein have raised reasonable complaints that deserve prompt adjudication and resolution. 

I can't see a proper reason why they should have to wait so long.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I am deeply concerned with American Airlines assertion that in the event of a carrier initiated change in schedule, they and they alone can decide which of the three options shall be offered to a customer.

While AA does say that they TRY to accommodate passengers, they also state that the airline can simply refund the money paid (or miles tendered) and the passenger has no choice. Please look past what AA says "we will do because we are nice guys".  What matters is what they MUST do.

As has been argued by the Complainants, the choice of which of the "three options" applies when a carrier initiated change occurs MUST lie with the passenger.  Any other interpretation will allow airlines to cancel flights and give back money and miles without accommodation of passengers who have entered into a contract of carriage and then find themselves without a ticket.

This particular aspect is larger than a matter of BA fuel taxes (the issue of these complaints), but can have significant repercussions to a great many travelers.  Passengers must be protected against airlines canceling flights or 'changing schedules' and forcing passengers to just get their money back.

Title: Bloomberg News
Comment:
April 13, 2015	
Mr. Jeff Gorham
Office of Airline Information
RTS-42, Room E34, BTS
1200 New Jersey Avenue SE
Washington, DC 20590-0001

Dear Mr. Gorham:
Bloomberg News respectfully submits this comment to request that BTS release the 20-year-old airframe and aircraft engine cost data of the 12 impacted airlines.  Bloomberg News, as part of Bloomberg L.P., provides data, news and analytics to decisions makers across all industries, including the aerospace industry.  Bloomberg News is delivered through the Bloomberg Professional Service, television, radio, mobile, the Internet, two magazines (Bloomberg Markets and Bloomberg Businessweek), and is syndicated in hundreds of newspapers globally.  In covering the world with more than 2,300 news and multimedia professionals at 146 bureaus in 72 countries, we are experts in disseminating and analyzing information.

The information at issue is now 20 years old. Given the passage of time, any interest in keeping the data out of the public domain has presumably lessened. A policy of disclosure of cost data after 20 years would seem to achieve a reasonable balance between transparency and maintaining the confidentiality of potentially sensitive commercial information.

Bloomberg News appreciates the Department of Transportation's reconsideration and review of the confidentiality period for BTS airframe and aircraft cost data. 

Sincerely,



Edward Dufner
Americas Industrial/Aerospace Team Leader
Bloomberg News

Title: Reply Comments of Open Allies for Airfare Transparency
Comment: Reply Comments of Open Allies for Airfare Transparency

Title: GRA, Incorporated
Comment: Comments of Frank Berardino of GRA, Incorporated

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
There's no excuse for airlines not offering "accidental"/"glitch" fares. It's standard business practice to honor products at the price they are posted at/advertised, unless/until you rescind the offer. You offered it, you honor it until you correct the fare. Period.

This also gives airlines too much leeway to say "oops, that was a mistake". Who's to say what's a glitch and what's cheap fare, where do we draw the line?

Airlines have no problem charging consumers for "mistakes", such as arriving late and missing a flight, packing a little too much in a suitcase, canceling due to life/schedule changes, etc. They also have no problem nickle & diming consumers on EVERYTHING. It's completely unethical and anti-consumer to give them an "out" from honoring fares they sold and offered.

Title: Travelers United, Inc. (Formerly Consumer Travel Alliance)
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Anonymous
Comment: If the DOT is considering not requiring air carriers to honor mistake fares, it should more clearly define a mistake fare and narrow the timeframe in which a carrier can cancel the ticket.  For instance, since the DOT already requires air carriers to allow customers to cancel fee-free within 24 hours of booking, a similar 24-hour timeframe would be reasonable for carriers.  Also a guideline for determining mistake fares might also be appropriate -- like "costs less than 30% of comparable fares in the same market".  Additionally, the Department should continue to require air carriers to give full reimbursement for all non-refundable hotel reservations, connecting air travel, etc. that were made while relying on the ticketed fare.

Title: Kyle Stewart
Comment:
There has to be some way for the consumer to tell if a fare is legitimate, and will be honored.  If the airline can choose to correct a mistake by voiding sold tickets but consumers can't, the system is unbalanced.  

Currently, operators Norwegian Air Shuttle and WOW Air have entered the trans-Atlantic market with shockingly low prices.  The latter entered fares that were not mistakes of $99 each way.  Additionally, there are business class fares currently in the range of $1200 to and from Europe on every alliance, yet British Airways claimed that $1800 fares form Austin to Dubai were clear mistakes.  How can a consumer know that when they book a $200 ticket to Iceland that the fare is valid, or that $1800 to Dubai is a mistake when competitive fares are still in that range?  Emirates also sold tickets (and does so frequently) in pairs for $899 from JFK-Milan, that's less than $450/person all-in, and United has fares to Hong Kong from Philadelphia for less than $550 today (5/20/2015).  

Average consumers can't be expected to understand complex fare construction and know, for example, that YQ (commonly used fare code for fuel surcharges) are meant to be included in some fares (British Airways) and not in others (American Airlines). If the YQ is absent, British Airways would call it a mistake fare, but buyers of tickets on their partner American would not know to look for that, identify the error, and then avoid the booking because it had been mislabeled.  

Airlines had carte blanche before CFR 399.88 was in place to choose when they would and would not be responsible for their mistakes.  They could choose to "honor" a fare out of goodwill, or to avoid legal action, but this is unfair to consumers.  If I, as a consumer, buy a product and make a mistake when I purchase it I don't get to choose whether or not to "honor" my original purchase, but rather I am subject to the company's return policy which is non-uniform and can vary store to store and state to state.  

I would not argue that the advent of resources in the frequent flyer community make these mistakes much larger than they were before, however, these same conditions exist elsewhere in industry.  Twitter, blogs, and forums exist in every niche community from "mom" groups to players of certain video games.  Dansdeals.com is a site where bargain hunters go to find great deals and occasionally price mistakes are highlighted on the site. However, if an order is processed - mistake or not - in most states the vendor is liable for the price they agreed upon with the customer.  Why is airfare different?

The title of this proposed rule: Transparency of Airline Ancillary Fees and Other Consumer Protection Issues will do little to resolve the murky waters of airline pricing if carriers aren't held accountable for what they sell.  I would argue that not only should they honor their mistakes, but the legislation should be extended to cruise lines, buses, trains and hotels.  

There are certainly bad actors on both sides of this transaction.  Some purchased tens of thousands of dollars worth of airfare, some of which they would not even fly for pennies on the dollar during the United Danish Kroner issue, and that seems unfair to the airline.  But is it not the responsibility of a business owner to make sure their merchandise is accurately priced?  What would stop a gas station owner from changing the price of a gallon of unleaded from $2.99 to $.29 and then once someone has already filled their car and there is a line around the block, claiming that the price was not valid and demanding the rest of the price.  "You should have know that was an error" the gas station owner might say, except that every now and again gas stations get people in the door by dropping their prices for a brief time to incredibly low rates.  

Airlines can be bad actors too.  Recently, several American carriers were found to have price fixed routes to Seoul or settled out of court on compelling evidence.  This isn't the first time this has happened and it is unlikely it is the last.

If I were to hold up signs with prices and routes (as listed above) without showing the airline's name, could you tell if it was a mistake?  If not, how can a consumer, and should they be liable for conducting thorough route analysis to determine that this carrier would go low but not that low? 

Finally, we live in an era where Twitter, forums, and other online presences can compound an issue for any business - airline or otherwise.  That does not mean the DoT should allow them to no longer be responsible for the mistakes of their employees or antiquated technology.  

Whatever choice is made regarding this CFR, it should be forced consistently and without prejudice.  If the rule stands, then United should be (in future situations) required to honor tickets, bad actors or not.  Consumers will continue to be on the hook for their mistakes too.  But the way the rule stands now (unenforced) is ineffective.

Title: John Buchan
Comment: Everything in the airline business, is done just to benefit the airlines. Enough is enough, if an airline sells a ticket, regardless if an error occurred or not, the airline must honor the ticket. If they charge my credit card, then they sold me a ticket and they must honor it!

Title: John Edmondson
Comment:
Airlines have extremely powerful tools imbued with incredible logic components such that mistake fares could be avoided.  These systems were put in place to help airlines most effectively increase their revenues. Airlines hold all the power in a purchasing relationship with the consumer.  So much power that when I wanted to keep an open seat that I paid for to be used by another traveler whose plans changed at the last minute and they could not travel, that the airline said no, they had the right to steal my money and sell the seat to someone else. 

If an airline makes a mistake, then their systems, processes, and employee(s) should be held accountable for that mistake. Consumers are held accountable for their mistakes, airlines should too... Unless they want to figure out how to work with all customers - so far, that hasn't been a direction they want to head.  

Do not relax the rule requiring airlines to honor their fares, and not to change already purchased fares upwards, this is the last vestige of sanctuary for the beleaguered travel consumer.

Title: Jeffrey Harris
Comment:
Airlines have incredibly sophisticated computer systems.  Airlines could easily avoid these types of problems by 
adding additional logic to their pricing programs; for example, if a fare is being changed to one that is 50% of 
historical averages, it would need to be routed to a manager for manual approval before being posted.

Airlines should be required to continue to abide by existing policies that require them to honor purchased tickets.  
If nothing else, this would provide them with incentive to fix their pricing systems.

Conversely, changing the existing policies gives airlines the ability to decide that a bona fide pricing change is actually a 
"mistake" (if for example, an airline realized it did not need to cut a fare as deeply as it purposely did) and cancel tickets 
people purchased in good faith, with no recourse for purchasers.

While the existing rules are subject to abuse by passengers, the travelling public has no other practical means of redress 
against large airlines and their contracts of adhesion except for rules issued and enforced by DOT.  Please do not eliminate 
one of the few means left to the travelling public to protect themselves against obnoxious practices of airlines, and actually
give airlines the ability to manipulate prices further in their favor as discussed in the previous paragraph.

Title: William D. Sturtz
Comment: I think that airlines ought to be able to rescind fare offers that are obvious errors.  I also think that in the interest of fairness, when a customer booking a flight makes a error (AM vs PM, typo in name, wrong date by a week, etc) the airlines should be forced to allow corrections of those errors without charge as well.  It would be grossly unfair if one side of the transaction is able to correct errors without consequence and the other side isn't.

Comment:
