Title: James Jacobs
Comment:
If I were to purchase an air ticket online and made a mistake in the spelling of a name, a destination, the departure or arrival dates/times, etc., Most airlines would charge a penalty of two or three hundred dollars to correct my mistake. When an airline makes a mistake by posting an incorrect fate on it's website, the airline's customer is told that the purchased ticket is invalid. 

I believe in fair play. If the airline wants to void a ticket purchased at an incorrect fare, it should be able to do so, but only if it pays the purchaser the same penalty that that airline imposes on customers who make a mistake during the purchase process. Payment to customer for such mistakes should be made in the currency used to purchase the airfare, not in credits for future travel.

Title: Joseph Banar
Comment:
Airlines should be made to advertise ticket prices such that the consumer clearly understands the total cost of the ticket and what the ticket includes for that price. Any mandatory fees, surcharges or taxes, should be included in the base price of the ticket. The advertised price should also clearly spell out what is included, assigned seating, baggage allowance, carry-on allowance and/or meals. This is the only way that the consumer can compare the cost of different airlines.
Having to do 3-4 international flights per year for the last 10 years selective ticket pricing and hidden fee assessments have caused confusion and anger.

Title: Karen Kenney
Comment: If a traveler makes an error when making a reservation, they are held to their purchase and any changes require a new ticket and a change fee.  If a traveler purchases preferred seating and their flight is cancelled forcing them to move to another flight, they are denied preferred seating on the new flight and no money is refunded.  Money is not refunded for checked luggage that is lost.  Travelers are told that once a purchase is made and things happen to affect the purchase, they are stuck with the consequences.  Shouldn't that apply to the airlines as well?  Why are all the regulations designed to favor the service provider rather than the customer paying for the service?

Title: Airlines for America
Comment: See attached.

Title: Director of Aviation Youngstown-Warren Regional Airport
Comment:
Dear DOT Airline Fitness Office,

The timely approval of the ADI firness and interstate air service certification is very much needed for the requested daily airline service between the Youngstown-Warren-Sharon communities from the Youngstown-Warren Regional Airport and the Chicago O'Hare International Airport. This will afford the communities connectivity to many connecting destiantions and for business in Chicago. ADI has responded in a positive and timely manner to meet all requests and requirements of the DOT. Approvals by the end of July would make daily service available on or slightly before October 1, 2015. Any further delays may jerpardize the success of this air service as such start-ups in the winter months are more difficult to inirially sustain. Service commencement during the months of October and November will give the service a good foundation to sustain the service prior to the cold winter months. The community has a SCASDP grant totaling $1.2M, has raised the Local Match, and has additional fund raising efforts planned when such service is approved and announced. The DOT's timely approval of the airline fitness and interstate air service certification is greatly appreciated. 

Thank You,

Dan Dickten, A.A.E.
Director of Aviation
Youngstown-Warren Regional Airport

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am a pilot for ADI. All I can say is that the previous comments are all true. I am sorry but all the pilots have been talking and we all say the comments are rough but there is nothing we can do. Its the truth. I hate to loose my job but I am concerned about my safety

Title: Aerodynamics
Comment: This Request for Additional Information has generated some negative posts from Anonymous individuals.  We the pilots of Aerodynamic's, Inc. would like to submit this document in support of Aerodynamic's, Inc. and to attest to the safety of the airline.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: With regards to Aerodynamics response to the department, ADI has knowingly concealed vital information about its fitness and business practices and lied again to the department. ADI claims that it was placed under cash only from its vendors as a result of the "aftermath" of the show order cause. That is simply not true and a lie. ADI was placed under a cash only basis because it stopped paying bills as soon as the show order cause was issued. The Flight Safety bill remained unpaid from January 2015 until august 2015 when ADI had no other choice to pay the bill or shut down because pilots were no longer current to fly. ADI claims it paid its crews on a timely matter. My salary is comprised of a base salary, per diem, and a completion bonus. As ADI reports it paid the base salary being paid a few days late, per diem was not paid in March, April, May and June until mid July. The stocking of the plane I had to pay with my own credit card was not reimbursed for 4 months and my bonus remains unpaid to this day. If ADI just chose not to pay its employees just like its vendors while directors enjoyed full salary and benefits.

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment: ADI Airlines has previously stated to the DOT that it is financially fit based on the financial strength of its parent ADI Acquisition Co, LLC.   ADI Acquisition Co is in default of obligations in the hundreds of thousands of dollars arising from contractual obligations from its purchase of ADI Airlines. A company that so wantonly defaults on its contractual obligations relating to its purchase of an airline within the first month of making them cannot possibly be found financially fit.  We urge the DOT to carefully examine ADI and its parents outstanding obligations including but not limited to those directly made as consideration for the purchase of ADI.

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment:
On behalf of our entire community we would like to express our appreciation of and support for the issuance of Order 2015-11-24 on behalf of Aerodynamics Incorporated under Docket DOT-OST-2014-0114. We appreciate the significant responsibility of issuing such an Order and can only imagine the work and effort required to meet that responsibility.

As you are aware, recent regulatory changes designed to help improve overall airline safety have also brought an unfortunate side effect of diminishing the availability of air service to non-metropolitan communities. Although we may believe that rules could be adjusted to provide both a safe environment and improve availability, we recognize that there may be more than one point of view on this topic and we do not consider ourselves experts in the field.

We are pleased that the Department of Transportation has demonstrated a willingness to approve carriers who are interested in serving non-metropolitan areas and are specifically pleased with the Order issued on behalf of Aerodynamics Incorporated (ADI). We look forward to engaging ADI in discussions to improve the availability of air service for our community and encourage the Department of Transportation to continue to support additional airlines who may wish to enhance rural air service.

Thank-you.

Title: Comment from Joan Deramo
Comment:
I am personally thrilled to hear of the proposed issuance of certificate authority to ADI for projected air service between the Youngstown-Warren Regional Airport and Chicago O'Hare Airport.  It would be a "dream-come-true" for my husband and me to conveniently fly to see our children, grandchildren and other relatives who live in the vicinity.  Currently we have to drive to CLE to catch a plane which is a nuisance and expensive with turnpike tolls and parking. There is no competition in parking prices anymore.  Also, as renovations continue prior to the Republican National Convention, the place is torn up and very confusing to navigate inside and outside the terminal.

I would welcome daily service between Youngstown and Chicago and would fly the route at least once or twice per month. This service opens up a whole realm of travel possibilities for the people of the Trumbull County and the Mahoning Valley.  I believe that not only business travelers will benefit, but anyone who wishes to connect to the world. I throw my whole-hearted support to this projected air service and hope that we are up and flying very soon.

Title: Comment from Dan Camuso
Comment: In regards to daily flights from Youngstown to Chicago and back, I believe it is a fantastic idea.  My wife and I travel a lot, mainly for pleasure.  We leave from Pittsburgh, Akron and Cleveland whenever we want to go out west or up north.  For Florida and Myrtle Beach we always fly from Youngstown.  The service and convenience utilizing the Youngstown airport in great.  When the Chicago flights are added, we will fly out of Youngstown much more often.

Title: Comment from Douglas Kibby
Comment: As a supporter of the Youngstown-Warren Regional Airport (YNG) and a business traveler, I have to say this has been a long time coming! I am very happy I will have another option to choose from when I have to travel for business on a weekly basis. Thank you to the DOT for the preliminary approval for ADI to provide daily service to a region that has been missing this daily and much needed economic engine for quite some time. The Youngstown-Warren-Sharon region is starting to see a bounce back with jobs and manufacturing and this new service will increase the well being of every individual and business in the region. I thank you again and look forward to the final official approval to get these flights started!

Title: Comment from Bill Ohlin
Comment: As a strong supporter of The Youngstown-Warren Regional Airport, I am looking forward with great anticipation to the start of scheduled daily air service from Youngstown to Chicago O'Hare International Airport. This much needed service will significantly enhance economic development in our region, and provide a direct connection between YNG and the rest of the world. I fully support ADI and it's management team, and urge you to expedite final certification.

Title: Comment from Chad Hughes
Comment: As a strong supporter of The Youngstown-Warren Regional Airport, I am looking forward to the start of scheduled daily commercial air service from Youngstown to Chicago. This much needed air service will provide a direct connection between YNG and the rest of the world. I fully support ADI/Seaport Airlines and it's management team. We look forward to the service, and new addition to our growing community.

Title: Comment from Youngstown/Warren Regional Chamber
Comment: The Youngstown/Warren Regional Chamber (YWRC) fully supports the approval of Seaport Airlines, operated by Aerodynamics, Inc. (ADI) to provide the much needed daily connecting service using a 50-seat regional jet aircraft. We appreciate the USDOT's tentative approval of the Airline to be fit, safe and able to conduct the air service for our community. The YWRC and the Western Reserve Port Authority have a strong partnership and and we'll continue to support the ongoing growth of the Youngstown/Warren Regional Airport (YNG). The daily connection to Chicago O'Hare International Airport will   not only be supported by many leisure travelers and but also our existing business community. The businesses throughout our region will travel to Chicago for meetings at their company headquarters or with their supply chain firms and also to access the many connecting destinations that O'hare offers. This daily connection will be a more convenient and cost effective service for the existing companies throughout our region, in addition to increasing the attraction of new investment. Being able to access daily flights to an international airport is a major part of the decision making process for a company selecting a new location. With this connection, our region will become that much more competitive for future opportunities.  Once appropriate, the YWRC is committed to doing our part in marketing this service to our nearly 3,000 Chamber members and beyond.

Title: Samuel Raphael
Comment: Additional documents supporting commuter application

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Hank Myers is nothing more than a bully and should stop wasting the DOT's time and also his clients time.   His latest letter claims "Air Excursions has raised the possibility of assigning the case to an Administrative Law Judge."  This letter was penned by him, as Air Excursions / Alaska Seaplanes is one of his clients.  There is no way that KC or MS have the inside knowledge of DOT regulations and the process to request this.

Just as when Alaska Juneau Aeronautics brought to the attention of the DOT Air Excursions' operations well exceeding the DOT limitations, Mr. Myers jumped in to defend this company tooth and nail by filing the dockets full of yabber.

See docket OST-2008-0318 and OST-2012-0178.

He at least makes these entertaining for the rest of us outside of Alaska.

Title: Jones Day - Request for Grant of Motion
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Menagerie Enterprises, Inc./Monarch Air Motion to Expedite and to Shorten Public Comment Period
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Monarch Air's email
Comment: Submission of emails dated 6/29/2015 forwarding amended air carrier certificate and operations specifications.  attachments to emails have already been placed in the docket as a single, consolidated .pdf file.

Title: Meir Libersohn
Comment:
I request that the US Government refuse this application due to the egregious attitude of this company on fellow customers.

As the US DOT have in file, the level of complaints against the United Airlines have raised up notoriously, and their refusal to make good, including for damaged luggage and goods, delayed luggage and the necessity of purchase of goods till arrival of such.  When actively the consumer complaints either customer care refuse to make good, or the customer is threatened with a potential lawsuit for insisting the airline to make good, they get corporate security involved, who the say that they will involve law enforcement, they ban the customer from flying United Airlines ever again and the frequent flier account is shut down and miles confiscated as well, at times they may allege that miles were bartered or sold.

Furthermore, united has actively engaged with Lufthansa and other carriers code-sharing flights, per say a intra-European flight marketed and sold as a united flight, reducing then change of competition nad harming the customer.

Skywest Airlines should be allowed to operate under its own name and as a provider to united, passengers should be able to acquire tickets and these should be issue directly by skywest, regardless of their relations with united.

Title: Kathleen Henke
Comment:
I am an American citizen living in Europe who travels to the USA from time to time.Although we music lovers, lay or professional, were delighted by the new ruling for taking musical instruments on a flight, I was shocked to discover this:
This is from United's requirements...
****
Musical instruments

Depending on their size, musical instruments can be carried on board, handled as checked baggage, or carried as cabin-seat baggage.

As carry-on

As part of the allowance of one carry-on bag plus one personal item, a passenger may carry a violin, guitar or other small musical instrument onboard the aircraft if:

The instrument can be stowed in the overhead bin or under the seat in front of the passenger; and
There is space for stowage at the time when the passenger boards the aircraft
Musical instruments transported onboard United and United Express aircraft must be in hard-shell cases.

****
This is a problem for those of us who have always had our small instruments in soft cases (in my case, a small harp or a wooden Irish-style flute), and it would be too expensive to have a hard case custom made for it. This contradicts the new ruling which says that instruments carried in the cabin are to be treated like other carry-on luggage. In addition carry-ons such as computers are not required to be in hard, shock-proof cases even though many laptops are worth hundreds of dollars. United's carry-on rule clearly discriminates against musicians!!  What can be done to bring United Airlines in line with the new regulation?

Title: Benjamin Edelman and Jason Steele vs. Delta Air Lines, Inc. - Comments
Comment:
(See attached file for formatted text)

1.	In its reply Delta has admitted to the violations and identified that fewer than 500 ticket transactions were affected by its 55-day long misrepresentation (page 1). Having identified the affected ticket transactions, Delta admits that it:
	a.	knows who the affected customers are;
	b.	has contact information for these customers;
	c.	has the credit card number used for payment, upon which a restitution credit can be easily applied.
2.	At approximately $400 per ticket of misrepresentation on fewer than 500 ticket transactions, this amounts to less than $200,000 in restitution due to consumers. I urge the DOT to mandate that Delta effect this administratively simple restitution without delay.
3.	Deltas argument that no customers were actually harmed (page 3) makes a mockery of the DOT rules at issue. The DOT rules require truthful information at every turn. With or without the DOT rules, Deltas statement was literally false. The DOT has already found in Edelman v. American Airlines Order 2013-12-6 that customers are entitled to receive truthful and accurate information. And the Complainants show persuasively the deceptive nature of Deltas misrepresentations (Complaint  13-14).
4.	Finally, Deltas reference to Edelman v. Cathay Pacific Order 2013-8-23 is irrelevant. There, a separate company (Oneworld Management Company) made a false statement that was imputed to Cathay through the principle that airlines are responsible for the actions of their ticket agents; here, Delta itself made the false statements. Cathay sells a small amount of tickets in the U.S.; Delta sells tens of thousands of tickets a day in the U.S. Moreover, the Cathay violation occurred relatively shortly after DOT guidance specifically alerted carriers to the risk of making false statements about tax, whereas these Delta false statements occurred years later, at which point Delta was abundantly on notice.

Title: Application of Air Medical Ltd for an Exemption and Foreign Air Carrier Permit
Comment: Amended Application of Air Medical Ltd for an Exemption and Foreign Air Carrier Permit

Title: Kitty Kelly Epstein, PhD
Comment:
I support the change in regulation to allow geographic-based hiring preferences in administering federal awards.    I live in Oakland, California, and I have been involved in campaigns for local hire for projects not involving federal funding.    Unemployment rates are high in our community.  These regulations have made some difference in the employment of our residents and it would be helpful to have such regulations applied to federal dollars and to transportation projects.

Kitty Kelly Epstein, PhD
Professor of Education and Urban Studies
Author of "Organizing to Change a City" (2012) Peter Lang

Title: Lyle Gunn
Comment:
I believe that this amendment is justified and beneficial. The amendment enhances the ability of state departments of transportation to bolster their local economies. This is an important function of state governments that reflects the public interest. Simply building roads and other transportation structures is beneficial to the state, but if the infrastructure is produced using jobs from another state, a potential benefit is not realized in the home state. States traditionally play a role in developing their economies. This can be seen through the existence of economic development departments and general government economic interventionism (e.g. targeted tax credits). Therefore,  it is not unusual for a state to spend money on developing private interests for the overall public benefit. The awarding of contracts is an opportunity for states to enhance and strengthen local economies, but they must be careful not to create an unfair competitive advantage. 
	There is one problem with the regulation. The inclusion of a geographic-based criterion for the awarding of DOT contracts could mean the most financially appropriate firm is not selected. A firm could gain an unfair competitive advantage if it is within a reasonable distance to a locality, but not within jurisdiction. For instance, a private firm specializing in highway construction that exists on the border of a state could be excluded from consideration in a nearby town simply because it is across state lines. This could result in a situation where a state government awards a project to a higher bid just because it is located within its borders. A firm with higher prices, and equal service provision as other firms, may be selected based only on proximity. The result is a less efficient government provision of services to the taxpayer. To avoid an unfair competitive advantage, the geography-based criterion should not be used as the only basis for awarding project monies.  Without this provision a state could inefficiently use money to bolster local economies.  The DOT monitoring mechanism that oversees such projects to ensure no unfair results have occurred could prevent unfair advantages and inefficient provision. In all, local economic improvement should be seen as an advantage of awarding contracts to local firms, not the goal.

Title: Lyle Gunn
Comment:
I believe that this amendment is justified and beneficial. The amendment enhances the ability of state departments of transportation to bolster their local economies. This is an important function of state governments that reflects the public interest. Simply building roads and other transportation structures is beneficial to the state, but if the infrastructure is produced using jobs from another state, a potential benefit is not realized in the home state. States traditionally play a role in developing their economies. This can be seen through the existence of economic development departments and general government economic interventionism (e.g. targeted tax credits). Therefore,  it is not unusual for a state to spend money on developing private interests for the overall public benefit. The awarding of contracts is an opportunity for states to enhance and strengthen local economies, but they must be careful not to create an unfair competitive advantage. 
	There is one problem with the regulation. The inclusion of a geographic-based criterion for the awarding of DOT contracts could mean the most financially appropriate firm is not selected. A firm could gain an unfair competitive advantage if it is within a reasonable distance to a locality, but not within jurisdiction. For instance, a private firm specializing in highway construction that exists on the border of a state could be excluded from consideration in a nearby town simply because it is across state lines. This could result in a situation where a state government awards a project to a higher bid just because it is located within its borders. A firm with higher prices, and equal service provision as other firms, may be selected based only on proximity. The result is a less efficient government provision of services to the taxpayer. To avoid an unfair competitive advantage, the geography-based criterion should not be used as the only basis for awarding project monies.  Without this provision a state could inefficiently use money to bolster local economies.  The DOT monitoring mechanism that oversees such projects could prevent unfair advantages and inefficient provision if it actively investigates projects. In all, local economic improvement should be seen as an advantage of awarding contracts to local firms, not the goal.

Title: Jeffrey Wharton
Comment: I understand the potential advantages of this rule as it applies to construction labor and services.  However, as a manufacturer of rolling stock systems under the FTA rules, we find it impractical and impossible to move our factory from geographic location to geographic location in order to obtain the local hiring preference.  This would cause a loss of jobs in our current factory location and a new-hiring and training of factory workers in a different location.  The net gain of jobs is ZERO.  The cost to implement would be very high with a great loss of efficiency to locate and set up new equipment.  Is it the intent of this rule to move manufacturing factories across the U.S for rolling stock procurements?  In addition to buses and trains, Rolling Stock Systems include Traction Power Substations, Catenary, Signals, and Communications equipment.  This could destroy U.S. manufacturing that supports the FTA Rolling Stock industry.

Title: American Public Transportation Association
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Butch Campbell
Comment: I understand the potential advantages of this rule as it applies to construction labor and services. However, as an operation manager of a manufacturer of rolling stock systems under the FTA rules, we find it impractical and impossible to move our factory from geographic location to geographic location in order to obtain the local hiring preference. This will cause a loss of jobs in our current factory location and a new-hiring and training of factory workers in a different location would be costly to the company as well. The net gain of jobs is ZERO. The cost to implement would be very high with a great loss of efficiency to locate and set up new equipment. Is it the intent of this rule to move manufacturing factories across the U.S for rolling stock procurements? In addition to buses and trains, Rolling Stock Systems include Traction Power Substations, Catenary, Signals, and Communications equipment. This could destroy U.S. manufacturing that supports the FTA Rolling Stock industry.

Title: Johnnie Burns
Comment:
This is a great idea. However, it must be carefully thought out. Will it be similar to section 3 of HUD? Does it relate to new hires? What are the percentages? What are the timeframes around the project in which some is hired and/or considered a new hire? Who will pay for the tracking mechanisms? What are the penalties for contractors who dont meet the preference or goal? 

I think local hiring is a powerful tool and Im glad FHWA and FTA are considering piloting. This would be great on design build and or mega projects. The efforts to track and maintain a local workforce is very time consuming and requires staff. It must be a deliberate effort.

Title: Nicholas Parks
Comment: I believe this amendment is correct in its reasoning and should be enacted.  This is largely because it allows state transportation agencies to benefit their local communities. By allowing them to use workers from their area, these agencies also help their local economies grow and develop along with their transportation infrastructure. With this policy, not only will these agencies develop transportation but also will create jobs in their areas where they are needed. There is a potential problem however, that workers/firms could be chosen regardless of their qualifications. For example, under this policy, firms with higher bids may be chosen for federal contracts purely because of their proximity to the location, even though they may cost more than a farther firm. It may also lead to unqualified workers being employed because of their proximity to the site, all because qualified workers are further away. So these precautions and situations must be kept in mind when administering Federal Awards even when they are based on geography. I think that with all these precautions taken into consideration, my local area will also benefit as there are a lot of roads in my town that often require maintenance. With these hiring methods, my area will not only have more jobs but will also benefit from the long term benefits of having a stable source of jobs that also improve our transportation infrastructure.

Title: State Senator Nan Orrock
Comment:
I strongly urge adoption of "local hire" policy. It is quite clear that there could be an enormous impact on spurring local economy and jobs availability in hard hit areas so as to maximize the value of the infrastructure project in communities.

My urban Atlanta Senate district 36 has high needs communities with high unemployment that would benefit greatly by having such policies in place as we build out transit and transportation projects.  We are currently passing increased funding for these types of projects and a federal policy in place on local hires would be a timely enhancement as projects come on line involving federal dollars.  Our Atlanta Beltline project is another great example of an opportunity that could be maximized by this policy change.

Thank you for forward looking improvements to past policy.  It can make a real difference for hardworking local people, our families and our communities.

Title: Sherri Bell
Comment: This type of regulation is much needed I live in Los Angeles where Black Workers are only employed at a %2 employment rate.  And women at a %1 rate  in the unionized construction industry.  Enforcement of federal  laws like EEO 11246 has been instrumental in addressing these major  construction agreements (PLA's)

Title: John Barberis
Comment:
Does this apply to rolling stock?

If not, is there another NPRM for local hire preference that applies to rolling stock?

Title: Gail Carlson
Comment:
I strongly support this legislation.  As a minority, woman-owned, small business, I have struggled to compete for projects in and near my home.  I am competing with large national firms, who have greater resources and capacity, but little community level knowledge or concern of constituent needs, particularly in disadvantaged communities.  

I urge you to move this bill forward and create an level playing field for local businesses.

Title: Ken Klem
Comment:
The intent of this rule is, without a doubt, good. However, in spite of good intentions, the imposition of rules, too often carry unintended side effects. 

I remember a luxury tax from the 80s. The intent was to take a little from the haves to provide more for the have-nots. Many of my friends at the time, employed in the manufacture of expensive boats, lost their jobs. The haves stopped buying the things subjected to the luxury tax. So government revenues did not go up. The have-nots ended up with less because they lost their jobs. Effectively, although full of good intentions, the legislation had a lose-lose outcome.

Rolling stock systems encompasses an array of specialized manufacturing and construction skill sets, processes, knowledge and understanding. In many cases the companies that produce these products and services bring 100s of years of experience to the bargain. Experience that reduces over-all project costs. 

As an employee of a Catenary systems and materials manufacturer, I fear the imposition of this rule will result in another lose-lose. The purveyors of Buses, Trains, Traction Power Substations, Catenary, Signals and Communications equipment have spent decades moving to their respective places on specialized learning curves. These companies and the people in them represent a unique knowledge base. 

The cost of quality and the cost of inexperience will ultimately fall on the taxpayers and public the intended beneficiaries of the rule. The trade-off between the benefit of local jobs and the detriment to the procurement process (and associated costs) cannot be justified.

The rule will strike a devastating blow to public transportation and the thousands of existing good paying jobs that support it.

Title: John H. Prince, Jr.
Comment:
I support the proposal to amend the regulation as it pertains to geographic-based hiring preferences in administering federal awards. Utilization of a local workforce accompanied by career training and education (CTE), an apprenticeship component should be an economic stimulus for the community, especially where there is over 20% unemployment in some urban areas in America.

The Civil Rights Act of 1964, and the various Civil Rights laws which prohibits discrimination on federally-funded and federally-assisted programs and projects must be vigorously enforced.

Somewhere, I read or I read somewhere Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. stated if we have a law, there is a need for enforcement. If there is no enforcement, we don't have a law.

Keep the faith,

John H. Prince, Jr.
FMR. Regional Civil Rights Officer
U.S. Department of Transportation (Ret.)

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I do not support the rule.  Working in the construction industry on Federally funded highway projects from several million to over one billion dollars, I have experience in this area.
The first issue is that funding matches from FHWA or FTA come from a nationwide tax base and therefore should not be funneled to a locality that can give preference to the local community.
The second issue is that large transportation projects offer opportunities for people to seek new opportunities.  Our sustained size is a function of our ability to expand into new markets when our market slows down.  When we move into a new market we bring people who are ready to grow into higher paying positions and we fill the needed positions with people from the local workforce.  Exporting people brings a diversity of ideas that bring new techniques and innovations to a new market.  If we are handicapped in our ability to bring the knowledge and skills that can provide a low cost solution, the end result will be stale local workforces with no new ideas. 
Third, the local market will adjust to the preference.  Say a 5% bidders preference is granted.  The local contractor will increase his price by 4% to still beat the non-local contractor.  Eventually the non-local contractor stops bidding and the local contractors bids become status quo. The result coupled with point two above is an expensive and stale workforce. OId ideas that cost more.
Fourth, we have bid in local government environments where a bidders preference was allowed (no federal funds).  The system is too corruptible and the enforcement is inconsistent.  We have opted not to bid on projects where we perceived the local government preference requirements to be ambiguous and the penalty for not being in compliance not worth the risk.  Essentially, conforming to the bidders preference, especially in regards to using local subcontractors and labor, only because they are local and not because they are "qualified," could compromise our core values of integrity and safety.
For these reasons, I oppose the rule.

Title: Ohio Contractors Association
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: The Associated General Contractor of America
Comment: Attached is a request to extend comment period to allow affected parties to submit meaningful comment.

Title: Patrick Scully
Comment:
I understand the possible potential advantages of this rule, however, as a rolling stock manufacturer the rule is essentially impossible to implement.  Moving a factory from location to location for particular procurements would be both a massive financial burden that would be passed along to the buyer resulting in higher costs but also a significant impact to the overall quality of the vehicle. 

We deal with a supply base that is diverse and the transit market typically makes up a very small portion of their customer base.  Components such as engines, transmissions and axles all come from suppliers in the trucking market.  The logistics and applications support for these components is highly complex and have been honed over years of a close working relationship.  Further, small suppliers developed within close proximity to our plants are even more critical to vehicle quality.  To disrupt these supply chain arrangements would be disasterous.

When it comes to assembly staff, the amount of training required and ramp up of a new production site would impact vehicle quality negatively.  Further, no new jobs get created in such scenarios.  It is merely a matter of moving jobs from one location to another with no net increase.

Consequently, it is both impractical and imprudent to implement such a policy.

Title: Jason Mordhorst
Comment:
Many of the contractors that perform federal highway work are part of a collective bargaining agreement with various unions.  This agreement prevents the selective hiring based on region where the employee lives, ethnicity of the employee, or whether or not they are a veteran of the Untied States Military. The agreement is the next qualified person on the list gets the project.  A general contractor cannot guarantee that all of the workers that they hire will be from a local region in which the project is bidding.  Therefore how can a preference being attained.

This creates an unleveled playing field when it comes to competition for low bid work.  Companies work can meet the preference and those who cannot because of union agreements.  

The preference should not be at the worker level but at the company that is bidding the project level.  A local preference is OK with us but not a preference in which there is no metric to measure at bid time but only a commitment.  What will be the consequences to the low bidder that took a project from another company due to the preference and the goals for local hiring are not met?

Please reconsider and remove this local preference completely from public works bidding.

Title: Charles Wochele
Comment: As a past employee of two different passenger rail rolling stock manufacturers I find the proposal to allow credit for local hiring preferences very impractical and an unreasonable preconceived judgment that medium and large cities need jobs more than rural areas and small cities/towns. Moving jobs from a companies core US manufacturing location to another location in order to obtain local hiring preferences is counter productive. Currently there are eight large passenger rail rolling stock manufactures with permanent facilities in the US. These companies have invested tens of millions of dollars in these facilities and worker training so it is not feasible for them to relocate. Most of these companies have made binding commitments to state and local governments to achieve employment goals in order to access industrial development funding and tax incentives. Local preference would cause a loss of jobs in a manufacturers current factory location and moving those jobs would substantially increase cost to the transit agency utilizing local preference with no overall gain in US employment. Many of these facilities are in rural areas that are very dependent on these manufacturing jobs as much as or more than any other area in the US. There is already a huge amount of overcapacity in the US passenger rail rolling stock market and this proposal will only weaken an already very cyclical market between the manufactures that are already in place.  Using local preference in evaluating projects while using Federal dollars is currently against current regulations which was put in place for good reason. If Recipients/Grantees want the federal funding, then hiring/subcontracting opportunities should continue to be federal as well.  If an agency wants to limit hiring/subcontracting preferences to local firms, then they should fund it 100% locally (i.e., city, county, state).

Title: Joseph Wilckens
Comment:
I believe the local residential requirements will have an adverse affect on our company.
 We are a specialty subcontractor serving the heavy & highway and site work industry in the northeast region of the country. We perform our work on approximately 150 individual projects. Our work is a small part of a larger general contract, and our crews are small and specialized. These small crews travel to the projects together to complete our work in a short time period.
 If we are required to hire local people at every location we go to, we will  decrease our production, by having to train new people at each location, which will make us less productive and our costs higher. It will also add a burden to our administrative staff to track all the diffrerent temporary employees this regulation would force us to hire.
 There are not contractors that perform our work in many of the locations we travel to, and the contractors rely on us to perform these specialty items.
 We cannot as a company be restricted to specific location to perform our work as there is not enough of our specialty work in one location to support all of our people. This would require us to reduce our number of employees.
 This sounds very similar to PLA requirements we have seen on projects. These projects are less competitvely bid, increasing the cost of the projects.
 I don't believe with the fiscsal crisis that many government agencies are experiencing, that increasing the cost of projects is desired.

Title: Armina Maxey
Comment: The City of Detroit is a place in desperate need of good jobs for our unemployed men and women, especially our black and brown men and women.  Recently there has been a great upsurge in construction jobs along Detroit's highways and thoroughfares.  While this development is great and welcomed, it is rare to see a person of color working on a federally-funded construction project in our city.  The City of Detroit is nearly 90% people of color, yet the majority of the city's construction projects are lacking in this diversity. The majority of construction workers are geographically from outside outside of the city, and are not representative of Detroit's citizenship.  Detroit has one of the highest unemployment rates in the state, and could most benefit from jobs created via federally funded construction projects.  This proposed rule would aid in ensuring Detroiters get an equal piece of the pie, and get equal access to these important and desperately needed jobs.

Title: Eric Hughes
Comment:
I currently live in Phoenix Az , I'm on disability and making ends meet is an every day battle, although I have some mental problems I am not a danger to anyone else and feel I could help with many of these projects if a chance was given to me i would try my best. I'm strong enough for most anything, Maybe if I was able to take extra time off depending on how I was feeling if I could self police my mental state I i could go as hard as a guy safely could but if /when my anxiety and other disorders started to weigh on me then I wouldn't need to not push myself 5 or more straight days.This way I would be an asset when I was there and any good hourly job would make me feel more accomplished than i have felt in years.
 thank you for your time
Eric Hughes.

Title: Jaime
Comment: I strongly support Geographic-based preferences in Admibistrring Federal Awards. As someone who works on local employment issues and economic development, I believe this would have a tremendous positive impact.

Title: Eric Kirkendall
Comment: I support the Geographic-Based Hiring Preferences in Administering Federal Awards rule.  It will help local people get local jobs, and since it will reduce commuting, will lower the CO2 footprint of DOT projects.

Title: League of American Bicyclists
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Charles Mason
Comment:
I strongly support local/geographic hiring preferences in administering awards. 
This will allow for greater opportunities for low income individual and individuals of color. 
This process should also include resources for effective community engagement to properly position these communities to position themselves for these contracts. 
Additional education and resources should be utilized to assure that the members of local communities have the training, tools and resources to participate in government contracting.

Title: General Contractors Association of New York
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Brad Wright
Comment:
Department of Transportation
2 CFR 1201
RIN 2105-AE38
Geographic-Based Hiring Preferences in Administering Federal Awards
We understand and support the DOTs desire and intent to support the Ladders of Opportunity.  Geographic preferences for construction and other commoditized services make sense where there is an abundant labor pool skilled in the required work.  For highly specialized services, there is a limited pool of qualified, potential bidders.  Restricting the pool of professionals by the imposition of geographic preferences will restrict access to experts in the applicable field and have more than an incidental effect on the pool of potential bidders.

Comment: Please find attached the comments of the Florida Transportation Builders Association (FTBA) regarding Docket No. DOT-OST-2015-0013.  If you have any questions regarding or problems with the attached document, please contact Bob Burleson at (850) 942-1404 or email bburleson@ftba.com

Title: John Barberis
Comment:
It is my personal belief that this will not stand the legal challenges that are bound to come. All Americans paid the taxes that fund these projects and all Americans should be able to compete for the work. It might be that simple.


 However, some other comments if it does fly.

The use of Geographic Based hiring in regards to rolling stock is unproductive.

Rolling stock is high technical with high quality requirements. Manufacturing can be moved, but quality processes and quality culture are not easily relocated.

Most rolling stock manufacturers employ people that live near the factory and have for many years,. We sometimes employ whole families. Awarding big contracts in distant cities will result in lay offs for our existing employees. It does not create jobs, just relocates them, which is unproductive.

Geographic hire is a shell game with winners and losers. The losers are our present employees. The winner are the folks that get new jobs, that is, until they are laid off as the work moves around. Then they become the losers.

This will undoubtedly result in higher costs, making American rolling stock manufacturers more uncompetitive than we already are. If you notice, we do not sell any buses or trains outside the US. Why make it any worse?

Construction and operation of federally funded new starts and transit projects are inherently local. Why overshoot? Do a good job with geographic based hiring in construction and operation and leave the marginal unproductive areas alone. What's the old saying? Do not harm.

If geographic based hiring moves forward, it will likely result is less competition for procurements. It will be one more thing to weed out potential interested bidders.

The devil is in the details. How will the proposals utilizing geographic preferences be evaluated? How do you score existing employees, versus rehire of furloughed employees, versus new employees? How long have the new employees lived in this country? There are all sorts of issues that new to be vetted.

This proposal just shuffles the deck with no net gain and is going to take enormous staff time to defend it from the inevitable challenges. This might better be called the attorney employment act.

Focus on creating new jobs. find new sources of funding, be creative with P3's, make proactive steps to get money into transportation projects.

Title: Ohio Contractors Association
Comment: See attached.

Title: Ronald Trimmer
Comment:
April 2, 2015

The Honorable Anthony R. Foxx, Secretary
U.S. Department of Transportation
1200 New Jersey Avenue, SE
Washington, D.C. 20590

RE: Geographic-Based Hiring Preference in Administering Federal Awards  (Local Hire) 2 CFR Part 1201 [Docket DOTOST20150013] RIN 2105AE38
 
Dear Secretary Foxx:
 
I am Ron Trimmer.  As a member of Gamaliel and the Transportation Equity Network, I led the successful effort to pass SAFETEA-LU section 1920.  Newly elected Senator Obama and his staff helped.  Senator Obama sponsored the provision in the Senate.  We all, including Obama, referred to the legislation as the local hiring amendment.

I am from the St. Louis Metro-east region (Madison County Illinois).  At the time the new Mississippi River Bridge was being planned.  We wanted the project to be used to help the maximum number of poor people, people of color, and women work their way out of poverty into good paying construction careers.

Unfortunately the civil rights department in the FHWA ruled that the language in 1920 was not strong enough and did not allow local hiring.

When I was working to pass 1920 I ran the numbers and showed that local hiring combined with other provisions already in place could move over one million underrepresented minorities into construction careers.  We demonstrated that this approach can work on the I-64 project in St. Louis.  The agreement that was used became known as the Missouri Model.  I am known as the Father of the Missouri Model.  Our MPO region has almost $2 billion in projects scheduled for 2015-2018.

I later found out in discussions with officials in DOT that the local hiring provision was originally put in place to base on competition as currently used to justify the provision, but to prevent good ol boy corruption.

It is recognized that all Americans should have an equal chance to benefit from Federal Infrastructure Investments.  However, women and African-Americans are significantly underrepresented in the trade unions.  There should be about 5 times as many women as there are.  In our St. Louis region there should be 50% more African-Americans in the construction trades than there are.  It is worse in Chicago where there should be 100% more African-Americans in the construction trades than there are.  The point is African American communities cannot benefit fairly from our Federal Infrastructure Investments until the construction trades reflect their communities.  Local hiring can help make that happen by providing opportunities for hardworking reliable African Americans and women to work their way into good paying careers.
Of the approximately $2 billion to be spent in our region about a third is to be spent on transit.  Studies show that transit produced far more jobs created for each $1 billion invested.  Thus, for the St. Louis region it is very important that local hiring be allowed so our poorest communities can work their way out of poverty and get their share of the work.  East St. Louis, Illinois area has some of the highest unemployment and poverty in the nation.  This is not possible with the current makeup of the construction workforce.

Sincerely, 

Ronald G. Trimmer
Past member of the Transportation Equity Network steering committee
Past chair of the Gamaliel International Assembly board
106 Lenox Ave
Mitchell, IL 62040-2729
618-604-6216
trimmer@charter.net

Title: Americans for Transit
Comment:
Americans for Transit is very supportive of policies that leverage transportation investments to foster more prosperous, healthy and equitable communities. Therefore, we applaud USDOTs efforts to allow city and state departments of transportation to set targeted economic and geographic preferences, as a step toward increased workforce inclusion for all Americans. 

Local hiring policies are a mechanism for connecting local residents, especially lower-income workers, women, and people of color, to jobs associated with transportation projects located in the communities in which they live. Many communities are utilizing local hiring and best value contracting provisions on infrastructure projects large and small. When paired with strong relationships between government, community, labor, and contractors, these provisions can maximize the economic benefit of transportation investments and provide ladders of opportunity to the unemployed and underemployed.

The proposed local hire program sets forth a pathway toward full workforce inclusion for workers who have been traditionally underrepresented in the transportation sector. Going forward, we urge USDOT to make this program permanent to solidify future gains in workforce inclusion.

Title: Faith Coalition for the Common Good
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Robert Pollin, Political Economy Research Institute, U. of Massachusetts
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Nick Sauvie
Comment: I am 100% in favor of amending regulations to allow local hiring on federally-funded transportation projects. I have been working with the East Portland Action Plan, a coalition working to improve low-income neighborhoods in Portland, Oregon. Community Benefits Agreements with a local hiring preferences is our top priority to increase the number of family-wage jobs and successful small businesses in our community. We have been working with the City of Portland on a local hiring agreement for the construction of two new parks. We would also like to see local hiring on a planned Bus Rapid Transit project in our community. Please change the regulations so that we will be able to add local hiring for this important project.

Title: Joe Policarpio
Comment:
Gillig is one of the largest manufacturers of heavy duty transit buses for many transit agencies throughout the US and as an executive I would like to provide our comments on this proposed rule making.

Geographic-based hiring practices for rolling stock on FTA funded projects is impractical and will severely limit competition on every project.  Manufacturers of buses bid on approximately 50 -100 projects per year.  To expect the manufacturers to establish new factories in each of those new cities for the production of those buses is not very realistic for a variety of different reasons.  

Gillig's core business philosophy includes the manufacturing of high quality buses and for us to achieve this goal it is critical for production to come from one centralized plant which builds buses on a large scale.  Experienced workers are the key to providing high quality buses.  That experience cannot be gained on a short and temporary basis for the build of one (or few) order(s) of buses. Quality would suffer with that kind of business approach. We will not risk our high quality reputation on inexperienced workers.

Bus assemblers are a highly trained group of employees.  It would be extremely improbable that we could attract and hire technically qualifed employees on a quick, temporary basis for those "pop -up" factories without providing that employee with a long term job commitment.   It should be noted as well, that this proposed rule making will cause significant job layoffs at our existing manufactuing facility so there will be actually no net increase in jobs in the US for this local hiring initiative.  It just provides for a shell game of moving those jobs from one city, or one plant, to the next.  Our communities would be devistated with the movement of our current jobs from of our area.

Another huge detriment to the deployment of geographic-based hiring is the ultimate cost of the project which would increase substantially.   To purchase or lease land, build a new factory or reconfigure an existing factory, hire new employees, train those employees, purchase and provide the necessary tooling, duplicate inventory and production management staff, etc on a city to city, temporary basis would increase overhead costs which would be passed on to the customer resulting in substantially increased bus prices. 

But most importantly, the biggest impediment to this proposed rule making will be limiting competition.  Gillig, as well as other bus manufacturers, have made huge investments in their existing manufacturing facilities and their commitment to their current  employee base.  Fractionalizing all these investments means decreasing production and costing effeciencies which would result in the reduction of already slim margins.  Therefore, Gillig would not find it prudent to participate in any procurement with geographic-based hiring preferences as we feel that would greatly negatively impact the proven success of our company in many ways.

Title: Eric Ustation
Comment: As a member of APTA, I am writing to express opposition to the U.S. Department of Transportations (DOTs) proposal to allow geographic-based hiring preferences in federally funded contracts. As the operator of a medium sized transit agency, our current employee resources are fully utilized with compliance and tracking efforts for existing state and federal grants/programs. The addition of a geographic-based preference for construction projects or any other project for that matter would add another layer of administrative oversight as staff would need to create checks and balances to ensure contractors and sub-contractors are in fact hiring local employees. While there may be (as it is yet still undetermined) positive impacts on local economies when geographic-based preferences are used for mega-projects, it is unclear whether such an impact would be the same for the small and medium sized projects that many agencies routinely enter into; and whether those impacts would offset the additional administrative burden placed on the local agency. Moreover, if there are positive effects on the local economy, they would most likely only be temporary. Additionally, any program that essentially limits the pool of bidders, even unintentionally, will result in the local agency paying more for the cost of goods and services  further straining already tight budgets. Lastly, the introduction of geographic-based preference requirements could politicize the procurement process and slow down the delivery of critically needed projects.

Title: Jobs to Move America Coalition
Organization Name: Jobs to Move America Coalition & 39 member organizations
Comment:
Dear Secretary Foxx:

We are writing on behalf of the Jobs to Move America Coalition (hereinafter JMA), an alliance of over 40 organizations from across the United States that is dedicated to the creation and improvement of jobs and opportunity for low income communities through the investment of public transportation dollars. Specific organizations signing onto this letter are listed below. 

We submit these comments in response to the DOTs Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (hereinafter NPRM) ID number DOT-OST-2015-0013-0002, Geographic-Based Hiring Preferences in Administering Federal Awards. Because the collective work of JMA is focused on the creation of good manufacturing jobs in the transit vehicle manufacturing industry, our comments relate primarily to strengthening the final rule currently entitled Geographic-Based Hiring Preferences in Administering Federal Awards (hereinafter Final Rule) as it relates to rolling stock and other equipment procurement. While we have seen many creative examples of geographic preferences and targeted hiring programs linked to the award of construction contracts, we leave other organizations to comment more specifically in that arena.

GENERAL COMMENTS:

First, we applaud the DOTs proposed rule as well as the recently launched DOT experimental program for 2015. Virtually all of the JMA member organizations have extensive experience in the creation of geographic and targeted-based hiring preferences in public contracting, and therefore recognize the historic nature of the DOTs proposed rule as well as the recently launched DOT experimental program. As discussed below, we urge the DOT to include a direct reference to targeted hiring programs in the Final Rule. The evidence shows that, if grantee agencies are allowed to apply innovative contracting language to all of their procurements, the job creation and economic development impact of that investment will grow substantially.  Past experience has also shown  as described below  that these increased community and economic benefits will occur without significant negative impacts on open competition in the bidding process. In addition, we believe that grantee agencies should be able to use geographic preferences in rolling stock procurement with certain limitations, as described in the attached letter.

There needs to be some allowances for those employers whose employees live in border counties since they could work on both sides of the state line, and still remain LOCAL.
Residents that live close to their state border should be allowed to work on either side of the border without fear of losing their chance to work locally just because they live in  the wrong state. Title: United Spinal Association
Comment:
United Spinal Association is pleased to offer the following comments concerning the U.S Department of Transportations (U.S. DOT) proposed rulemaking on Geographic-Based Hiring Preferences in Administering Federal Awards. 

Founded in 1946 by paralyzed veterans, United Spinal Association is the largest disability-led nonprofit organization serving and representing the interests of more than a million Americans living with spinal cord injuries and disorders (SCI/D).  United Spinal has dedicated its energy, and programs, to improving the quality of life for these Americans of all ages and advancing their independence.  People with disabilities must have equal and safe access to all transportation options, and employment opportunities in the transportation sector.  

United Spinal Association is supportive of policies that leverage transportation investment to foster healthy, equitable and inclusive communities of opportunity. We support the U.S. DOTs efforts to allow city and state departments of transportation to set economic and geographic preferences, as an initial step toward workforce inclusion for all Americans. Local and targeted hiring policies are a mechanism for connecting local residents, especially lower-income people, women, and people of color, to jobs in the communities in which they live. 

Many communities have employed local and targeted hire provisions on projects large and small, with tangible benefits for their residents seeking quality employment.  Milwaukee implemented local hire policies which increased the employment of local residents on transportation jobs by 16% over in just 4 years.  Los Angeles and Oakland are utilizing local hire policies as well on major projects.  Unfortunately, a U.S. Department of Transportation prohibition on local hire for federally-funded projects has made it difficult for other cities to leverage investments for job and training opportunities.

Research has shown that low-income workers, women, people with disabilities and communities of color are vastly underrepresented in jobs in the transportation sector, when compared with their overall participation in the workforce.  According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, people with disabilities comprise just 3.8% of the transportation and utilities industry.  In February 2015, only 20% of people with disabilities participated in the workforce compared to 68% of people without disabilities.  

The proposed local and targeted hire program sets forth a pathway toward full workforce inclusion for workers who have been underrepresented in the transportation sector. Going forward, it is important that U.S. DOT make this program permanent, to solidify future gains in workforce inclusion. 

We urge the U.S. DOT to extend this allowance for targeted hiring provisions to apply to women and people with disabilities, who also stand to benefit significantly from such policies. This can be accomplished by inserting a provision into the federal surface transportation authorization that would allow for local and targeted hiring.   In addition, we recommend the U.S. DOT include language supporting contractor compliance with the U.S. Department of Labor Section 503 rule requiring affirmative action policies leading to the employment of people with disabilities.

We urge the U.S. DOT to support such efforts as they are entirely consistent with the departments Ladders of Opportunity Program and represent an important tool for fostering economic and social equity. 

Thank you again for the opportunity to provide comments.

Title: San Francisco Municipal Transportation Agency
Comment: See attached comment from the San Francisco Municipal Transportation Agency.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
County of Los Angeles Department of Public Works

The County of Los Angeles (County) supports the proposed rule change permitting local hiring preferences on DOT grant funded projects.  The proposed rule change is in line with the Countys efforts to increase local participation in construction projects, to strengthen communities, spur the local economy, and improve the quality of life for its residents.  The County has its own local hiring programs such as the Local Small Business Preference (SBE) Program, Community Business Enterprise (CBE) Program, Disabled Veteran Business Enterprise (DVBE) Program, and Local Worker Hiring Program which is currently implemented on capital projects.   These programs can now have a greater impact to our communities, especially the disadvantaged communities as these programs expand to include DOT grant funded projects.  Local agencies are very aware of the specific needs of its communities; therefore, the local agency should have the delegated control on the formalization and implementation of the local hiring elements.  We suggest State oversight in local agencies review or approval of the program or selection of projects be limited, as long as the program does not conflict with existing Federal and State regulations.
 
The County is very eager to participate in the pilot program.  We are concerned about term of the pilot program and the length of the SEP-14 approval process on FHWA funded projects.  A pilot program of only 1 year does not allow agencies to take full advantage of the pilot program and advertise enough projects to complete a thorough evaluation of the impacts of the new contracting requirements.  The Countys experience with the SEP-14 process has been lengthy with State and Federal approval and developing protocols for State oversight on new processes.  We recommend that the pilot program be extended beyond its current sunset date of March 2016 and request an expedited approval process by FHWA with clear instructions to all State agencies to expedite implementation and avoid unnecessary and timely oversight protocols.
 
Best regards,

Title: Kelly M. Kupcak
Comment:
U.S. Department of Transportation
Docket Operations

I have been a tradeswomen with I.U.O.E. Local 18 , am currently a member of the National Task Force on Tradeswomen, and an advocate for women and other marginalized workers for over a decade - advocating for fair access to high-wage construction careers. There have been a wide array of communities which have employed local and targeted hire provisions on construction projects, typically through "community benefits agreements".  When complemented with strong partnerships between government, community, Labor, contractors, and training, these can maximize the economic benefit of public investment in local communities. However, the experience of these efforts is mixed with regards to the benefits and implementation process - in particularly for women.  Without keen oversight and partner cooperation, if the Local Hire Policy does not also include policies and practices that ensure that women are hired and retained for the duration of the project, either no or very few women are ever hired, let alone retained for any length of time once hired.  Therefore, all Local Hire Policies must also prioritize the hiring and retention of women, even if the women do not live within the target area.  At the very least, the Executive Order 11246 Regulations governing Federal Construction Contractors Affirmative Action Requirements with goals for women work hours and required actions must be observed and enforced at the same level as local hiring provisions. 

Meaningful access for women into jobs in the transportation industry would narrow the continuing wage gap between men and women, eradicate long-standing patterns of occupational segregation, and help solve the upcoming labor shortages that DOT is predicting. And it would ensure that women are part of the DOTs Ladders of Opportunity and ensure that women are not excluded from construction sites with Local Hire Policies -  including journeywomen, who often do not benefit from these efforts as the focus tends to be on new hires. Putting successful Local Hire Policies together with successful Equal Employment Opportunity practices can solve this problem ensuring both equal opportunity for women and minorities as well as local hires. 

For far too long, the U.S. DOT has not enforced the equal opportunity regulations for federally funded projects.  As such, U.S. DOTs investments have not fulfilled their potential to serve the communities and women and minorities most in need of good transportation jobs.  Lifting the geographical prohibition for federal aid recipients and sub-recipients will not aid women and minorities unless the regulation makes clear that the lifting of this restriction is not instead of EEO regulations but must be done in conjunction with the applicable federal EEO regulations. 

The following policy recommendations are suggested to be implemented along with the implementation of a Local Hiring Policy:
1.	A goal of 15% of all hours worked shall be filled by women. 
2.	Convene compliance/oversight committee of industry stakeholders to ensure that the partnerships are working together to meet the Local Hire Policy workforce goals.
3.	Use On-the-Job-Training/Supportive Services funds to support the workforce goals and retention of those workers - some examples include funding a pre-apprenticeship training, scholarships for new apprentices/hires for work clothes and/or tools, transportation, childcare, and other needs.
4.	Ensure state DOTs notify communities of both Local Hire Policy and OJT/SS funding through a transparent ,  open, and timely process by state DOTs to ensure full collaboration by the community.

To ensure that future gains in workforce inclusion, the U.S. DOT must extend targeted/local hiring provisions to apply to women who stand to benefit significantly from such policies. This can be accomplished by inserting an EEO provision into the federal surface transportation authorization that would allow for both local and targeted hiring.  Please consider supporting such efforts as they are entirely consistent with the departments Ladders of Opportunity Program and represent an important tool for fostering economic and social equity.

Sincerely,
Kelly M. Kupcak
