Title: National Urban League
Comment:
U.S. Department of Transportation
Docket Operations
1200 New Jersey Avenue SE
Washington, DC 20590

Docket DOT-OST-2015-0013
RIN 2105-AE38
 
Comments Submitted by the National Urban League (NUL) concerning the U.S Department of Transportations (DOT) Proposed Rulemaking on Geographic-Based Hiring Preferences in Administering Federal Awards

The NUL is pleased to offer the following comments in strong support of local hire on federally-funded transportation projects in the U.S. DOT's proposed rulemaking on Geographic-Based Hiring Preferences in Administering Federal Awards. [See PDF for full statement]

The NUL is a historic civil rights and urban advocacy organization dedicated to economic empowerment in historically underserved urban communities.  Research shows that we have a long way to go in order to secure economic equality in this country.  According to our just-released 2015 State of Black America report, the National Urban League 2015 Equality IndexTM  of Black  America stands at 72.2 percent, meaning that Blacks experience less than three-fourths the quality of life experienced by white Americans.  Additional key findings from our report dramatize the need, among other policies, to create well-paying jobs that can be accessed in African American communities:

	Black median household income is about 60% of that of whites - $34,815 vs. $57,684 respectively.
	African Americans are more than twice as likely as whites to be living in poverty. The poverty level Equality IndexTM for Black-White is 40%, with 27.6% of Blacks living in poverty vs. 11.1% of whites.
	With the Black-White Unemployment Equality IndexTM at 47%, the Black unemployment rate is more than double the white unemployment rate  with Blacks at 11.3% and whites at 5.3%. 
	With an Equality IndexTM of 6%, Blacks have a median wealth of $6,314 vs. whites who have $110,500  meaning the median African-American household has just 6 cents in wealth for every dollar of white household wealth. 
 
Transportation construction projects provide access to well-paying jobs and, if accessed, can bring economic relief to the unemployed and under-employed. Yet, research  has shown that low-income workers, women, people with disabilities and communities of color are vastly underrepresented in transportation sector jobs when compared with their overall participation in the workforce.  

For far too long, the U.S. Department of Transportation has held on to a prohibition on local hire for federally-funded projects. The Proposed Rule would finally loosen this prohibition and make it clear that geographic hiring preferences may be used in Department of Transportation grant programs. Many communities have employed local and targeted hire provisions on projects large and small with positive results for local residents and the local economy. For example, Gary, IN Mayor Karen Freeman-Wilson cites the positive impact that local hire provisions have had in her city:

During the past three years, contractors entrusted with public projects have been pressed to meet local hiring ordinances. Additionally, businesses that move into Gary or expand their business have worked with the city to hire local residents. These efforts are reflective of the reality that new businesses in Gary have the greatest long-term impact when they create employment opportunities for Gary residents. During the course of the past three years, more than 1000 new jobs have been added to the city. At least 65 percent of these jobs have employed city residents.

As cited by PolicyLink, Los Angeles, CA represents another example of the benefits of local hire where the LAX/Crenshaw Light Rail project will create 7,500 jobs.   According to PolicyLink, equity advocates worked to embed a targeted hire provision for the nearly $2 billion project that will ensure that low-income and underemployed residents will benefit from this investment, because 40 percent of the project's work will be reserved for these workers. Upon announcement of the Department of Transportations proposed rulemaking on local hire, Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti noted that the City has $36 billion committed to public transportation projects in the L.A. region (including the Crenshaw-to-LAX rail line), and said that locals will be defined as construction workers living in L.A. County.  Other major city mayors outlined what this rule change on local hire would mean for low-income residents in their respective cities. 

The NUL fully supports DOT's efforts to allow city and state departments of transportation to set economic and geographic preferences, as an initial step toward workforce inclusion for all Americans. The NUL also strongly recommends that the DOTs proposed local and targeted hire program be made permanent to solidify future gains in workforce inclusion. 

Thank you for consideration of our comments on this most important rule change.

Sincerely,

 
Marc H. Morial 
President and CEO

Title: Interstate Sealant & Concrete, Inc
Comment:
VIA ELECTRONIC SUBMISSION            

April 6, 2015 

Docket Clerk
Docket Management Facility
U.S. Department of Transportation
1200 New Jersey Ave. SE
W12-140
Washington, DC 20590-0001

Re:  RIN 2105-AE38, Comments on Department of Transportations Proposed Rulemaking on Geographic-Based Hiring Preferences in Administering Federal Awards

I am writing in opposition to the U.S. DOT proposal that allows states and local governments to impose geographic hiring requirements on contractors performing federally funded contracts. 

My company builds construction projects that receive federal assistance from the Federal Highway Administration (FHWA) and/or the Federal Transit Administration (FTA). The proposed local hiring preferences may force me to discriminate against some of my existing workforce because I would be required to replace them with new workers I must hire from the jurisdiction with the local hiring preference. My existing workforce is highly trained and skilled, which allows our company to offer to taxpayers the best possibly construction project at the best possible price. If I am forced to hire new and unfamiliar employees, it will impact my ability to deliver an on-time and on-budget project for this contract and other contracts that may not be subject to this order. The culture and safety in our company is created over time and takes an enormous amount of managerial leadership and teamwork to build on.  A mandate to utilize a local workforce will dilute those qualities.

In addition, understating this new mandate and installing appropriate compliance measures, laying off workers and hiring new workers will increase compliance and human resources costs. As a result of these new risks and uncertainties, I may choose not to bid on projects with these requirements. In short, this rule limits competition and is likely to increase project costs for companies and taxpayers.  

Recipients of federal dollars with local hiring requirements should be concerned about the unintended consequences of this rule. It could impact the ability of local residents from working on similar projects in neighboring areas that have instituted their own local hiring rules. Unless there is a steady supply of local construction contracts, the proliferation of local hiring rules could actually lead to less opportunities for the demographic this rule is intended to help.  The mobility of the construction workforce is critical to staffing the manpower needs of the construction industry and any effort to restrict the ability of contractors to meet market demands is problematic.

Respectfully,

Title: Russell Crane
Comment: This proposal should be rejected. Please see uploaded file for complete text

Title: Susan E. Sneed
Comment:
The Honorable Anthony R. Foxx, Secretary
U.S. Department of Transportation 
1200 New Jersey Avenue, SE
Washington, D.C.  20590

RE: Geographic-Based Hiring Preference in Administering Federal Awards (local hire) 
2 CFR Part 1201 [Docket DOT-OST-2015-0013] RIN 2105-AE38

Dear Secretary Foxx, 


I am an organizer with Metropolitan Congregations United (MCU) and an ordained clergywoman in the United Methodist Church. I have been active in job creation and economic develop projects through MCU for over 20 years. We have seen the value of local hiring in our St. Louis communities time and again, most notably in transportation based projects. 

St. Louis is finally coming out of the recession of 2007-08 but unemployment is still 6% overall and 10.3% in the African American community. Local hiring keeps unemployment at a low level for everyone. It insures that people are being paid good wages that enable them to invest in their community through spending on basic living expenses and on discretionary spending unachievable on low-wage jobs. 
 
The East-West Gateway Council of Governments, our MPO, lists in its TIP for 2015-2018 over $726 million in projects for the entire St. Louis Metropolitan Statistical Area (St. Louis City and counties surrounding St. Louis in Missouri and Illinois). Over $503 million is projected to be spent on the Missouri side alone.  This can translate into thousands of jobs over the next three years. 

By MCU working with the Missouri Department of Transportation in creating the Missouri Model on the Interstate 64/40 rebuild, the St. Louis region was able to dedicate $2.5 million to job training out of a $550 million project. 30% of workforce hours were dedicated to apprentices. The goal of local hiring in a transportation job is not just to put people to work once, but to prepare them for future and continued employment. 

Amending the preferences in administering federal awards to specifically impose local hiring rules, has the power to uplift an entire region. We are looking forward to applying those preferences here in St. Louis. 

Sincerely,
Rev. Susan E. Sneed
314-402-0778                  Susan@mcustl.com

Title: Meredith Levy
Comment:
On behalf of the Jobs for Somerville committee of the Somerville Community Corporation in Somerville, MA, we are writing to express our support for this amendment. For the last 5 years, we have led a campaign to ensure that the new jobs created by the expansion of the MBTAs Green Line Subway into our city are available to local low-income, minority, and female residents. The use of geographic hiring preferences is a key tool in achieving that goal, as local residents are most vulnerable to displacement due to gentrification but also most impacted by the possibility of a new transit system. 

We have worked with our city government, state delegation, and the local and state transportation authorities to make this goal a reality through the MassWIN/GLX program, which extends to the cities of Medford, Somerville and Cambridge. Without the explicit approval of the federal government, it is more challenging for us to reach our local hiring goals, because many local players are concerned about potential violations of the constitutions commerce clause. The proposed provision will greatly facilitate our shared goals of making sure the local workforce can be prioritized when making hiring decisions for transit projects of this scale.  The extension of the Green Line in Massachusetts is one of the largest public works projects in the pipeline, with over $1 billion committed to achieve. This scale of work will be an important job generator for our local residents.

Thank you.  Sincerely,

Meridith Levy
Deputy Director
Somerville Community Corporation

Title: Center for Community Change (CCC)
Comment:
U.S. Department of Transportation
Docket Operations
1200 New Jersey Avenue SE
Washington, DC 20590

Docket DOTOST20150013
RIN 2105AE38

Comments Submitted by Center for Community Change concerning the U.S Department of Transportations Proposed Rulemaking on Geographic-Based Hiring Preferences in Administering Federal Awards

The Center for Community Change is pleased to offer the following comments concerning the U.S. Department of Transportations (U.S. DOT) proposed rulemaking on Geographic-Based Hiring Preferences in Administering Federal Awards. 

The Center for Community Change works to build the power and capacity of low-income people, especially low-income people of color, to change their communities and public policies for the better. Our work has included supporting policies that increase transportation equity and access to good transportation jobs for residents in the communities we work with.  We believe policies to support targeted hiring in geographic areas and for people who have had trouble accessing these jobs, such as women and formerly incarcerated people or people with conviction histories, are critical. We support the U.S. DOTs efforts to allow city and state departments of transportation to set economic and geographic preferences, and we view this as a very important step towards creating more jobs that are open and accessible to all.

We want to emphasize our support for the U.S. DOTs proposed rule as well as the recently launched DOT experimental program for 2015. We also urge the DOT to include a direct reference to targeted hiring programs in order to make clear that in addition to geographic hiring preferences, grantees can implement targeted hiring programs aimed at increasing the number of women, people of color, people with disabilities, formerly incarcerated people and people with conviction histories in quality transportation jobs.  Additionally, we want to echo and expand on the comment submitted by the Jobs to Move America Coalition, specifically regarding the creation of a suggested implementation framework that will help ensure transparency, accountability and effective evaluation by grantees. 

Past experience shows that when grantee agencies are allowed to apply innovative contracting language to all of their procurements, the job creation and economic development impact of that investment will grow substantially without significant negative impacts on open competition in the bidding process. Research has shown that low-income workers, women, people with disabilities and communities of color are vastly underrepresented in jobs in the transportation sector, when compared with their overall participation in the workforce . Many communities have successfully employed local and targeted hire provisions on projects large and small, which not only fosters increased economic and social equity but also builds broad support for transportation projects. 

Each year hundreds of thousands of incarcerated people complete their sentences and return to their families in neighborhoods suffering from underemployment and lack of opportunity. Through clearly and specifically making clear that targeted hiring programs can be implemented by grantees, we can help pave the way for more initiatives to help these workers get access to good jobs. 

In order to ensure that employers take targeted hiring seriously, we suggest that the DOT require its grantees to implement basic common language that is inserted into awarded contracts. This language  at a minimum  should spell out reporting requirements on the achievement of targeted or local hire goals, proposed enforcement mechanisms in the case of noncompliance or inaccurate reporting as well as cooperation by the private contractor with the awarding agency in the evaluation of the results of the hiring language. This kind of contract language will give both the grantee and the DOT the ability to assess the success and effectiveness of the grantees language and program. 

Again, the Center for Community Change applauds the DOT for launching this bold initiative and is excited for the ways this rule will support all Americans in gaining access to high quality transportation jobs. 

Sincerely,

Steve Savner
Policy Director
The Center for Community Change

Title: Chicago Women in Trades (CWIT)
Comment:
As a member of the National Task Force on Tradeswomen, Chicago Women in Trades welcomes the opportunity to offer the following comments concerning the U.S Department of Transportations proposed rulemaking on Geographic-Based Hiring Preferences in Administering Federal Awards. These provisions, when paired with strong relationships between government, community, labor, and contractors, and employment and training opportunities, can maximize the economic benefit of public expenditures in local communities.  However, the experience of Task Force members across the country is mixed. Without keen oversight and partner cooperation, if the Local Hire Policy does not also include policies and practices that ensure that women are hired and retained for the duration of the project, either no or very few women are ever hired, let alone retained for any length of time once hired.  

Therefore, all Local Hire Policies must also prioritize the hiring and retention of women, even if the women do not live within the target area.  At the very least, the Executive Order 11246 Regulations governing Federal Construction Contractors Affirmative Action Requirements with goals for women work hours and required actions must be observed and enforced at the same level as local hiring provisions. For far too long, the U.S. DOT has not enforced the equal opportunity regulations for federally funded projects.  As such, U.S. DOTs investments have not fulfilled their potential to serve the communities and women and minorities most in need of good transportation jobs.  Lifting the geographical prohibition for federal aid recipients and sub-recipients will not aid women and minorities unless the regulation makes clear that the lifting of this restriction is not instead of EEO regulations but must be done in conjunction with the applicable federal EEO regulations. 

Women have faced years of entrenched discrimination and barriers in attempting to access work on federally funded construction projects, a struggle that has kept their numbers far too low. The U.S. DOTs own workforce reports provide ample evidence of the lack of attention to ensuring equal opportunity for women on DOTs construction sites.  The Federal Aid Highway Construction Contractors Annual EEO Workforce Reports FHWA 1391 and 1392,  confirm the consistent underuse of women far below the EO 11246 6.9% goal and even further below the 17% benchmark set for women in similar occupations.Our own experience working in the Chicago area with construction industry stakeholders and tradeswomen is that local hire policies have negative outcomes for women - simply put - women are not hired. City and neighborhood residency requirements are promoted and enforced while gender goals are just that, goals. When contractors do make efforts to meet goals for women on a project, they insist that women also meet residency requirements despite a local ordinance requiring goals for tradeswomen.  

CWIT suggests the following:  
1.A goal of 15% of all hours worked shall be filled by women;2.To satisfy that goal, women must be employed a minimum of 100% of the average staff hours for the category of work for which they were hired throughout the duration of time that the category of work is performed for the covered project.  For example, if cement finishers employed on a particular DOT project an average of 40 hours each week throughout the duration of time that cement finishing is performed, then women cement finishers should work the same amount of time to count towards meeting the 15% goal for women;3.Priority should be given to women who reside within the area and there should be no prohibition of meeting the goal with women who do not live in the targeted area;4.Implement a compliance/oversight committee of industry stakeholders should be convened to ensure that the partnerships are working together to meet the Local Hire Policy workforce and disadvantaged business goals; 5. Use of On-the-Job-Training/Supportive Services funds should be utilized to support the workforce goals and retention of those workers - some examples include funding a pre-apprenticeship training, scholarships for new apprentices/hires for work clothes and/or tools, transportation, childcare, and other identified local needs; 6.Local Hire Policy implementation and complimentary OJT/SS funding should be communicated to communities through a transparent, open, and timely process by state DOTs to ensure full collaboration by the community.

To solidify future gains in workforce inclusion the U.S. DOT must extend targeted hiring provisions to apply to women who stand to benefit significantly from such policies. .  We urge the U.S. DOT to support such efforts as an important tool for fostering economic and social equity.

Sincerely,
Jayne Vellinga
Executive Director
Chicago Women in Trades

Title: Amanda Smock
Comment: I am in favor of geographic hiring because more people of color, women, and low-income people are trained and secure jobs in municipalities where geographic hiring has been implemented, such as St Louis, MO.

Title: Thomas McCrossan
Comment:
We are opposed to the U.S. DOT proposal that allows states and local governments to impose geographic hiring requirements on contractors performing federally funded contracts. Our company primarily builds transportation projects that receive federal assistance from the Federal Highway Administration (FHWA) and the Federal Transit Administration (FTA). 

Local hiring preferences will force us to make staffing decisions that may not be in the best interest of our employees or the individuals the preference is intended to help. For example, while the local preference may benefit local labor, the preference requirement will indirectly disadvantage nonresidents by restricting their ability to work in nearby cities or counties. It can also discourage the local labor force from pursuing positions in the construction industry as a career. 

A typical construction crew consists of many specialty craft workers. They may be operators, cement masons, laborers, carpenters and truck drivers. Our approach is to train individuals to be a part of a crew and perform tasks related to that crew's work type specialty. We have found that this method allows an employee to learn a trade and become very proficient in their field of vocation. This works especially well if an employee is inexperienced. As a member of a crew, they have experienced individuals nearby that can give advice and answer questions. But our crews move in and out of projects throughout the season. We may have a crew on a project for a day or a month or the entire season. 

If we are required to maintain a workforce that is based on an individual's address rather than their skill set, it will take away a vital component of training and information exchange. This can result in poor workmanship and create safety issues. It may even dampen an individual's desire to make construction their career by not allowing them enough time to become proficient in a valued skill. This is also true of journeymen workers. 

Over the years most craft workers have worked on perfecting a particular skill set. They might have operated a front end loader for most of their career. When a loader is needed on a project, the operator generally goes with the machine. Once the work for the loader is complete, the machine and operator will move to the next project. By keeping the employee in a specific job task, it provides consistency and continuity to the employee, and allows for continued improvement for the employee in their position. 

We understand the motivation to require contractors to hire unemployed individuals on federally-funded projects; however there are more practical approaches to address this issue. For one, providing the needed training that will provide individuals the skills needed to have a successful career in the construction industry. In addition, it would be beneficial to have long term, stable and sustainable funding for transportation and transit. It is crucial to provide certainty to individuals who may chose to make construction their career.

Based on the issues we have described above, we respectfully request that you do not allow local hiring preferences to be used on FHWA and FTA funded projects.


Sincerely,


Letter sent through the AGC Legislative Action Center

Title: Alissa Schneider
Comment:
Sent via email to: Secretary

I am opposed to the U.S. DOT proposal that allows states and local governments to impose geographic hiring requirements on contractors performing federally funded contracts. My company builds transportation projects that receive federal assistance from the Federal Highway Administration (FHWA) and/or the Federal Transit Administration (FTA). Local hiring preferences force me to discriminate against some of my workers by laying them off because I have to hire new workers from the jurisdiction with the preference. My workers are well trained and highly skilled. These skills allow our company to offer the taxpayers a high quality construction project that is built safely at the lowest possible cost. Because of the need to lay off some of my workers, I may choose not to bid on projects with these requirements. This limits competition and can increase project costs.

I understand the motivation to force contractors to hire unemployed individuals on federally-funded projects; however, as a Union contractor, we actively participate in numerous training and recruiting efforts already and do not require the government intervention on this issue.

Also, our work as an advanced certified steel erector requires highly trained employees to reduce risk in a dangerous work environment. 

I urge you to not allow local hiring preferences to be used on FHWA and FTA funded projects.

Sincerely,

Alissa Schneider
President
 

Letter sent through the AGC Legislative Action Center

Title: Richard Barcaskey
Comment:
I am writing to you today on behalf of the members of the Constructors Association of Western Pennsylvania (CAWP), a trade association representing over 200 heavy and highway construction and construction-related companies operating in the thirty-three counties of western Pennsylvania. The Association is opposed to the U.S. Department of Transportation's proposal that would allow states and local governments to impose geographic hiring requirements on contractors performing federally funded contracts. 

CAWP contractors build transportation projects that receive federal assistance from the Federal Highway Administration (FHWA) and/or the Federal Transit Administration (FTA). Local hiring preferences would force contractors to discriminate against certain workers by laying them off in order to hire new workers from the jurisdiction with the preference. Construction employees working for CAWP contractors are well trained and highly skilled. These skills allow western Pennsylvania contractors to offer the taxpayers a high quality construction project that is built safely at the lowest possible cost. However, local hiring preferences have been shown to limit competition and increase project costs.

Through their membership in CAWP, contractors contribute to several joint labor and management training programs that provide individuals the skills needed to have a successful career in the construction industry. These training programs provide a better way for unemployed individuals to work on federally-funded projects, without mandating local hiring preferences.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: We are extremely supportive of the change to allow geographic-hiring preferences.  We do think though that prior to fully implementing the program, as assessment should be done of the pilot program which would help flesh out any needed tweaks.  Further, there seems to be a number of unanswered questions.  These unanswered questions are always going to exist for those just ademantely opposed to the program; but, a good result of the pilot program would go a long way to alleviating unnecessary fear.  Further, we would like to see some discussion of the use of Project Labor Agreements which is the way that most agencies are imposing local hire requirements especially in the construction arena.

Title: Sam Gramling
Comment:
Geographic-Based Hiring Preferences would be extremely disadvantageous for the improvement of our deteriorating infrastructure. Our company has extremely loyal employees that not only bring their vast knowledge and experience to every project throughout the country but their checkbooks to feed the local service industries (i.e. hotels, restaurants, bars, etc...). The already short-supplied skilled workforce of operators, truck drivers, mechanics etc... would become extremely magnified if the pool was reduced to a certain geographical areas. 

Allowing companies to bring experienced and knowledgeable employees to projects is the best (and sometimes the only) way to introduce new advancement in products and techniques. In our industry we have taken a concrete mix design from a project in Minnesota that withstands Semi-Truck traffic in 2 hours from the time it is poured and introduced it on a project in Louisiana (as well as other places). This would not and will not be attempted if a company has to train new employees as well as the governing body to these types of advancements. 

In an effort to reduce the overall impact to the traveling public most transportation projects are coming with accelerated completion dates and/or shortened work windows avoiding rush hour or heavy traffic situations. Contractors can't be expected to risk substantial penalties/liquidated damages on projects with an unknown and un-proven workforce.

Title: Cheryl A. Sment
Comment:
VIA ELECTRONIC SUBMISSION           
April 6, 2015
Docket Clerk
Docket Management Facility
U.S. Department of Transportation
1200 New Jersey Ave. SE
W12-140
Washington, DC 20590-0001
 
Re:  RIN 2105-AE38, Comments on Department of Transportations Proposed Rulemaking on Geographic-Based Hiring Preferences in Administering Federal Awards
I am writing in opposition to the U.S. DOT proposal that allows states and local governments to impose geographic hiring requirements on contractors performing federally funded contracts.
My company builds construction projects that receive federal assistance from the Federal Highway Administration (FHWA) and/or the Federal Transit Administration (FTA). The proposed local hiring preferences may force me to discriminate against some of my existing workforce because I would be required to replace them with new workers I must hire from the jurisdiction with the local hiring preference. My existing workforce is highly trained and skilled, which allows our company to offer to taxpayers the best possibly construction project at the best possible price. If I am forced to hire new and unfamiliar employees, it will impact my ability to deliver an on-time and on-budget project for this contract and other contracts that may not be subject to this order. The culture and safety in our company is created over time and takes an enormous amount of managerial leadership and teamwork to build on.  A mandate to utilize a local workforce will dilute those qualities. 
In addition, understating this new mandate and installing appropriate compliance measures, laying off workers and hiring new workers will increase compliance and human resources costs. As a result of these new risks and uncertainties, I may choose not to bid on projects with these requirements. In short, this rule limits competition and is likely to increase project costs for companies and taxpayers. 
Recipients of federal dollars with local hiring requirements should be concerned about the unintended consequences of this rule. It could impact the ability of local residents from working on similar projects in neighboring areas that have instituted their own local hiring rules. Unless there is a steady supply of local construction contracts, the proliferation of local hiring rules could actually lead to less opportunities for the demographic this rule is intended to help.  The mobility of the construction workforce is critical to staffing the manpower needs of the construction industry and any effort to restrict the ability of contractors to meet market demands is problematic.
Respectfully,
 
Cheryl A. Sment,
President & CEO
Interstate Sealant & Concrete, Inc.

Title: The Leadership Conference on Civil and Human Rights
Comment: On behalf of The Leadership Conference on Civil and Human Rights, a coalition charged by its diverse membership of more than 200 national organizations to promote and protect the rights of all persons in the United States, we are pleased to submit the following comments in connection with the Department of Transportations (DOTs) proposed rulemaking on geographic-based hiring preferences in administering federal awards. The DOTs current prohibition on local hiring is an impediment to transportation equity, and we believe that the proposed new local hire program is a step in the right direction.

Title: Siemens Rolling Stock USA
Comment:
Department of Transportation

Docket DOT-OST-2015-0013
RIN 2105-AE38
Geographic-Based Hiring Preferences in Administering Federal Awards
 
Comment of Siemens Rolling Stock USA
 
Thank you for this opportunity to comment on the above-captioned proposed rule.  The most recent notice stated:
 
"The DOT has also received a comment to the docket asking whether this proposed rule applies to rolling stock.  The DOT specifically requests comment on this issue and whether the DOT should clarify the proposed rules application to the procurement of rolling stock."  80 Fed. Reg. 18784 (April 8, 2015)
 
We respectfully submit that DOT should clarify that this rule does not apply to the procurement of rolling stock.  The main reason is that applying the rule to rolling-stock procurements would unduly limit competition, which DOT acknowledges it does not have discretion to do.  See 80 Fed. Reg. 12092, 12093 (March 6, 2015).
 
Globally, there are at most a dozen passenger rolling-stock vendors with the economic and legal ability to manufacture within the U.S. in the foreseeable future.  In the case of most of them, the company has already established the U.S. factory in which it manufactures rolling stock for customers here. 
 
Establishing a rolling-stock manufacturing facility requires large investments in real estate, structures, equipment, and a trained workforce.  The volume of orders for passenger rolling stock in the U.S. is too low for any vendor to be able to afford to maintain multiple rolling-stock manufacturing plants in this country. 
 
Moreover, it is not economically or socially possible for a company to shutter its rolling-stock manufacturing plant in one part of the U.S. and establish a new one elsewhere in the country for each new order.  As an illustration, Siemens rolling-stock manufacturing plant in Sacramento, California employs nearly 800 people and covers approximately 300,000 square feet. 
 
If an entity procuring passenger rolling stock with the help of federal funding (and very few passenger rolling-stock procurements happen without the help of federal funding) were to require local manufacture, the only vendors that potentially would bid on the project would be those that coincidentally already have a rolling-stock manufacturing plant in that locality, plus those that have not yet established a plant anywhere in the U.S.  That group is substantially smaller than the population of vendors currently in a position to compete for a rolling-stock order in the U.S. today. 
 
Moreover, if this DOT rule were to apply to rolling stock, then any vendor to win an order and consequently establish a manufacturing plant in the customers locality would become part of the population of vendors that would not bid on subsequent procurements in different parts of the U.S.  In short, the inclusion of rolling stock in this DOT rule would immediately shrink the population of rolling-stock vendors able to compete in new procurements in the U.S., and that population would continue to shrink with every additional procurement.  Such a consequence sits comfortably within any definition of unduly limit competition.  Artificially constrained competition leads to unnecessarily high project costs.  It also generates pressure on the excluded vendors to give up on the U.S. market  an outcome that would be to the long-term detriment of metropolitan mass transit and inter-city passenger rail in the U.S.
 
There is at least one other reason this rule should not apply to rolling-stock procurements.  History has shown that a well-established rolling-stock manufacturing plant tends to avoid cost overruns, delays, and quality problems better than a plant that has only just been established and is trying to fill its first order.  DOT should avoid creating a dynamic that leads systemically to more cost overruns, delays, and quality problems.
 
For the foregoing reasons, Siemens Rolling Stock USA respectfully asks DOT to clarify in any final version of this rule that it does not apply to the procurement of rolling stock.

Title: The American Concrete Pavement Association (ACPA)
Comment:
The American Concrete Pavement Association (ACPA) submits the attached comments in response to the United States Department of Transportations (U.S. DOTs) notice of proposed rulemaking (NPRM) concerning geographic-based hiring preferences in administering Federal-aid contracts for highway and transit projects.

In summary, ACPA opposes the U.S. DOTs pilot program and other regulatory initiatives aimed at geographic-based hiring preferences in administering federal awards. We feel that the proposed actions are discriminatory, will limit competition, will compromise the integrity of the bidding process, will increase costs to the public, and are based on an erroneous and inadequate regulatory analysis.

The pilot program and the NPRM are focused on objectives that are not consistent with the overarching goal of procurement rules for Federal-aid contracts. As stated in a 1986 opinion, the U.S. DOT Office of Legal Counsel reaffirms that the efficient use of federal funds is the touchstone by which the legality of state procurement rules for federally funded highway projects is to be tested. U.S. DOT has failed to show how the proposed action addresses the efficient use of federal funds.

Instead, we urge the U.S. DOT to focus on voluntary efforts that maximize the economic growth and job-creating opportunities presented by transportation construction. These are not only the best practices in terms of public policy, but also have long served the best interests of taxpayers and all entities responsible for constructing, rehabilitating, and preserving our nations surface transportation infrastructure.

Respectfully,

Leif G. Wathne P.E.

Title: G.A. & F.C. Wagman
Comment: See attached.

Title: Jeffrey R. Clyde
Comment: The Geographic Based Hiring Preference will only add additional administrative work and cost to projects.  The local hiring preferences that our firm has been involved in as generated frustration among owners, employers and employees.  In a highly skilled, craft level and professional level, industry an regulation to require firms to hire local employees seems to limit an employer to his ability to determine the skill level of local preferences.  As an employer, we try to maintain a skilled workforce and keep them employed throughout the duration of the construction season.  With a regulatory mandate, we will not want to lose our employees and will add additional cost to a project to hire and meet the local preference regulation.  The last local preference contract we were involved with we actually found out after the bidding process and we ended up paying a fee to the tribe, who could not provide any local help.  As a contractor, we need to be able to determine the skill level of our workforce in order to accurately calculate production rates and schedules to complete the work.  A local hiring preference will remove that ability from the firm, and in order to protect our interest a firm will put a contingency into the bid to ensure that they have their cost covered.    There appears to be no advantage to this regulation.  In an industry that is facing a lack of skilled work force anyone that is qualified should be able to find a position in this industry anywhere.  If you want to increase the lack of unskilled labor and add additional cost to projects this regulation will meet those goals.  As a firm and tax payer I oppose this regulation.

Title: Metropolitan Transportation Authority
Comment: Los Angeles Metro believes that geographical hiring preferences can and should apply not only to construction projects, but also to its Rolling Stock Projects. This belief is founded on our determination, based on past experience, that geographical hiring preferences applied to Metro's Rolling Stock projects can be implemented in a reasonable and measured manner that is consistent with federal objectives for free and open competition. As a result, Metro has proposed a Local Employment Program (LEP) that meets the federal grant rule standards for encouraging open competition with no barriers to entry. Metro's LEP is patterned after its successful U.S. Employment Program (USEP). Metro's USEP has been proven to create no advantages or disadvantages to any interested proposers, and all TVMs have an equal ability compete without drastic alteration to its means and methods of production. To support this assertion Metro describes two case studies that prove that Metro's USEP, and by extension Metro's proposed LEP, fosters competition and creates local jobs without disruption to existing jobs and manufacturing efficiencies. (See Case Studies Attached)

Title: Joseph Gibson
Comment: New Flyer of America Inc. opposes geographic-based hiring preferences for FTA funded transit bus procurements.  For many years, transit bus purchases have been for replacement vehicles with little or no purchases to expand bus fleets.  This lack of growth has led transit bus manufacturers to focus on a well-trained workforce at their facilities.  To require a transit bus manufacturer to hire local workers for a bus manufacturing contract will result in shifting employment from one location to another.  It will increase the cost of transit buses as transit bus manufacturers will need to acquire facilities locally and train new employees.  The learning curve may lead to a decrease in quality.  As a bus contract is completed in a relatively short period of time, one to two years for a several hundred bus contract, those employees that were hired locally will be laid off at the conclusion of the contract.  New Flyer has a recent experience with the above.  In 2013, New Flyer was awarded a contract by the LA Metro for 550 firm plus 350 option buses.  A determining factor in the contract award was a commitment to hire local workers.  After contract award New Flyer established a 103,646 square foot facility in the Los Angeles area and hired and trained a total of 53 employees to perform final assembly.  This action led to reduction of an equivalent number of employees at New Flyers St. Cloud, MN facility.  The result was a zero gain in total employment.

Title: E.E. Cruz & Company, Inc.
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Charles Lovorn
Comment:
RE:  Docket No. DOT-OST-2015-0013; Geographic Based Hiring Preferences in Administering Federal Awards

Dear Sir/Madame:

On behalf of the Board of Directors of the Kentucky Association of Highway Contractors (KAHC), this letter is to advise of this
associations opposition to the U. S. Department of Transportations proposed withdrawal of the ban on utilizing local hiring 
preferences on federal-aid highway and transit projects.  KAHC represent more than 250 highway construction contractors who
are pre-qualified for work on federal-aid projects in Kentucky.  Additionally, KAHC represents approximately 230 associate
members who supply materials and services  to those contractors.  The membership of KAHC performs the majority of the 
federal-aid projects administered by the Kentucky Transportation Cabinet.  This work is typically bid through a competitively
bid process. 
 
We believe the change in the proposed policy to provide jobs for residents of specific cities will inhibit the normal ability of 
contractors to provide the particular skills and workforce required to meet the performance standard of projects.  There are
many specialties required in highway construction work that can only be met by having a skilled, mobile work force.  Residency
preferences will limit job opportunities for careers in construction because of the restrictions of mobility.  The workforce must be 
able to be mobile and move to where the work is required without the restriction of residency requirements.  Employers need 
the skilled employees to perform the necessary construction operations of the project efficiently in order to be produce a 
quality project at a competitive price. 

Local hiring preferences will negatively impact competitive bidding.  Local hiring preference may also undermine the needed
safety requirements that are necessary for a safe worker environment.  Mandates from local hiring preferences will make labor
an undefinable factor due to the demand that  the labor come from a largely unknown pool of workers whose skills and
proficiencies are unknown by the contractor.  The use of financial penalties has an adverse impact on competitive bidding. 
No local entity can guarantee the availability of specific skilled employees at a specific time when multiple projects are 
occurring in a locality. As a result, this risk cannot be determined adequately and subsequently included in a bid.  

This proposal for a government entity to exclude qualified individuals from a specific job based on their place of residence is
wrong.  To have to exclude individuals who have the appropriate construction skills for a job simply because of where they 
do not live is simply not right. The detrimental impact to the safety and efficiency of a contractors proven record of operations 
at a competitive price by forcing exclusive mandates on residency is not justified.  We respectfully request that this initiative to 
allow the use of local hiring preferences not be advanced.

Respectfully submitted,

Charles R. Lovorn
Executive Director

Title: Associated Builders and Contractors, Inc.
Comment: Associated Builders and Contractors, Inc. submits the following comments in response to the notice of proposed rulemaking published in the Federal Register on March 6, 2015, which proposes to amend 2 CFR Part 1201 to allow geographic-based hiring preferences in administering federal awards.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
This violates substantial precedent and at best has no effect on growing jobs for local and targeted communities in the nation as a whole, and will likely have severe impacts on U.S. Manufacturers of rail and bus vehicles. 
For example, there currently are eight large passenger rail rolling stock manufactures and now only four heavy-duty bus manufacturers with permanent facilities in the US; often in rural and economically distressed areas that depend on these jobs
-          Zero-Sum Game  Create Jobs in One Area, Lose them in Another
-          These companies have each invested tens of millions of dollars in their facilities and provided years of worker training to develop the highly skilled manufacturing workforce that is required to build the highly advanced rolling stock technology
-          Most of these companies have made binding commitments to both State and Local governments to achieve employment goals in order to access industrial development funding and tax incentives
-          Local hiring preferences would cause a substantial loss of jobs at the current manufacturing facilities across America by forcing the carbuilders to shutter their plants and move jobs to a new facility for each new procurement.  This is a zero sum game with no net gain in employment.
Impact on Transit Projects
-          Today, transit agencies benefit by not being fully burdened with 100% of the capital investment manufacturers put into their facilities and amortize on multiple projects
-          This proposal will substantially increase the cost of rolling stock procurements, according to some of the manufacturing experts of the industry, since each agency would have to pay 100% of the capital investment on their project
-          The effects of the program would likely reduce the total number of projects that can be implemented because the funds are being used inefficiently, could thus actually lower jobs overall
Please stop trying to "help the industry" and instead focus on growing the program overall, through additional funding and financing options that will actually create additional demand and grow orders and thus jobs.

This administration, given what it had to contend with in its early days, should by now understand that our 30-year experiment with "supply side solutions" to any of our economic troubles has simply not worked. This proposal if adopted would be only one more unworkable and possibly counterproductive addition to the list of such failures.

Title: The Partnership for Working Families
Comment: The Partnership for Working Families is pleased to submit the following comments in support of the U.S. Department of Transportations proposed rulemaking on Geographic-Based Hiring Preferences in Administering Federal Awards.  Please see the attached document.

Title: LIUNA Mid-Atlantic Regional Organizing Coalition
Comment:
PLEASE SEE THE ATTACHED LETTER.

SUMMARY:

The LIUNA Mid-Atlantic Regional Organizing Coalition (hereinafter, MAROC) respectfully submits this comment in support of the proposed rulemaking to permit geographic- based hiring preferences with respect to projects that receive grants from the Department and the Federal Highway Administration. 

MAROC submits the following points for the Departments consideration in support of the proposed initiative:

1.	Local-hiring preferences are necessary within urban areas to promote the employment of local residents in areas like the District of Columbia, where city residents have been traditionally excluded from the construction industry.

2.	Use of local hiring preferences by the District of Columbia has not limited competition in the procurement by DC of building construction.

3.	Local hiring can be carried out in non-discriminatory ways.

4.	Local hiring requirements will not reduce competition because contractors can meet these requirements by signing project labor agreements with local labor organizations.

MAROC agrees with the Departments preliminary assessment that, in ordinary circumstances, geographically-based preferences do not limit competition or raise costs for the government. Rather, they simply allow local governments to leverage federal and state funds into local jobs and economic growth. MAROC and the unions affiliated with the Laborers International Union of North America (LIUNA) have long experience with promoting local-resident hiring by offering training and job placement to urban populations that often are excluded from employment in the construction industry. We have seen firsthand that these initiatives do not limit competition because construction contractors from anywhere around the globe easily can make arrangements with organizations like LIUNA to facilitate hiring from local communities. Consequently, these preferences have the entirely salutary effect of concentrating the economic benefits of construction projects within the communities where the projects are located, without reducing competition.

Title: David Harrington
Comment:
I support the Departments proposed rule and urge that a direct reference to targeted hiring
programs be included in the Final Rule and that separate guidance in the Rule be made for
construction and rolling stock contracts.  Construction work be done in a specific location
 where the infrastructure is being built redeveloped. Thus, the ability for local and targeted hire preferences should be permitted with
minimal change to the Rule. However, in rolling stock procurement, it may be financially
untenable to require that the manufacture of the vehicles be conducted in a specific geographic
location. Thus, we urge the Department to establish guidance for a set of factors that must be
attained for states or local governments to use local or geographic preferences for
procurement of rolling stock, such as the size and value of a procurement and local transit
market demand.
The proposed local and targeted hire program makes great strides towards providing more
Americans a Ladder of Opportunity and would improve grantees ability to foster economic
growth and see the full benefit from their investment. Transportation for America strongly
supports the pilot and the proposed changes in the Rule, and ask that that Department include
the changes recommended above that would make the proposal even stronger.  Making these rules stronger will connect the local economy to these rail projects.

Title: Cemex USA
Comment:
May 6, 2015

United States Department of Transportation
Docket Management Facility
1200 New Jersey Avenue S.E.
W12-140
Washington, D.C. 20590-0001

Re:	Docket ID Number DOT-OST-2015-0013, Geographic-Based Hiring Preferences in Administering Federal Awards

Dear Secretary Foxx:

CEMEX USA appreciates the opportunity to provide comments on the United States Department of Transportations (U.S. DOTs) notice of proposed rulemaking (NPRM) concerning geographic-based hiring preferences in administering Federal-aid contracts for highway and transit projects.  CEMEX is a global building materials company that provides high quality products and reliable service to customers and communities in more than 50 countries throughout the world.  Our U.S. network operates in 27 states, where employ approximately 10,000 people in 13 cement plants, 46 active distribution terminals, 79 aggregate quarries and 366 ready-mix concrete plants.

While CEMEX agrees with the U.S. DOT claim that Transportation investments and policies can improve access to jobs, education, and goods movement, while providing construction and operations jobs, we are in strong opposition to the assertion that local and other geographic-based hiring preferences are essential to realizing such economic benefits at level. 

Though we could provide lengthy documentation for the reasons we are opposed to the Rule, we have read the comments from the American Road and Transportation Builder Association (ARTBA), the Highway Materials Group (HMG), the American Concrete Pavement Association (ACPA), and the Associated General Contractors of America (AGC) and believe that their comments in opposition accurately reflect our concerns.  We are in full support of their comments opposing the U.S. DOTs pilot program and other regulatory initiatives aimed at geographic-based hiring preferences.  

In closing, CEMEX appreciates the opportunity to comment on U.S. DOTs proposed rule, but we believe that U.S. DOT should focus on voluntary efforts that maximize the economic growth and job-creating opportunities presented by transportation construction. These are not only the best practices in terms of public policy, but also have long served the best interests of taxpayers and all entities responsible for constructing, rehabilitating, and preserving our nations surface transportation infrastructure.

Sincerely


James W. Mack, P.E.
Director Market Development
CEMEX
929 Gessner Road, Suite 1900, Houston, Texas 77024
jamesw.mack@cemex.com 
www.cemexusa.com

Title: Lois Campbell
Comment:
April 2, 2015

The Honorable Anthony R. Foxx, Secretary
U.S. Department of Transportation
1200 New Jersey Avenue, SE
Washington, D.C. 20590

RE: Geographic-Based Hiring Preference in Administering Federal Awards  (Local Hire) 2 CFR Part 1201 [Docket DOTOST20150013] RIN 2105AE38
 
Dear Secretary Foxx:
 
My name is Lois Campbell and I am the Executive Director of The Pennsylvania Interfaith Impact Network (PIIN),  a coalition of over 50 congregations and other faith based organizations committed to work for justice in Pittsburgh and Southwestern Pennsylvania. PIIN is a member of the Gamaliel National network of faith-based organizations.  PIIN supports local hire on federally-funded transportation projects.

The unemployment rate in Pittsburgh is 5.4% but the unemployment rate in the African American community is more than twice that rate.  In some Pittsburgh neighborhoods and surrounding boroughs, the actual jobless rate is as much as 30%.  The lack of access to family sustaining jobs cripples these communities and impacts all aspects of community health.

The current Minority and Women's Hiring Goals (Executive Order 11246) for the Pittsburgh MSA is 6.3% for minorities and 6.9% for women.  They have not changed since 1980 and if regularly updated using the same formula the minority number would rise to 17%.  The women's number is a national number, but our colleagues at Wider Opportunities for Women and several of the tradeswomen's groups are calling for 10% for journey level and 25% for apprenticeship level.

 The largest percent of federal funds coming into our communities, regions, and states comes from the U.S. Department of Transportation.  For every billion dollars of public infrastructure spending, approximately 13,000 jobs are created.  Approximately $373 million of federal money will be used in the Pittsburgh area on transportation projects in FY 2015.  Under current federal regulations, the contracts on these projects cannot include local hire provisions.  If, however, local hire provisions could be applied to the $373 million of federal transportation money coming into the Pittsburgh area, nearly 5000 jobs would be createdmany of them could potentially be held by local residents.  
Between February 2013 and February 2014, Southwestern Pennsylvania lost 5,200 jobs, the biggest loss in percentage terms among the top 40 regions in the country.  Having local hire for a percentage of the career path transportation construction jobs created could make a significant difference in our community. 

 Gamaliel affiliates in Kansas City and St. Louis, for example, secured local hire ordinances on projects that did not receive federal funds. The results have been significant: more people of color and women were actually trained and secured jobs on those cities construction projects. Also, because the ordinances included a reporting requirement, contractors and the city became accountable to the community. 

As the U.S. Department of Transportation considers allowing local hiring preference on federally-funded projects, it should also consider including percentages of those jobs that should be set aside for women and minorities which would lead to real economic security for our community.


Sincerely, 

Lois Campbell
