Title: Meir Libersohn
Comment:
I request that the US Government refuse this application due to the egregious attitude of this company on fellow customers.

As the US DOT have in file, the level of complaints against the United Airlines have raised up notoriously, and their refusal to make good, including for damaged luggage and goods, delayed luggage and the necessity of purchase of goods till arrival of such.  When actively the consumer complaints either customer care refuse to make good, or the customer is threatened with a potential lawsuit for insisting the airline to make good, they get corporate security involved, who the say that they will involve law enforcement, they ban the customer from flying United Airlines ever again and the frequent flier account is shut down and miles confiscated as well, at times they may allege that miles were bartered or sold.

Furthermore, the usage of older aircraft as such can create a major environment havoc in such area, and in now way this damage can be repaired.

I respectfully request that the application should be denied.

Title: Juliean Galak
Comment:
I am taking this opportunity to express my support for the proposal to implement eLORAN.  I am a private pilot, operating a small single engine aircraft for personal and business purposes.   

I currently use VOR and GPS navigation systems, with GPS being the more used of the two.  Unfortunately, GPS is a single point of failure system.  A software problem, satellite problem, whether accidental or the result of deliberate attack, can significantly disrupt navigational capability.  No other system currently available has the accuracy and flexibility of GPS.  Modern moving-map navigation systems universally rely on GPS, and if GPS capacity is degraded navigation will have to be done with VOR and paper maps, a system that is less accurate and far more attention-demanding.  

I believe that if eLORAN is implemented, manufacturers will release new navigational systems that utilize GPS and eLORAN signals to provide navigational capability.  Such systems would allow for better accuracy by cross-referencing the two, as well as much greater redundancy if one is disrupted.

Therefore, I strongly urge you to implement an eLORAN system that has equivalent accuracy to GPS-WAAS and at least North American continental coverage.  Better yet would be world-wide coverage.

Title: Joe Preston
Comment: I think it is vitally important for us to have an alternative navigation system to GPS. While GPS works fabulously, it is vulnerable to jamming and attack by extremists and unfriendly governments. I was very disappointed when E-Loran was terminated a few years ago. This system would become a major asset to our country if implemented.

Title: Ben Ellison
Comment:
(a) A brief description of your application(s) of positioning, navigation, and timing services

I'm a recreational boater who cruises the coast of Maine, and often transits to the Carolinas in the fall and back in the spring.

(b) the positioning, navigation, and/or timing performance required for a complementary PNT capability to support operations during a disruption of GPS that could last for longer than a day, 

My personal safety and peace of mind when boating are quite dependent on accurate GPS positioning and I would greatly appreciate a complimentary system that provided similar accuracy.
My ability to communicate by cell phone and also use cellular for Internet connectivity are also important to my welfare on the boat, and I understand that a complimentary PNT system could help ensure cellular viability during a GPS outage.

(c) availability and coverage area required for a complementary PNT capability, 

My needs would be satisfied by coverage similar to the old LORAN C system.

(d) willingness to equip with an eLoran receiver to reduce or prevent operational and/or economic consequences from a GPS disruption, 

That will depend on cost but I believe that manufacturers will compete to produce reasonable cost eLoran receivers, including integrated GPS/eLoran receivers, if a large market like the U.S. indicates a strong commitment to building the infrastructure.

(e) current and planned availability of e-Loran capable user equipment, 

To the best of my knowledge -- and my work is researching and writing about marine electronics -- current eLoran receivers are expensive and primarily designed to provide accurate timing and for other industrial purposes. But please see question (d).

(f) other non-eLoran PNT technologies or operational procedures, currently available or planned, that could be used during a disruption of GPS for longer than a day.

I'm old enough to have navigated extensively coastwise and offshore without any electronic assistance, and I keep paper charts and the tools to use them on board, but my skills are getting quite rusty.

Title: Robert Gardner
Comment:
There is no question in my mind that the shutdown of the Loran-C system and concomitant development of eLoran was a mistake based on politics. Everyone who deals in navigation knew that we were throwing away the only viable backup to the Global Positioning System.

The world is a more dangerous place today and the need for backup has never been greater. GPS signals from the satellite constellation are so weak that the can easily be spoofed or jammed...it is only a matter of time.

I was the original Commanding Officer at two Loran-C stations, St. Paul Island, Alaska, and Gesashi, Okinawa. Loran duty is not easy; most stations are unaccompanied by family. It is a sacrifice worth making to avoid losing the most precise mode of navigation yet invented.

Title: William Ben Welch
Comment: I wish to add my name to the list requesting restoration of the eLoran navigation as a backup to GPS as a pilot operating aircraft.

Title: Eugene Brusin
Comment:
The idea of having two different navigation and timing systems for the United States is a step toward protecting the "critical Infrastructure" of transportation, commerce and security of America.
By having two systems that utilize a different frequency to transmit data, increases the "no fail mode" of the signals to the users.
If anyone wants to jam the GPS signal, although illegal, it will be hard to trace the jamming device if it operates on a random basis and different geographical locations.  To trace or track the device will be time consuming and man power intensive, should there be multiple jamming efforts, the C/A code will be rendered suspect to the users.  Spoofing is another worry, that has been proven in demonstrations by various universities and organizations to lead a ship's electronics to plot a wrong course, same could happen to avionics.
By the addition of the eLoran signal, system integrity is strengthened, both navigation and timing signals will harder to jam or spoof.  Since most of the Loran infrastructure is still intact in the USA, the capital investment will be lower, thus saving money and time of installation to bring the system online.  The certification process will be able to use the UK eLoran data and the FAA NPA certification to bring the system online in a short time, rather than design a brand new system with all the money and studies needed to complete the task.
The idea of eLoran is a technological answer to a critical infrastructure problem that is facing the United States today.

Title: Thomas Nolan
Comment:
It would seem the the U.S. should "get-onboard" with eLoran before the dismantling of our Loran-C stations has progressed to the point where the cost of implementing eLoran becomes too high.

After all, historically ALL of the studies which were done pointed to the fact that eLoran is the ONLY viable terrestrial electronic backup to GNSS.

Other countries in the world have figured that out long ago and with the increase of GNSS jamming & spoofing, the U.S. should also be on board.

Among other areas, eLoran has been successfully tested & using in the English Channel.

Title: Gus Schage
Comment: I would realy like to see this system come on line. we are taxed on so many other things you could have to regester your machine and a pay a yearly fee for use.of course free would be better. the advent of solar flares that affect GPS as well as the state of affairs around the world, it would very nice to have a back up. the cost of fishing today is up three time of that when i started fishing offshore on my own in the 70s.PLEASE.

Title: George Stone
Comment: We certainly need a back-up system to the GPS.  Ground-based systems to complement satellite systems seems like good sense.

Title: Michael Nutt
Comment:
The shutting down of the LORAN system, when many aircraft and nearly all vessels had LORAN equipment installed, was a mistake.  As a pilot and sailor, I know the value of precise navigation.  LORAN had reached nearly the precision of GPS, with equipment that functioned about the same as GPS (the controls on most GPS units were based on LORAN, making the transition to GPS easy) and it offered an alternative to GPS.  This was a ground-based system that seemed less affected by solar activity, periodic downgrades of performance by the military and other factors.  Despite this, the system was shut down.

Here we are, several years later, with the VOR system (a ground-based aviation navigation system for aircraft only) being phased out, leaving "all of our eggs in one basket" with GPS.  For aviation, or those on the lakes and seas, it will be GPS or nothing.  Solar activity, accidental or intentional shutdown of the GPS system, or even jamming of the system (the hardware and software is widely available and has already been used to jam GPS in small areas) all can cause havoc for navigation, since this is all we have for marine use, and will soon be all we have for aviation use.  We need redundancy, as well as a "check and balance" for GPS.  The combined GPS/eLORAN system would provide not only redundancy, but also potential improved accuracy.

I urge you to consider this proposal for an updated form of LORAN for navigation.

Title: F. Kerwin
Comment: GOOD IDEA: F

Title: Charles Linenfelser
Comment:
I am an ATP rated pilot and have been flying since 1968. It is my opinion that E-Loran would be an invaluable assest for the aviation community in the event of GPS interruption or worse. E-Loran would essentially be a direct replacement with regard to direct navigation capability for all aircraft. Not to have a backup navigation source that is more robust than present day GPS, in my opinon would be dangerous and irresponsible. Presently we american aviators are in a postion of having all our "Begs in one Asket" which should be considered unexceptable. Any responsible person should have a plan "B" action in the event plan "A" is compromised. I have flown using both Loran and GPS in concert, and found both navigation sources to be very dependable and accurate. I was disappointed when the Loran system was decommissioned. Lets bring back E-Loran and establish a Belt & suspender approach to our national airspace.

Sincerely,

Charles Linenfelser

Title: Steve Singler
Comment: There was no reason to discontinue LORAN in the first place, please put it back on line, both for redundancy and improved navigation, and because it's the right thing to do for the public. After all, we, the public, pay for it, and deserve what we pay for.  There is no reason, not national security, or cost, why this shouldn't be brought back.  The amount this costs to operate annually is about a minute of Defense Dept. daily costs!

Title: James Farrell
Comment:
With this communication I wish to affirm the crucial importance of eLoran to maintaining safety and security of the United States.  While the exceptional performance of GPS is obvious, there is less awareness of its vulnerability.  Evidence of that is crystal clear from the decision in 2010 to decommission Loran-C, and thereby eliminate the infrastructure needed for eLoran.  All that despite the universally acclaimed report dated Sept 10 2001 from Volpe National Transportation Systems Center, highlighting GPS vulnerability.  Now after all these years a reliable backup, widely and repeatedly advocated, is still not firmly established.  A day of reckoning, denying vital capability for both navigation and timing, could occur at any time.  Cost incurred would completely overwhelm the $190 million "savings" over five years estimated by the Office of Management and Budget.

That $190 million figure is likewise dwarfed by funds that would be required to undo the damage inflicted by destroying existing provisions for Loran.  That destruction would expose our failure to act on what we've always known: Reliance on any one single information source vital for safety and security is reckless.  That is especially true for a resource with the dazzling success of GPS in today's danger-prone environment.  Thank God the eLoran decision is being reconsidered.

Title: Marl Halbrook
Comment:
I'm a recreational user of our navigation and timing systems.  I use GPS for flying and for outdoor recreational activities.  For my purposes, having a back-up to GPS would provide an increase in safety, not just convenience.  For most of my use, an accuracy of +- a second or 100-150 feet would be completely adequate (more accurate would be nice, but not necessary).
I would be willing to purchase new equipment to be able to access eLORAN.  I do still have my LORAN equipment that was previously in service and would appreciate being able to utilize it to help recoup some of the costs involved in it's original purchase, but I do fully understand that newer technology would be available if eLORAN was brought into service.
As an end user of navigational capability, I fully support the possibility of activation of eLORAN as a back up to GPS on a National level.

Title: Jim Dall
Comment: Given the vulnerability of the current GPS system; I believe that reconstituting the eLoran program is a wise and cost effective method of assuring the integrity on the US industrial infrastructure through the provision of precise timing and navigation for all forms of transportation.

Title: Richard Bulova
Comment: I am a retiree  and have no commercial interest in this regulation.  My comments are as an American citizen and retired soldier.  GPS is indeed a wonderful technology, and has become the "go to" means for many purposes, which also includes national defense.  Given that, America's enemies, both current and future, are sure to explore and possibly develop ways to disrupt this vital capability.  eLoran mighty well prove to be the essential back-up to protect our nation's security.  As a correlary, no one, at the birth of today's internet protocols, envisioned the problems now facing us with hacking.  The cost is minuscule compared to the impact of not having a back up system at all.

Title: Regional Air Cargo Carriers Association
Submitter Representative: John W. Hazlet, Jr. Vice President
Comment: Please see the attached PDF.

Title: Tommy Harmon
Comment: I believe eLoran may be the most important back up system for GPS navigation available for sea and air operations. I currently use GPS for my boating trips and believe we need a back up system to the GPS. Loran worked very well in my previous boat and airplane.  The only other navigation equipment on my boat is a compass.   Please proceed with a new eLoran system.

Title: David Cooper
Comment:
During my Coast Guard career, I used LORAN A while standing Officer of the Deck watches on the USCGC ACTIVE on the often foggy waters off of New England. The three step manual process was quite an art because of electronic interference, especially at night, or when operating near base line extensions. However, one good time delay line plus a bearing from the high powered automatic direction finder (ADF) tower on Nantucket Island was much better than dead reckoning alone.

  Five years later, when flying over the same waters, our aircraft were equipped with LORAN C mini-navigators which provided Latitude/Longitude readout and navigational computing, That was a giant leap forward, and I used LORAN C for a quarter century, until the arrival of GPS.

  When the first attempt to shut down LORAN C was made, I argued against it for the reason that the Chinese proved by destroying one of their obsolete satellites: someone might destroy enough GPS satellites to render the system useless. Since LORAN C is now gone, it would be prudent to set up some land based long range navigation system as a backup to GPS. My recommendation would be eLORAN for long range navigation, and we should also retain  some VOR/ILS airways and approaches to permit recovery of aircraft in event of GPS failure.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I support developing eLoran as a supplemental navigation method.

Title: Simon Cotts
Comment:
As an electronics student studying eLORAN as a final year project, this is terrific news!

Should the US choose to use eLORAN as complementary PNT system to GNSS, it would mean a large investment into the future of robust PNT technologies, and an encouragement to developing PNT solutions.

With the US onboard, the coverage of eLORAN will cover more of the world, and aid more industries and individuals.

Title: Rae Willis
Comment: I believe a big mistake was made when in February 2010, the LORAN-C system was shut down. This should not have been a Coast Guard issue (why would they care about a land-based system?), but should have been a Military-FAA-HSA issue. It seems to me that keeping LORAN-C and upgrading to eLORAN would have been a more economical approach to back up GPS (which is vulnerable) vs. the outdated and expensive VOR system. Unfortunately private GA owners have lost a lot of money abandoning aircraft LORAN receivers. It is unlikely that private GA aircraft owners will come back to LORAN unless modernization of avionics includes affordable combination/automatic receivers.  That said, I believe a land-based backup for the GPS system is a necessity for national security.

Title: Nickolaus Leggett
Comment:
The attached document contains my comments on the establishment of an enhanced Long Range Navigation (eLORAN) system as a backup and complement to the Global Positioning System (GPS).  The impact of major GPS failures is discussed.

Nickolaus E. Leggett
Pilot, Analyst, Inventor, and Radio Technician

Title: Gerald Bourgeois
Comment:
The Department of Transportation seeks input on: (a) A brief description of your application(s) of positioning, navigation, and timing services; (b) the positioning, navigation, and/or timing performance required for a complementary PNT capability tosupport operations during a disruption of GPS that could last for longer than a day, (c) availability and coverage area required for a complementary PNT capability, (d) willingness to equip with an eLoran receiver to reduce or prevent operational and/or economic consequences from a GPS disruption, (e) current and planned availability of e-Loran capable user equipment, (f) other non-eLoran PNT technologies or operational procedures, currently available or planned, that could be used during a disruption of GPS for longer than a day.

I fly helicopters in support of the offshore, Gulf of Mexico, oil and gas industry. I also fly in the National Guard. 

I think 1/8 to 1/4 mile accuracy would be very good for my use.

The coverage area would be Gulf of Mexico and adjacent land areas. 

I do not have authority to add equipment to our aircraft, but I think the aviation radio manufacturers would gladly and the eLORAN capability to their GPS receivers for commercial sale, thus offering greater functionality. 

During GPS outages, having eLORAN capability would greatly improve navigation and operations as a whole in the offshore oil and gas industry. Of course the boats in the Gulf of Mexico would also benefit.

Title: Capt John
Comment: Having a land based backup (e-loran) to our space-based GPS system is a great idea whose time is long overdue. With the world in constant conflict these days, it's not too difficult for a third world instigator to throw our daily lives back into the stone age by disrupting the civilian band GPS that more e-gadgets rely on to provide order to our everyday lives. It's also nice to have loran-C (or some version of it) back into play, so that old sea captains can find their secret wrecks and fishing holes that were lost in cyberspace when GPS was unceremoniously switch off a half dozen years ago. Finally, a government program that all boaters (and landlubbers) should find appealing!

Title: Daniel Farren
Comment:
Prudent seamanship dictates that every mariner, especially navigators use every safety device and tool possible. Currently, the world wide GPS system is the only electronic system available to most mariners.

Having an e-Loran system would provide another tool which provides a check system of one against the other and a fail-safe if one system goes down.

Traditional methods of marine navigation, Dead Reckoning, Piloting, and Celestial navigation are indeed tried and true and always useful. However, without a means of checking ones fixes against those of electronic equipment, there will be an element of doubt about the accuracy of those fixes.

It would be a very wise investment in the safety of marine (and aviation) navigation to build the eLoran system.

Title: Benjamin Reed
Comment:
I would like to see the LORAN E continue in service as a reliable backup to the GPS system currently in place.
The Loran E system was very accurate in returning to a specific site programed into the receiver.
The system was also not easily altered by electronic interference.

Title: Merit McCrea
Comment:
I support eLORAN. It would provide critical navigation capability, and a key backup right here in the US and an alternative to GPS, if national security were ever to reqire GPS signal be made unreliable and imprecise again globally.

Turn LORANC back on!

Title: Jon Hill
Comment:
The decision to discontinue Loran C in 2010 and not develop an eLoran system was potentially disastrous to national security and remains so today.

While GPS has proven to be an excellent navigation and timing system its fragility and susceptibility to disruption is well proven and certainly should be of concern.  The ability to alter or interrupt GPS with relatively inexpensive equipment isn't just a potential terrorist threat when one considers the recent LightSquared fiasco.

An accurate navigation system is absolutely essential to commercial marine users while
trucking and agriculture to name only two, have become dependent on accurate GPS navigation for positioning and asset tracking. A loss of the GPS system, even temporarily would be devastating to millions of essential users.

The need for a backup navigation system should be obvious but pales in comparison to the need for accurate timing signals used in commerce, communications, transportation and many other vitally necessary services.

eLoran is a cost effective answer to the need for navigation and timing backup to GPS and should be implemented as soon as possible.

Title: Robert Lilley
Comment:
The eLoran alternative is certainly the best choice for the necessary alternative to satellite-based positioning, navigation and timing (PNT). Across most or all of the categories of critical infrastructure protection, eLoran offers a robust, dissimilar backup/alternative system that not only can continue many services during a GPS outage, but can expand options as a partner to GPS in "normal" times. eLoran is essential to a total PNT system-of-systems architecture!

As to equipage: I, like so many others, am fully invested in those communications and positioning services that make modern life modern -- to which we entrust our personal and business communications, our utilities, finances, and our safety. I am already equipped! 

I have spent a significant portion of a career supporting  the improvement of Loran-C and the development of eLoran, particularly in the aviation sector. This engineer sees the system as the natural and most efficient alternative for multi-modal PNT. It promotes continued cost-effective application of today's PNT systems in aviation, while insuring the resilience of Next-Generation advances throughout the economy.

Let's do this!

Thank you for the opportunity to comment.
     

--------------------------------
Robert W. Lilley, Ph. D. 
Santa Barbara, CA

Title: David Bentley
Comment:
Dear Transportation Department,

As an avid boater who relies upon instrument navigation for safety purposes, I strongly urge you to re consider activating eloran signals.

Title: Robert Lilley
Comment:
I'd like to draw attention to a previous Federal Register notice regarding the future of Loran-C and the potential for 
deploying eLoran. The docket was USCG-2007-24685.

Some 900+ comments were received, with a very high percentage expressing the need or desire to continue 
the system and develop eLoran.

The link for that 2007 announcement is:
https://www.federalregister.gov/articles/2007/01/08/E6-22421/long-range-aids-to-navigation-loran-program-office-of-navigation-and-spectrum-management 

And the link to the 982 comments is:
http://www.regulations.gov/#!docketBrowser;rpp=25;po=0;dct=PS%252BO;D=USCG-2006-24685

Thank you for your consideration of these data in the context of the 2015 notice.

Title: Rex Buddenberg
Comment:
Complementary Navigation, Position and Timing Capabilities.


Global Positioning System is an excellent positioning system but it has limitations.  These include inadequate integrity (the system can provide data that is in error but is advertised as good) and inadequate availability (easily jammed, inadequate reach to non-line-of-sight locations, etc).  

Further, GPS has become a critical input to a burgeoning array of uses ranging from cellphones to ambulance and fire engine dispatching, vehicle safety, electric power system control, agricultural equipment control, etc, etc.  Thus the impacts of GPS failure are steadily increasing.  I therefore agree with the inferred intent of this inquiry  an complementary alternative is increasingly necessary.

eLoran is an imperfectly defined term.  In general it is a good idea.  It should include the following components:
     - the Loran navigational signal as an alternative positioning independent of GPS.
     - differential GPS signals that provide integrity checks for GPS itself as well as GPS pseudorange corrections for increased precision.  This capability is currently provided in port areas by the US Coast Guard's dGPS system and certainly should be part of the eLoran data stream.
     -  differential Loran is a secondary inclusion.  I believe that the value is less than that of dGPS but it better positions Loran to be a complement to GPS and the marginal cost of inclusion is small.
     - this list might be extended but the data communications capacity of the Loran signal is limited so there is a finite list of features that can be supported.

Coverage should at least be over the entire territory of the United States as well as the harbor/harbor approach zones and territorial seas.  Unlike Loran in its origin, eLoran as a GPS complement should be considered much more than just a maritime navigation system  it should be capable of supporting all mobile platforms.  


-----------------------

Currently retired.  In second career I taught information systems design at the postgraduate level.  In my first career before that, active duty Coast Guard including Loran Branch CGHQ, Electronic Systems Planner CGHQ, Commander of Loran C station and deck officer on two cutters.

Title: Robert Lilley
Comment:
The eLoran alternative is certainly the best choice for the necessary alternative to satellite-based positioning, navigation 
and timing (PNT). Across most or all of the categories of critical infrastructure protection, eLoran offers a robust,
dissimilar backup/alternative system that not only can continue many services during a GPS outage, but can 
expand options as a partner to GPS in "normal" times. eLoran is essential to a total PNT system-of-systems architecture!

As to equipage: I, like so many others, am fully invested in those communications and positioning services and devices
that make modern life modern -- to which we entrust our personal and business communications,

I have spent a significant portion of a career supporting  the improvement of Loran-C and the development

while supports the resilience of Next-Generation services throughout the airspace, and for non-aviation users as well.

Title: Robert Spitzer
Comment:
In response to the request for public comments entitled Complementary Positioning, Navigation, and Timing Capability, docket number [DOT-OST-2015-0053]:

The current GPS system will soon become the sole means of navigation for aviation after the phasing out of NDB (already obsolete) and VOR systems (relatively obsolete and high maintenance costs).

In aviation this means a critical aspect of flight safety will be dependent on a single system with no redundancy in case of failure. Failure could include natural noise- generating phenomenon, intentional jamming, or technical unexpected satellite failures. Having a single such system without backup for critical functions like aviation presents the possibilities of serious danger. A systemic failure could affect many aircraft simultaneously, unexpectedly and without a means of recovery in adverse weather.

eLoran represents a highly feasible, simple and cost-eefective means of providing a safety backup to the GPS system. A relatively small number of strategically placed transmitters can provide wide coverage on a completely different frequency band, with land based systems to complement the satellite based GPS system. The cost of installation is relatively nominal, especially when compared to existing VOR systems.

Technically speaking, all aircraft currently equipped with GPS systems are already virtually equipped for eLoran. What would be needed is a firmware upgrade (and probably/possibly some minor hardware modification in some cases) to allow an external position input for X and Y coordinates from the external, add-on eLoran receiver, and altitude from the altimeter. Then, the entire existing GPS computer, databases, user interface, etc. can be used as-is without modification. In case of GPS failure, the existing GPS unit could be programmed to switch to the eLoran input, indicate a safety message on the screen, recognize new/different limits or margins, and continue to function using the different input signal. This would provide a high degree of redundancy and safety.

I currently use GPS for aviation navigation. In preparation for upcoming changes, I have equipped the aircraft with 2 GPS units and ADS-B. I have eliminated NDB and have nearly eliminated the use of VOR (to be phased out). I have alos removed two older Loran units. Based on future available technologies, within 5 to 10 years there will be NO backup navigation available during significant IFR conditions.

If commercially available, I would equip my aircraft with one or two (redundant) eLoran external receivers to feed the GPS units with position information, in a manner described above. This would provide complete redundancy at reasonable cost, not impact flying procedures or training, nor change the panel configuration.

The external eLoran should be capable of continuous background operation, with a display available to show its status on the GPS system (minimum available, unavailable). The accuracy should allow at least accuracy for non-precision approaches at a minimum

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I agree that a ground-based backup to GPS is a good idea.  However, in 2010, the Commandant of the Coast Guard, the Secretary of Homeland Security, and the President signed off that Loran-C was no longer needed for navigation.

If implemented the Coast Guard should not be burdened with the operation, development, or funding of the new eLoran system.  This belongs in another agency such as DHS S&T, NPPD, or NIST.

Additionally, the Loran-C system was shut down because it became an orphan.  Funding was limited and it was not upgraded soon enough to make manufacturers want to produce receivers.  GPS evolved quickly and manufacturers soon made that their choice for timing and navigation.  Loran-C never caught up and died on the vine.

What is the incentive for me to buy a GPS/eLoran combination receiver if I am a recreational boater?  After seeing what happened to Loran-C, how long will eLoran be around?

Title: Dan Riley
Comment:
As an aviation end user of the "old" Loran system, I never quite understood the big hurry to shutdown Loran before GPS problems were solved. I, as other pilots in my community, have found the system solid for our navigation needs. 

Yes, I have had the downtime and expense of GPS upgrades but would welcome eloran back into our system. As other navigation options shutdown and soon become obsolete it would seem an imperative to restart and improve with eloran.

Title: Atlantic Offshore Lobstermens' Association
Comment: Please see attached document.

Title: Keith Peshak
Comment:
I built an eLoran CatIIIc ILS, instrument landing system, zero zero weather conditions, any runway anywhere on US territory (including the grass strip in your back yard), utilizing Loran-C for horizontal guidance, pressure altimetry for vertical guidance, eLoran for data transfer supporting a wide area augmentation system for additional secondary factor corrections based on position to Loran-C (similar to but different from WAAS used for GPS guidance).  This is written up in the Wild Goose (International Loran Society) library on line.  The demonstrated accuracy was: "according to this box the runway threshold should be right about BLAM here" (about ten feet).  Demonstrably, this beats the best that GPS could ever do.

GPS is now "down" regularly, unable to maintain three 9s; insufficient for air navigation and most particularly completely insufficient for terminal navigation and approach.

http://sapttest.faa.gov/raim-summaries.php?outageType=129001450

This is why most civil aviation aircraft now use Glonass for navigation.

http://glonass-iac.ru/getImageFromDB.php?type=BRDC-IAC_GLO-SIS-Inst

When the Secretary of Transportation and Secretary of Defense both agreed that Loran was not necessary because we have GPS, they shut down the only PNT system that is unjammable, unspoofable, more available, and more accurate then all alternatives; thereby leaving us depending on the superior technology of the Soviet Union for reliable PNT today (idiots).

http://www.nstb.tc.faa.gov/Full_RAIM_RNP1.htm

Title: Anonymous
Comment: eLORAN is the most practical and effective option if GPS service is denied or degraded.

Title: Emadeldin Mubarak
Comment:
Hi DOT responsible,

GPS (Global Positioning System) adds too many values to everyone daily activities, it expands from serving some very specific applications and fields in the past to reach normal people daily activities, but what if GPS suddenly been stopped?, i think with the current givings of watching how the GPS affects the human activities round the clock, a sudden miss-communication will happen not only to the normal people activities, but will reach the infrastructure of the now a days life, as a telecommunication expert i knows that GPS timing used to synchronize too many telecommunications infrastructure, as  an Ex-maritime telecom. and electronics expert it also used to synchronize too many systems like Radars and AIS within the maritime navigation, think of how will be the size of the GPS cut/stop disaster will be?.

The above was a focus on the increasing negative impact of the GPS stop/jammed any time, this very very high severity should be handled correctly, the proposal above of having a complementary Positioning, Navigation and Timing system became a necessity to compensate the rapid increasing severity of the GPS Jammed/Cutting/Stop/errors risk, for my far knowledge the risk is treated according to its impact versus probability, in our risk case here the risk severity/impact is almost reaching the top and still increasing, on the probability side, we witness many cases of jamming/errors of the GPS, for my best knowledge and experience i witness myself a case when the AIS system positioned two ships in Damman port berths having a wrong position over the berth land, imagine if this happened again when a ship reaches the port channel and having a wrong GPS data!! this of course happens in sea and we have no records of it, not only in commercial applications but also military, what if the fires navigated over wrong GPS info., this for sure is a disaster and unforgivable errors and mistakes.

Based on the above, I fully agree with a Complementary Positioning, Navigation and Timing system.

As a proposal, in the past decades we have witness the Loran-C wonderful service, for my best knowledge as Ex-expert in Saudi Arabia - SEA Ports Authority (SEAPA), i witness myself the importance of that system till now a days, and how it best served the US forces and allies during the first Iraqi War in the early 90's and still survived as a backup in the second one, the responsible at SEAPA and also the Royal Saudi Naval Forces (RSNF) was fully pleased of such level of service. Now E-loran became more accurate than the Loran-C and its accuracy almost reaches the GPS accuracy, and expected to compete it. In Saudi Arabia, the Loran-C system still broadcast and i know they will going to upgrade.

For the United States, I believe having the E-loran as complementary system to GPS over the whole territory is something inevitable for the sake of honesty and transparency, and a backup that is necessary to people daily activities which suffers the hidden errors of GPS to public and a possible disaster of GPS Stop/Jammed, Saudi Arabia Still believes in Loran-C and planning to migrating to E-loran, other countries migrated already, some others are following the steps, for the sake of the US citizens, the United States should follow the migration steps especially when the cost margin with E-loran calculations are almost nothing comparing the Loran-C previous operations cost.

Based on the above, i highly recommend the Eloran as a complementary positioning, navigation and timing system to GPS.

Best Regards
Emadeldin

Title: Phil Railsback
Comment:
As a systems, software, and electrical engineer working in air transportation systems, and as a commercial pilot, I have been very concerned about the lack of RNAV backup for the fragile GPS system.  I have personally experienced cases where I have been dependent on GPS for navigation and FAA-Certified and well-maintained GPS equipment has failed to produce a solution in cases where RAIM prediction indicated it should fine, and I've had to fall back on ATC vectors.  Such occurrences constitute a significant safety hazard.

We used to rely on LORAN as a fallback RNAV system.  There are very few common failure modes between GPS and LORAN or eLORAN, which makes eLORAN an ideal secondary system.

I strongly support the development of eLORAN and consider it essential.

Title: Thomas Imrich
Comment:
Reference the "Complementary PNT" [DOT-OST-2015-0053] request for comment, any consideration of "eLoran" is a complementary source of PNT is an obsolete, unnecessary, complete waste of effort and money. 

Vastly better and less expensive methods are available to assure PNT. 

Accordingly, "eLoran" (or any other Loran) should now be permanently removed from any further consideration for practical use, and relegated to the list of obsolete, poorly functioning, and unnecessarily expensive concepts, along side MLS, PAR/GCA, REGAL, GEE, DECCA, TACAN, and scores of other ancient NAV ideas, that were once considered potentially useful, but were unworkable at affordable cost, or pushed the limits of the laws of physics and electromagnetism.

Instead, all future NAV and PNT should be based on good clocks, related to multi-constellation GNSS, filtered as needed with inertial, while using augmentation means as necessary, with a variety of other better methods, used to attain the needed degrees of robustness (e.g., accuracy, integrity, and availability). Examples include multi-constellation GNSS networked with GBAS [e.g., in multi-lateration pseudolite configurations], and use of backup residual radio aids (e.g., DMEs) in multi-sensor NAV systems (like RNP capable FMS) for at least the next several decades (until GBAS is globally deployed to replace ILS, and backup robust multi-lateration is available from those GBAS facilities).

Title: Allan C. Stover
Comment: I support eLoran.

Title: John Hartline
Comment: The technology for a robust eLoran system is available and user equipment has been designed and tested.  Once the government makes a commitment to eLoran or other LF based supplement to provide a complimentary system to GPS, industry will start to mass produce integrated receivers.  There is no good reason not to be proactive in building the infrastructure to protect the integrity of positioning, timing and navigation. This is not our father's Loran. The precise timing and positioning available with eLoran will nicely compliment what is available with GPS and provide additional integrity and  backup for critical systems. Please move forward in protecting our infrastructure.

Title: Lingwei Zhan
Comment:
Wide-area Measurement System is crucial to smart grid, and Phasor Measurement Units (PMU) provide real-time power grid measurement results to Industry such as Utilities, ISO. However, currently GPS is the only timing source for PMUs, and they cannot measure the power grid accurately once  GPS is lost or unstable. It is very important to study GPS independent timing source for PMUs. 

Collaborating with UrsaNav, we applied eLoran successfully in wide-area power grid monitoring area. Experimental results demonstrated that eLoran can provide accurate and stable timing for PMUs. eLoran shows a great potential to act as a GPS alternative timing source in the area of smart grid monitoring to enhance the reliability of power grid monitoring system.

Title: John Beukers
Comment:
Comment for eLoran

The author of this comment has been involved in the discipline of Radio Aids to Navigation for the whole of his professional career. Engineering HF, VHF & UHF Radio Direction Finding systems in the 1950s led to design improvements of the Instrument Landing System and the design of the Wide Aperture Doppler VHF Omnidirectional Range.  His interest in using the experimental single station Loran-C system in the early 1960s prompted the development of radio signal retransmission systems for positioning of remote objects.  As Loran-C stations were installed across the United States and other countries; it became the radionavigation system of choice.  In addition the stability of groundwave radio propagation and the signal format of the Loran-C system enabled the transmission and dissemination of precise time nationwide to meet the most stringent requirements of the developing communication technology. Later precise time became the backbone of the US airways navigation. 

The GPS project that was initiated in 1973 became operational in 1995 providing a positioning and navigation resource of higher accuracy and wider coverage than Loran-C and also provided the transmission of precise time.  For this reason, in May 2009, President Obama declared Loran-C obsolete and announced plans to terminate the Coast Guard provided service.  While this decision may have appeared logical it did not address the essential need for continuity of service in the event of GPS denial.

Since its inception, the vulnerability of GPS to natural and man-made interference, both unintentional and intentional has been known but generally ignored.  Without the Loran-C stations in the event of an interruption of GPS service continuity of precise time would no longer be guaranteed leading to the potential breakdown of the United States vital infrastructure. Further reliance upon a single source for navigation violates the basic requirement for a backup in the event of denial of the primary system.

Loran-C with its restructured format eLoran is the only available nationwide candidate for a back-up to GPS.  It is difficult to jam and while not immune to interference and denial, eLoran has the advantage in the dissimilarity to GPS of frequency of operation, modes of propagation and signal format.  Together the probability of simultaneous denial of both systems is highly unlikely.

The recommendation of this author is to move ahead with the implementation of eLoran without delay to strengthen the security of the United States infrastructure.   The cost of this insurance is dwarfed by the consequences of GPS signal unavailability.

John Beukers
Formerly Beukers Laboratories Inc.
Past President of the International Loran Association

Title: Thomas Lusch
Comment:
I am a 1200-hour private pilot that hasn't flown for the past decade-and-a-half.  I utilized LORAN-C for VFR navigation back before GPS was available.  I was very impressed with its capability back then, as I could even determine my position while on the ground.  These days, as a retired federal air traffic controller, I simply utilize GPS for land-based navigation in my car. 

With technology, there are unforeseen problems...even by the brightest minds.  Mode S secondary radar comes to mind.  The smart folks at MIT didn't expect the "Terra P4 problem."  It made legacy transponders invisible to the their new interrogation format.  It wasn't supposed to, but it happened.  I experienced that personally.  Engineers are still dealing with that issue to this day.  

With complex technology there are invariably latent errors that exist, yet rarely surface, except, incredibly, at the most inopportune time.  Radar data processing comes to mind, wherein, at times, the only radar data that is available is *not* processed to the air traffic controller's display.  An example of that was AAL77, the 9/11 Pentagon aircraft.  It wasn't lost on radar as probably most everyone still thinks...it simply wasn't displayed on the controller's display at Indianapolis ARTCC (see TomLusch.com if you're interested).  

Also, with fragile complex technology, there are inevitably those who will learn how to take advantage of disrupting this technology, just because they can.  And then there are those who will do it with the most evil of intentions.  Imagine a terrorist launching a weather balloon with a transmitter designed to jam the weak GPS signals.  Imagine everything being dependent upon those weak GPS signals, and no backup.  It makes no sense whatsoever for us to be this vulnerable.  We have too much at stake.  We need to guard against those who disrupt society.  We need to make it so they are powerless to do so.  

As a minimum, the coverage area required for a complementary PNT capability would be over the United States of America.  Each country can build their own backup system.  Utilizing islands for sites to erect antennas to support ocean travel should be investigated.  Possibly we could cover most of the world?  

When I was an active general aviation pilot, I always strived to equip myself with technology that could be put to use in an immediate nature, such that it would turn a very bad situation into simply an inconvenience.  That backup handheld radio made all the difference in the world to me on a cross-country flight wherein I encountered a complete charging system failure.  I would like to see a future disruption of the GPS system be merely an inconvenience.  

As a retired individual, I have no current or planned use of eLoran equipment.  Yet, if eLoran becomes adopted, and my smartphone would be capable of including a eLoran receiver within it, I'd likely upgrade.  Ultimately, I desire a redundant, terrestrial-based system available for all relying on satellite based navigation.  

If we keep all of our eggs in the orbital basket, expect chaos with a major GPS disruption.  Our ubiquitous GPS system permeates every aspect of our culture now, and it would be an incredible hardship for society to lose this capability...even for a day.  To simply be able to fallback, utilizing a terrestrial navigation system, while dealing with a satellite disruption, would be optimum for society.  

Those who have made past short-sighted decisions to not have a suitable backup capability available will not be looked upon fondly by historians should our GPS system be disrupted in a major way.  

I'm delighted to see this issue discussed.  For the good of our country, implement a backup system that is not totally space based.  eLoran is the obvious choice, as it is wide-area, difficult to jam, proven, and completely non-dependent upon satellites.  

Thank you for the opportunity to comment.

Title: Douglas Espy
Comment:
The running of a nation with just one mode of electronic time based navigation is simply dangerous, Its like driving off road in a vast wasteland without a spare tire. In addition, GPS "localized" navigation has failed already on occasion by both natural and un-natural means, to further without going into technical details; GPS widespread outages can and eventually will occur in the future. Resources to replace "compromised" low orbiting birds are getting thinner by the day. Actually this is a doable and inexpensive solution since some of the old infrastructures do still exist (but not up and running).
Many of us that understand time based navigation actually fear the possibilities of GPS failure and what that would do to both civil and military infrastructures across many nations in comparison to our own. May I rest my case without concern beyond this note?

Title: Dennis Frederick
Comment:
Eloran and its ground waves are a perfect companion to GPS and its sky waves.

British have a receiver that can shift from GPS to Eloran seamlessly if issues are detected with GPS signals.

GPS is too easily compromised to remain as a stand alone only source navigation system.

Title: Durk van Willigen
Comment:
GNSS is an unbelievable aid to the development of many countries. However, relying exclusively on GNSS is like sailing an ocean steamer without lifeboats.

GLONASS, Galileo and Beidou are no backups to GPS as all GNSS systems are nearly identical sensitive to jamming.

Today, eLoran is the most effective and low-cost system capable to backup GNSS albeit with less accuracy and 2D only.

Title: Patrick Warr
Comment:
The vulnerabilities of Satellite PNT is clearly understood by the US Military. 

Civilian integration of GPS PNT has reach a point that loss of PNT will has a devastating effect on the economy of North America, individual safety and security and the infrastructure that every person now depends on constantly. 

Implementation of eLoran has been shown to provide an independent, secure and relatively low cost second source and back to the existing GPS system and other satellite based PNT systems.

I believe it is essential to re-build eLoran in North America to ensure every citizens safety and security.

Title: Ross Norsworthy
Comment: As a Subject Matter Expert in maritime navigation and communications, now serving as Chairman of the RTCM Special Committee 131, developing a technical standard for the IMO performance standard for a Multi-System GNSS Receiver that requires a terrestrial back-up PNT system, I can confidently testify that eLoran is essential to the safe navigation of ships in ports, coastal and inland waterways. The safe passage of these ships is essential to our national economy, security and environment.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am fully in support of an eLoran system for use in the Continental United States. Currently, we are vulnerable to system failures in our satellite GPS systems, which could easily be supported by the eLoran system.

Title: James Avilas
Comment:
I am excited and encouraged by this joint DHS and DOT initiative for inquiry on eLoran as a potential viable and cost effective position, navigation and timing alternate service.  The eLoran along with the GPS infrastructure will provide a seamless PNT service to the United States citizens and our societys modern way of life.

As a service provider of Radio Frequency Interference resolution it is a challenge to provide high quality service to customers when their relied upon GPS services are disrupted and they have no other means to sustain operations until the problem is resolved. Although we strive to tackle any radio interference disruptions to the maximum extent and eliminate disruptions immediately the variables and circumstances of such disruptions are exponentially wide and in some cases final resolution to eliminate signal disruptions can take unacceptable length of time.

With the possibility of a second signal independent PNT service that can sustain and provide users a seamless non-disruptive environment it will create the opportunities to better investigate the initial disruptions to primary PNT services and offer greater potentially resolution responses. If the results of this initiative show solid support for the eLoran implementation it would have positive effects in many other services as well.  Looking forward to an exciting time ahead.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: The eLoran system is vital to the safety of navigation at sea. The seafaring community has become too reliant on GPS and GPS supplied equipment and if there were to be an intentional or unintentional failure of GPS, not only the US, but the world would be dramatically effected in a negative way.

Title: Gene McCall
Comment:
What an incredibly bad decision made by people who are suposed to be familiar with GPS technology and its value to the nation.
eloran is an inadequate, dead-end technology.  There is no vertical component to the position solution.  The 2-D accuracy is a factor of 10 poorer(20 meters) than that of the GPS, and the timing accuracy(100 ns) is a factor of 100 poorer.
The decision appears to be a rush to judgement forcing the choice of a technology that has no value in the modern world.
A dollarspent on eloran is a dollar wasted.
A detailed review of possible pnt technologies should be done to define the path forward for 21st century PNT technologies.
Given all the activity in developing communication and networking technologies, there is likely to be a way forward that will improve on GPS.
eloran is a solution that is far below even second best.

Title: Jeff Cowan
Comment: GPS is too vulnerable to jamming either electronic or from solar flares. Extensive disruption of our daily lives if the timing feature of GPS is minimized due to jamming.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
eLoran Decision: Based on the IAT report, DOT and DHS jointly recommended to the National
Space-Based PNT Executive Committee (NPEC) on 28 March 2007 that eLoran be the national
backup for GPS. The policy decision, eLoran as national backup, was reached at that NPEC
meeting, with implementation assigned to DOT and DHS. The formal announcement was made
in a press release by DHS on 8 February 2008 (Appendix B).

IAT Conclusions and Major Recommendation (see report charts 4, 10, 37, and 38):
 Reasonable assurance of national PNT availability is prudent and responsible policy,
needed for ubiquitous, critical safety of life and national and economic security, as well
as quality of life, applications dependent upon GPS-based PNT.
 eLoran is the only cost-effective backup for national needs; it is completely interoperable
with and independent of GPS, with different propagation and failure mechanisms, plus
significantly superior robustness to radio frequency interference and jamming. It is a
seamless backup, and its use will deter threats to US national and economic security by
disrupting (jamming) GPS reception.
 The US Government policy decision is needed to motivate users to equip and to
demonstrate continued leadership internationally.

Thus, the IAT unanimously recommends that the U.S. Government complete the eLoran
upgrade and commit to eLoran as the national backup to GPS for 20 years.

Title: Michael Roskind
Comment:
Position, Navigation, Timing and Synchronization (PNTS) is critical to the United States Economy, critical infrastructures, public safety and emergency services.  Creating a redundant system which can provide alternate sources of PNTS is a reasonable investment, as more-and-more systems have become increasingly dependent on GPS services to provide that critical communications.  

Having served in law enforcement and worked in and around these issues for decades, I understand the public safety requirements to ensure continuity of emergency services communications.  As a former private pilot, aircraft mechanic Naval Flight Officer, and Naval Air Traffic Control Officer, I understand the life-critical information provided in FAA concepts of operations which are often single-threaded back to GPS.

GPS is a wonderful tool.  However, because of the trillions of dollars might be lost during constellation failures, which could be natural, or manmade, such an investment is entirely reasonably justified in eLoran.

Title: Gregory S.
Comment: GPS is a valuable tool, undoubtedly.  It is used for positioning, navigation, and accurate time across a broad range of commercial and residential applications.  Unfortunately, it is a single point of failure exacerbated by the fact that it is a high frequency, low power system.  Terrorists or other malcontents could easily disrupt GPS signals which would create significant problems for dozens of industries including transportation, banking, utilities, etc.  the associated cost could be billions of dollars, lost productivity, etc.  A high power, low frequency complementary system, such as e-LORAN, is required to ensure the low probability, extremely high consequence event of GPS failure never occurs.  An e-LORAN system would be both effective and affordable.

Title: Greg Tylawsky
Comment: Let's assume that for 15 minutes, all GPS systems crashed.  What would be the global effect?  How would the interests of the United States be compromised? There is no valid argument for not investing in technology for a LAND BASED GPS backup.  LORAN gave us this repeatability and human interfaced security for many decades.  It's time to get a backup that we can rely upon that is not floating miles above our heads.  Every satellite is vulnerable.  There is too much riding on this to take continued chances for our future.

Title: David Martin
Comment:
As a product development company, we partner with our clients to address the business and technical challenges inherent 
in developing complex software-intensive systems. Providing a full complement of engineering and consulting services aligned
to real business needs--applied over the entire product lifecycle, Foliage enables companies to accelerate their product 
development efforts, and drive more predictability and productivity into their businesses.

As a provider of software and services to the US Department of Transportation, and other government agencies related 
to aviation and transportation, as well as commercial companies involved in the Commercial and Business Aviation and 
Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) industries, we note that the countrys sole reliance on GPS, without a reliable backup and 
complementary Positioning, Navigation, and Timing (PNT) system could prove to be penny wise and pound foolish.  We 
believe that eLoran has great potential to minimize the potential disruption to the economic health and national security 
interests of the US by providing a difficult to disrupt and complementary PNT service to GPS. 

Foliage is interested in implementing eLoran services for PNT into several product development efforts that we perform for 
our clients. We also would be interested in the wide area low bit-rate data-channel capabilities that eLoran could provide if 
these services were available publicly. We believe that eLoran provides the necessary timing and navigation accuracy for 
our applications and we would be interested in integrating mass market eLoran receiver technology into our client's products. 
Our applications would require eLoran coverage throughout the continental United States including out to the 200 NM EEZ. 
We could also make use of additional coverage outside the continental United States and indeed coverage in Europe, Asia, 
and the Middle East would be beneficial as well.

Title: Jeffrey Borelli
Comment: Aviation in the U.S. has maintained its superb safety record by including redundancy in its methods and technology.  It is important to keep the LORAN system as a land based backup to the GPS system in orbit.  I am a commercially certificated pilot with multi-engine and instrument ratings and 750 hours flight time.  I have been flying since 1974.

Title: Phil Yoder
Comment: The Loran system is a VERY practical, economical and realistic system to backup our current GPS system in the event of sabotage or other subterfuge.  The cost of maintaining a 100%-coverage Loran system is minuscule compared to the VOR/ADF based system(s) and should never have been discarded.   I fly full time (47 years and 12,000 hours) and have experienced all of these systems.  Common sense dictates maintaining the Loran system.

Title: John McHale
Comment:
I have reviewed the subject draft.  Since the mid 1970s during my many years as head of aircraft navigation for the navy and during my subsequent years at the Institute for Defense Analyses, I have always  maintained a need for a backup to GPS. This requirement goes back to my flight test years for the navy and my conversations with Navy Captain Philip Van Horn Weems.  Always have a backup is not an idle comment relative to survival.  We are at a critical juncture in the pursuit of safe navigation in the air, in space, on land and on the seas. Accurate time is a dominant requirement for navigation and E-LORAN provides that to safeguard from denial of GPS.  I do not think the draft document clearly makes the point about accurate time availability.  This point about accurate time needs to be repeated several times in the document to emphasize the national criticality.  Maybe, I missed the subject of secure money transfer using POSITIME. However,  the encoding of accurate position and time for financial transfer purposes should be a national requirement.
 
As noted in the Spring 2015 Edition vol 62 of the Navigation Journal of the Institute of Navigation Page 83 titled "Railway Track Irregularity Measuring by GNSS/INS Integration" there is a critical requirement for fast train railroad tracks to be relatively aligned to an accuracy of 1mm. I assume there is also an accuracy for high speed roads.  Nowhere in the draft proposal are these requirements discussed.  I recommend a change to the draft in the respective parts of the draft relative to the use of E-LORAN.

Title: Allan Garfinkle
Comment: As a career mariner holding a USCG unlimited tonnage, any oceans masters license and 30 years experience, 19 of which were as master on a US Flag containership in the coastwise and foreign trade, I strongly support alternative system of navigation, such a eLoran as GPS is a vulnerable system, and will continue to be so, particularly in times of conflict. I

Title: Ronald Perry
Comment: I would strongly recommend the implementation of e-loran. The benefit would most certainly outweigh the cost. We are living in an age of over reliance on technological marvels. This is leading to a false sense of security. More and more equipment on the bridge is connected to the GPS and dependent on its information. A single satellite system is quickly becoming the sole means of acquiring a position for many navigators on many ships. A back up system would give the navigator a secondary means of acquiring a fix while at sea. It could also act a secondary or back up system to the countless pieces of bridge equipment dependent on a constant position feed to function. It would also provide a system which is not vulnerable to the same types of interference and potential sabotage which threaten GPS. All navigation officers are taught from an early age to use all available means to acquire a position at sea. Our options are becoming fewer and fewer, in an age in which technological advancements should be producing more and more. We have more gadgets but they are all tied to the same source of information. Not to mention the ever shrinking availability of fixed and floating aids to navigation.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
eLoran and Decca C are aids to Navigation of the past.
These aids do not belong in the present times or the future.

It is saying - lets strap sun dials to our wrists becase you can never tell when your wrist watch will conk out.
GPS's are one of the most reliable aids to navigation.

Title: Mark Haggerty
Comment:
We most clearly and urgently need a back-up to the GPS system.  As a SanFrancisco Bar Pilot piloting ships of just over 1200 feet length in very confined channels and turning basins, we rely heavily upon surveyor grade DGPS e-navigation hardware and software to avoid allisions with fixed structures, and standard GPS in frequent poor visibility and dense traffic situations.  Adding e-loran is a crucial and long-overdue redundancy upgrade that will ensure safety and protection of the marine environment.
I strongly support the establishment of a North American e-loran system.
Thanks You;
Capt. Mark Haggerty
San Francisco Bar Pilot

Title: Paul Cheney
Comment: We live in interesting times. Defending freedom against terrorism has been in the forefront of our national platfrom since the 9/11 attacks in New York.  A caveat of terrorism includes cyber terrorism.  Introducing malware into a positioning system such as Global Positioning is not a new idea, but one we still need to defend against. The former LORAN-A and LORAN-C systems were highly effective and used in a time before NATO recognized the term cyber terrorism.  Both LORAN-A and LORAN-C were instrumental providing long range positional guidance to mariners and aviators across the globe.  e-LORAN is a system that is not only necessary to ensure safe passage but to provide a well-being for the mariner and end user at the same time.  e-LORAN, like all other binary based systems, will be exposed to cyber security flaws, but one that the Department of Transportation should not dismiss as we attempt to move forward in a safe and cost effective means of ensuring safe passage for all end users.

Title: G. Lin Roth
Comment:
As someone who was deeply involved in the efforts to continue and modernize Loran and, as the owner of a company
that specialized in spread-spectrum radios and Loran receivers, I might provide a slightly different perspective to the 
governments solicitation for comments on the potential creation of an eLoran system as a national backup to GPS.

First, let me state that the governments history regarding radionavigation policy and the Loran system is embarrassing 
at best and dangerous at worst.  In that condemnation, I include all parties involved, i.e. the Departments of Transportation 
and Homeland Security, the Federal Aviation Administration and the US Coast Guard.  As anyone who was involved in 
radionavigation since about 1990 knows, the government was virtually dysfunctional in developing, coordinating, and 
implementing a cohesive, comprehensive, national radionavigation policy and system.  For example, the FAA and USCG 
could barely speak to one another, let alone cooperate on a national level (e.g. they developed two different systems, 
WAAS and the marine radiobeacon DGPS, that fundamentally did the same thing, and astonishingly, the FAA actually 
advocated sole means GPS for a considerable period of time).  The DOT regularly vacillated on Loran continuation,
termination, and enhancement, could not produce a credible Federal Radionavigation Plan, and certainly could not facilitate 
cooperation between the FAA and USCG, which were under its aegis during that time.  With regard to DHS, it did not - from 
its inception -understand the fundamental importance of providing a national GPS backup for time and frequency applications,
and I am not sure they are there yet today.

Second, let me state that nothing much has fundamentally changed over the last 15  20 years except in two important areas:
1) our GPS dependence, hence our vulnerability to GPS disruption, has grown; and 2) Loran has continued to develop even 
more capabilities as a GPS backup.  Briefly, eLoran can now provide navigation, positioning, time, frequency, and secure 
messaging.  In addition, eLoran is practically unjammable and can penetrate buildings, thereby providing an indoor time and 
frequency source.  So, in essence, eLoran is the ideal complement to GPS in nearly all critical aspects of the national 
infrastructure and can operate independently or in an integrated system as the individual application demands.

Yet, here we are in 2015, and the government is once again soliciting input on whether we need a GPS backup and if eLoran 
fits the bill.  In 1999, I published an article, The Case for Loran, that outlined the fundamental reasons why GPS needed a 
backup and why Loran was the best system to complement GPS in the national infrastructure.   In the article, I tried to be 
rational and objective, and made the argument that Loran really should be an essential part of the national infrastructure and 
that a strong national infrastructure required a GPS backup.  I failed.  So, Ill change tactics now and be blunt: the US (and 
every other first world nation) is crazy if it does not have a system to backup GPS (or their own satellite system).

I am retired now, and must have something better to do, so let me get to my final point.  If the US government decides to 
implement an eLoran system, it really needs to do so in a complete and coordinated manner that not only meets the technical 
requirements necessary but also assures manufacturers that a long term market will truly be established.  Only then will 
people be willing to risk their own funds and efforts to develop and evolve eLoran receivers and antennas.  I know of what I 
speak.  I actually decided to sell my companys spread spectrum radio product line because I believed what the government 
was telling me at the time, to wit, that Loran would be continued.  Thats why I am retired.

Given the abysmal history of the government with regard to Loran and radionavigation policy, I would also make a final plea 
to those in the government now tasked to decide the fate of eLoran.   Your actions will have consequences, potentially of 
enormous significance.  It is time for every department, agency, and individual involved in this decision to have the courage 
and integrity to put the countrys needs first, not sinecures, interagency budgets or rivalries, or political concerns.

G. Linn Roth, Ph.D., FRIN
Retired Gentleman
Former President, International Loran Association

Title: Resilient Navigation and Timing Foundation
Comment:
Transportation Systems Sector -   

The attached comment document was developed by the Resilient Navigation and Timing Foundation, its members, and subject matter experts from this critical infrastructure sector.

It validates US government studies and the government's 2008 decision to establish an eLoran system as a complement and backup for GPS.

Executing this decision will fulfill the 2004 NSPD 39 mandate to acquire "...backup position, navigation, and timing capabilities that can support critical transportation, homeland security, and other critical civil and commercial infrastructure applications within the United States, in the event of a disruption of the Global Positioning System." It will also greatly help the nations PNT architecture meet the 2013 PPD-21 requirement of being secure and able to withstand and rapidly recover from attacks.

We urge the government to move forward and execute the eLoran project as soon as possible to reduce the on-going risk to the Transportation Systems sector.

Comment:
Information Technology Sector -   

The attached comment document was developed by the Resilient Navigation and Timing Foundation, its members, and subject matter experts from this critical infrastructure sector.

Financial Services Sector -

Title: Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA)
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2015-06538
Government Agency: General Lighthouse Authorities of UK and Ireland
Comment:
The uploaded document provides the response from the General Lighthouse Authorities (GLA) of the United Kingdom and Ireland. The GLA are public bodies that provide statutory Aids-to-Navigation services in the UK and Ireland for the safety of maritime navigation, protection of the marine environment and operational efficiency of shipping. GLA services are provided for all mariners and people at sea.

The GLA declared the Initial Operational Capability (IOC) of maritime eLoran for ports on the east coast of England and Scotland on 31st October 2014. eLoran IOC operates continuously, with high reliability and availability, providing a cost-effective backup to GPS for maritime resilient positioning, navigation and timing.  

In the uploaded document, the GLA share with the US DOT their extensive experience encompassing research, development, implementation, integration and operation of eLoran. The GLA now have experience of user, regulatory, environmental and business case aspects of eLoran that go beyond the maritime domain and into other cross-sector applications. Transportation and other systems that use navigation and timing are interconnected across the globe and need to work together seamlessly. The US is a world leader in PNT; thus, US policies and actions concerning complementary PNT systems greatly influence other nations. This is a major reason for GLA to provide these comments to the DOT.

Comment:
Communications Sector -
