Title: Sidonie Sansom
Comment:
It's critical that the U.S. have a robust and cost effective back-up to GPS.  eLoran is a seamless backup, a proven technology, already integrated into new GPS systems, and at $37M a year - a bargain!  

As a sailor and aviator I have depended on a variety of navigation systems over the years, none of which have the accuracy of GPS.  The maritime and aviation industries depend on GPS for navigation.  We cannot go back to depending on VOR in aviation, or radar on board ships, as primary navigation methods.  They are too inaccurate and will reduce the throughput of aircraft which the FAA system can control, and of ships which vessel traffic systems can monitor - all of which which will harm the U.S. economy.  Utilities, cellular networks, and computer systems rely on GPS technology.  Hospitals are so technology-reliant that lives will be lost if the GPS system fails or is degraded, without a seamless backup/switchover system in place.  At a cost of $37M per year, eLoran is that cost-effective backup system.  It does not require large financial outlays for new equipment or costly upgrades by companies and individuals which currently depend on GPS.  

We cannot afford a single-point failure to degrade the technology upon which we rely for so many critical functions of daily life.  Making eLoran the official backup to GPS systems is a no-brainer!!

Sidonie Sansom, Port of San Francisco

Title: Resilient Navigation and Timing Foundation
Comment:
An eLoran Primer - 

The attached one page summary provides a general description of eLoran for both the general public and technologists who may not be familiar with this particular system. It also provides a link to a paper presented to the Institute of Navigation showing system performance of 6-8 meters horizontal accuracy and 50ns timing.

Title: Resilient Navigation and Timing Foundation
Comment:
Americas Decision to Build eLoran  Rationale & Analytic Rigor -
Numerous government, academic and industry studies have examined Americas dependence upon GPS and the risk that creates for our systems and infrastructure. Of all the documents we have been able to find:
	All recommend the risk to the nation be mitigated by diversifying the source of PNT signals
	All that make a recommendation for a complementary and backup system for GPS have named eLoran as the most effective and economical system.  
	None recommend against eLoran. 

The attached paper summarizes the US government's rationale for deciding to build eLoran and provides links to five analytic efforts that support that decision.

Title: Resilient Navigation and Timing Foundation
Comment: Governance and Execution - US Complementary PNT System. Should the US decide to build an eLoran system to protect and augment GPS (a proposal we support), success will depend upon the way the project and system is governed and executed.  The attached paper provides some recommendations.

Title: Resilient Navigation and Timing Foundation
Comment: Extensive Public Comment on Loran - As of this writing, this docket has received only a fraction of the 978 comments received by a 2007 docket addressing retention of Loran. At that time, numerous important stakeholders and stakeholder groups responded, and 93% of the comments supported retention of Loran. The attached paper outlines some possible reasons for a low response rate to the current docket, summarizes the responses received in 2007, lists many of the companies and groups that responded, and recommends that the federal government also consider the comments received in 2007 as part of its current deliberations.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: As our adversaries around the world continue to become more technologically advanced, our own technologies becomoe more and more vulnerable to attack and exploitation. The number of systems, both military and civilian, that rely on GPS have proliferated and become integrated into every aspect of our society, making the prospect of losing this capability nearly unthinkable. As a result, the US needs to be proactive in developing and implementing a back up system such as eLoran now. Doing so will allow system developers and companies time to troubleshoot and integrate this technology into our systems now rather than waiting until the next national disaster when it is too late.

Title: Michael Christie
Comment: I support critical infrastructure resilience and the U.S. governments 2008 decision and announcement to establish an eLoran system as a complement and backup to GSP. This decision was supported by a very thorough review of the options by the Institute of Defense Analysis that was eventually published in 2009 (http://rntfnd.org/wp-content/uploads/Inst.-Defense-Analysis-Report-to-DHS-DOT.pdf). I believe the analysis done then is still valid and urge the federal government to promptly implement this decision.

Title: David Louisiana
Comment:
The decommissioning of LORAN-C not long after the Continental Gap was closed was shortsighted in the extreme. The U.S. lost it's most efficient (cheapest to deploy & operate) point-to-point navigation system already operating flawlessly. As a former extensive LORAN User, this system was highly accurate & reliable and used in Aviation navigation on each flight. The expensive, maintenance intense, & aging VHF VOR system should have been considered for reduction instead of LORAN.

Bring back LORAN as an important & economical back-up to GPS for point-to-point nav. Sat-Nav (GPS) is located in international orbital outer space and could be disabled too easily by the acts of hostile nations or entities. LORAN principally is U.S. &/or ally territory based and therefore much more secure.

Correct a recent past mistake. Recommission LORAN.

Title: Brooke Clark
Comment:
There have been a number of unintentional jamming incidents of GPS that have caused various problems. It would be possible to jam a facility in such a way that it would take a long time to stop simply by using a large number of low cost jammers. So there needs to be another system that's hard to jam, such as eLORAN, to act as a backup.
In addition there are locations where GPS is difficult to receive but eLORAN would be easy to receive that need precision timing information. This is critical for many of today's digital communication protocols.
Get eLORAN on line.

Title: iPosi, Inc.
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: The Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: David Hershberger
Comment: Some of the comments disparage Loran as being inferior to GPS. Such comments miss the point. By analogy, if your car has a small spare tire with speed and distance limitations, that is no reason to get rid of it. It will get you where you need to go, which is better than being immobilized by a flat tire. Similarly, Loran will get you where you need to go, which is better than being immobilized by a GPS outage. Loran would be a cost-effective backup technology, not a competitive technology.

Title: Comment on FR Doc # 2015-06538
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Kim Taehwan
Comment:
I am advocating eLORAN for the complementary PNT system as a private citizen.  Based on previous publication in 2006 IEEE MILCOM Homeland Security session paper, An Evaluation of the Effectiveness of Intentional Interference to eLORAN, coauthors James Chadwick and I have objectively shown that eLORAN can adequately protect national PNT and Synchronization (PNTS) service for all critical infra-structure sectors that weak GNSS signals could no longer support in fast-faced global economical and geo-political changes.  Around the world, GNSS signals have been repeatedly interfered, jammed and even spoofed. 
Besides the facts that eLORANs strong signal will mitigate unintentional GNSS interference and deter intentional GNSS jamming and spoofing attempts, the complementary eLORAN PNTS solution could provide at least two critical future economy-boosting killer applications that the current single-point of failure GNSS-only PNTS solution could not usher in.
1.	Unmanned Aircraft Systems (UAS)
Without complementary backup or joint navigation solution to GNSS, the commercial UAS industry, government aviation safety and homeland security authorities may not be able to put a safe and economically viable UAS integration architecture together in National Air Space (NAS).  Interruption of GNSS-based geo-fencing and no-fly-zone enforcement is more likely unless GNSS interference, jamming, and spoofing are mitigated by complementary and robust PNTS solution for which eLORAN is the most viable solution, as eLORAN antenna and receivers are cost-effectively integrated in commercial low-altitude UAS navigation system.  eLORAN is likely to provide robust ADS-B and collision avoidance solution.
2.	Integrity solution for e-commerce, including Internet-of-Things and Smart Power Grid solutions

In next decade and later, the proliferation of multi-national GNSS constellation (U.S., EU, Russia, China, India, Japan, and other regional GNSS augmentation systems) is likely to push GNSS chip and receiver makers to acquire and track all available GNSS signals to gain global market share where Intelligent Transportation Systems, Ubiquitous Location-based Service (including indoor) Internet-of-Things and Smart Power Grid will represent only some of the most critical economy and safety applications that require Integrity and Continuity of service that are supposed to be certified by GNSS service providing states.  However, as shown in several historical signal anomaly (e.g., Evil-waveform) in GPS and erroneous ephemeris broadcast by GLONAS, there have been single and multiple GNSS system failure modes that modernized GNSS receivers will try to detect, isolate, and mitigate by Advanced-Receiver Autonomous Integrity Monitoring (A-RAIM) algorithm.  However, A-RAIM is facing a new challenge as the number of satellites in view are rapidly increasing and constellation-wide failure mode is not necessarily zero that A-RAIM cannot detect.  By having eLORAN observables into a new RAIM algorithm (to be developed), those users under eLORAN coverage, will be able to have a higher integrity and continuity even when any GNSS constellation accidently exhibit multiple SV failure mode and/or inter-constellation time offset bias may not be accurate.

Title: Rol Murrow
Comment:
My name is Rol Murrow.  I am currently the Executive Director of the Wolf Aviation Fund and I have previously supported the continuation of Loran and the adoption of eLoran as an extremely important backup for the satellite based system now in use by General Aviation users for navigation.

By way of background I have training and experience in electrical engineering and an MBA with a concentration in Management Information Systems from the UCLA Anderson School of Management.  I am a 3,500 hour general aviation pilot and use GPS now and have used Loran in the past until it was discontinued.  I have flown as an instrument rated pilot and as a certified flight instructor.

I am also a founder of the Southern California Airspace Users Working Group (SCAUWG), which set the pattern for the involvement of airspace users and their organizations as stakeholders in the development of proposals for modifying or defining airspace boundaries, procedures, and rules.  The SCAUWG white paper on Reclassification which I authored became our group's official comments as well as the basis for those of the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association during the national Reclassification of airspace in the 80's. Most of the recommendations were accepted by FAA in the final Reclassification effort and those procedures are still in effect.  Our work also led to the development of the Los Angeles Class B VFR Corridor routes and procedures.

Our satellite based system is quite vulnerable to disruption or failure.  Precipitating events could include a massive solar coronal ejection that damages satellites, a faulty software upload that leads to system failure (this was the cause of a major telephone system blackout in the Northeast a number of years ago), hostile manupulation of satellite programs, anti-satellite warfare by a technically capable belligerent nation, or widespread broadcast of faulty signals by those bent on harming our nation's air transportation system.

General aviation aircraft, pilots, and passengers are especially vulnerable because the only backups currently commonly available are the VOR and related systems, which are being phased out.  In addition they do not function at low altitudes in many parts of the country as does GPS.

In addition to my regular work for the Wolf Aviation Fund I serve on the boards of the Air Care Alliance and the Recreational Aviation Foundation.

The Air Care Alliance is the umbrella group for more than 70 volunteer pilot and other volunteer based charitable flight organizations whose members fly patients for care, medical supplies, organs for transplant, observers for environmental and conservation support purposes, veterans for treatment, disaster relief, and many other charitable purposes.  Many of these flights are at low altitudes in remote and rural areas of from them to cities with central hospitals, or in remote areas with difficult terrain.  Thus they are currently dependent on GPS and loss of that capability could prove very dangerous for flights in progress, especially in instrument conditions.

Likewise for the Recreational Aviation Foundation member pilots and their passengers and for others flying into the backcountry of Alaska or the mountain and Southwestern states in the lower 48.  Current ground based navigation facilities are very often unusable and GPS has become essential.  A ground based backup system suitable for general aviation is sorely needed.

The airlines have additional navigation systems available in case of GPS failure, but these systems are impractical and unaffordable for most general aviation users.

A ground based wide area navigation system would provide essential navigation capabilities for general aviation and many other users, and provide additional redundancy for the airlines and the military users.

Technically the problem is easy for navigation receiver manufacturers.  New units could use much of the same circuitry, logic, and displays as used for GPS, and much of the same database management and update technology.  New units could be manufactured with the additional receiver circuits.  Older units could be retrofitted to accept input from auxiliary eLoran receiving devices by the use of adapters and updated code.

Such solutions have been under implementation in other countries and are needed here in the United States as soon as possible.   With so many GA aircraft upgrading to ADS-B out technology, this is a great time for the installation of eLoran capability at the same time.

I strongly support the development of eLoran capability and urge rapid adoption of a technically excellent and affordable solution for general aviation users.

Rol Murrow
Executive Director
Wolf Aviation Fund

Title: Reid Sprague
Comment:
As a ship's officer and former Navy man, I've had decades of experience with electronic navigation systems. I remember the first Loran-A systems, when you had to plot the TDs to get your position. Then Loran-C came out, and we all thought we'd died and gone to heaven! And now we've had GPS for some time, and it's great, too. But also very vulnerable in ways that Loran was not.
Loran-C was rock-solid and accurate. I never understood why the decision was made to decommission it for a negligible saving, when that action so negatively impacted our positioning resilience. Bringing Loran back in the form of eLoran would be a wise decision, giving crucial functions, both civilian and military, a reliable backup in times of crisis. 
It's begging for trouble to keep all our eggs in one (fragile) basket. Let's correct that situation with eLoran.

Title: Robert Powell
Comment: I support the use of an equivalent or complementary Percision navigation system or; E Loran,due to the extremely fragile nature of GPS,it's signals, and space basing it's relative inaccessability to remediate problems, service or upgrades, and it's extreme vulnerability to hack or even low grade technical or terrorist attack .it is unfortunate that we had in place all of the Technology, hardware and infrastructure in place to simply convert to E Loran from C broadcasts and have not utilized it so far.as a long time member of the transportation industry, "aviation" I urge the embracing of "E Loran as a complementary and or alternative, at the very least "land-based" Nav system affording our industry and all other dependent industries a viable alternative

Title: Bob Bechler
Comment: Why do we need to go back to Loran navigation?  I would not buy that equipment. GPS is more than enough

Title: Al Studt
Comment:
I would use eLoran only if it was user configurable to display federal standard US National Grid (USNG; FGDC-STD-011-2001) to include grid lines on any map display and of course present position, search functions, etc. For the USA, USNG is coordinate system all responders, land-based and even those in the air supporting land operations SHALL use. 
See this Florida Fire Chief's Association document about this: http://www.ffca.org/files/pdf%20files/USNG%20National%20Grid%20Letter.pdf
See: https://www.fgdc.gov/usng

Title: John Allan
Comment: I think that eLoran should be used as a backup to the GPS system. The GPS should have some sort of backup. The GPS system is susceptible to intentional jamming, unintentional jamming, and natural jamming (solar flares etc.). The cost to start up and enhance the present Loran-C equipment is small compared to the losses that would occur if there was a problem with the GPS system. When such a low cost altenative to GPS is available can the US afford not use it?

Title: Christopher Treib
Comment: I support critical infrastructure resilience and the U.S. governments 2008 decision and announcement to establish an eLoran system as a complement and backup to GSP. This decision was supported by a very thorough review of the options by the Institute of Defense Analysis that was eventually published in 2009 (http://rntfnd.org/wp-content/uploads/Inst.-Defense-Analysis-Report-to-DHS-DOT.pdf). I believe the analysis done then is still valid and urge the federal government to promptly implement this decision. IT systems require accurate, reliable timing infrastructure to support nearly ever facet of the economy, including the operation of markets world wide. I firmly believe eLORAN is the best avenue to directly address this immediate need.

Title: Daivd Willis
Comment: I support critical infrastructure resilience and the need to provide a complementary and backup system for GPS. That system should be National Positioning".

Title: Roger Barnett
Comment:
The eLoran solution is the best choice for an alternative to satellite-based positioning, navigation and timing (PNT). The U.S.'s GPS has become a integral part of our national critical infrastructure and requires protection. Where GPS is space-based and thus lacks any ground-based or self-defensive capabilities we must have an effective and ready to use solution as an alternative. The eLoran system offers a robust backup/alternative system that can continue many services during a GPS outage. The eLoran system is based on a well established and proven design. This solution can provide additional options such as partnering with GPS to expand capabilities and provide an immediate fail over long range navigation system for ships and aircraft. 

Additionally, when one compares the cost of building, launching and maintaining a single GPS satellite and the greater cost to keep an entire constellation in proper orbits, it is a highly expensive solution. When one satellite stops normal functioning, or has used up its fuel reserves via repositioning, there is a end to end replacement expectation of over $250 million (http://www.globalcomsatphone.com/hughesnet/satellite/costs.html). There is a life expectancy of 6-10 years per satellite. An entire U.S. eLoran coverage solution, however, could be established for possible cost of $750 million, and would provide 20+ years of service per station. This could support Hawaii, Alaska, North and Central America and the Caribbean. 

Like several others, I have significant career experience supporting the maintenance and improvement of Loran-C; particularly in the aviation sector. As a former U.S. Coast Guard Engineering Officer who directly worked with both Loran-C and GPS, I envision this system as best and most effective alternative for a multi-mode PNT. 

I am fully on board with this system!

Thank you, I appreciate the opportunity to comment.

Title: Robert Burns
Comment:
DOT,

I have been a sailboat operator for much of the last 35 years, cruising in inland waters, coastal ocean waters, and on the high seas.  My first electronic navigation system was Loran and I gradually changed to use GPS since I sailed beyond the range of US Loran systems.

Assuming the price of eLoran receivers was reasonable (in the $200 range) I would like to have that option for navigation in addition to GPS.  As a sailor I always prefer to have redundant systems aboard and the accuracy of Loran has always be excellent when trying to find anchorages, enter harbors, or find a fishing spot that proved productive a week earlier.

I support the Government's intention to develop and field an Enhanced Loran system.

Title: Clifford Appel
Comment:
The eLoran concept may sound good as "back up" or "alternative" to GPS if the GPS system should fail. But, resurrecting
 the old LORAN C stations would be costly since they've not been maintained for four or five years. The trained personnel 
who once kept the stations running and maintained are retired or need "refresher training" if such a thing is possible. The 
system would only be available in U.S., not world-wide as GPS is.

What companies make a reasonably priced LORAN C receiver these days? GPS equipment is readily available and cheap,
with prices measured in only a couple of hundred dollars as a consumer product. The eLoran concept uses some of GPS 
capability so if GPS goes down does that mean eLoran would suffer, or go down, too?  LORAN C by itself has "about" one 
tenth to quarter mile accuracy whereas GPS accuracy is measured in feet.

Industry presently uses GPS for timing purposes. If LORAN C or eLoran were to be resurrected, would industry manufacture 
back up timing receivers for power utilities, cell phones, banking, and any other industry that needs precision timing? 

LORAN C is dead. It served its purpose once upon a time. Let it rest in peace.

Title: Joe Safaryn
Comment: The loran system is helpful to the commercial and recreational boating public and should be place back in use. It would be beneficial to have a system that supplements GPS.

Title: Kent Howell
Comment: I support building the eLoran system as a backup to GPS. Too much of our economy has become dependent on area navigation to have "all our eggs in one (GPS) basket". I was opposed to the elimination of the original LORAN system some years ago.

Title: Kelly Townsend
Comment: Important as GPS is, I believe there should be supplemental technology for navigation. And the wide band of separation of frequencies, and their opposing point of origin (earth vs space), makes it the most desirable alternative. With current world strife & tensions from various radical groups, GPS could be targeted by them, and eLoran would be available as a backup if it's installed.

Title: David Cooper
Comment:
I am surprised that there have been so few comments concerning this vital national security and navigation safety issue. I expect it is due to a lack of awareness by stakeholders and others concerned potentially with those considerations.
     Once again, one only has to remember that China destroyed one of its obsolete satellites to see the vulnerability of GPS to physical attack. And in today's digital world, could cyber-attack effectively do the same thing?

Title: Robert Sheen
Comment: I support critical infrastructure resilience and the need to provide a complementary and backup system for GPS. That system should be: eLORAN

Title: Wayne Klepczynski
Comment: The arrogance and stupidity of relying on a single thread system can only be imagined in the minds of bureaucrats and public officials who should have the pubic interest in their minds and not their own self-interests. Please develop eLoran so as to have a back-up to a great system that has some shortcomings.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: We need an alternate PNT. eLoran is our best choice.

Title: The American Pilots' Association
Comment: See attached file.  The American Pilots'  Association and its members appreciate the opportunity to offer constructive comments on the potential implementation of eLoran.  We strongly support the DoTs efforts to improve navigational safety by implementing a complement to GPS.

Title: Mike O'Dell
Comment:
I would like to encourage the adoption of eLoran as a parallel (alternative or backup) Positioning, Navigation, and Timing (PNT) system in the strongest possible terms.

The merits of GPS need no defense; when it is good, it is very very good and it has transformed society's expectations of location-based services such as navigation and situational awareness, on the street, on roads, or on the water.

However, the first rule of Seamanship is to never rely upon only one source of navigation and positioning information. Even setting aside willful jamming, GPS signals are vulnerable to ionospheric disturbances and cannot provide reliable signal coverage in dense urban canyons because the signals require line-of-sight to enough GPS satellites. 

eLoran is an *excellent* system to pair with GPS because its weaknesses are highly uncorrelated with GPS. eLoran is a VLF signal at 100KHz transmitted at very high power. That makes it a ground-wave signal which is extremely robust in the face of interference, natural or intentional. It also penetrates buildings quite easily, even into basements in many cases. While the original Loran-C system was not suitable for this purpose, the updated eLoran signal and station infrastructure is highly accurate and extremely stable, quite suitable for PNT purposes. It also carries additional information which can include DGPS corrections.

Even ancient Loran-C receivers delivered outstanding repeatability of positions ("get me back to *here*") even if the accuracy was well below that of GPS ("meet me on the other side of the world at this Lat/Lon"). Modern eLoran receivers apply the signal processing concepts developed for GPS recievers that use "all satellites in view" to use "all chains in view" to produce highly accurate positions maintaining excellent repeatabiility. 

Loran-C was already used as a timing source for communications systems before the availability of GPS timing and a combined system will again provide the best of both worlds - outstanding precision and stability and immunity from interference or denial.

We have needed a parallel PNT system for a long time now, and we were on the verge of getting eLoran when the conversion process was aborted for reasons still not adequately explained. It is high time to finish conversion, reconstruction, and deployment of an eLoran network for at least CONUS and interoperable with all the other eLoran systems being deployed worldwide. This will dramatically reduce a strategic vulnerability that currently exists because we are extremely reliant on GPS for Positioning, Navigation, and Timing signals that our modern world has come to rely upon.

Please move forward aggressively on getting an eLoran system deployed and operational as soon as possible.

Thank you.

Title: David Smukowski
Comment:
A brief description of our application(s) of positioning, navigation, and timing is a mems based navigation grade Inertial Navigation System
 that could potentially cost less than $100 and requires no external satellites, signals.   DARPA and others have proven the 
technology which couples with earth rotation and gravity.  It is a non-eLoran PNT technologies currently available or planned,
 that could be used during a disruption of GPS for longer than a day.
Applications include drones, autonomous vehicles, tractors and industrial vehicles.

Title: Radio Technical Commission for Maritime Services
Organization Name: Radio Technical Commission for Maritime Services
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Steven Flanagan
Comment: I feel that the shutdown of LORAN was a mistake for the simple reason that as a mariner I lost a critical navigational tool. Having a Loran system would be benficial for a backup system to GPS. As a licensed mariner I was serving as master of a passenger vessel at night in the fog when my GPS unit stoppd working. I was in an area of narrow channels where I needed an electronic aid to safely navigate. Thankfully Loran was still working and I was able to safely get the vessel to her destination. I feel that we should take this opportunity to set up this system

Title: Guy Null
Comment: Long-range non-spoofable coverage offshore for e-Navigation applications, and potential underwater usage are big advantages over (D)GPS in maritime applications.  Internet of Things (IoT) relies upon strong infrastructure of timing applications, and eLoran would greatly benefit the current GPS-based system through both alternative delivery and redundancy.  There is a slight risk of having 'two answers that do not agree', but that is not critical compared to lack of redundancy in current approach.

Title: Jerry Golabowski
Comment:
GPS is vulnerable to jamming, spoofing and loss of the space-born asserts by enemy action (satellites can be shot down). A robust complementary system, that can also serve as a stand-alone back-up, is a necessary component to our geolocation infrastructure.
In a marine environment, a second position determining system is valuable should the vessel's GPS fail.

Title: Christian Hempstead
Comment: I support critical infrastructure resilience and the need to provide a complementary and backup system for GPS. That system should be eLoran.

Title: Ron Lee
Comment:
Reliance upon GPS only is unwise given known and unknown threats. 
Please do not place non-required performance standards on this system in a veiled manner to prevent its implementation. For example, do not require that the system meet 99.9% availability of supporting non-precision approached throughout the CONUS if it otherwise provides a highly reliable en route navigation capability.

Title: Wayne Gilham
Comment:
As a recreational boater (sailor) with some experience in coastal and offshore passage-making in my 43-foot sailboat, I assure you that I would equip my vessel with necessary gear to position-locate using the (proposed) complementary eLoran system.  I was MOST discouraged when the old Loran system was dismantled in 2010(?), as up to that time I did keep old Loran gear available in case ever the rather fragile (satellite-based) GPS system were "compromised". A land-based system would inherently be more robust, and quite possibly less susceptible to "jamming"...  I also look forward to the economic benefit of development of newer, much more sophisticated Loran receiving equipment for the recreational boater.  As COLREGS implies, the prudent mariner must use ALL means at his disposal....

Regards,
Wayne Gilham, S.A.
Marine Surveyor (member, Society of Accredited Marine Surveyors)
1st VP (legislative affairs), Recreational Boating Assn of WA

Title: Peter Swaszek
Comment:
Given the vulnerabilities of the GPS, I think that a groundwave-based backup at 100 kHz makes perfect sense. The spectrum is still available, the real estate and towers are still in the government's hands, etc. 

Having been involved in the previous US eLoran engineering effort I offer the following suggestion: don't just duplicate the eLoran system from 10 years ago (or what is currently operating in Europe) but take the time to REALLY update the 1950's concept to today's technology and modern signal processing concepts. The prior US effort included improved transmitter hardware and FPGA-based receivers, but stuck with the 1950's pulse shape, groups, chains, rates, phase codes, dual rating, blanking, etc., all to maintain backwards compatibility; even the data channel methods, Eurofix and 9-th Pulse, were add-ons so as to minimally impact the navigation performance of the 1950's system. Take advantage of Loran being turned off in the US; drop the backwards compatibility requirement and develop a 21st century, high performance, groundwave, 100 kHz navigation/communications system.

Title: Greg Young
Comment:
I would love to say that I support this eLoran proposal but can't. I am a private pilot  and fly my personal aircraft on a significant number of cross country trips each year. I see a definite need to have a non-satellite navigation backup to GPS. What it should have been was the original Loran system for enroute and LOC/ILS for approaches. Loran should never have been decommissioned. It was dirt cheap and worked. I was a Loran user in the 90's. I was convinced that manufacturers would have integrated Loran into GPS units as a failover, albeit degraded, position source. It still  could. If GPS fails enroute I don't need my position within 25 feet, I need it within a mile or two.

eLoran is too complicated, too complex and too costly. I do not believe the DOT can pull it off. This notice is 7 years after the "aha moment" of realizing we should have a backup. That was a no brainer that any user could have told you. Then the request for comments was not publicized to the user community. I found out just before the deadline. This system will attempt to duplicate all the functions and accuracy provided by GPS. Just the term "positioning, navigation, and timing (PNT)" reeks of cost and complexity.

I suggest you just turn on the old Loran system and the market will utilize it.

Title: Elmer Croan
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Tom Nolan
Organization Name: Maritime Institute of Technology & Graduate Studies
Comment:
I have been involved in the eLoran debacle since the U.S. terminated it's Loran-C stations after the U.S. being advised by all creditable studies that it was the only viable backup to GNSS.

Now, that the U.S. is close to re-authorizing it's Loran-C stations in an eLoran configuration lets not make the same mistake that we made years ago!

If the U.S. does not move on establishing it's participation in eLoran, by the end of the year, countries in Europe which now very successfully participate in eLoran and D-eloran as a SUCCESSFUL back up to GNSS, intend to terminate the service,

All studies indicate that eLoran is the only viable backup to GNSS in the areas where eLoran exists and at an accuracy comparable to GNSS.

eLoran due to it's high power and much lower frequency (MF) is very difficult to jam.

eLoran in addition provides a cellular system timing source when GNSS is jammed, penetration deep into urban canyons, even beneath the waves for those who need it there & by the way, why is South Korea installing an eLoran chain? Could it be that North Korea is jamming the South Korean GNSS signals?

The U.S. must take the lead in the global effort to re-establish this invaluable adjunct to GNSS.

GNSS has & will be jammed & spoofed by nefarious nations bent on disrupting it's incredible capabilities.

Let's get real & rejoin the eLoran effort before it's too late!

Title: Nautel Maine Inc.
Comment:
Nautel Maine Inc. appreciates the opportunity to comment on Docket Number DOT-OST-2015-0053 and would like to draw your attention to the following points:

-Significant interest in terrestrial LF PNT solutions exists in our own country and worldwide.
-Nautel has developed modern, solid-state terrestrial LF PNT transmission solutions to address the worldwide opportunity
-A positive terrestrial LF PNT decision in the US will help influence international demand creating opportunity for Nautel Maine, its employees and our domestic suppliers.
-In addition a positive decision will help our country further its leadership in this strategic technological sector.
 
Growing worldwide terrestrial LF PNT interest:

Extensive market research has been undertaken by Nautel and our Value Added Reseller (VAR) partner, UrsaNav Inc, which confirms both US and worldwide interest in a modernized ground based, terrestrial LF PNT network to complement and back-up the critical satellite based PNT network. We expect that numerous other responses will highlight the growing list of US and worldwide experts, government officials, agencies, departments and industry leaders who have publically commented on the need for a modernized ground based, terrestrial PNT network.  

 Nautel Maine: Modern LF PNT ready solutions: 

In response to this emerging demand, Nautel has developed a new series of, solid-state transmitters, designed to be a critical part of LF Position, Navigation, Timing and Data (PNT&D) system which could include LORAN and/or eLORAN. These state-of-the-art LF PNT&D transmitters utilize a patented pulse power recovery technique to provide outstanding efficiency, significantly reduced size and weight, greatly reduced operational costs and a future proof design to allow modernization as the system is further developed. 

Economic implications of a positive decision

Nautel Maine Inc.s fully integrated Bangor Maine facility is well positioned to manufacture, test and support all requirements for these US and worldwide transmitter deployments. Our local supply network as well as our suppliers in other areas of the United States would benefit greatly from the opportunity which would be presented should a LF Position, Navigation, Timing and Data (PNT&D) system be deployed in the United States.

Export and technological implications of a positive decision

Nautel and our VAR, UrsaNav Inc. continue to market, discuss and demonstrate this technology in the United States and throughout the world. We have ongoing international sales commitments, ever increasing interest in both the United States and internationally to discuss the many advantages of a complimentary LF PNT system as more countries are concerned about the real threat to their critical infrastructure and defense with their sole dependence on a satellite based PNT system. It is worthwhile to note the importance that the world attaches to technology decisions made in the United States. Although the rest of the world is already moving to implement Complementary Positioning, Navigation, and Timing Capabilities, a positive decision in the US would create an increased momentum. This should offer significant opportunity to the PNT industry in this country and could position the US once again as the leader in this field.
	
Nautel Maine Inc. thanks you for the opportunity to provide our comments on this very important docket item. We trust that a positive outcome will result, ensuring a Complementary Positioning, Navigation, and Timing Capability is implemented to protect the critical infrastructure sectors and defense systems of the United States. Please be assured that Nautel Maine Inc.s more than 30 full time, experienced and highly trained fabricators, assemblers, electrical test and support personnel as well as our local, state, and U.S. suppliers and contractors are up to the challenge of building the technology needed for this resilient, wide area and terrestrial PNT system. 


Very Best Regards,



Charles Drillen
Plant Manager, Nautel Maine Inc.

Title: Edward Majewski
Comment: As a private sailboat coastal waters sailor GPS is a mainstay. But what happens when GPS is jammed or negated by other means (solar flare jamming, terrorist or hostile state jamming, etc) ? The US needs an alternative to space based GPS for maritime PNT and coastal navigation. Planning and funding that alternative now for East/West and Gulf waters will enable continued safe navigation for decades to come.

Title: Sue Curran
Comment: I support critical infrastructure resilience and the U.S. governments 2008 decision and announcement to establish an eLoran system as a complement and backup to GSP. This decision was supported by a very thorough review of the options by the Institute of Defense Analysis that was eventually published in 2009 (http://rntfnd.org/wp-content/uploads/Inst.-Defense-Analysis-Report-to-DHS-DOT.pdf). I believe the analysis done then is still valid and urge the federal government to promptly implement this decision.

Title: Brian O'Connell
Comment: I think this system would increase the safety of both shipping industry and recreational boating

Title: Exelis
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: John Monk
Comment: Spectrum has a patent pending for precise short range navigation using emitters and sensors that will compliment the proposed merger of eLoran and GPS. The close in position verification system has aviation and maritime applications and will be used as a comparator for eLoran and GPS during low visibilty conditions near airports and in harbors.

Title: Gregory Johnson
Comment:
There is a long sequence of government and academic studies starting with the 2001 Volpe Report that have identified, discussed, confirmed, and validated the vulnerability of GPS to interference - intentional and unintentional. Since 2001, the importance of Position Navigation and Timing (PNT), a role filled by GPS. to our critical infrastructure has just increased. The need for a backup system to protect our critical infrastructure should no longer be an argument; rather the discussion should be on when, and how.

eLoran has been shown to be a fully capable and independent backup system to GPS. As someone who worked on developing eLoran in 2002-2008 I am a big proponent; however, I think that the best solution now is a more generic and encompassing R-Mode (ranging mode) system with Alternative PNT (APNT) receivers that can range off of eLoran, DGPS, and AIS signals. Such a system would leverage the existing worldwide investment in MF DGPS and VHF AIS transmitters and antennas and reduce the number of eLoran towers needing to be built thus bringing the system online more quickly and at lower cost. This concept has been investigated and shown to be feasible in a study that Alion conducted as part of the European ACCSEAS Project. The final report can be found online at http://www.accseas.eu/publications/r-mode-feasibility-study/.

An APNT receiver would be able to seamlessly switch between GPS and APNT modes during the loss of GPS and back again, with no loss to navigational integrity or action on the part of the user. This concept was also demonstrated as part of the ACCSEA project.

Title: George Garbe
Comment:
There is of course, no comparison between the accuracy of GPS and cloran, GPS being the far more accurate. The value of maintaining a cloran capability in the US would be in the event of hostilities wherein GPS satellites are destroyed by an enemy, thus disrupting GPS navigation,  In such an event, cloran could provide a more secure backup with decent navigational precision.
Cloran proved itself to be an effective NavAid worldwide and a mainstay of the US worldwide navigation plan until GPS superceded it.

Title: Continental Electronics Corporation
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Spectracom Corp
Comment:
Spectracom Corp. respectfully submits these Comments in response to the request for public comments published in the Federal Register, DOT-OST-2015-0053.

Spectracom serves a large customer base requiring precise positioning, navigation, timing and frequency references for critical operations.  The sectors we serve include military, aerospace, financial services, datacenters, telecom networks, public safety and scientific/industrial instrumentation.  

Many of our products contain GPS receivers to provide precision PNT.  However, the limitations of GPS are well known and becoming a growing concern to our customers  a weak signal that is easily jammed by either intentional or unintentional sources, and the lack of availability in shadowed or indoors environments.  

We see eLoran as being an excellent alternative to GPS because of its true diverse nature  literally at the other end of the spectrum:
	Long wave vs.  microwave radio propagation
	Terrestrial vs. space-based transmission source
	High power (megawatt) vs. low power (<100 watt) transmitter

By providing precise positioning, UTC timing, and a stable frequency reference, eLoran is analogous to GPS and therefore is easy to interface with existing GPS systems. 

Though eLoran does not provide the full worldwide coverage a Global Satellite Navigation System (GNSS) does, the commitments from Europe, Asia and the Middle East to support eLoran provides the foundation for sufficient coverage in the developed world if the United States joins in.  Moreover, the areas of the world uncovered by eLoran are less susceptible to GPS denial and as the threat changes, can be filled in after the USA demonstrates its support.

No one solution has proven to fulfill all the needs for a robust PNT solution, but the complementary GPS-eLoran systems along with other technologies will provide the resiliency so greatly needed for PNT critical operations.

Title: Pauline Cook
Comment: I support critical infrastructure resilience and the U.S. governments 2008 decision and announcement to establish an eLoran system as a complement and backup to GSP. This decision was supported by a very thorough review of the options by the Institute of Defense Analysis that was eventually published in 2009 (http://rntfnd.org/wp-content/uploads/Inst.-Defense-Analysis-Report-to-DHS-DOT.pdf). Unless a better GPS backup system has been developed by DOD and is made available to industry and the general public now, I urge the federal government to promptly implement the 2008 decision to develop eLORAN to cover the U.S. and it's territories.

Title: Peter Gilson
Comment:
Good afternoon,
As an avid recreational boater with fifty years of sailing and powerboat experience, I consider a backup/complementary systems to the current GPS highly desirable, in fact, mandatory.
During fifteen years of delivering boats between Maine and Florida, I experienced GPS "outages" due to various problems. The earlier LORAN system, while not nearly as universal as GPS, provided quite accurate waypoint  navigation when returning to a previously visited waypoint.
I strongly support establishment of a eLoran system.
Respectfully,
Peter Gilson

Title: Exelis, Inc.

Title: Gene McCall
Comment:
I believe that the eloran system is being considered as a complementary system to the GPS.  As a scientist and engineer, I can state definitely that eloran is in no way a substitute for the GPS.  It is an obsolete, "dead end" technology with positioning and timing accuracy completely inadequate for the needs of a modern nation.   The position accuracy is a factor of about 10 worse than that of the GPS, and the timing accuracy is a factor of 100 poorer than the GPS results currently attainable.
I believe that the emphasis of the U. S. government should be on enhancing and protecting the system that we have, rather than building a system that is a very poor "second best".
In my opinion, eloran is a poor investment.  The funding of such a system with the misleading label of "complementary" is a disservice to the Nation.
DOT should search for better pnt capabilities, not encourage poorer ones.

Title: Tanadgusix Corporation
Comment: See attached file(s) filed on behalf of The Tanadgusix Corporation by Blank Rome Government Relations LLC and Smith Advocacy Group LLC. Inquiries may be directed to: C.J. Zane | Managing Principal | Blank Rome Government Relations LLC 600 New Hampshire Avenue, NW | Washington, DC 20037

Title: William Walsh
Comment:
The GPS is indeed an amazing system for precise navigation, timing and a constantly expanding list of applications. The GPS however is a very fragile system that there is too high a dependence. An interruption in the availability of GPS can easily lead to significant economic and safety of life problems. A terrestrial based radio navigation system backup is necessary and the most suited to fill this role is eLoran.

I have been involved in telecommunication synchronization for more than 25 years and have used a mix of Loran-C and GPS to maintain highly accurate time and frequency. Using Loran-C it was possible to realize phase synchronization on the order of 1us over a distance of more than 1,000 miles from a Loran-C transmitter. The use of a GPS and Loran mix provided redundancy and integrity monitoring and allowed the ability to satisfy extremely high system availability requirements. While Loran-C worked well in telecommunication applications the enhancements made available in eLoran would significantly improve its usefulness in time and frequency (not to mention navigation) applications.

One of the most significant problems of GPS (or GNSS) is the very weak signal received at the Earths surface making it easy to jam. I have experienced many cases of un-intentional and intentional jamming of GPS ranging from broadcast station harmonics to Personal Privacy devices sold on the Internet to prevent GPS tracking of individuals.

The ease in which GPS can be jammed and the potential impacts make the reliance on this single system a potential terrorist target. eLoran on the other hand, given the high transmit power and low carrier frequency makes jamming a very difficult proposition.

The United Stated federal radio navigation policy needs to include a truly redundant alternative to the GPS. eLoran in my opinion would be the best solution as it is low cost, has a proven reliability, is highly accurate and compliments the weaknesses of the GPS (i.e. is truly redundant).

Title: Bob Pokress
Comment:
The Chinese have had successful tests of anti-satellite technology over the past several years that represent the means by which they can blind the U.S., navigationally, in a matter of minutes if we had a confrontation with them. eLORAN represents a very inexpensive very secure means of electronic navigation as a reliable, very accurate, backup means of electronic navigation to an increasingly vulnerable GPS system (an adversary would have to nuke the eLORAN stations to knock the system out of service compared to the ease by which GPS satellites can be destroyed by the anti-satellite technology the Chinese have successfully tested). Other adversaries, such as Iran and North Korea, will soon have the same anti-satellite technology as the Chinese. Our GPS system is very seriously at risk. 

In the world of technology, you always use completely different technology as your backup. That is a well proven backup best practice. Putting more satellites in orbit as a supposed backup to destroyed satellites is making the backup just as much at risk as the primary group. If your primary electronic navigation system is satellite-based, then the best mode of reliable, accurate backup electronic navigation in an international confrontation should be terrestrially based.

Title: Eugene Brusin
Comment: Since the GPS system is part of the United States critical infrastructure and has no backup, despite universal agreement that there should be a backup, nothing has been done by DOT and DHS.  Since the Loran infrastructure is still mostly intact and already paid for, the upgrades needed to be eLoran ready would be minor and cost effective.  The positive aspects of this system would truly enhance and protect a national navigation and timing system.

Title: Mark Boguski
Comment: Comments attached.

Title: Winn Brown
Comment: We need earth based navigation systems.  I supported Loran C and support eLoran.  It is necessary to have an alternative to GPS.

Title: Jeffrey Moskin
Comment:
I am a pilot, and although GPS has replaced LORAN as a means of navigation, I always wonder what would happen if for some reason GPS were to be knocked out of service?

I think LORAN would be useful as a backup system.

Title: David Rubenstein
Comment:
This submission is in strong support of the enhancement of the Loran positioning system (eLoran) originally proposed in 2008, and terminated by the DHS in 2010. The virtues of using eLoran as a complimentary solution to GPS for critical PNT applications was and is a no-brainer. The liabilities of each of the two methods almost perfectly align with the strengths of the other. Whats more, many of the time and seasonally variant error components inherent in the Loran solution can be largely mitigated by hosting the two in a combined receiver system. In doing so, mathematical algorithms can be designed to allow for the learning of Loran error contributors during GPS coverage periods which can then, in turn, be applied in a compensation arrangement, resulting in a highly jam-resistant, drop-out resistant, robust integrated PNT solution, essentially superior to either individual resource!

The combined eLoran/GPS solution would be the ultimate PNT resource for countless applications, including those associated with unmanned ground, air and marine systems. This integrated system would eventually become the standard for PNT solutions of all kinds. Without proceeding with the proposal to complete the enhancement of Loran, this critical advancement for the future of the nations defense and communications infrastructure will not be possible.

Title: Automate Marine Systems
Comment:
Response to DOT Request for Response Regarding Enhanced LORAN complimentary PNT

Summary information that the DOT seeks input on:
(a) brief description of your application(s) of positioning, navigation, and timing services;
     ARPA Needs eLoran to Reference eChart (SEEMP Fuel Saving) 

(b) the positioning, navigation, and/or timing performance required for a complementary PNT capability to support operations during a brief disruption or error of GPS that could even last for longer than a day,
 
(c) availability and coverage area required for a complementary PNT capability (inland waters etc.)

(d) willingness to equip with an eLoran receiver to reduce or prevent operational and/or economic consequences from a GPS disruption,  and replace SOLAS arpa, upgrade to 164.38 Marad/ARPA (A+B)

(e) current and planned availability of e-Loran capable user equipment, (manufacturers now ready)
 
(f) other non-eLoran PNT technologies or operational procedures, currently available or planned, that could be used during a disruption of GPS for longer than a day. eLoran-underground and underwater
 
I have been an active eLoran advocate for several decades. As an MIT Aerospace engineer, AF Space pioneer and iotron (DigiPLOT) founder. I have become passionate in this critical and worthy cause to resurrect eLoran.
 
Advocating eLoran is based on my 30 years experience at MITRE in NAVWAR and GPS, and was the only eLoran advocate for military missions improvement with prior actual experience that identified some of the many beneficial ways of complimenting GPS with eLoran.  The goal was to recover GPS former strategic advantage from its current civil and military status, particularly its recently identified/acknowledged GPS no detect spoofing vulnerability.
 
 International development of eLoran continues in response to initiatives such as eNavigation

  Critical Infrastructure that rely on GPS for precise time includes power grids, financial, and telecoms and all air and maritime transportation ocean and inland water, as the basis of most worldwide commerce

  Interference, jamming, and spoofing are all real and potential threats are all mitigated by eLoran
 
This response includes civilian and military eLoran applications for:
   -Ship collision/allision avoidance as well as navigational caused groundings to prevent oil spills

   -Ship navigation SEEMP steering fuel savings for greenhouse gas reduction, lessening climate change
 
   -Underground communication, positioning, navigation and mapping in caves, tunnels and mine shaft disasters for   emergency lifesaving and military use in mountainous areas 

  -eLoran's Combat Laser Range Finder- 10 times better targeting minimizing collateral damage

To Reduce Oil Pollution & GNSS National Economic Vulnerability, the US needs eLoran NOW. 
 Please see attached 20 pages supporting documentation included.

Title: John Olthuis
Comment: The vulnerability of DGPS to disruption and degradation has been well documented.  Precision navigation and timing is essential to ensure safety of navigation; the United States cannot afford to rely on  single source PNT especially since this vulnerability can be addressed with a relatively inexpensive and easily deployed system, namely eLoran.  The Sandy Hook Pilots use every tool at their disposal to safely navigate some of the world's largest vessels into the Port of NY and NJ, it is disconcerting that all these systems rely on a single source of PNT which has no redundancy and is vulnerable.  eLoran is long overdue and must be funded and deployed without delay.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Putting all our eggs in one basket (GPS) is unwise and an invitation to disaster. We have all become totally reliant on our new toys without regard to the consequences should they be unavailable. Providing a back up to GPS through a solid proven technology such as Loran is a must. It is without doubt cheap insurance that will pay a huge dividend should the inevitable wide spread GPS outage occur.

Many other nations already recognise that without a solid back up to Sat Nav  they are making themselves vulnerable. The US also needs to protect its interests across the broad range of industries and applications that GPS is entrenched in. It has already been demonstrated that e-Loran can fill this role effectively.

Title: Marlene Barrington
Comment: It is imperative that the United States have backup to GPS.  Recreational boaters rely upon GPS for safety while recreating on the nation's waters.

Title: Captain Kevin Coulombe
Comment:
Docket ID: DOT-OST-2015-0053
Agency: Department of Transportation (DOT)


Greetings,
I am a serving master mariner for the international US maritime transportation system. I support Redundant Navigation Systems and I support the international effort to require that redundant and independent electronic navigation system(s) (such as e-Loran) be established to back up Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) technology.


This is important both for navigational assurance, environmental protection and national security.

Regards,
Captain Kevin G. Coulombe

Title: Ronald Dennison
Comment:
I support critical infrastructure resilience and the U.S. governments 2008 decision and announcement to establish an eLoran system as a complement and backup to GSP. This decision was supported by a very thorough review of the options by the Institute of Defense Analysis that was eventually published in 2009 (http://rntfnd.org/wp-content/uploads/Inst.-Defense-Analysis-Report-to-DHS-DOT.pdf). I believe the analysis done then is still valid and urge the federal government to promptly implement this decision.
I used Loran as a navigation tool in aircraft for many years and know its value. GPS is too easily jammed, blocked or spoffed to be the sole source of navigation data for aircraft and vessels.

Title: William Haimes
Comment: GPS is highly vulnerable to jamming and interference from many sources. Experiments have proven it can be spoofed and vessels diverted. E-Loran will be a more reliable and robust system to provide for precision navigation when GPS is not available or under attack.

Title: David Moskoff
Comment:
RE: U.S. Government Notice  (DOT-OST-2015-0053)
Commenter:  CAPT David B. Moskoff

Thank you for this opportunity to comment.  I am speaking for myself and not for any government entity.

(a) A brief description of your application(s) of positioning, navigation, and timing services;
Having served earlier in my career as a ship's officer, primarily aboard U.S. coast-wise tankers, I came to quickly appreciate the critical necessity for navigation positioning and the benefits of electronic satellite and loran systems.  I have learned first-hand how important it is to know your ship's exact location, especially in shallow areas where a high speed vessel proceeding in excess of 20 knots can run into difficulty in a mere matter of minutes.  As a Master aboard these tankers, my appreciation for accurate electronic positioning understandably became more acute.  

As a private pilot with FAA single engine high horsepower rating as well as an avid small boat owner, I know that electronic positioning is not just a concern for large tankers just off the rocky shores of the U.S. coastline.  Large ships that go aground on our shores can inflict severe consequences in magnitudes almost beyond comprehension.  The oil spill this past week off Santa Barbara is yet another grim reminder of the extreme and long-lasting damaging effects of oil to the marine environment.  The 2010 BP blowout of the DEEPWATER HORIZON in the Gulf of Mexico reached a cost to BP in excess of 42 billion US dollars by 2013.  A VLCC (Very Large Crude Carrier) also can spill significant amounts of oil.  These vessels come to our shores every day.  Vessels deliver dangerous cargoes besides oil daily via our environment.

We are aware this wayward oil does not have to be the ship's cargo to cause serious harm since the engine fuel (bunkers) alone is carried in such large quantities that damage to a single bunker tank can have significant impacts as we have seen on numerous occasions off our shores and others.   If a CONUS eLoran system were implemented only to serve the marine transportation sector, it would be a very wise investment for this use solely.  The known cost of a single medium size oil spill from vessel grounding may very well run into the same hundreds of millions of dollars that it is anticipated to cost to implement and run CONUS eLoran for 20 years.  Preventing one oil spill could pay for the system for 20+ years!  For comparison, a single GPS satellite costs this type of money by the time it is designed, bid, built and launched.  As a complementary navigation positioning source, eLoran would be a very worthwhile investment.  As many know, the PNT acronym's most important letter has morphed from its early days assisting with positioning and timing, to become the super-critical (T)imekeeper of the world.

As a professor at a maritime academy, I have a enhanced appreciation for PNT systems and particularly GPS due to the timekeeping aspects.  Since I use many parts of the U.S. critical infrastructure daily, it seems fair to say that outlining "A brief description of your application(s) of positioning, navigation, and timing services" for me would not be unlike most other U.S. citizens who use electricity, telecommunications and banking, etc. every day.  This would be especially critical if "(b) the positioning, navigation, and/or timing performance required for a complementary PNT capability to support operations during a disruption of GPS that could last for longer than a day".

Since the timing aspect of PNT has largely become more important than the positioning aspect and so inherently crucial to everything we do, how could we not immediately implement a second system for timing in the form of eLoran? 

(c) availability and coverage area required for a complementary PNT capability;
Coverage needs to be similar to GPS so the two systems can be universally and uniformly relied upon to support the same system and user demands at similar tolerances. Since GPS (and all GNSS including GLONASS, Galileo, etc.) are satellite based and eLoran is terrestrially based, this would be the very best of partnerships.  The two systems, GPS and eLoran, are so very different in transmission frequencies, signal power, vulnerabilities, etc. that they have quite different failure modes - what impacts one will probably not impact the other.  Please see the attachment describing the units used in the English Channel for years now that automatically switch from one system to the other during failures. 

To accomplish this uniformity between systems for both timing and positioning (about 8-10 meters?), coverage would need to extend throughout the Alaska/CONUS coastlines and include those "fringe" areas where present geometry of eLoran stations requires stations in Canada and Mexico, some new. These areas, like the Florida Keys, Gulf of Mexico and southern California areas would seem to require two new stations in northern Mexico perhaps totaling 35-45 stations.

Title: Marc Mularz
Comment: It would seem that in this day and age that having a back-up system for GPS which is easily jammed would make a lot of sense. The costs of this are minor compared to the necessary redundancy and safety it would provide.

Title: Wendall Weidemann
Comment: As a lifetime pilot using all economically available navigation aids including GPS and formerly Loran, I fully support the safety of a redundant ELORAN system. I understand we have the technology to build and implement highly accurate and affordable Loran navigation systems that will not be affected by the same anomalies that could and possibly would affect the successful (however expensive and totally dependent on other and somewhat new technology) GPS. We have the technology and I know we have the funds to support a backup system to the "all eggs in one basket" approach of 100% reliance on GPS.

Title: Steven Jones
Comment: As a private pilot, I believe eloran is a critical backup to our GPS system.

Title: Hugh Shane
Comment: I have previously conducted research into integrated navigation systems that utilize measurements from Loran receivers and inertial sensors. This research suggests that integrated eLoran/inertial navigation receivers could provide GPS-like, precision navigation in certain GPS-denied areas such as urban canyons and inside structures. This would be of great benefit to emergency responders and foot soldiers.

Title: Allen Stone
Comment: Relying solely on GPS is classic "all your eggs in one basket" thinking. Back up is direly needed to prevent a disaster.

Title: John Neff
Comment: Before Loran was decommissioned I used it on almost every flight as a cross-check to VOR navigation and at times as my primary navigational tool. I worry about the GPS system going down, either due to natural events or as the result of satellites being destroyed or otherwise compromised by an unhappy foreign government. Consequently I support the government's decision made in 2008 to establish an eLoran system to complement and backup the GPS system. I urge the government to implement that decision as soon as possible.

Title: Charles Linenfelser
Comment: Being in the aviation business I feel it is vital that we have an alternative to GPS. Since GPS is extremely vulnerable to jamming, I feel it is essential that we have a reliable backup in place. Cell phones and other communication devises are dependent on critical timing for their proper operation. Loran is a proven technology that should not have been taken from the public use. Being solely dependent on GPS is like having only one form of transportation such as planes. Scraping buses, trucks, automobiles and trains.

Title: Martin Kingston
Comment: I support critical infrastructure resilience and the need to provide a complementary backup system for GPS. That system should be based on technology dissimilar to GPS to maximise that resilience, eLORAN meets that requirement.

Title: Don Young
Comment: I support critical infrastructure resiliance and the need to provide a complimentary and backup system for GPS. That system should be eLoran. Most of the transportation industry is already familiar with the Loran system so the use of eLoran would have a shorter learning process than other possible systems. The need for a backup/complimentary system is well documented.

Title: Russell Morton
Comment: I support critical infrastructure resilience and the need to provide a complementary and backup system for GPS. That system should be:eLoran

Title: Twain Braden
Comment: I understand that the future funding of Loran is now being evaluated. I write to support continued funding of this system. I am a vessel captain (fourth issuance of license), maritime lawyer, former instructor of nautical science, including celestial, radar, and coastal piloting, and former magazine editor of the magazines Ocean Navigator and Professional Mariner. The reason I support a continuation of Loran is that the system is so different from the ubiquitous GPS. Unlike GPS, Loran is land-based and requires no satellite support. Loran is a basic system that is easy to use. It's unique and valuable in determining our position near shore. It is inexpensive to use. One of the most basic tenets of nautical science and, indeed, maritime law in the rules of the road, is that one never relies wholly on one navigational system or one navigational aid. I remember when Omega disappeared; I remember when SatNav disappeared. Now, we're faced with the possibility of having a single, albeit exceedingly accurate and brilliant, system of GPS that is wholly satellite based. Loran is a perfect complement to that system. Like many mariners I value my ability to navigate by celestial, by radar, by Loran, by GPS, by dead reckoning, and by coastal chart plotting. Each of these systems is important. But, together, they make up the panoply of the available resources I and others use to make navigational decisions in the challenging marine environment. One never knows which system might not be working on any particular day and any particular voyage. In times of lean budgets it's tempting to say, "We don't need this old system because we have this great new one that does it all!" But this is contrary to maritime tradition where the use of a diverse set of resources is considered fundamental practice as to be common sense. Please do not phase out Loran. It's an important, useful system that is worth maintaining. -- Twain Braden, Esq., Portland, Maine

Title: Michael Colby
Comment:
I am a charter for-hire operator in the Eastern Gulf of Mexico and these comments reflect a long held consensus among commercial and charter fishermen that some back-up navigation platform is needed.  Enhanced LORAN would be a welcome safety net for the fishing industry.  It is my assumption that the field accuracy of eLORAN would fall somewhere between LORANc and the current GPS.  With this level of repeatable accuracy, I think you would find buy in from the industry.  I cannot speak to the needs of other fishing operators in the South Atlantic or other SE areas; however, coverages that are complimentary to LORANc would be satisfactory.  Fishermen are an interesting group, although we use LAT/LONG GPS receivers, many still convert to phantom LORAN and prefer to talk in LORAN TD language.  Old habits are hard to break!

Making a determination of how many operators would install eLORAN receivers is likely a supplier question.  The fishing industry would probably embrace this if units were user friendly, priced right and available.  

If my memory is correct I recall that when we produced LORANa, not long after OMEGA navigation was retired.  When LORANc was introduced, LORANa was phased out.  When GPS was introduced, LORANc was phased out.  I have never felt comfortable with maritime and/or aviation interests having only one navigation platform.  It is probably time for eLORAN.

Title: Chronos Technology Ltd
Comment: Please find attached our Comment document and 6 supporting documents as attachments which are referenced from the Comment Document.

Title: Alliance for Telecommunications Industry Solutions (ATIS) Copper/Optical Access, Synchronization and Transport Committee (COAST)
Comment: In response to the Department of Transportations request for comments, the Alliance for Telecommunications Industry Solutions (ATIS) Copper/Optical Access, Synchronization and Transport Committee (COAST), please see the attached letter, which includes information on the committees view regarding the timing needs of the communications industry as it relates to wired and wireless services.

Title: Bob Cockshott
Comment: The world is looking to the US for leadership on eLoran. All satellite navigation systems, whether used for positioning, navigation or timing, are dangerously vulnerable to jamming and natural or accidental interference. eLoran is a proven and robust low cost alternative. Deployment by the US will send a strong message to encourage adoption by other countries. This will benefit the US by expanding the market for eLoran equipment, and ensure wider global availability for US adopters.

Title: Lindsay Fuller
Comment:
Before the old inexpensive Loran C system was discontinued, Americans had access to BOTH Loran C and GPS positioning. GPS has proven to be easily tampered and interfered with and the solar activities also affect GPS. Those events reduce the safety level substantially for users.
It is a different world out there and if we do not develop a system that is difficult to tamper with, we will be making a huge mistake considering the relatively small amount of money it will take to build security into the system for users who use both GPS and eLoran.
GPS positioning at the public's level is also not as repeatable as Loran C was in many circumstances.

Title: Keith Jones
Comment: Loran should be available as backup for GPS. The FAA navigation structure is being slowly but surely shut down ( NDB, VOR ) leaving GPS as the only system for aviation use.

Title: Joe Coccia
Comment: Fully and heartily endorse and urge immediate adoption of the DOT proposal to implement the eLoran system for the US.  An independent redundancy capability for the GPS system is imperative, and the investment associated with the proposal is but a very small insurance policy supporting elemental national security and transportation & economic viability & wellbeing.  A no-brainer!

Title: Kenneth Fogle
Comment: I support the 2008 US government announcement to establish eLoran as a back up system to GPS. I am very concerned that our reliance on GPS has become so infused in all we do that satellite disruption could cripple our economy, aviation, shipping and the military. The ground based Loran system within our countries borders and compatible European system offers excellent securable backup to GPS vulnerability. Please implement the eLoran system authorized in 2008.

Title: Russell Morton
Comment:
As one of 3 companies offering high accuracy world wide PPP correction services for GNSS we are acutely aware of the vulnerability of the system to both deliberate and accidental jamming. One of our major client groups are dynamic positioned vessels such as drill ships which rely on GPS and other GNSS signals for safe operation and environmental protection. In an attempt to insulate these vessels from the threat of loss of GPS we have introduced systems using INS to give a short breathing space in the event of total loss of GPS. These systems are effective for a few minutes, not for a prolonged period.
eLoran can be use as an aiding source to the INS to enable safe station keeping for hours following complete GNSS shutdown, this would give ample time for the safe termination of drilling operations.
eLoran is also useful when partial GPS outages occur as good GPS can do a running calibration of the eLoran data further improving accuracy, to the point where it can 'fill in' such outages.
eLoran has another advantage for mariners in that it can also calculate true heading with certain antenna configurations. This again backs up users who use GPS derived compasses.
Russell Morton
C-Nav Systems Development Manager
www.cnav.com

Title: Dan Gingras
Comment: It's absolutely essential that we have a secondary and more resilient navigation system available for both civilian and military use. GPS has proven essential, but is highly vulnerable to spoofing and a secondary system is required.

Title: Tony Yacono
Comment:
Many years ago, my Mooney was certified IFR with the Loran system.
After many hours of training, flying, and money to sent the aircraft to meet the requirments  it went away. If I recall correctly , we were the only plane set up to be testing the Loran system in Florida.
NOW I feel that a secondary system is needed What if the GPS system is turned off by some world power?
The Mooney and the two Pilots are still flying and the equipment is still in the aircraft.

Title: Tony Yacono
Comment:
Many years ago, my Mooney was certified IFR with the Loran system.
After many hours of training, flying, and money to sent the aircraft to meet the requirments  it went away. If I recall correctly , we were the only plane set up to be testing the Loran system in Florida.
NOW I feel that a secondary system is needed What if the GPS system is turned off by some world power?
The Mooney and the two Pilots are still flying and the equipment is still in the aircraft.

Title: Tony Yacono
Comment:
Many years ago, my Mooney was certified IFR with the Loran system.
After many hours of training, flying, and money to sent the aircraft to meet the requirments  it went away. If I recall correctly , we were the only plane set up to be testing the Loran system in Florida.
NOW I feel that a secondary system is needed What if the GPS system is turned off by some world power?
The Mooney and the two Pilots are still flying and the equipment is still in the aircraft.

Title: Raymond DeVine
Comment: I have owned boats for years and have used the Loran system for navigation for many years. The GPS system is very nice and works well but I truly believe we need a back up system and the Loran system served us boaters well for very many years. I was hesitant to change to GPS but I am used to it now. When you bring back the Loran system you will also need to teach the younger generation to use it and to use their brains to operate it.

Title: Patrick Wentworth
Comment:
Government is responsible for the infrastructure of the safe travel, time based information systems, and military subsystems. The reliance on one system (GPS) with a single point of failure is essentially a clear failure of good governance. A backup in the form of E-loran type systems provides an alternative and complementary solution available within a short term technical time horizon. 
Of course it is a duplication .. That is the point exactly.
Current technology (consider the number of Apple IOS and Android units produced annually) rollout could be available as a near term solution.
As a former military electronics warfare officer and current pilot I am aware of the challenges to GPS reliability which is why I respectfully implore you to consider beginning to develop an alternative.

Comment: Locata Corporation

Comment: See Attached
