Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Bering Pacific Seafood's
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: City of Glendale
Comment:
Please keep the Access Services "Coordinated Fare" scheme.

The City of Glendale, which operates both fixed route and paratransit services, wholeheartedly thanks DOT for consideration of a coordinated fare for the County of Los Angeles ADA complimentary service.  With 88 cities in one of the largest and most complex counties in the U.S., persons with disabilities are relying on a paratransit service that provides a straight forward and easily understood fare payment system.  With the two tiered fare system that has been in place for 20 years, an overwhelming majority of Access services patrons have paid the standard fare of $2.75 regardless of trip destination, numerous jurisdictions traveled through, or which of the multiple fixed route service providers served any comparable part of a desired trip.  

The current process is simple and effective for a very diverse population with a wide range of disabilities to navigate.  Glendale has over 5,000 Access users in our jurisdiction who have been very well served by the current coordinated fare structure and access to countywide destinations.  We have a very large community of persons with cognitive disabilities that are able to travel independently in part because of the simple fare structure.  

As the daughter of a person with cognitive disabilities, the potential for an alternative, possibly dynamic fare system, would severely complicate my mother's ability to understand and respond to the fare fluctuations without becoming frustrated, confused or needing additional outside assistance to be able to continue to use Access service.   The goal should be to keep persons with disabilities as independent and mobile as possible and not burden them with additional complications.

Kathryn Engel
Transit Manger
City of Glendale

GlendaleBeeline.com

Title: R. Adams
Comment:
As a paratransit rider, I think the proposed rule changes for the fare structure in Los Angeles County are a really bad idea. Why would the Federal Government demand a change to a simple and easy-to-understand fare structure that has been in place for 20 years already? 
The proposed multi-tier fare structure doesn't make sense to anyone, so how is it going to work out for paratransit riders who are developmentally disabled?

Title: Kathleen Barajas
Comment:
Hello,
My name is Kathleen Barajas, and am a customer of Access Services. I am writing you regarding the proposed fare structure change which the Department of Transportation is imposing on Access.
Although the disability community is totally in favor of not being overcharged for their transportation, there are many other issues in doubling the fixed route fare in L.A. Countys complex system that have not been considered and would be detrimental to Access riders. 
The fare structure being proposed by Access Services would prove to be too difficult for its riders, but especially for those with cognitive/intellectual disabilities. To illustrate the point, here is how the new fare will be calculated. When a rider calls to schedule a ride, there will be a computer program that will look the requested trip on Metros Trip Planner website. Already this is an issue as there will be no human eyes here, such as determining which of several routes make the most sense. The reservationist would then use the cost of, I believe, a trip with the lowest fare as a base. The base would then be doubled, then rounded down to the nearest dollar, or to 50 cents if less than a dollar. Possible fares would be no charge, $.50, $1.00, $2.00, $3.00, or $4.00. Currently, Access fare structure is $2.75 for trips up to 20 miles, $3.50 for trips over 20 miles.
It is my understanding that Access developed this proposed structure of six (6) fares based on the vast array of comparable fares of Los Angeles Countys Transit System. Because Los Angeles County is comprised of many, many cities, there is an equal number of varied fares, ranging from free to $5 or more. Although it is unfair for Access riders to be charged more than double for some of their rides, compared to the same fixed-route trip, I can ensure you that these riders would prefer to continue to be overcharged as opposed to having to deal with a complex structure of six different fares which would cause the following issues.
The first issue is about the use of Metros Trip Planner. This website tool proves to be difficult to use, and I have heard of many non-disabled individuals who cannot figure out how to use the site. If these individuals cannot use this online tool, how can someone with a cognitive disability be expected to navigate such? It can be argued that Access riders are not required to be able to use this website, however, the ability to do so will help riders estimate the fare of the rides they will book.
The concept of a fare structure that will be comprised of six possible fares will prove to be a nightmare for many Access riders. As mentioned above, individuals with cognitive disabilities will find it impossible to remember what the fare is for each trip. It is likely that even the current structure of two fares is challenging enough for these riders, however basing the fare on the distance of the trip is the way that the current fare can be thought of.
This new fare structure will make it very difficult, if not impossible, for riders to estimate their monthly transportation costs. Most of Access riders have Social Security as their only source of income, and are forced to allocate a fixed amount per month for Access rides. Having an array of six possible fare amounts, as opposed to only two, will make it impossible for these individuals to figure out how much to budget each month for transportation. This is serious, because should the individual run out of money before the month is over and find themselves needing to go see a doctor, they might have to forego receiving crucial medical attention. 
Finally, Access riders have been forced to deal with fare increases in the last few years, and cannot afford to have still another fare increase. Should a maximum of $4.00 be implemented, riders could experience an increase of $1.25 on rides which they are currently paying $2.75 for. Riders who live in group homes or other facilities are left with a budget of $35-$50 per month for extracurricular expenses, including transportation. How are these individuals expected to afford still another fare increase? Many of these riders are severely disabled, and not able to freely get out in the community. Raising the fare once again will deprive these individuals of the little enjoyment that they get when they are able to go on outings and such.
As a Disability Rights Advocate, on behalf of the disability community of Los Angeles County, I am pleading with the FTA to allow Access Services to continue using their current fare structure. Exceptions sometimes need to be made to accommodate the needs of the public, this is certainly a perfect example. The disability community already has other obstacles against us; we should not have to struggle with our transportation needs as well.
Thank you in advance for your time and support in this matter.

Title: Michael Bailey
Comment:
My name is Michael Bailey.  Thank you for the opportunity to comment on this important issue.  I am a regular user of OCTA ACCESS in neighboring Orange County.  OCTA charges more for ACCESS service at $3.75 a trip.  As nearly everyone who uses paratransit services is on a fixed income and as SSDI monthly payments to benificiaries are due to be cut 20% across the board next year, I do believe strongly that there should be a cap placed on paratransit fares per boarding where they would not go higher than 30% of the cost per boarding on a fixed route bus line.  I also would support creating a system where fares for persons who receive MediCaid, MediCare, or Department of Veterans Affairs help be provided with reduced fare programs for paratransit services that would reduce the per boarding fare by up to 25%.  This should be allowed for transit systems like OCTA and LAMetro where reduced fare programs are already in effect on the fixed route bus system specifically for those passengers who receive MediCaid services.  
The issue of how many tiers or zones should there be in any county, city, or regional transit system before they become unmanageable for persons with disabilities is also a critical factor.  For persons who have developmental disabilities (ID/DD), the fewer zones to worry about the better and the fewer problems for all concerned.  Here in Orange County, it is easy because there are no fare zones intra-county.  In Los Angeles County, the different fixed route bus systems need to do a better job of coordinating their fare structures so you would have a countywide level fare.  Or, there would be only one fare zone that would be a fare for the metropolitan City of Los Angeles and a single level fare for the rest of Los Angeles County.  Either way would make things easier for disabled passengers to figure what they need for round trip bus fare and make it easier for paratransit riders paying their fares.  The per boarding cost of paratransit fares is the critical factor since most clients are on fixed incomes.  For everyone who uses paratransit, it is the glue that allows us to live as independently in the community as possible by connecting us to housing, medical access, supported employment jobs, and various community services.  Thank you.

Title: Michael Bailey
Comment:
Our OCTA ACCESS fare each way is $3.50 or $7.00 a round trip.  OCTA is doing a fare study now which will probably mean fare increases proposal sometime next year.  I did want to add some additional thoughts to my comments of last night--8/21/2015.
Some transit systems in California have on-demand call-in service in some areas they serve instead of regular fixed route service and other systems operate flex-route bus lines that can deviate off the regular fixed route.  OCTA is looking at possibly doing both types here in Orange County.  In the case of the on-demand call-in service, everyone who needs transportation in the on-demand service area calls in for service and usually the smaller ACCESS size minibuses are used to pick up everyone and provide a curb to curb type service.  In cases where the bus system uses on-demand call-in service in a given service area and does not provide any specially set aside paratransit service, the fare paid should be the same for all passengers--not more than 10% of the fixed route bus system fare should be the cap.  This would mean that persons who get ACCESS service now would see their fare come down some and people who use fixed route bus system but they live in an on-demand service area with no fixed route bus line would see their fare for on-demand service increase some from the regular fixed route fare.  The same should apply on bus lines that use flex-route service if there is no paratransit option for disabled passengers.  I think a 10% cap in areas where everyone must use the same on-demand call-in service; or use the same flex-line service; and there is no special paratransit service for these areas this is a good compromise.   It would be fair for non-disabled passengers living in the on-demand area to pay a little more for their on-demand connection to the fixed-route bus system; and since more people would be using the minibuses in the on-demand area, it would be fair for passengers who would otherwise be using the paratransit system, to see their fare come down some.
Since on-demand call-in service and flex-route service would link to the regular fixed route bus system, there would be two fare zones.  One fare zone would be for people who live in an on-demand area or flex-route area.  The other would be for paratransit in the fixed-route bus system but the fare for paratransit in the fixed-route system operating area would be no more than 20%-25% of the regular fixed route bus fare and be capped at that point.  While certain parts of a transit system's territory may be on-demand and/or flex-route service for everyone and other parts be regular fixed-route service with corresponding paratransit service' the on-demand and flex-route fare would be level across the operating territory of the transit system and the regular fixed-route and ACCESS fare would be level throughout the agency's operating territory.  The fare zone would be based on type of service, not miles of distance to travel.  One zone for on-demand call-in service/flex-route service; one zone for regular fixed route service that has corresponding ACCESS service.  Thank you.

People with disabilities are often on a limited income, and they have very few options when it comes to transportation. Even this amount is often more than many people can pay, and so they are not able to participate in a lifestyle which most of us take for granted - social events, faith based activities, entertainment, etc.

Title: Philip Posner
Comment: I strongly support this request for a modification in the methodology for calculating paratransit fares. Approval of the request will make it easier for passengers to understand the fares they are being charged and make the method transparent. I would hope that if approved, this method of fare calculation would be applicable nation wide fr agencies serving multiple jurisdictions. Currently WMATA serves 3 major jurisdictions (Md, Va and the District of Columbia and smaller areas within, such as Montgomery County and prince George County). Their current calculation of fare per trip is based upon the "fastest trip" and varies between bus and rail fares at various times of the day and week between nthe same 2 points. The calculation is done by computer using a complex alagorithm which can be quite opaque and confusing to customers. If the current proposal is approved, it might be applied to WMATA to make its system simpler for riders to understand while still generating fair and sustainable revenues.

Title: Matt Cornelius
Comment:
To Whom It May Concern:

By regulations stipulated within the guidelines of the fare shall be being "no more than twice the regional average fixed-route 
fare", this regulation should be adhered to unless the regulation policy changes.  That being said, being familiar with bus 
systems and ADA paratransit services, for such a route as in the Los Angeles area where the issue stemmed from 
raising the paratransit fare because the paratransit trip was 20 miles or more from the central bus route location.
Because of this, the fare seemingly was greater than twice the regular bus fare.  Express buses (buses that travel
 outside the normal bus route/city system) usually have zoned areas which charge more to go to those zoned areas, being
more expensive the farther from the central point the express bus travels.  So, that being said, is there an express bus
which has such a zoned fare schedule for the Los Angeles area in question, and, if so, would the paratransit fare charged
be within the parameters of the set fee schedule of not being more than twice the regular fare.  If this is indeed the case,
then the fare charged for paratransit would be within the guidelines of the regulation already put into place.  Currently in the
state of Connecticut, paratransit services do not travel express zoned bus routes.  Doing so would greatly increase the
availability of transportation services needed by many individuals with disabilities.  So, if what was just stated could be
put into place within new regulation guidelines, ADA compliance would be much better served.  The current public 
transportation system is very limited to those in rural areas and with a beginning step to change a federal regulation to 
assist in implementing such a small change would greatly increase economic viability for those with disabilities so they
would be able to get to and from a job.

Matt Cornelius, M.A., COMS
State of CT: DORS: Bureau of Education and Services for the Blind

Title: Deborah Miles
Comment:
Hello,

My name is Ms. Deborah Miles, and I use Access Services Paratransit in order to maintain my independence with regard to transportation.
As you may be aware, Access Services is proposing a new fare structure.  Instead of the current 2-tier rate system, they are 
proposing a system in which the cost of each ride would be calculated individually. 
The proposed fare structure would calculate each trip fare by comparing the cost of the same fixed route trip and would double 
and round down to the nearest proposed fare.  The proposed fare levels are $0, $.50, $1, $2, $3, $4.  
Most trips would then be in the $3-$4 range.

At local community meetings sponsored by Access Services Inc., passengers have objected unanimously to this 
new proposed fare structure for the following reasons:

1)This new fare structure would mean a fare increase for many trips;

2)The new fare structure is confusing for most people using Paratransit especially those with cognitive, 
     intellectual, memory, and some physical and sensory disabilities;

3) Many Paratransit riders qualify for the service due to their inability to navigate a complex fixed route system,
    which is exactly what the new are structure is proposing;

4) Each trip does not have a consistent fare and thus it will be impossible to budget for transportation;

5) The new fare system may result in further isolation for people with disabilities who rely on Access 
     in order to maintain their independence.
 
In order to maintain the CURRENT fare structure, Access Services needs a Rule Change to apply to our county {Los Angeles County} 
which is a coordinated system of many transit providers.  If this new proposed fare structure becomes a reality this will be devastating 
for many Access Services Passengers! Please remember that it's the passengers who keep this Paratransit Provider employed. 
If we can no longer afford to utilize this service, what good is it to us or it's employees? 
Thank you for your time and consideration regarding this important matter.

Sincerely,
Ms. Deborah Miles, BA
Access Services Inc. Paratransit Passenger

Title: Carol A. Peters
Comment:
I am writing to oppose the proposed increase in Access transportation.  Viewed singly, each proposed increase appears small, but viewed monthly, or per patient, whose income is most often limited to a flat grant, the Share Of Cost and Food budgeting by that individual would be adversely affected.
You have to look at the whole monthly budget, and see the Big Picture.
Many families work day-time jobs and keep their disabled relative at home, which saves the State money (lower outflows for SNF and/or ALF Waiver care costs).
So based on what I am often asked, I foresee such "nickel and diming" as creating incentives for placement, which will result in increased cost to the state, diminished family relationships for the patient, less independence for the patient, and greater divisions in society.

I am one of two elderlaw Attorneys in LA County with prior employment experience at DPSS, administering public benefits.  
As a result, I am often asked questions about how public benefits work.
My comment above is the result of reflection about the questions I am asked by many various families.
They are able to soldier on' because of local resources such as Access transportation.

Title: Kimberly S. Hudson
Comment:
Secretary Anthony Foxx
US Department of Transportation						September 7, 2015
1200 New Jersey Ave, SE
Washington, DC 20590
Subject: Support for Access Services' Petition for Rulemaking

Dear Secretary Foxx:

As both a social worker who works with people with disabilities and Access Services rider for nearly 20 years I am writing in support of Access Services' Petition for Rulemaking that asks for an amendment to the Department of Transportation's regulations concerning the calculation of Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) paratransit fares.  I work at OPICA Adult daycare and United Cerebral Palsy in Los Angeles. The majority of clients at both these agencies use Access Services as their primary means of transportation. 

Access uses a simple, two-tier coordinated fare that has been in existence for nearly twenty years.   It was implemented after consultation with the disability community and a number of advocacy groups because it is fair and easy for our customers to understand.   We are very concerned that any new fare system will be significantly more complex and lead to confusion amongst our clients.  We are also concerned that a new fare system could lead to higher fares for certain clients, many of whom live on fixed-incomes. 

Any changes to the fare structure may prevent people from being able to get to and from doctor appointments and or other daily programs due to prohibitive costs. Therefore, Access riders may be forced to choose between essential activities and their health and safety could be at risk. In addition many Access riders have difficulty handling money and without a fixed fare system they will not be able to use the coupons that are their only means to pay their fares independently.

The Americans with Disabilities Act has been a blessing for people with disabilities in America and the Department and the Federal Transit Administration deserve a lot of credit for ensuring that transit agencies comply with the regulations.   However, in this instance, we would urge the Department to amend the regulations to allow Access' coordinated fare to continue as it has for the last two decades.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.   If you have any questions, I can be reached at 310-473-6924 or by email at crismir6@yahoo.com.

Sincerely,

Kimberly S. Hudson MSW

Title: Sylvia Drzewiecki
Comment:
9/11/2015

To the US Department of Transportation,

I am a rider of Access Services. I am writing in regards to the proposed dynamic fare issue. It is too complicated. A rider will not know the cost of a ride until they make the reservation. I may not have the money to cover the fare. I am on a fixed income. The price could change in the morning and it could be different in the afternoon or evening. This is very disconcerting to me. I use coupons for my payment. Under this proposed system we may have to use multiple coupons for a one way trip. I cannot handle multiple coupons because I am afraid I will drop them. The cost of the ride can be various prices, from 50 cents up to $4. This is also very confusing and cost ineffective for fixed income recipient. I can not ride on a bus route. My main way of transit is Access Services. If these prices go up, I will not be able to make some choices of where I travel. I would prefer that you keep the present fare system. Can you allow a tiered system based on mileage because that is the impression I have? I need clarification about price range. How much will the book of tickets cost? 

I live independently in the community in my own apartment and live on SSI and SSA. I must budget all my expenses for the month so that all my expenses are covered. 

Thank you for letting us communicate our concern with you. I am a registered voter. I support Access' petition and wish the current fare system stay the same because it is much easier to understand.

Please notify me about your decision and what type of fare will be implemented and start date. Thank you very much.

Title: Andrew Bate
Comment:
Thank you for the opportunity to comment on this Petition for Rulemaking.

The Access Services proposes the following addition to 49 CFR 37.131(c) on service criteria for complementary paratransit:
Alternatively, the maximum fare that may be charged by an entity which administers a coordinated paratransit plan for 20 or more fixed route members pursuant to 49 CFR 37.141 and approved pursuant to 49 CFR 37.147 shall be no more than twice the regional average fixed-route fare determined as follows:

 The entity may calculate a regional average fixed-route fare by obtaining a statistically-valid, random sample of its recent paratransit trips, calculating the applicable fixed-route fare for those trips and averaging the results. The sample may be subdivided by distance to determine the regional average fixed-route fares for trips of a certain mileage.

I have pasted the amendment to the current rule on paratransit fares in this document because, upon reading it several times I think that this rule may allow paratransit providers to exploit persons with disabilities who use paratransit services. Please consider these two points.

1. The proposed amendment appears to rely heavily on statistical analysis and averages. Right now, it is easy for the vast majority of people to determine what double a fare might be. For example, as a Paratransit rider here in Connecticut, I know that a regular fixed route ride within the Greater Hartford area cost $1.50 any paratransit then a Paratransit rider knows that his or her fare is going to be $3. From an enforcement perspective, it is much easier for people to catch transportation providers when the math is easy, rather than when an average is used. For example, a paratransit rider may have to utilize a FOIA request in order to find out how the average was arrived at, how the sample was done etc. All of this would have to be done before filing a complaint.

2. The US DOT should also consider that entities that provide services to individuals with disabilities try to find ways to interpret regulations so that regulations work most favorably for the entity providing services. For example, who is going to be doing the statistical sampling and computing the average fare for a particular trip? Will the average truly reflect the full data set for a trip, or will the transportation provider be able to pick the highest number of the data set?

There is no question that paratransit services cost more than fixed route services. In Connecticut, the average paratransit trip costs $55 of which only is provided by the consumer. Revenue is an issue for providers of paratransit services, however I think there are alternatives to generate new revenue that have not been considered. For example, paratransit providers can provide extended services outside the typical fixed route operation. Perhaps fares for these rides could be capped at the same level as taxi fares, thereby generating more revenue for the provider. In addition providing extended services outside of the fixed route operation would allow consumers more flexibility in getting more they need to go.

I would also like to propose that the comment period for this document be extended, as I believe independent living centers across the country would be very interested in this petition. At a minimum, I believe that the Department should make a reasonable effort to mail information regarding this docket to agencies that serve people with disabilities, such as independent living centers.I know that if this petition is granted, paratransit providers will jump at it as a reason to raise fares. Before that happens, all efforts should be made to make sure that this petition is considered deliberately. I also think that if the US DOT made a reasonable effort to reach out to agencies that serve persons with disabilities this petition will be, not by far more than 91 individuals (At the time of this writing, and including my comments.)

I thank you for your consideration,

Andrew Bate

Title: Washington State Governor's Committee on Disability Issues and Employment
Comment:
DOT-OST-2015-0075 Comments by Washington State Governor's Committee on Disability Issues and Employment

Urging denial of the petition to allow coordinated fares for ADA Paratransit.

Simplicity is the persistent theme of the comments offered in support of this petition. However, there is no impediment in the existing rules to a paratransit provider implementing a coordinated tiered system, as long as they take the simple precaution of ensuring that the rates they choose are no more than twice as high as the full fare for the lowest cost fixed route trip in each tier. All of the clarity and predictability of a coordinated tiered system are readily available to any paratransit provider willing to operate within that simple restriction. So, the only real change that granting this petition will allow will be the elimination of the existing cost cap on paratransit fares, and along with it the elimination of any linkage between the cost of a trip by fixed route and the same trip by paratransit. That linkage between the cost of the same trip by fixed route and paratransit is an expression of the single most fundamental principle of the Americans with Disabilities Act. The purpose of the Act is to prohibit discrimination based on disability. The parallel paratransit requirement is a recognition that fixed route design an operation denies some individuals an equal transportation opportunity, and that paratransit is necessary to restore that equal opportunity. Allowing a paratransit provider to charge a person with a disability twice what a person without a disability to be charged to obtain an equal transportation opportunity, already strains that principle substantially. Allowing the fares to go even higher than that, and eliminating the link between the cost of trip by fixed route and the same trip by paratransit would violate the principle on which that linkage was based. 

Several of the commenters supporting the petition correctly point out that pratransit fares are already are a substantial burden and barrier for substantial numbers of people with disabilities (While also expressing the misguided opinion that maintaining the status quo cap on fares would somehow cause fare increases.) Eliminating the existing limit on those fares would place mobility with their communities outside of the reach of many.

The petitioner has several options for easy solutions, allowing it to comply with the spirit and letter of the law, with little impact on its operations, or bottom line. Instead, it has asked the Department to clear the way for substantial and burdensome increases in the fares for many paratransit trips, and to do so through a rule change that would violate the purpose of the law the rule is meant to enact.

Title: Communities Actively Living & Free
Comment:
September 16th, 2015

Docket Management Facility
US Department of Transportation
1200 New Jersey Ave, SE., W12-140
Washington, DC 20590-0001

Subject: Support for Access Services' Petition for Rulemaking
Docket No. DOT-OST-2015-0075

To whom it may concern:
On behalf of Communities Actively Living & Free (CALIF), we are writing in support of Access Services' Petition for Rulemaking that asks for an amendment to the Department of Transportation's regulations concerning the calculation of Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) paratransit fares.  CALIF serves people with disabilities in 50 zip codes of Central Los Angeles, and all its diverse communities of minority races, ethnicities and other population categories.

Access uses a simple, two-tier coordinated fare that has been in existence for nearly twenty years.   It was implemented after consultation with the disability community and a number of advocacy groups because it is fair and easy for our customers to understand.   We are very concerned that any new fare system will be significantly more complex and lead to confusion amongst our clients.  We are also concerned that a new fare system could lead to higher fares for certain clients, many of whom live on fixed-incomes.

The Americans with Disabilities Act has been a blessing for people with disabilities in America and the Department and the Federal Transit Administration deserve a lot of credit for ensuring that transit agencies comply with the regulations.   However, in this instance, we would urge the Department to amend the regulations to allow Access' coordinated fare to continue as it has for the last two decades.
Thank you for your attention to this matter.   If you have any questions, I can be reached at (213) 627-0477 or via e-mail at Lnavarro@calif-ilc.org.
   .
Sincerely,

Lillibeth Navarro
Communities Actively Living Independent & Free (CALIF)
Founder & Executive Director
634 S. Spring Street, Second Floor
Los Angeles, CA.  90014

Title: Dianna Pike
Comment:
Para-transit Fares
I am with the Senior Helpmate program in Sioux City, IA
I will give my input on how I do my transpiration hoping it can somehow help you. First of all I don't do any wheel chairs or anything with a lift.  We dont have the capacity to deal with wheelchairs/lifts because we use volunteers with their own private vehicles.  My drivers not only volunteer their vehicles, but also their time.  They go house to house or to a facility, and take clients to doctors or grocery stores etc. The price of a 1-way trip is $3.50 to the customer (roundtrip: $7.00). I try and line my clients up with a volunteer that lives in their vicinity hoping to keep the price down.  Volunteer drivers receive a stipend of 40 cents a mile to help them cover their costs.  Depending on how far a customer needs to go, the price the customer pays does not cover the actual cost of the service.  My program is affiliated with a regional senior center (Siouxland Center for Active Generations) that has to absorb the shortfalls.  More federal support for transportation would be very helpful. 

Dianna Pike

Senior Helpmate

Title: Catherine Fischbach
Comment:
Greetings to you:

I am writing to voice my concerns as a passenger regarding the proposed changes to the fare structure of Los Angeles Access Paratransit.  No matter what the fare structure that is ultimately decided upon, more attention should be given to the negative impact to riders who are much more likely to be unable to be paid in a fulltime job than their able-bodied counterparts.

First and foremost, the flier we received last month on this subject was misleading; it said that we were to be charged twice as much for paratransit as we would be charged for a comparable trip on the bus; So, all blind passengers should be free and all disabled should pay no more than $1.50; any user of Medicare or MediCal should pay only 70 cents per trip during certain times of the day.  That has never been the case; it is always based on the "normal" bus riders fare.  This is true for a group of people least likely to be fully-employed or of even a middle-class income!  It has placed an undue burden on us for the service!

And what exactly is a comparable trip?  InLos Angeles, especially, there are so many options!  While the train may be the fastest, many bus riders may choose the bus because it drops them nearer their favorite shopping area or closer to home.  Some may choose to walk further and get a direct ride to where they're going instead of many transfers.  Which route will the computer trip planner randomly pick and therefore how many buses will be calculated?  In response to my query about this, they said the fastest route would be chosen first and then the cheapest from that list.  But, in reality, if a paratransit trip were to take the same amount of time as a slower alternative, shouldn't be pay less, or have the initial option of doing so?  It's a crap shoot!  The whole law needs to be revised!

Furthermore, the law's allowance to charge based on twice the bus fare for regular bus riders is patently unfair.  It is not even based off of disabled discounts on the bus for the same riders.  It does not take into consideration a passenger's income or the ability for a rider of paratransit to pay for the ride; so, even if the disabled person's insurance plan allows at least trips to the doctor to be free, one of the portions of the population least likely to be able to afford the service must depend on it for everything from groceries to school to volunteer positions; perhaps, financial aid could be required to reduce the pain in the pocketbook and to make this a little more equitable.  

In addition, paratransit riders do not have the options that many smart able-bodied bus riders have to save money; we cannot get passes of any duration; if we were able to access these passes, (charged double the disabled rate for the same passes) that would help a lot.  That would also make it not as important to figure out the cost of different routes involved in each reservation.  We already use the Tap card system; so, why couldn't that be incorporated in that or even by using a state-issued ID and the numbers and picture to go withit?

If you do decide to keep the original fare structure for the present, it still needs to be overhauled big time.  The inclusion of financial aid based on income and need, as mentioned earlier, might benefit both paratransit and bus riders alike.  The addition of extra tiers of distance and payment might also move the company closer to compliance.  So, instead of only two tiers, (with such a huge difference between them) could become four or more--starting at one or two dollars. 

Also, the whole notion of twice the fare definitely has to be revised to include pass options, disabled fares, and financial need.

Thank you for your time and consideration.  Have a truly fantastic day.

Warmly,


Catherine Fischbach

Title: Gary Talbot
Comment:
Comments on DOT-OST-2015-0075
I am a person who has a disability and a fulltime wheelchair user and have used paratransit on many occasions and have also served as the assistant general manager for system-wide accessibility at the MBTA. Access Services proposes that the current DOT rules be changed to allow paratransit providers to calculate the costs for a fare based on a two-tier fare structure versus the current DOT requirement. The logic proposed by Access Services is that paratransit users will benefit from a fare system that is easier to understand. The reason Access Services has proposed a rule change on the fare structure is based on the findings that Access Services received on a DOT/FTA triennial review. The DOT/FTA triennial review found that Access Services was using a two tier fare structure that increased the costs for paratransit riders, a cost that was above the maximum allowable given the current DOT rules. Access Services answer to the DOT/FTA triennial findings was to propose their fare structure, a two tier fare structure, as an easier to understand system. Access Services makes the claim that people with disabilities would find an easier to understand fare structure more important than maintaining the current less expensive paratransit fare. A higher cost trip is still a higher cost to the user.  Higher costs for paratransit trips for any reason will only force some to decide not to make a trip due to the higher costs which is exactly what I believe the proposed two tier fare structure will do.  How can this be a positive change for people with disabilities who use paratransit systems? Paratransit systems were created because fixed route systems were not accessible. Today many fixed route systems still have significant ADA deficiencies that make their systems less than 100% accessible or compliant.  Lack of an accessible route to public transportation, remaining inaccessible stations and remaining noncompliant rolling stock all factor into the growth and increased need for paratransit services.  Factor in the expanding senior population and the reduction in community based senior transportation services and it's clear why there is additional need for paratransit services. The question is how do we properly plan and fund for larger paratransit systems that will be required to do more?  The answer cannot be to change the ADA requirements whenever a DOT/FTA triennial review finds an entity is in violation of the ADA and the DOT/FTA rules. How could an entity that just violated the ADA be allowed to change the rules they just violated rather than changing their current policies/procedures to bring their system into compliance with the ADA?  If the DOT/FTA accepted the proposal to change the paratransit fare structure based on Access Services triennial review findings, where would this type of rule change stop? If this strategy is allowed by Access Services we are at risk of losing many of the gains we have made in the past 25+ years of the ADA. Entities that provide public transportation must comply with the ADA requirements, all requirements and the DOT/FTA must enforce the ADA and ensure public transportation is accessible and compliant.  

Access Services was found by DOT/FTA to be in violation of the ADA rules/requirements and as a result, Access Services must change how they calculate paratransit fares to correct the DOT/FTA findings and bring their fare structure into compliance with the ADA. The DOT/FTA must not accept the rulemaking proposal by Access Services for a two tier fare structure and require Access Services to comply with the existing ADA fare requirements; The fare for a trip charged to an ADA paratransit eligible user of the complementary paratransit service shall not exceed twice the fare that would be charged to an individual paying full fare (i.e., without regard to discounts) for a trip of similar length, at a similar time of day, on the entity's fixed route system. The users of paratransit are not responsible for fixed route systems that are not compliant and are also not responsible for reductions in community based transportation services or increases in the senior population all of which have increased the population that uses paratransit.  The costs of paratransit as a result are rising and will continue to rise but making the very population that must use paratransit as their transportation option pay for these increases is not right and must not be allowed. Allowing Access Services and others to use a two tier fare structure to calculate the paratransit fare is nothing more than a fare increase and must not be allowed. The DOT/FTA must therefore deny the proposal by Access Services to change the fare structure and ensure Access Services brings their system into compliance with the ADA. 
Gary Talbot

Title: Jennifer Dexter
Comment:
Easter Seals has worked for decades with Congress, federal agencies, transit agencies, people with disabilities and the general public to create solutions that increase access to safe, affordable accessible transportation options for people with disabilities.   We were early and strong proponents of the transportation provisions of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) which includes the right to ADA-complementary paratransit services.      

Ever since the first transportation ADA rulemaking in 1991, Easter Seals has advocated for positions that strike a balance between assuring that the rights of people with disabilities are protected, but that are also based in the reality or operational issues faced by providers.  In fact, we work directly with transit agencies all over the country to develop, perfect and deliver paratransit services and eligibility reviews.  

The requested rulemaking could upset that very delicate balance if not crafted expertly.  We fear the unintended consequences of a rulemaking approach to addressing the concerns raised in the petition.  Given that risk, and the uniqueness of the situation in this specific service area, we urge the United States Department of Transportation (DOT) to work with Access Services in other ways to create a solution to the issue the petition addresses.  We must craft a solution that:
1.	Protects access to paratransit services in Los Angeles County by not raising fares to untenable levels.  Paratransit fares are already a barrier to mobility for many.
2.	Gives Access Services the ability to create a fare structure that is understandable and predictable for riders.
3.	Does not set precedent for other paratransit services to raise fares or in other ways restructure services with implications that would limit mobility for people with disabilities.

While Easter Seals recognizes there is an issue in Los Angeles County that needs to be addressed, we do not necessarily believe a rulemaking is necessary.  We urge DOT to work directly with Access Services, people with disabilities and others affected to create a solution with fewer unintended consequences to the broader paratransit system.  Easter Seals is a willing partner in this effort and would be happy to add our expertise to a specific discussion.

Thank you for the opportunity to provide input and your consideration.

Who is Easter Seals?
Easter Seals is the leading non-profit provider of services for individuals with autism, developmental disabilities, physical disabilities and other special needs.  For nearly 100 years, we have been offering help, hope, and answers to children and adults living with disabilities, and to the families who love them. Through therapy, training, education and support services, Easter Seals creates life-changing solutions so that people with disabilities can live, learn, work and play.  To learn more about Easter Seals and services in communities nationwide

Title: Linda Deavens
Comment:
September 21, 2015


Docket Management Facility
U.S. Department of Transportation
1200 New Jersey Avenue SE
W12-140
Washington, DC  20590-0001

Subject: Comments on Access Services Petition for Rulemaking (DOT-OST-2015-0075)

Dear Docket Clerk:

Paratransit, Inc. in Sacramento, California, is writing in support of Access Services Petition for Rulemaking, which proposes to make a small change to the DOT regulations to allow a different methodology for calculating a compliant paratransit fare in a coordinated paratransit system with 20 or more fixed-route members.
Our comments are as follows:

	While the DOT regulations are very clear about how a single fixed-route entity should calculate the maximum-allowable paratransit fare, they are silent on how a coordinated paratransit system, like the one in Los Angeles, with 44 individual fixed-route entities with different fare tables and overlapping service areas, should calculate the maximum-allowable paratransit fare.   In its petition, Access makes a persuasive argument that moving to a so-called dynamic fare system would make it harder for its customers to determine in advance what their fare might be compared to their current two-tier distance-based fare.   This added complexity is not helpful for their customers, many of whom have intellectual and cognitive disabilities.

	I would note that the current Access Services fare system has been in existence for nearly twenty years and is broadly supported by numerous groups that represent and advocate for people with disabilities in Los Angeles County.    Access' Petition is also supported by these groups.

	In general, the Department should be encouraging the creation of coordinated paratransit systems to allow for transfer-free travel by people with disabilities.   By allowing for a different methodology that still adheres to the original "two-times" limitation found in the DOT regulations, the Department would be encouraging large geographic areas to form coordinated paratransit systems.   Overall, I believe this would be a net positive for people with disabilities.

Sincerely,


Linda Deavens, Chief Executive Officer
Paratransit, Inc., Sacramento, California

Title: United Spinal Association
Comment:
Thank you for the opportunity to provide comments regarding the petition to amend the DOT ADA regulations concerning paratransit fares.  United Spinal Association strongly urges the DOT to deny the petition. 

Founded in 1946 by paralyzed veterans, United Spinal is the largest disability-led nonprofit organization serving and representing the interests of more than a million Americans living with spinal cord injuries and disorders.  United Spinal has dedicated its energy, and programs to improving the quality of life for these Americans of all ages and advancing their independence.  United Spinal has a long history of advocating for equal access to all modes of transportation and was active in advocating for, and the crafting of, the ADAs transportation provisions. 

United Spinal Association recommends denying the petition for the following reasons: (1) the petition request goes against the intent of paratransit under the ADA to ensure equivalent fixed route service, (2) paratransit rates are already too high, (3) approving this petition could lead to unintended rate increases for paratransit riders across the country, (4) the technology is available for operators and passengers to determine rates.  

1. Increased Fares against the Intent of the ADA to Ensure Equal Access to Transportation
ADA paratransit is meant to provide an equivalent and accessible service for individuals who cannot use fixed route service.  Increasing fares will place accessible transportation even farther out of reach for many individuals who rely on paratransit for transportation to work, school, medical appointments, maintain relationships, and to participate in society.   Anecdotal evidence suggests that some people with disabilities utilize paratransit because, while buses are accessible, many subway stations, sidewalks, and bus stops remain inaccessible.  Adverse weather conditions can also lead to inaccessible public rights-of-way and make travel via traditional fixed route service impossible.  Increasing fares when the fixed route system remains inaccessible to many does not ensure access for all.

2. Income is a Barrier: Paratransit Fares are Already Too High
According to an Institute of Medicine Committee on Disability in America report, lower incomes are likely a factor and barrier to adequate transportation for people with disabilities.    Nearly 30% of working age people with disabilities live in poverty (a poverty gap of 15.1 percent compared to individuals without disabilities) and only 34% are employed.   While rates may be increasing across the board for all transit users, people with disabilities should not be expected to pay a disproportionate amount.  Expecting that passengers with disabilities should be able to afford twice the fixed route amount is already unreasonable and goes against the intent of the ADA to ensure access to existing public transportation is available to all.  

3. Amending DOT Regulations Could Lead to Unfair and Increased Rates across the Country
If DOT chooses to amend the ADA rule based on this petition, providers and agencies across the country could begin modifying fare calculations that lead to increased fares.  We understand that transit agencies across the country are facing budget shortfalls across the board.  Disproportionately increasing paratransit fares places the burden of addressing increasing costs on those who have the fewest resources and greatest need.

4. The Amendment is Not Necessary
As noted in comments submitted by the Disability Rights Education and Defense Fund (DREDF), amending the current ADA regulations is not necessary.  Paratransit fares in Los Angeles County only need to be corrected for a few routes. Existing technology could be used to easily calculate fares for drivers and passengers.  New Jersey Transit calculates fares for the entire state.  In addition, Access Services asserts its existing fare structure is simple for riders to understand, implying that the simplest, potentially costlier fare structure should be offered to passengers with disabilities, rather than ensuring the lowest cost, highest quality transportation is made available.  This argument places the onus of a fare structure that exceeds the amount allowed according to existing regulation on the passengers themselves.  People with disabilities should be given the same options and information as passengers using traditional fixed route public transit.  

Deny the Petition Request, Ensure Community Concerns Considered
Thank you for the opportunity to comment on the petition to amend the DOT ADA regulation.  Should you decide to consider or allow the petition, we urge you also to meet with opponents of the petition to ensure all perspectives are considered.  If you have questions or would like further information, please contact or Carol Tyson, Director, Disability Policy, (202) 556-2076 x7104, ctyson@unitedspinal.org.

Title: Disability Rights Tennessee
Comment:
September 21, 2015 

Kathryn B. Thomson, General Counsel 
U.S. Department of Transportation 1200 New Jersey Avenue SE., W12-140  Washington, DC 20590-0001 

RE: Petition to Allow Coordinated Fares for ADA Paratransit (DOT-OST-2015-0075) 

Dear Ms. Thomson: 

Disability Rights Tennessee (DRT) is a private, nonprofit organization which works to end discrimination and protect the civil rights of people with disabilities. DRT is Tennessees federally mandated Protection & Advocacy system. DRT has significant experience protecting the legal rights of persons with disabilities in accessing their communities. DRT has engaged in these efforts through representation of individual clients, collaboration with other disability rights agencies and policymakers, and training initiatives.  

DRT has grave concerns regarding the petition submitted to the Department of Transportation by Los Angeles Countys paratransit provider, Access Services Inc. (ASI). DRT believes this petition for rule making is an inappropriate response to a unique scenario and other means are available to prevent paratransit riders from being charged more than the comparable fixed route fare.   

1. The High Cost of ADA Paratransit Fares Already Limits Full Access to the Community for Many Persons With Disabilities 
DOT must remember that the ADA is a civil rights law. ADA paratransit is intended to be an equivalent service for people with disabilities who are unable to use the fixed route service. 
ADA paratransit fares are already far too high. The current DOT ADA regulation, which requires that ADA paratransit fare not exceed two times the full fixed route bus and/or train fare, should be scrupulously maintained. 
Since the first DOT ADA rulemaking in 1991, the disability community has taken the position that the ADA paratransit fare should be no higher than the full fixed route fare itselfthat is, it should equal to the fixed route fare, not exceed it. At the earliest stage in the development of the ADA, no one anticipated that bus fares would ever rise to the level they are today, nearly 25 years later.  

2. The Situation in Los Angeles County Can be Resolved Without Rulemaking  
Regarding the specific situation in Los Angeles County, the change that Access Services Inc. (ASI), the ADA paratransit provider in L.A. County, is calling for is unnecessary. DRT recommends looking to other complex systems such as New Jersey Transit which have resolved similar issues without resorting to changes in rules.   
  
3. Rulemaking is an Inappropriate Response  The situation in Los Angeles County is an outlier.  Accordingly, rulemaking is an inappropriate response.  If DOT proceeds to amend the ADA rule based on this atypical situation, DOT should exercise care to draft the revision extremely narrowly.  Otherwise, it is likely that transit agencies could utilize the new rule in a way that betters the agencies financial situation at an unfair cost to riders.  

For these reasons, DRT urges DOT to deny this petition.  

Thank you for considering DRTs comments on this issue. We are available to provide additional information as requested.  

Respectfully submitted,  
Angela Webster, MSW 
Public Policy Advisor

Title: City of Moorpark
Comment:
September 21, 2015

Docket Management Facility
U.S. Department of Transportation
1200 New Jersey Avenue SE, West Building
Ground Floor, Room W12-140
Washington, DC  20590-0001

RE:	Docket No. DOT-OST-2015-0075

Dear Docket Clerk:

The City of Moorpark (Moorpark) appreciates having the opportunity to comment on the proposed Service Criteria for Complementary Paratransit Fares.  Moorpark provides fixed-route and paratransit services for its residents and is a member of the East County Transit Alliance (ECTA) which consists of the Cities of Camarillo, Moorpark, Simi Valley and Thousand Oaks, and the County of Ventura.  The ECTA works to coordinate transit services between the member agencies.  Recently, the ECTA established a single operator for InterCity ADA and Senior services.

Moorpark is attempting to connect its fixed-route services with the neighboring Cities of Simi Valley and Thousand Oaks.  One issue that will need to be addressed is the fares for complementary paratransit services for the area covered by both transit operators, which can be no more than double the fixed-route fare for the same trip.  Moorpark's fixed-route fare is less than its neighboring cities, which could impact their complementary paratransit fares.  Moorpark is sympathetic with the request from the paratransit operator of our adjacent county (Access Services), to allow use of an averaging method that does not have to meet the requirement of being no more than double the base fixed-route fare for every possible trip.  Moorpark believes that at the end of the day the complementary paratransit customers will greatly benefit from a more simplified and thus more easily-understood paratransit fare structure made possible by this change.

While being sympathetic with Access Services' request, Moorpark would note that it sees no reason why the issues faced in an area having more than 20 fixed-route operators would not exist in other areas such as eastern Ventura County.  The additional flexibility proposed for Los Angeles County would also greatly assist in Moorpark's efforts to provide simplified paratransit fares for its residents.  Moorpark therefore respectfully requests that FTA consider eliminating the threshold for the number of fixed-route operators, to provide all paratransit operators, as well as coordinated or interconnected paratransit services, with an additional tool allowing flexibility to implement simplified fare structures.  Having such flexibility will encourage innovation and cooperation among paratransit operators.  If you would like any additional information or would like to discuss Moorpark's comments, please contact Shaun Kroes, Program Manager, at 805-517-6257.

Sincerely,



Steven Kueny
City Manager

If Access Services is forced to change their fare structure, the typical rate charged to me would be increased. In addition, some of the trips I take may change in cost depending on the time of the trip. A policy like this will be very difficult for me to keep track of. The role of government should be to keep things simple and understandable, not more complex.

I am an Access Services rider that is 76 years old and has suffered a stroke. I live on nominal social security funding. Any increase fares would make it much tougher to make important trips to my doctor, dentist, and supermarket. I have no other method of transportation. 

I appreciate Access Services for the independence it affords me, and the kindness that the drivers show me. I've ridden with Access Services for 14 years; I value the long-time relationship that I've had with the service and hope that this relationship will remain intact. 

It will be a real hardship for me, should the fares increase and then constantly be changing depending of the time of the trip. Please keep things easy and simple and grant Access Services the waiver they have requested which would allow them to keep its current fare system. 

Sincerely,
Ruth Feinberg

Title: Kurt Hagan
Comment:
I am writing to express support for Access Services' petition for Rulemaking requesting the ability to maintain our current, coordinated, fare structure.  In order to comply with DOT directives, Access would need to switch to an overly complicated dynamic fare structure that would remove fare predictability and accountability.  

Access covers a very unique service area that is served by over 43 fixed route providers. The terrain and number of overlapping fixed route service areas would make any dynamic fare structure incredibly completed in calculating the individual trip fares, as well as making it impossible for individual riders to verify quoted fare amounts.

Please grant Access' petition and allow our region to maintain the current, two-tiered coordinated fare structure as it is the best match foir our unique region, as has been demonstrated for the last two decades.

Thank you.

Title: Helen Nilon
Comment:
Behavioral Health & Wellness is a statewide nonprofit located in Washington State. We provide education, advocacy and support to persons impacted by behavioral health challenges themselves. As such, we are well aware of the negative impacts that passage of the Proposed Rule would have upon many we strive to serve.

There are hundreds of thousands or millions of disabled people in the United States who - due to their disability must rely upon Access transportation systems and the ADAs enforcement of the law to live their lives. Far too many are forced to spend a disproportionate amount of their income for transportation. If allowed to pass, these Proposed Rules will further widen the gap between those who have resources to live their lives in the least restrictive setting and those who do not. 

We request that the ADA Access Rules remain at the local level to allow for the vast differences between communities. We implore you to NOT pass these Proposed Rules.

/s/ Helen E. Nilon

Title: Terri Skidmore Lantz
Comment:
RE: D=DOT-OST-2015-0075-0013

I am writing in support of the Access request for a rulemaking change to allow Access to continue use of the current "Coordinated Fare" that has been successful for riders and providers in L. A. County for over 20 years. Without a rulemaking change, the "Coordinated Fare" cannot continue and Access will initiate a "Dynamic Fare" this January. 

For over 44 years I have worked with people with disabilities throughout Los Angeles County, the last 42 yrs.of which have been at United Cerebral Palsy and I serve on various transportation committees including the Access Quality Services Committee and Access Community Advisory Committee.

At the recent community meetings regarding the current Access fare issue, riders and agency representatives repeatedly expressed support for the request for the rulemaking change to allow the continuance of the "Coordinated Fare".These individuals and groups have also repeatedly provided clear examples of why the Dynamic Fare would not work well here in Los Angeles County, one of the largest counties with one of the most complex fixed route fare structures in the U.S. To use the Dynamic Fare you would have to find a similar fixed route trip, calculate that fare (as the cost would based on the overly complex fixed route system of the 44 providers in Los Angeles County, a system that most Access riders are not  able to use). The proposed fare for any ride could vary at any of these levels - $0, $.50, $1, $2, $3, $4. per ride with most trips falling into the $3. to $4. range.In L.A. County.

 All of the riders I work with are completely confused by this Dynamic Fare concept. "It is just too complex, too hard to understand".  The Los Angeles community of riders, disability agencies and support people are united in requesting a rule change for the following reasons:

1)      The current coordinated fare is easy for people to understand, remember and use independently and has worked for over 20 years! Conversely "the Dynamic fare is not proven, is not rider friendly, is too complex to use in Los Angeles County, too hard for riders to understand, remember, plan or budget for, too difficult to use and at $4.00 a ride for many of trips, is unaffordable.

2)      The Coordinated Fare has worked for over 20 years; why change now to a fare structure that is more confusing to use especially those who are blind, deaf or those with cognitive, intellectual, memory, or limited speech and those who have difficulty holding on to multiple bills or coins who have physical disabilities. 

3)       ADA eligible paratransit riders qualify for the service due to their inability to use the complex fixed route system, including paying for the rides in that system. With that in mind, L.A. County has
used a Coordinated Fare that is easy to understand and use. ADA transit was created for those individuals who cannot use the fixed route system including the fare structure. ADA provides accommodations for people with disabilities in transit but what about the fare structure for their rides?

4)      The current Coordinated Fare enables riders to use a simple single coupon to pay for the trip so no change is involved. With the Dynamic Fare, each route could be a different fare so multiple coupons would have to be used, making it impossible for some riders to independently pay for their fare.

5)      The current coordinated fare has allowed people of all disabilities to travel throughout the county for all their needs as independently as possible which is in the spirit of the ADA. A majority of Access riders have said they would prefer that the coordinated fare continue than to save a little money on one route only to be charged $4. on another route and would not want Access to use the Dynamic Fare that could result in riders limiting their trips to what they can understand, plan and budget for, restricting them to only the rides they can afford...  does that not constitute a capacity constraint? Who benefits from this change?

I would urge that you consider the Access request, given the complexity of the current fare structure in Los Angeles County 2015 and the need for usability of the fare structure by thousands of people of all disabilities (including those with severe developmental and other disabilities) and amend the regulations to allow the Access Coordinated Fare to continue.


Respectively,

Terri Skidmore Lantz

Title: Raymond Bridge
Organization Name: National Coalition for Mental Health Recovery
Comment:
Comments, National Coalition for Mental Health Recovery

DOT-OST-2015-0075

The National Coalition for Mental Health Recovery represents people in recovery from serious mental health conditions in policies that affect our lives.  Our member organizations are primarily statewide mental health consumer networks and other peer-run organizations that provide peer support and education to people with serious mental health conditions and provide a collective voice for people served by local and state public mental health systems.

People with psychiatric disabilities are among the largest populations of people with disabilities, and many have extremely low incomes.  Therefore, many of us do not have our own transportation and must depend either on public transportation, or on paratransit because of the nature of our disabilities or medical conditions. We ask DOT to deny the petition of ASI.

Public transit fares are rising rapidly, and especially in large metro areas such as the Washington DC area from where these comments are being submitted.  A round trip ride on Metro Access, for example can cost up to $6.50 in each direction. This is a substantial cost for a person living on SSI or SSDI in a high-cost region who must make a number of trips for services, medical visits, rehabilitation, education and other purposes. Fares for regular Metro rail and bus riders in our region continue to escalate, raising a concern that paratransit fares could rise in concert and become unaffordable for people with disabilities. We oppose the ASI petition for changing fare setting rules because it could result substantial paratransit fare increases without regard to their affordability for people with extremely low incomes. One factor of concern is that housing for people with disabilities in some large suburban metro jurisdictions is clustered in marginal areas that make very long trips necessary, which could boost fares under the proposed method.

We have reviewed the analysis in the comments submitted to DOT by the Disability Rights Education and Defense Fund.  The National Coalition for Mental Health Recovery supportst the reasoning of their analysis and their conclusion that there are compelling reasons to maintain the present fare setting rules and to deny the petitioner's request for new rules.  

Thank you very much.

Raymond Bridge, Director of Public Policy, NCMHR

Title: Tammy Haenftling
Comment:
While the DOT regulations are very clear about how a single fixed-route entity should calculate the maximum-allowable paratransit fare, they are silent on how a coordinated paratransit system, like the one in Los Angeles, with 44 individual fixed-route entities with different fare tables and overlapping service areas, should calculate the maximum-allowable paratransit fare.   In its petition, Access makes a persuasive argument that moving to a so-called dynamic fare system would make it harder for its customers to determine in advance what their fare might be compared to their current two-tier distance-based fare.   This added complexity is not helpful for their customers, many of whom have intellectual and cognitive disabilities.

	I would note that the current Access Services fare system has been in existence for nearly twenty years and is broadly supported by numerous groups that represent and advocate for people with disabilities in Los Angeles County.    Access' Petition is also supported by these groups.

	In general, the Department should be encouraging the creation of coordinated paratransit systems to allow for transfer-free travel by people with disabilities.   By allowing for a different methodology that still adheres to the original "two-times" limitation found in the DOT regulations, the Department would be encouraging large geographic areas to form coordinated paratransit systems.   Overall, I believe this would be a net positive for people with disabilities.

Title: David Norstrom
Comment:
I realize this is past the comment period, but I just became aware of the issue today.  Access is a unusual situation and to my knowledge the only organization of its kind.  The ADA is very straight forward in terms of the fare that can be charged.  I understand that Access would like an average fare to make it simpler on them.  However, the issue is complementary paratransit services.  For any trip within the service areas of any transit agency, the fare should be no more than twice the base fare.  Any trip in the LA Metro service area could be up to $3.50 with the LA Metro basic fare being $1.75.  For a trip entirely within the Foothills Transit service area the most that could be charged is $2.50.  For a trip entirely within the Culver City Bus or Big Blue Bus service areas the maximum fare would be $2.00.  With the technology available, when a trip is assigned a fare can be associated with it.  If Access provides a trip that crosses boundaries and is not within a single service area, such a trip is not required by ADA, since it it not complementary.  Access could set any fare it wanted for such a trip.  If a trip were entirely within two service areas, the lower fare would apply.  For example, if a trip in Santa Monica was within 3/4 miles of Line 20 and the Big Blue service area, the fare would be $2.00.

Using average fare is creating a basis for fares not is not necessary if the regulations are followed.

Title: Martin Erwin Anderson
Comment:
The Hill (http://thehill.com/blogs/congress-blog/246656-unbuckled-seat-belts-and-violent-turbulence-open-skies-and-trade)

Unbuckled seat belts and violent turbulence: Open skies and trade
By Martin Edwin Andersen
July 02, 2015

Portrayed in advertising as akin to a chic airborne Bedouin-and-breakfast oasis, three Middle Eastern airlines are wielding power more like 19th century robber barons  exploiting their workers at home while shifting valuable U.S. aviation jobs overseas.

The story behind these state-owned carriers  Qatar Airways, Etihad Airways and Emirates  shimmers like an illusion in the desert, luring world-weary travelers to the inn of supposedly Open Skies refuge. Incredibly, during a decade in which this trio is estimated to have received more than $42 billion in illegal subsides from the United Arab Emirates and Qatari governments, official U.S. policy has been to embrace the illusion, casting aside our ethical and economic interests in the process.

The issue is disturbingly similar to the all-but-signed Trans-Pacific Partnership, the massive trade agreement riddled with concerns about enforceable labor standards, subsidization, non-discrimination and other international norms. While the Middle Eastern Open Skies saga deserves attention in its own right, the lessons it teaches on the dangers of rushed and insufficiently transparent trade deals are needed now more than ever. After all, at the heart of the TPP debate has been the question of fast-track authority. By prioritizing speed over deliberation, once more the United States risks reliance on misconceptions, both skillful and willful. Let us instead actively revisit the errors of Open Skies in the hope that by righting one wrong, far greater harms might be averted. 

Currently, U.S. legacy airlines  American, Delta and United  face competitors with unfettered access to the worlds oldest democracy, a phenomenon fueled by ill conceived and rapidly negotiated bilateral agreements. All this generosity, however, has served only to displace U.S. airline market share. While Delta and United each offer only a single daily flight to Dubai and none to Abu Dhabi, Emirates alone flies to nine U.S. cities from its Dubai hub, now the worlds busiest travel nexus. 

Open Skies was meant to limit government interference in airlines commercial decisions. Implemented fairly, everyone prospers. But with the Gulf Statess near-monopoly, Open Skies has become open seasonon U.S. jobs, U.S. values and basic common sense. 

Just this month, the United Nationss International Labor Office found Qatar Airlines violated international law by flagrantly disrespecting womens rights. CEO Akbar Al Baker responded: I dont give a damn about the ILO. Perhaps this arrogance shouldnt come as a surprise. Human Rights Watch has been pointing out for years that Qatari law codifies discrimination against women. Even marital rape is permitted. 

Other labor abuses in the UAE and Qatar border on slavery; free speech is a profile left to the truly courageous; and ethnic, social and religious prejudices evoke the worst of the Confederate-flag-waving Jim Crow South. The Wall Street Journal recently noted that Emirates Airlines faces its most difficult labor challenges to date due to expanded shifts, restrictions on dress and mistreatment by supervisors  plus the fact that unions are illegal. While in the region, Secretary of State John Kerry correctly stated that such gross inequity rips and tears at the fabric of the rule of law.

In both Qatar and the UAE, the LGBT community faces state terror: In the former, gay relationships are punishable by death, while in Qatarnow mired in the FIFA scandal2022 World Cup fans were told they might be screened to detect homosexuality.

With one of the worlds smallest native populations  slightly more than a quarter-million  Qatar has the largest percentage, 88 percent, of non-nationals. Counting only native citizens, it is the worlds wealthiest nation. This begs the question: Aside from subsidizing airlines and constructing artificial island playgrounds, where does all that money go? David Harris, executive director of the American Jewish Committee, recently described Qatar as the ATM for jihadist groups. ...

The Hadith (the sayings of Muhammad) points to the manumission of slaves as one of the most meritorious deeds available for the expiation of sins. Let us help ourselves, as well as the peoples of Qatar and the UAE, to do just that, opening the sky only for those who repent.
__
Martin Andersen was a senior adviser for policy planning at the Criminal Division of the Department of Justice, where he received the U.S. Office of Special Counsels Public Servant Award, one of the highest awards for protecting national security information. He is also a former assistant professor of national security affairs at National Defense University and senior professional staff at the U.S. Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

Title: Matthew Perry - Comments
Comment: The government subsidies provided to foreign carriers, such as Emirates, Etihad, and Qatar air lines, is the equivalent of performance enhancing drugs in sports and athletics. The benefit of having fair play rules, like the Open Skies Agreement or a ban on steroids, is that it allows for a naturally competitive market. When we allow air lines that are subsidized by billions upon billions of dollars by their prospective governments to move into the U.S. market, we are essentially opening the U.S. market to cheaters. Now, not decades down the road, but now, is the time for the U.S. Government to establish a precedent for the kind of game we want to be playing when it comes to the air lines. Do we want a game where we allow the players with the deepest pockets, or best steroids, to be dominating the field, or a match between self-made competitors on an even playing field? When we allow foreign governments to influence our industries, we diminish one of this country's greatest economic benefits: a free market. Please consider the implications of allowing these foreign carriers to go unchecked and the damage it will do to an American industry that is still recovering from the tragedies of September Eleventh, an industry that has become heritage for this great country.

Title: John H.
Comment:

One of the routes I used to fly to Mumbai (Bombay) India has been eliminated because of unfair competition from the Gulf Carriers (Emirates Airways, Etihad Airways and Qatar Airways) flying from the United Arab Emirates (UAE) and Qatar.  Open Skies requires that each participating country flying to the United States is not subsidized by their government so as to offer unfair competition.  Emirates Airways, Etihad Airways and Qatar Airways have received over $40 billion in subsidies.  This is contrary to the Open Skies agreement.   

All new landing rights in the United States should be halted (as Canada and the Netherlands have done) now and a complete investigation done to ascertain the subsidies going to the Gulf Carriers (Emirates Airways, Etihad Airways and Qatar Airways).
