Title: John Carroll
Comment:
My name is John Carroll.  I'm a pilot for Delta and a retired AF Veteran of nearly 25 years. I am concerned that governmental subsidies have allowed Gulf airines to rapidly expand to the point
where they pose a threat to U.S. airlines, businesses big and small to further exand their economies beyond oil and gas.

Resounding evidence shows that, the state owned Qatar Airlines, Etihad Airways and Emirates Airline have
collectively received over $40 billion in government subsidies in the last decade. Together with the
subsidies, these unfair advantages virtually eliminate cost concerns for the Gulf airlines and fuels
massive growth in their fleet size and the number of routes they serve. The Gulf carriers have added
new capacity at rates that far exceed market demand. In order to fill this excess capacity on
international routes, they take passengers and revenues from U.S. airlines. In response, the big three
American carriers- American Airlines, Delta Air Lines and United Airlines will be forced off routes or will
reduce their service.

I am simply asking we level the playing field to ensure the ME3 abides by the Open Skies Treaty.  I will happily compete with them on a level buisness playing field, but with their subsidies the odds are heavily in their favor.  

When air service is lost or reduced jobs are lost. Every daily international roundtrip flight lost by the U.S.
airlines to the Gulf carriers equates to more than 800 good-paying U.S. jobs lost. Job loss will not be
limited to cities with large international airports  Atlanta, Detroit, New York and, but smaller cities throughout
the United States with regional airports that depend on regular service to the hubs of U.S. carriers.

Business owners and employees here are working hard to be successful. They should not be punished by the actions
of Gulf States. I am requesting that the U.S. government open consultations with Qatar and United Arab
Emirates in order to address the flow of subsidized capacity into the U.S. market. I also believe that the
U.S. government should immediately freeze the introduction of new passenger service by the Gulf
carriers during these consultations.

Title: Kirk Wise
Comment: I am writing to encourage a United States government response to violations of Open Skies policy by the gulf carriers. Failure to respond to these events present a major threat to American aviation jobs. As a flight attendant for Delta Air Lines I feel that it is in my best interest and the interest of my colleagues at Delta, American and United to encourage an immediate government response to end these violations. In the past 10 years the three Gulf carriers have utilized more than $42 billion in subsidies providing unfair advantages to these carriers over their U.S. competition. Please take action to prevent further damage to the United States aviation industry and the potential loss of American jobs like mine.

Title: Ana Hoover
Comment:
Gulf carriers, in fact, any carrier that has government subsidies have an unfair advantage under the open skies agreement of the USA. How can a carrier that is not state subsidized survive in a cuthroat competitive environment. 
US owned carriers are responsible for transporting and improving the country's economy by infusing much needed funds by each eligible traveler. 

In an environment where US owned carriers have consolidated in order to ensure survival, the US Government is essentially bleeding out the US carriers and promoting non US carriers. If this action continues, you will be hard pressed to see a US carrier remain in business. US carriers can not competitively compete against a Gulf Carrier that has deep pockets.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Im writing today as I am primarily concerned about the current issue with the three rising airlines, Emirates, Qatar, and Etihad. 
As I am sure you are aware, Emirates, Qatar, and Etihad receive $42 Billion from their governments to pay for their aircrafts, in doing so, they intentionally flood their markets with capacity as to beat out any remaining competition.  They receive no consequences for their actions; absolutely no financial penalties are pushed upon them for doing so.  
This issue directly impacts not only Atlanta citizens, but the U.S. as a whole. For every new route added by these airlines, 800 U.S. jobs are at stake. The President of the United States recently stated: We need only look to the Middle East and North Africa to see that large numbers of young people with no jobs and stifled voices can fuel instability and disorder." The fueled instability can be seen in the uselessly fully fueled jets they are flying the most popular destinations, stealing, from the rest of worlds markets. Soon, if Emirates, Qatar, and Etihad are not penalized for their actions, they will dominate the U.S. markets as well. 
I hope to see shortly in the future control taken on this manner. Many U.S. jobs are in jeopardy. If these airlines are not fiscally punished for their behavior, we will reward them with entrance into the United States of Americas well running industry. A colossal collapse of the industry and surely an economic decline on travel would instantly result.

These carriers have unfairly taken advantage of billions of dollars in subsidies in violation of this policy.  As a result, the Gulf carriers unfairly compete against U.S. carriers putting the airline industry, as well as, our economy in jeopardy.  Our economy relies on a strong airline industry, not only directly in the airline jobs, but indirectly through the vendors and other airline service employees. Furthermore, American business needs a strong, reliable and safe airline industry for transportation.  Violation of the Open Skies policy is a direct threat to this industry and our government must take action to prevent further violation.

Title: David
Comment: Dear Department of Transportation:  When an air carrier adds capacity and frequency to international routes, it is usually because there is a demand for such transportation.  Carriers of the Persian Gulf States (such as Emirates and Etihad) have been been adding dozens of new routes and frequency of flights at a rate far greater than any other Flag Carrier in the world.  The current world airline market does not support such risky business ventures.  But for the Persian Gulf carriers, it appears that the financial risk is being assumed (funded) by their host governments.  This is unfair competition, and unless it is stopped, the U.S. airlines will suffer greatly.  Thousands of U.S. jobs will be lost if U.S. airlines reduce international flying because they can't compete with the government-subsidized Gulf carriers.  The U.S. airline industry is a giant economic engine, and brings in astounding amounts of revenue to the U.S. Treasury in taxes and fees.  It would be a travesty for the U.S. government to not enforce existing world airline agreements, and not defend it's own airlines.  I write this as a concerned citizen, and airline employee.  Please do your part to stop the Persian Gulf Carriers from competing unfairly in the global airline marketplace.  Thank you.

Title: Thomas Larson
Comment:
I think it is extremely unfair that the government subsidized Sate owned Gulf carriers are allowed to operate under an "Open Skies" agreement while taking billions of dollars to offset their liabilities.  America has prided itself on free enterprise and allowing these carriers with their unfair practices to compete against the US carriers goes against all we are about.  As an employee for a US carrier I feel my career is in jeoperdy with these unfair parcatices.  This can be linked directly to the US economy as US jobs decline so does our counrty as a whole.  I am all for competition.  But tell me this, how can you expect to win the game when the opponet has unfair advantage?  When I was a child it was called CHEATING!  And it is still called that today.  The Gulf carriers are cheating at global business.  Even up the playing field, take their unfair advantage away, and then let the competition begin.  

Thank you for allowing me to speak.

Title: Sharon Griffies
Comment: I am a United States Citizen and an Airline Employee. A failure to properly respond to violations of Open Skies policy by the Gulf Carriers puts American jobs and spedifically my job at risk. Title: Taylor Smith
Comment: The backbone of the US economy is free market capitalism where businesses compete to provide the best product with the resources they have because of their business success. The Gulf Carriers destroy this concept by operating with an unrestricted subsidy, which allows them to provide a better product without planning for the costs of improvement. This gives them an extremely unfair advantage. The level playing field needs to be reestablished with common rules for all the players. This is a clear violation of the Open Skies Agreement.

Title: Josh Jessup
Comment: Allowing Gulf carriers to compete with our own domestic carriers while they are being subsidized by their governments is a violation of open skies and is putting the jobs of thousands of US airline employees at risk. These practices are detrimental to an industry that for the first time in history is finally being managed responsibly as a viable deregulated industry. Title: Ivan Ramon
Comment:
Hello, 

My name is Ivan Ramon and I am a Delta Employee. I wanted to comment on this issue because my job may be in jeopardy due to the unfair competition that these gulf airlines have against the aitlines in the US; Against my Air Line.
Gulf carriers are clearly a result of the massive amount of Oil money these countries have. You can see it on their cities, on the major advancements in their technology and how they have become competitive in the market place out of nowhere. Delta Air Lines for example, have been flying since the 1940's. Emirates or Quatar Airways?  Since 1985 and 1993 respectively. You can see how they started flying right when their countries became super wealthy with their oil. And like everything in their countries, they have been built by their royal families, ergo, the government. How fair is it for an "independent" and "private" company to get an approximately 40 BILLION subsidy? That is ridiculous! If any company in any market got a 40 billion dollar subsidy from the government, there is no way it could fail. Quite the contrary, they would be in an unfair position to compete with other companies in the world. Now, these company want to come to the US and steal the routes that Hard working American companies currently posses, won by fair competition between Airline companies in the world then that should not be allowed. Its time our government steps in to protect its companies and its peopole from these unfair airline companies that want to come and steal our routes, our jobs with support from their Oil tycoon governments.

Please help! Our jobs are on the line!

Thank you.

Title: Brandon Popinga
Comment: State-owned airlines in Qatar and the UAE have an unfair advantage in the global airline industry because of inequalities and biases toward the financing of these foreign carriers through the U.S. Export-Import Bank. We are using U.S. tax payer monies to give lower finance rates to foreign carriers when purchasing aircraft and it gives them a huge advantage to compile superior fleets at exceptional prices. This put the U.S. airline industry at risk, especially as we take a big picture, long-term view. U.S. airlines have long been world leaders in this industry as they have compiled the best safety records. The U.S. airline industry is a vital part of the U.S. economy, providing thousands of quality, high-paying jobs and is a chief economic catalyst as people travel by aircraft to accomplish the countries business. As Open Skies continues to expand it is vital to this industries survival that the playing field is level. The U.S. airlines need competitive aircraft financing to update their fleets and compete on a global basis. The forecast for the demand on air travel is continued and widespread growth worldwide as countries improve their own economies in developing areas of the world so this means the U.S. airlines have the opportunity to provide more U.S. jobs in the future through continued growth. That has to be both provided and safeguarded.  We cannot slip in an area that we already have so much expertise and brand recognition in, we must invest in continuing to grow U.S. airlines and safeguard those jobs in place. We have to legislate a fair playing field for all the worlds airlines so competition can still exist with fairness yet we should also promote our airlines just like we do our banks, car companies, and other companies that are of interest to the U.S. economy and way of life.

Title: Michael Sykora
Comment:
In the past ten years, three Gulf airlines have taken advantage of more than $42 billion in subsidies and unfair benefits to undercut companies like ours and tilt the playing field in international aviation.

I am a Delta Flight Attendant and I live in Minneapolis, MN - which is one of Delta's Largest hubs and an International Gateway for our Company.  Thousands of jobs in the Minneapolis area depend on the long term success of Delta.  I have proudly lobbied in Washington, DC on behalf of Delta and the Communities it serves and I strongly encourage the U.S. government to respond to violations of Open Skies policy by the Gulf carriers, and to know that American jobs - like mine - are at risk if the government fails to act now on this critical matter.  I, and my colleagues at Delta, along with the other legacy carrier's employees, ask for fair competition - a level playing field.  

Together we can ensure a level playing field for American Carriers and others who seek financing through the Ex/Im Bank who compete with other US companies and the men and women who work for Delta.

Our message to the U.S. government is simple: Enforce our Open Skies agreements, open consultations with the UAE and Qatar to address these subsidies, ensure that U.S. airlines are able to compete on a level playing field, and protect U.S. jobs.

Govt. subsidized airlines are also receiving low interest loans and cause an unfair competitive with US Airlines who must work for Profit and returns for the stockholders.

Title: J Wilson
Comment:
Dear Department of Transportation,
The Emirates Airline, Etihad Airways, and Qatar Airways are heavily subsidized by their state governments and have enjoyed very generous loans from the Ex-I'm Bank. I respectfully request you open discussions with the governments of United Arab Emerites and Qatar to negotiate a solution to violations to the "Open Skies" agreement. These airlines are operating unfairly in relation to all other world airlines. These airlines should be subject to the costs of the free market; their operations unfairly affect the jobs of those carriers who play by the rules of fairness and current agreements. Please remove their state subsidies, or remove their landing privileges in countries being affected by this unethical business practice. Thank you for your consideration.

Title: Erfath Chowdhury
Comment: The government subsidies provided to foreign carriers, such as Emirates, Etihad, and Qatar air lines, is the equivalent of performance enhancing drugs in sports and athletics. The benefit of having fair play rules, like the Open Skies Agreement or a ban on steroids, is that it allows for a naturally competitive market. When we allow air lines that are subsidized by billions upon billions of dollars by their prospective governments to move into the U.S. market, we are essentially opening the U.S. market to cheaters. Now, not decades down the road, but now, is the time for the U.S. Government to establish a precedent for the kind of game we want to be playing when it comes to the air lines. Do we want a game where we allow the players with the deepest pockets, or best steroids, to be dominating the field, or a match between self-made competitors on an even playing field? When we allow foreign governments to influence our industries, we diminish one of this country's greatest economic benefits: a free market. Please consider the implications of allowing these foreign carriers to go unchecked and the damage it will do to an American industry that is still recovering from the tragedies of September Eleventh, an industry that has become heritage for this great country.

Title: Janine Miller
Comment: PLEASE..... The U.S. government MUST respond to violations of Open Skies policy by the Gulf carriers. If you fail to act, American jobs are at stake. Safety is at stake.  Research shows clear parallels from the decline of the domestic shipbuilding industry in the 80s-90s to the present-day trade dispute with the subsidized carriers. Qatar, Etihad and Emirates have received more than $42 billion in subsidies and other unfair benefits from their government owners in the past decade, in violation of Open Skies agreements. The effects of foreign subsidization on our economy are substantial and detrimental, as jobs that are lost do not come back. Portions of the industrial base can be eroded, devastating companies and communities. If these foreign carriers are successful in shifting traffic from American companies to their own, then American aviation will suffer. If this foreign, subsidized capacity remains unregulated, the U.S. aviation industry will be decimated by a loss of almost 200,000 jobs, when considering losses from passenger traffic and those jobs supported by passenger aviation. So I hope the U.S. government will act on this issue of subsidized Gulf carriers distoring the global marketplace, and threatening our economy, jobs, communities, and families. Thank you

Title: Stony Lockridge
Comment:
Good Morning

I am a mechanic employed by a major airline. I am also in the military and have been to the countries that compete for our domestic business. We have been through bankruptcy and have come out stronger but lost major benefits and a large partion of our retirements forever and substantial pay cuts at the time. These other airlines do not have to face bankruptcy or see driving competition to keep cost down to stay competitive. This is a delicate issue with global cooperation with allies and political relationships that are important. I have four children and a wife. We have now started putting our 1st through college and God has graciously alllowed us to help her, through my income and no student loans so far. My shop now has 12 less people that last year and we are doing 20% more work which proves how competitive we are. Our healthcare has gone up over 80 percent in the last few years. I would ask that you consider keeping unfair competition in check because we are doing our part in being more productive with less people. We monitor our health diligently and are driving those cost down also. I know international relationships are delicate and sometimes difficult to maintain, I am just asking and praying for your wisdom as you make these decisions affecting domestic jobs in a prudent manner. Thank You

Stony Lockridge

It is very difficult to understand why they are allowed to fly to the United States under and open skys agreement and take costumers away from Airlines that must rely on their own means to pay for such things as "Fuel", "Wages" "Aircraft" and other operating expenses.

We must keep our airlines healthy so they can compete fairly in the world market.

Title: North Houston Association - Comments
Comment:
June 10, 2015

Secretary Anthony Foxx
U.S. DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION
1200 NEW JERSEY AVENUE, SE
WASHINGTON, DC 20590

Re: Open and Fair Skies Policy
Dear Secretary Foxx:

The Houston Airport System and United Airlines have been strong partners with the North Houston Association for more than a decade. We have worked closely with these partners to help further the growth of the North Houston region.

It has come to our attention that a small group of state-owned airlines in the Arabian Gulf (Gulf carriers) are alleged to be receiving substantial subsidies from their governments, which would violate the longtime Open Skies policy designed to foster healthy competition.

While we recognize that the Gulf carriers play a key role in this growth, the legacy US carriers should be given an equal opportunity to provide service along the same routes as the Gulf.

The North Houston Association urges the federal government to investigate these allegations, and, if proven to be true, take appropriate action by opening a dialogue with the governments of Qatar and the United Arab Emirates to address such subsidies.

Sincerely,

Alex Sutton 			        Jon Lindsay
Chairman of the Board 		President

Title: Richard Merrell
Comment: Foreign carriers, many of them state owned and /or subsidized by their governments should not have Open Skies access to the U.S. air market.  Many of these countries have very limited markets within their own borders making any reciprocal flying by a U.S. carrier in their internal markets unfeasible and uneconomical.  Landing fees charged by U.S. airports are far less than those paid by U.S. carriers at foreign airports.  U.S. airlines face questionable financing and opaque managements unwilling to fully disclose subsidies being paid by their respective governments.  Without foreign markets and without subsidy, Qatar and the UAE would be completely uncompetitive.  Allowing Qatar and the UAE to fly within the U.S. would be highly detrimental to U.S. airlines, their employees, and would only benefit these small, heavily subsidized middle-east carriers.

Title: Todd Patterson
Comment: Hello.  With respect to the US airlines (American, Delta, and United) protest of current US Government Open Skies policy with respect to the Mideast carriers (Emirates, Ethiad, and Qatar), I urge the DOT to carefully consider the issue and re-evaluate our Government's current position on Open Skies with the Mideast carriers.   I urge the DOT to respond, and address head-on, the valid and important allegations made by the US carriers with respect to the obvious and material violations of our Open Skies policy by the Mideast carriers.  It should come as no surprise here that with respect to the current, ongoing, gross violations of our Open Skies policy by the Mideast carriers, important and valuable and numerous jobs here in the US are directly at stake.  Jobs both within the US airline industry, and like all big industries in the US and around the world, jobs in all of the industries built up and operated to support the US airlines, which provide incalculable benefits to the American public in terms of providing efficient and fast global air transportation.  I believe the case here, on its face, is immediately obvious, and on that basis alone I urge the DOT to respond immediately to the Open Skies policy violations by the Mideast carriers.  That such violations are obvious, and immediately harmful, is clear:  how on earth could just one airline of the three (Emirates), operate out of a massive airport in the desert, and be currently building another, and operate/have on order over 140 Airbus 380 aircraft, which can seat over 600 passengers in their current two class configuration.  Where are these tens of thousands of people who are going to fly on these aircraft?  In Dubai?  Hardly, with a population of merely 2 million?  It is on its face absolutely obvious, and the whole scheme is clearly absurd to anyone who looks at this issue.  The US airlines are vital to our country, and have struggled for decades post deregulation.  They receive no assistance from the US government, even in the face of our government providing massive subsidies to certain industries in the US (eg, farm subsidies).  The US airline industry is forced to stand on its own and compete globally like most companies in the US.  But with the Mideast carriers, how do they possibly have the hundreds of billions of dollars required to buy all these massive expensive new aircraft - answer:  through government subsidies to these carriers.  How on earth do they intend to make a profit flying these massive, fuel intensive, expensive aircraft, when common airline industry analysis shows that it is the fare for the last and final seat on a 100 seat aircraft that provides a profit, whereas the other 99 seats merely permit the carrier to cover its operating costs?  If Emirates does not fill their 140 500-600 seat A380s (75000) seats every single day on every flight, they will not turn a profit - but why should they care!  They are not competing on the global stage, they are wholly-funded by the state and their operating costs and paid for through state subsidies.  This puts our US carriers and other global airlines, who do have to compete, earn back their cost of capital and answer to shareholders, at a great disadvantage.  Especially when the Mideast carriers have a very small base population and native passengers of their own ... so they will just poach the passengers flying US airlines, which is frankly an attack on our country and must be repelled.  I urge the DOT to take up immediate review of this gross violation of our current Open Skies policy by these Mideast carriers.  The US airline industry, and all of the millions of jobs it creates and supports, is vital to the national security and national interest of the US, and vital to providing and maintaining efficient and affordable air transportation for the 300 million plus US citizens. Thank you.

If allowed to continue, they will, due to artificial market forces, erode the viability of US airlines, leading to loss of jobs within US airlines and the travel and service industries that depend on them.  I ask that the US Department of Transportation take all appropriate actions in keeping with its mission to Serve the United States by ensuring a fast, safe, efficient, accessible and convenient transportation system that meets our vital national interests and enhances the quality of life of the American people, today and into the future. Title: Joset Wright-Lacy - Comments
Comment:
Dear Secretaries Foxx, Kerry and Pritzker:

The National Minority Supplier Development Council works to advance business opportunities for certified Asian, Black, Hispanic and Native American business enterprises. We connect these businesses to our corporate members in an effort to increase procurement and enhance supplier diversity.

As an organization, our leadership and members are becoming increasingly concerned about the impact of government subsidies and other unfair benefits that have been provided to state-owned airlines of Qatar and the United Arab Emirates (UAE) over the last decade.

Qatar Airways, Etihad Airways and Emirates Airline have collectively received at least $42 billion in government subsidies and other unfair benefits in violation of U.S. Open Skies policy. These subsidies are contributing to excess capacity, which draws passengers and revenue from U.S. airlines. If U.S.-based airlines continue to lose market share, this uneven playing field will lead to service cuts and job losses. Experts believe that each route that is lost to Qatar, Etihad or Emirates will result in an average net loss of 821 good, high-paying U.S. jobs.

If the US government does not act, minority-owned small businesses will feel the effects of these job losses through fewer contract opportunities and lower revenues. Ultimately, our regional economies will suffer as supply chains will be less robust and competitive.

The U.S. Census Bureau stated that, Minority-owned firms are an engine of job creation, demonstrating the highest levels of new job growth and company formation compared to non minority-owned firms. Minority-owned firms generate over $1 trillion in economic output in this country and are part of the backbone of the American economy. The big three U.S. carriers, Delta Air Lines, American Airlines and United Airlines all understand this critical work. They are members of our organization and have helped to shape the global supplier diversity landscape. United Airlines alone spent over $1.1 billion with diverse suppliers. 

On behalf of our members and constituents, I urge the U.S. government to not impede the growth of small, minority-owned firms that are so crucial to our countrys economic growth and open consultations with Qatar and the United Arab Emirates (UAE) in order to address the huge subsidies that those nations provide their state-owned airlines. NMSDC also believes that the U.S. government should seek a freeze on the introduction of new passenger service by the Gulf carriers during these consultations.  

Sincerely,
Joset Wright-Lacy
President

Title: Vernon Wagner - Comments
Comment:
The business model being promoted by the Gulf carriers is very disconcerting.   The US major airlines are the first to ring the alarm bell but other airlines are affected as well.  In the USA we have embraced the idea of fair competition.  We did not endorse South Korea dumping below cost steel on the US market and we should not allow the Gulf carriers to pull off their version of the SK steel dump either.  The Gulf carriers try to equate US bankruptcy protection laws with their version of subsidies and equity stakes, with one glaring flaming exception.  BANKRUPTCY LAWS APPLY TO ALL BUSINESSES IN THE US.  Only the Gulf carriers benefit from their country's subsidies, fee waivers, interest free loans, and equity stakes.  When a loan will NEVER BE REPAID, it is not a loan.  
This directly affects a rare success story in the United States.  Aviation related jobs in the US are multi-generational. Pilots and flight attendants fly for the same companies their parents worked for.  These are good paying labor jobs where someone with a clean record can make a decent income without being a member of upper management.  Families depend on these jobs in New York, Miami, Atlanta, Chicago, Los Angeles, Phoenix, Melbourne Florida, San Antonio and Shreveport.  The point is in many cities in America, these are the top labor jobs in the area.  We used to say the same thing about the maritime shipping industry.  Now, the Maritime industry in America is generally shrimpers and lobstermen, fighting for scraps on run down boats while Filipinos and other third world nationals work for wages we pay at Wendy's. 

Airline workers pay taxes and contribute to American society.  Airline workers lead their families by example and teach the nobility of labor, buy going to work and bringing home a living wage. Unfair competition by the Gulf carriers (to be honest, their governments) threaten this multi-generational industry in America. The choice before you is clear.  Do you want to support American families or Qatari investors and foreign workers?  

One other issue before you is something not often mentioned, but literally the elephant in the room no one discusses.  The huge US military base in Doha Qatar is whispered about but not really addressed.  Let's be clear.  We defend the entire region there Saudi Arabia, Qatar, Kuwait, Bahrain, UAE; from the Iranians and provide stability for their monarchies.  Please do not allow the sacrifices from American servicemen (who overwhelmingly come from working class American families) to be used against our interests in dealing with the Gulf carriers.  It would be especially galling to have the parents of American servicemen, serving at Al Udeid AB in Qatar get furloughed as a result of your lack of action.  We provide a needed service to the Gulf region by stationing our sons and daughters in the region.  Do not allow the issue of Al Udeid to be used against the parents of the American servicemen in the region or the Reservists and Guardsmen that work in US Airlines.  

Arrogant and misinformed politicians will tell us, "you dont understand the bigger issues".  We do understand, and we expect you to help defend our jobs from unfair foreign competition.

Title: Thomas Taylor - Comments
Comment:
To whom it concerns,
I am writing regarding my concern of the practices of the Gulf Carriers, Emirates, Etihad and Qatar.  As part of the Open Skies agreements, it is hardly fair that these State Owned carriers have received tremendous financial support in the form of various subsidies from their governments(40B+ over 10 years). The gulf carriers are not creating new market share, they are just capturing it from carriers like DELTA, American and United and that is hurting the US carriers ability to compete fairly in these foreign markets. Competition on a level playing field is what the Open Skies Agreement is about and these carriers need to be investigated for their violations of that agreement.  THEIR VIOLATIONS are threatening the future viability of a strong US Airline industry that is able to serve its vast domestic markets as well as destinations around the globe.

Title: Michael Dorsey - Comments
Comment: Please stop,this travesty of the Gulf Carriers exercising their rights in open skies agreements. They don't play by the rules. Their governments heavily subsidize them both financially and with under market fuel. They create no new traffic, only siphon off flying  from other airlines. They have very lax labor law. Let's  make open skies agreements that have airlines competing by the same rules. Let's level the playing field.

Title: James Mckay - Comments
Comment: THE PLAYING FIELD SHOULD BE EQUAL.  GOVERNMENT RUN AIRLINES AND CANNOT COMPETE EQUALLY. WITH PRIVATE ENTERPRISES DUE TO THE FINANCIAL ADVANTAGES THEY HAVE.

Title: Mark Vosmek - Comments
Comment:
As an American citizen and airline employee with over 25 years in the industry, I am encouraging the DOT to address the
current situation in the Gulf that is creating an unfair playing field for US airlines.  The state-owned Gulf airlines of
Qatar Airways, Emirates, and Etihad have all received heavy subsidies from their respective governments that virtually
make it impossible to compete on an international level for our airlines here in the US.  Doing nothing will create a situation
that destroys American jobs and careers in the US airline industry.  Doing nothing will do untold damage to the US airline
industry and virtually hand over all international level flying to these Gulf States.  They know this and are planning
accordingly with record level orders for large international aircraft to penetrate and destroy our international market share.
Please act now and don't let this happen. Now is the time to act not after the damage has been done!  Thank you for hearing my
opinions on this issue.

Title: Anonymous - Comments
Comment: I encourage the US government to respond to the violations of the Open Skies policy by Gulf carriers and to protect American jobs, like mine. American jobs are at risk if our government fails to act!!!

Title: Richard Kneeland - Comments
Comment:
State owned airlines of QATAR and UAE will dominate the world international markets with unlimited government  funding.
This must be stopped by new Open Skies agreements to stop this illegal activity and loss of many many American JOBS.

Title: Joel Gannon - Comments
Comment:
Hello,
As a longtime U.S. airline employee, I emphatically request that the DOT do a thorough inspection of the state owned airlines against the requirements of the "Open skies" treaties.  These airlines and perhaps others are in violation of the original agreements by providing funding from the state's treasury, rather than normal competition based revenues.  Their actions provide an out of balance playing field and the subsidies need to stop.  Additionally, these airlines should be fined if found to violate the terms of the treaties.

Sincerely,

Joel Gannon

Title: Jennifer Munns - Comments
Comment:
I respectfully request that there be serious consideration concerning the flagrant violations 
of open skies regulations by the Gulf carriers.  I work for Delta Airlines and this is vitally important for both my airline and my job.  Thank you.  Jennifer Munns

Title: Anonymous - Comments
Comment: I encourage our US government to respond to the violations of the Open Skies policy by the Gulf carriers and to protect American jobs like mine. American jobs are at risk of the US government fails to act!!!

Title: Darby Huntington - Comments
Comment:
"For the people, by the people of the United States of America."  This should be the slogan we rally around regarding the abuses of the "Open Skies" agreement.  In our country we embrace a free market economy, so long as it is realitively fair.
Why?  Because we view ourselves as a land of opportunity, where anyone can make something of themselves if they work hard enough.  Is life always fair? No, but we have made great strides to protect the individual from being run over by unfair competition- such as monopolies and bribes.  

The airlines in the United States do not receive the same favorable loans and subsidies that the gulf carriers do, which gives them an unfair competitive advantage.  One only need to look to the European and Australian carriers, to see how their international business has been decimated by this unfair advantage.  We are next unless we renegotiate a truly fair agreement.  To not do so would be to risk loosing hundreds of thousands of airline jobs, revenue, and even national security.  
The loss of jobs, and revenue is obvious, and so should the fact that our government relies upon our domestic airlines to transport the bulk of of troops all over the world in times of conflict.  What happens to this uplift capability if the gulf carriers take over international travel?  

For the above mentioned reasons we must renegotiate the "Open Skies Agreement" and make it truly a level playing field, 
too much is at risk not to!

Please do the right thing.

Thank you,

Sincerely,
Darby Huntington

Title: Neel McSwain - Comments
Comment:
The only desire of U.S. airline workers is the ability to compete on a level playing field.  Our airlines are neither state owned nor supported and we feel allowing Middle East carriers who are supported by their governments to compete in the free market place disrupts fair and open competition. Over the last decade, the state-owned Gulf airlines of Qatar Airways, Etihad Airways and Emirates have received over $42 billion in subsidies and other unfair benefits from their governments in an effort to dominate the global aviation marketplace. The U.S. airlines and their workers cant compete against the enormous handouts that are harming American jobs and vital airline service to communities across the country.
I ask that you review and amend where necessary the Open Skies agreement between the United States and the countries of Qatar and the United Arab Emirates. The final agreement should ensure fair competition. Without fair competition the airline industry of the United States will become like the shipping industry of the United States, practically nonexistent.

Title: William Shinners - Comments
Comment:
I am a pilot for a United States based commercial air carrier. I fly into Dubai in the United Arab Emirates.  I constantly see 
the large quantity of commercial aircraft being flown by Emirates Airlines.  I am not afraid of competing against any air carrier
as long as I compete on a level playing field.  This is not the case with Emirates Airlines and several other Middle Eastern air
carriers.  I am encouraging the U.S. government to respond to violations of the Open Skies policy by the Gulf carriers. These 
violations are a direct threat to my job as well as many other American jobs if the U.S. government fails to act.  My company is  
not afraid of tough competition.  Just let it be fair.

Title: James Sullivan - Comments
Comment: I sincerely urge you to look in to and take action on Gulf Carriers subsidies. They have more aircraft on order than all of the US carriers combined, by almost twice. They are intent on poaching international traffic at below industry standard fares due to the subsidies they have received. They have used US Taxpayer monies to buy much of their fleet through the ExIm Bank. Open Skies was designed for fair and bilateral trade, not a dumping ground affair where 600 seat, subsidized, super-jumbos undercut fair competition. For countries that have no work rules and lax enforcement of regulations this all adds up to the death knell for fair competition and our US airlines international routes, profits, taxes, and thousands of US workers jobs. Do nothing and our industry will become what our shipping industry is now, a hollow form of its' previous self. Would you trade away your jobs to a country or individuals that will do it cheaper at any cost and with no governance? Another added point, thousands of our workers, from pilots, mechanics and all manner of ground support workers are former military, do you want to stiff them also?

Title: Brian Hoffmann - Comments
Comment:
I am writing to encourage the U.S. government to respond to violations of Open Skies policy by the Gulf carriers!
Failure to enforce these policies put American jobs, like mine as a Delta Air Lines Pilot, at risk if the government fails to act.
WE HAVE STOOD BY LONG ENOUGH!  NOW IS THE TIME THAT WE MUST TAKE ACTION!
HELP PROTECT US JOBS!


Respectfully submitted,

Brian M. Hoffmann
CAPT     US NAVY

Husband of 23 years and Father of 4

Title: William Demiris - Comments
Comment: What is commonly refered to as the global economy is at times a means for some companies to gain an unfair competitive advantage in markets such as the U.S. by circumventing rules, regulations and other business norms which U.S. Companies must follow. Further more U.S. airlines do not get subsidies from our government as do some foreign carriers further putting them at a disadvantage.

Title: Anonymous - Comments
Comment: protect our Nation aviation jobs , stop the rapid expansion of the non US carriers to our airports

Title: Blas Miyares - Comments
Comment: I highly encourage that the US gov respond to violations of open skies policy by the gulf carriers. These violations are a direct threat to american jobs like mine at Delta Airlines.

Title: Robert Stevens - Comments
Comment: Receiving financial support from an airline's home country does not seem at all fair.  The playing field should be leveled as much as possible!

Title: Anonymous - Comments
Comment: As a professional pilot, Fair skies directly impacts my country, community, and profession.  Fair competition is a an airline's right. Simply put, please protect the U.S. Airline industry, preserve fair competition among ALL carriers, and enforce violations of Open Skies rules by the Gulf carriers.

Title: Multiple Submitters - Comments

Title: Stanley Hill -  Comments
Comment:
I am a Delta Air Line pilot  

It is not in the spirit, or substance,  of the Open Skies police that private corporation in the USA (or other countries for that matter)  should have to compete against the state-owned Gulf airlines of Qatar Airways, Etihad Airways and Emirates.  They have received over $42 billion in subsidies and other unfair benefits from their governments in an effort to dominate the global aviation marketplace. 

We in the U.S. airlines cant compete against the enormous handouts that are harming American jobs and vital airline service to communities across the country.

Title: Michael Brady - Comments
Comment: I'm writing to you today to encourage you to respond to violations of the 'Open Skies policy by the Gulf carriers(Emirates Airline, Qatar Airways and Etihad Airlines, a.k.a. ME3). The American airlines can compete with, even dominate, any airline in the world given a level playing field. The ME3 have been allowed to steal market share from other airlines around the world, including U.S. carriers, thru massive government subsidies, estimated at over $42 billion, by the UAE and Qatar. Not only has this resulted in fewer U.S. jobs, it results less income tax collected by the U.S. Treasury. Eliminate the subsides now and level the playing. Only then will the competition be fair.

Title: The Asian/Pacific Islander American Chamber of Commerce & Entrepreneurship (National ACE) - Comments
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: LiUNA Laborers Nevada Local 872 0- Comments
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: James Yoger
Comment: I am writing you today about my concerns for the very unfair practice supported by EX-IM Bank that is severely hurting one of the most important industries in the U.S.- The Airline Industry. The EX-IM Bank Giving access to billions of dollars of low-cost loans to other foreign airlines such as Emirates and Qatar the purpose of low cost financing of aircraft is directly hurting our U.S. Airlines because the cost of aircraft acquisition is so much higher and therefore the cost of doing businessis so much greater.  This directly affects what US airlines must charge  for tickets and therefore directly affects their ability to attract and retain customers vs. their subsidized competition.  Being one of the most important industries in the United States the airline industry accounts for over 10% of GDP when considering the US airline industry and all the complementary and flow-through business these airlines support.   The US airline industry is the model for the rest of the world and sets the bar high for professionalism and  safety standards. We must not weaken our US airlines for it takes many years & a lifetime of dedication for someone to become an airline pilot such as myself.   These just are not jobs these are very serious professions that have many lives at stake and we cannot afford to lose the strength of this most important US industry.  Our country needs and deserves the very best safe and strong  US airline industry.  This can be done by allowing US carriers to compete effectively by denying any further foreign carrier US subsidies through the EX-IM  Bank to and allow them to compete on a level playing field.

Title: David Towne - Comments
Comment:
As a pilot for United Airlines and US Air Force pilot,  I find it difficult to see how our government can support outright anti competitive subsidies to foreign airlines that will cost thousands of middle class jobs.

 Over the last decade, the state-owned Gulf airlines of Qatar Airways, Etihad Airways and Emirates have received over $42 billion in subsidies and other unfair benefits from their governments in an effort to dominate the global aviation marketplace. The U.S. airlines and their workers cant compete against the enormous handouts that are harming American jobs and vital airline service to communities across the country.

David Towne

When is our government going to wake up and defend our vital US airline transportation industry. In the spirit of fairness and compliance of Open Skies agreement, US government should take more aggressive steps in preserving American competitive and jobs--namely preventing the government funded Gulf carriers to take more routes.

This type of violation places American jobs and my positions a pilot at Delta Air Lines at risk. It is imperative that a review be completed to create a level playing field for all carriers.

Title: Anonymous - Comments
Comment: I have worked for United Airlines for 29 years and am deeply concerned about the unfair business practices of State-Owned Airlines in Qatar and the UAE.  It is difficult to compete in the airline industry under regular situations but how can we expect to compete fairly if these foreign governments are providing "perks" like free or underpriced fuel etc.  If they want to do business in our country they need to play fair!

Title: James Dunn - Comments
Comment: I am requesting that the US Department of Transportation and elected officials investigate potentially unfair subsidies received by Qatar and UAE owned airlines and make clear the desired course of action to remedy this potential distortion of the aviation industry.

Title: Rebecca Jones - Comments

I am encouraging the U.S. government to respond to violations of Open Skies policy by the Gulf carriers, and that American jobs  like yours - are at risk if the government fails to act.

Please Act Now!

Title: Robert F. Britton II - Comments
Comment:
They can label it however they wish.  The fact remains that the Gulf State carriers are receiving "benefits" from their respective
governments that cast a huge unfair advantage onto the worldwide aviation scene.  Their simple minded idea to counter the 
bad press by saying "we'll skip Boeing and buy Airbus next time..." is hollow rhetoric.  

Look at the facts, Boeing is pushing 50+ 737's a month out of their factories, in addition to B-777 freighters, B-787 Dreamliners, 
B-747-8 Freighters, 100+ KC-46's for the Air Force, and over 100 more aircraft for FedEx.

Don't allow their unbridled growth (through government subsidies) to kill off American jobs in the airline industry.  We need to 
protect the travelers by protecting the American workers who provide that service!

Thank you.

Robert F. Britton II

Title: Richard Lester - Comments
Comment:
Over the last decade air carriers from the Gulf States have had a unfair advantage over US carriers. Government
subsidies for carriers like Qatar, Etihad, and Emirates have violated open skies policies.
I urge you take action to remedy this unfair competitive advantage and level the playing field for US carriers.

Title: LaShawna McFadden - Comments
Comment:
I am encouraging the U.S. government to respond to violations of Open Skies policy by the Gulf carriers, and that American jobs  are at risk if the government fails to act.

Title: David Clayton  - Comments
Comment: I urge the US government to respond to the violations of Open Skies policy by the Gulf carriers. Their government's violations by providing huge subsidies to offset thier operating costs are causing a risk to hundreds of thousands of US employee's jobs. The US governmant must act!

Title: Snir Cohen - Comments
Comment: As a flight attendant for a major U.S. Carrier, I have watched as these unchecked subsidized gulf airlines are damaging all of the U.S. Carriers. Many things they do are clearly in violation of the open skies agreements. If they aren't going to abide by the agreements they signed with us, something must be done to protect our interests. The state dept and DOT must get involved and stop the damage this is doing to US aviation.

Title: Michael McDonald - Comments
Comment:
Over the last decade, the state-owned Gulf airlines of Qatar Airways, Etihad Airways and Emirates have received over $42 billion in subsidies and other unfair benefits from their governments in an effort to dominate the global aviation marketplace.  
This is in direct violation of our Open Sky agreements.   Why we let these companies have access to our markets when the access to there markets is limited by their governments and by the size of the countries.  US airlines only operate into one airport,  Dubai,  while we let these airlines have access to most of our major cities.
This arrangement hurts our competiveness and is ludicrous on face value.  These countries are not our allies or friends and actively support terrorism.  We need to stop looking the other way at this violation and put a stop to it.

Title: Paul O'Halloran
Comment: I am a pilot for a major U.S. passenger airline. Since 9/11, this industry has been buffeted by an unending and historic stream of negative factors ranging from terrorist attack, SARS/MERS, a Great Recession, and a decade of unprecedented energy costs. We have weathered every storm so far, but the tools of downsizing and consolidation are defensive in nature, and they have been used.  Yet now we are under economic attack from a trio of massively subsidized, mid-east carriers that are blatantly violating open skies agreements with massive fleets of aircraft from nations whose traveling populations are grossly insufficient to warrant such operations.  These carriers are extensions of their nation states and do not operate under the framework of 'fair' and competitive practices that open skies agreements are based on. If allowed to operate in violation of open skies, these 3 carriers will achieve the demise of the U.S. travel industry and the multiple jobs, both directly and indirectly, related to it.  I implore and encourage the U.S. government to respond to violations of Open Skies policy by the Gulf carriers, and protect American jobs and economic interests.

Title: Ken Martinez
Comment: I am encouraging the U.S. government to respond to violations of Open Skies policy by the Gulf carriers, and that American jobs  like mine- are at risk if the government fails to act.

Title: Marcie Swanson
Comment: I am encouraging the U.S. government to respond to violations of Open Skies policy by the Gulf carriers, and that American jobs  like mine - are at risk if the government fails to act.

Comment:
It's time we start putting American jobs first. A level playing field of fair competition is not too much to ask. The U.S. airline industry is vibrant providing thousands of citizens with good paying, quality jobs. The U. S. Airline industry has been highly competitive since deregulation. We can compete with these carriers fairly with some help from the DOT.

A strong U.S. airline industry is good for the economy and it's citizens. Please help.

Title: Robert Halvorsen
Comment: I encourage the US Government to respond to violations of Open Skies Policy by Gulf carriers. Thousands of American jobs are at risk if the Government fails to act. Please help stop the funding of the expanding Gulf carriers in direct competition to American expansion and jobs. Gulf carriers can buy US made aircraft with low interest funding provided by their own governments. We should not be funding the expansion of airlines that directly compete with US jobs.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Protect American jobs!!!

Title: Bruce Mason
Comment: I am asking our goverment to respond to rules of fair skies and save some american jobs

Title: Thomas Scott Jones
Comment: There is no denying the massive amount of illegal subsidies that forensic Accointing has shown the three large middle eastern carriers receiving.  They are not adhering to the agreement spelled out by the Dept. of State open skies agreements.  They are and will continue to have an unfair market advantage ultimately dwindling the United States and European carriers in to purely domestic markets or worse- non existence.  This direct threat to our economy will manifest in the loss of jobs, GDP, quality corporations, and have widespread effects on those who rely on them.  The U.S. Can compete in a global level with each of these carriers if they are held to the same standards. Currently, they are not.  I urge the powers reading this to open an investigation immediately and request immediate compliance with the open market agreements we have signed.   This is a direct threat to our economic and national security.

Title: Keith Shewbart - Comments
Comment: Please recognize the unfair practices the Middle East Air carriers utilize in the United States. This results in unfair competition and ultimately impacts American jobs. Please just level the playing field as it pertains to the airlines. Thank you.

Title: Edwin Thiel - Comments
Comment: Please address the unprecedented subsidies received by the Mid East carriers and it's effect on legitimate airlines of the world.

Title: William Shivell - Comments
Comment:
Over the last decade, the state-owned Gulf airlines of Qatar Airways, Etihad Airways and Emirates have received over $42 billion in subsidies and other unfair benefits from their governments in an effort to dominate the global aviation marketplace. The U.S. airlines and their workers cant compete against the enormous handouts that are harming American jobs and vital airline service to communities across the country.

Additionally, they are purchasing these aircraft using discounted financing through the EX-IM Bank, which amounts to the U.S. taxpayers subsidizing these foreign carriers even more, placing U.S. carriers at an even greater disadvantage.

It would seem that, through Open Skies and our own EX-IM Bank, the U.S. government assisting the Gulf nations, their state-owned carriers and the foreign workers they employ, ahead of U.S. carriers and American employees - the very same taxpayers that are funding these programs!  

When will Congress end these disastrous economic policies?

Title: Eric Schoenbaum - Comments
Comment:
I'm writing to encourage our US government to review and respond to violations of the Open Skies policy by the Gulf Carriers (Qater, Emirates and Etihad).  Not only are airline jobs at risk, for me and my colleagues at Delta Air Lines, but large numbers of American jobs can be negatively impacted if our government fails to act on these violations.  

The Gulf Carriers have an unfair competitive advantage flying nonstop to many markets in the United States however the US network carriers (Delta, American & United) have very limited service into this region on a nonstop basis from the US.  They are saturating the US market with seats and routes that aren't supported by the capital market.  In contrast they have prevented the US carriers from providing similar service into the Gulf region which is a violation of the Open Skies policy.  

As these carriers dominate several US markets it causes the US carriers to react by reducing or eliminating service (as we have already done here at Delta).  This change in service not only has a negative impact on airline jobs but the thousands of ancillary businesses that support the airline and the operation.  These are American jobs that are at risk from the aggressive expansion plans of the Gulf Carriers.

I urge our US government to take action quickly to review these violations of the Open Skies policy by the Gulf Carriers to prevent any additional loss of American jobs to the foreign competition.

Title: Buddy Steele - Comments
Comment: I feel, it's gives an unfair advantage, for air carriers to be subsidized by their governments. It won't matter if they make a profit or not, they can operate and expand more easily,with the extra monies supplied by their respective governments. They need to restricted in some form or fashion, to make the playing field equal to all.

Comment:

Title: Peter Sahler - Comments
Comment: I would like you to please carefully consider the impact of these state owned airlines subsidies and their impact on our economy. I am really concerned over a level playing field when it comes to our vital air travel.With the over $42 billion in subsidies and benefits from foreign governments, these airlines can virtually buy their way into markets with no concern of price and competition. The U.S. airlines and their workers cant compete against this type of economics and American jobs are at stake.

Title: Commissioner Jack Morman - Comments

Title: Joseph Judkins - Comments
Comment: I've worked in the airline industry for over 30 years and most of that time, the airlines made little or no profit. Now that the industry is making a profit, I would hate to see it go back to employee layoffs due to unfair competition. Please let the airlines compete on a level playing field

Title: Samuel Curry Jr.
Comment: I am an airline employee that is deeply concerned about the business practices of state owned air carriers. Therefore I am encouraging the U.S. government to respond to violations of Open Skies policy by the Gulf carriers, in order to protect American jobs like mine - that are at risk if the government fails to act.

Title: Gary Dickinson
Comment:
Although on the surface giving a consumer the right to chose and the cheapest fair available seems like a great thing to do, in the case of State owned Airlines, it goes against the fundamentals of our democracy.  We believe in fair competition and in this case this is not fair.  It has been proven on numerous occasions that sate-owned airlines are heavily subsidized which gives them a huge advantage over US airlines.  They are able to undercut current fares, provide services which are cost prohibitive and undermine free competition with US carriers since they are not responsible for making a profit without the help of their governments.  In addition, if allowed to continue to fly without respect to the open skies agreement, US jobs were be severely threatened and in the end will cause catastrophic results to the travel industry and the thousands of  individuals employed in this industry.  In addition, competition will dwindle and in the end, fares will be much higher than they are today.  Lastly, the US government will lose the ability to protect its citizens from unfair practices in the travel industry.  

Therefore, I am asking that the US government to respond to the violations of the Open Sky agreement currently occurring.  The livelihood of thousands is at risk if the US government does not respond.  Thank you.

Title: Gregory Olson
Comment: Tell the U.S. government that it must act now to enforce our agreements with these countries  and save American jobs in the process.

Title: Michael Berggren
Comment:
allowing these airlines to operate freely in the U.S is a blow to all U.S air carriers. Either we must be subsidized by our own government or we must not allow these airlines to operate freely in this country. We can not compete on a free playing field with welfare airlines it just make no sense to allow this to continue. If they want to compete then these airlines should not be owned by there respected governments. 

Thanks Michael L.A Berggren

Help America! Help Americans keep their jobs.

Comment: I am encouraging the U.S. government to respond to violations of Open Skies policy by the Gulf carriers, and my job is at risk if the government fails to act.

Title: Sean Bradford
Comment:
Hello.  My name is Sean Bradford

I am an airline pilot with Delta Air Lines.  I am writing to urge  you to  respond to the violation of the Open Skies policy by the Gulf carriers such as Emirates, Eithad and Qatar Airlines.  These foreign air carriers are being subsidized by their respective governments.  This has resulted in absolutely unfair competition against our U.S. airlines to include Delta. 

Unless these carriers are required to adhere to the open skies policy and compete fairly with our U.S. airline industry we will lose hundreds of thousands of jobs in the United States.  Additionally, our U. S. airline fleet is of strategic importance to national defense as it participates in the CRAF (Civil Reserve Air Fleet) in times of national crisis.  Our airlines must remain in business and healthy in order to be there when our country calls

We have the best most competitive airline industry in the world. We can compete with any other airlines as long as the playing field is fair.  Please do what is right by our nation and its citizens and require these foreign airlines to compete under the same rules that our own airlines abide by.

Thank you,
Sean Bradford

Comment: I am encouraging the U.S. government to respond to violations of Open Skies policy by the Gulf carriers, and that American jobs are at risk if the government fails to act.

Title: Marjorie Todd Speight
Comment: I am encouraging the U.S. government to respond to violations of Open Skies policy by the Gulf carriers, and that American jobs  like mine - are at risk if the government fails to act.

Comment: How about taking care of our own by protecting our home industries as other countries do, stop sacrificing our workers on the alter of open free markets when you know they are anything but free.

Comment:
I is well past time to level the business environment that state subsidized foreign airlines operate under.
