Title: Rob Nelke
Comment: The U.S. government must respond to violations of the open-skies agreement by Gulf carriers. The U.S. negotiated this treaty, and now it must enforce it's provisions. The Gulf carriers have been violating the spirit and letter of the agreement for many years now, and American jobs have already been lost. Act now to save the jobs that remain.

Title: Michael Grosman
Comment: i am  are encouraging the U.S. government to respond to violations of Open Skies policy by the Gulf carriers, and that American jobs are at risk if the government fails to act

Title: Jason J. Mastanduno
Comment: At a time when the U.S. airline industry is finding ways to become stabilized and profitable, it's more imperative than ever to make certain that the bankruptcies, massive layoffs, deep cuts, and restructurings of yesterday are not for naught.  Fair Open Skies must be on the U.S. government's agenda so that world-wide aviation can thrive on its own merits alone.   U.S. airlines must not compete against governments.  The U.S. government must investigate and determine what is going on here and take seriously the research collected by Delta, United and American.   Consider not the politics of it but the individual lives of every U.S. airline employee (and dependent industries) whose way of life depend on the U.S. government to be on their side.    Way to go Delta Air Lines for taking the initiative!  Department of Transportation: it is incumbent of you to take into consideration all arguments from all sides and, where appropriate, take swift action in the realization of equal and fair open skies as open skies truly intended, without loopholes exploited by any foreign carrier to the long-range detriment of our home carriers!

Title: Bruce Ellis
Comment: Dont give away my job. Do the right thing and enforce the Open Skies agreement.

Title: Dino Pomeran
Comment: I am encouraging the U.S. government to respond to violations of Open Skies policy by the Gulf carriers because American jobs are at risk if the government fails to act

Title: Pete Ferraro
Comment: Level the playing field for US carriers. State owned airlines in the Middle East have an unfair competitive  because of massive government subsidies. US jobs are at stake. Let US airlines compete fairly.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: The state owned airlines, Qutar, Etihad, and Emirates Airlines are exploiting the Open Skies policy by receiving over 40 billion dollars over the past 10 years in subsidies from their respective countries. We cannot afford these airlines to come here and take over our jobs and life careers. I do not agree with the DOT to allow this to happen.

Title: Mark F
Comment: To whom it may concern: My name is Mark. I am a husband and father of two. I am the sole bread-winner for my family, and an employee of Delta Air Lines, Inc. I want it to be known that I am encouraging the U.S. government to respond to violations of Open Skies policy by the Gulf carriers. I work in Delta's Global Sales division, and know first hand that we can compete with ANY CARRIER IN THE WORLD *** if the playing field is level. *** If the government fails to act thousands of jobs, and the livelihood of tens of thousands of American homes could be lost. I am not willing to allow that to happen, and am doing my part to beg that you act on the behalf of myself and my family (and those like us)!

Title: Nathan L.
Comment: I encourage the U.S. government to respond to the violations of Open Skies policy by the Gulf Carriers. American jobs are at risk by allowing the Gulf Carriers to continue their unfair business practices in the global airline industry. As Americans we should all stand together to protect our people and the jobs that support those people. It is not ethically or morally right for any private industry to rely on government subsidies to conduct its business. All businesses should have a level playing field so that only their own investments and business decisions make the difference between winning and losing in the marketplace. It would be wrong for the U.S. government to step in to help a private entity in the U.S. survive, and we should stand united to fight other countries from doing the same since the airline industry touches global markets. In the end, not taking a stand against unfair global practices would also take away from American taxes as there would be a smaller American tax base to draw from given the loss of American income and jobs. We should all stand together to build a stronger U.S. airline industry and support free and open skies for all both foreign and domestic.

Title: Charlotte Pyle
Comment:
OPEN AND FAIR SKIES:  

We want a fair playing field!  The US government must inforce our agreements with state-owned airlines in the Middle East.  Qatar Airways, Etihad Airways and Emirates have set out to dominate global aviation by exploiting Open Skies policy with more than $42 billion in unfair benefits and subsidies.  US jobs are at risk if our government fails to act!  Again, please make the skies fair!!

Title: Todd Hensley
Comment: Open Skies implies rights AND RESPONSIBILITIES. Qatar, Emirates and Etihad claims the right but none of the responsibility for fair global competition.  With the backing of sovereign wealth funds of their home countries, below market rates for capital expenses and fuel, and aircraft orders that can in no way support reasonable growth, they are systematically destroying the US aviation industry by providing below cost service.  Ultimately the Middle East carriers are all that remain unless the US and global aviation regulators ensure that we all compete by a common set of rules.

Title: Jonathan Boyne
Comment:
With more than $42 billion in unfair benefits and subsidies in the last ten years, state-owned Qatar Airways, Etihad Airways and Emirates have set out to dominate global aviation by exploiting Open Skies policy.

We have a chance to speak up and fight back, but only for a little while longer. The U.S. government that it must act now to enforce our agreements with these countries  and save American jobs in the process.

Title: Lynn Hardwick
Comment: It appears that Arab Gulf carriers are not adhering to the Open Skies Agreement.  I urge the DOT to respond to violations of Open Skies policy by the Gulf carriers.  American jobs  such as my own -- are at risk if the government fails to act.

Title: William Waldron
Comment: As a proud employee of an incredible company, and the largest Global and US carrier, I encourage our leaders to please consider the negative ramifications on people like myself and our thriving company if we continue to allow the Gulf Carriers to grow as rapidly as they are currently.

Title: John T.
Comment: The state funded airlines from UAE and Qatar are a total sham.  Let's LEVEL the planning field immediately!

Title: Samuel Curry Jr.
Comment: I am an airline employee that is deeply concerned about the business practices of state owned air carriers. Therefore I am encouraging the U.S. government to respond to violations of Open Skies policy by the Gulf carriers, in order to protect American jobs like mine - that are at risk if the government fails to act.

Title: Michele Waters
Comment:
I encourage the United States government to respond to the violation of the Open Skies Policy by the Gulf carriers.
My job and the jobs of other United States of America's citizens are at risk if the U.S. government fails to act on this.

Title: Cindy Curphey
Comment: As a 37 year Flight Attendant for Delta Airlines I am fully aware of how difficult times for us can get in the airline industry.  We are finally almost back to where we were 25 years ago with our pay scale after giving everything up.  Do not make us all go back to industry slashing so you can allow these subsidized airlines to take our jobs.

Title: Anonymous - Comments
Comment:
American Airlines, Delta Airlines and United Airlines are afraid of competition. They are scared of foreign competitors encroaching on their turf. At its core, Open Skies seeks to avoid just this fear. The fact of the matter is that so many foreign carriers--and not just those from the Gulf--now provide far more favorable products, enhanced service, younger fleets and lower prices than do U.S. airlines. We must keep the skies open if we want our home airlines to improve themselves and stay competitive. Curtailing the activities of the Gulf carriers will set back the aviation industry as a whole.

As a frequent flier from the U.S., most of my miles are flown on the big three U.S. carriers. I support the U.S. carriers. But as a former student of Economics, I support market competition; as an aviation industry enthusiast, I believe in Open Skies.

Title: FedEx - Comments
Comment: Please see attached.

Title:
QATAR AIRWAYS: DELIVERING CONSUMER BENEFITS
MADE POSSIBLE BY US-QATAR OPEN SKIES
Comment: Qatar Airways: Delivering Consumer Benefits Made Possible by U.S.-Qatar Open Skies

Title: US Travel Association
Comment: See attached document.

Title: Southwest Airlines Pilots Association - Comments
Comment: See attached Second Letter in Support of Public Consultations & Proposal of Remedies

Title: Robert Rover
Comment: Please address the unfair loans and benefits foreign carriers are receiving and using against US carriers.

Title: Steve Lion
Comment: I feel the gulf states airlines are violating the open skies agreements with government subsidies . Their is no way they came buy all the new aircraft without the gulf states government giving them money.

Title: Trent Woodworth
Comment:
Hello,
I'm writing to explain that I am encouraging the U.S. government to respond to violations of Open Skies policy by the Gulf carriers, and that American jobs are at risk if the government fails to act.

Please hold these carriers accountable for their government-sponsored subsidies. These subsidies are contrary to international agreements and give them an unfair advantage. 

The United States economy does not need one more reason to lose jobs. Airfair is low across the board, please support US Air Carriers and US jobs. 

Thank you,
Trent Woodworth

Title: David Gilliland
Comment: I am urging you to act now to enforce our open skies agreements.  Qatar and the UAE  are subsidizing their airlines to the tune of 42 billion dollars thus far to ultimately dominate the international airline industry.  This outrageous violation will lead to the loss of tens of thousands of U.S. airline jobs.  Whose side are you on????  Stand up for your fellow Americans !!!!!!

Title: Kent Muilenburg
Comment: I am encouraging the U.S. government to respond to violations of Open Skies policy by the Gulf carriers, and that American jobs are at risk if the government fails to act.

Title: Eric Shiigi
Comment: I am an airline employee and for years all USA based airlines have a significant disadvantage towards them with the Emirates airlines which is subsidized by their government so in other words they cannot go bankrupt but on the other hand USA airlines can go bankrupt as it has shown in the last 15-20 years,(of course they also had incompetent CEO's and incompetent executives to blame also) but all in all USA airlines had to fend for themselves with this unfair ruling. I myself went through many bankruptcy and layoffs due to this contributing factors.If our own government cannot protect us who will?Enough of this nonsense and let these Emirates airlines play on a level field!

Title: Law Offices of Amy Chelini, P.C.
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Ellen Persons
Comment: As a resident of Central Florida employed in the tourism industry, I fully support keeping the Open Skies policy as is.  My company is reliant on inbound international visitors, and the Open Skies policy has allowed not only our business, but the US inbound tourism industry in general,  to grow in leaps and bounds in the past 10 years.  Many do not realize that tourism is actually an "export" and that it employs millions of people in the US - hotels, restaurants, theme parks, shopping venues... the list goes on.  The 3 big US carriers are concerned about their profit margin, bottom line. This will not destroy American jobs. On the contrary, forcing out the Gulf carriers (or anyone else that the US legacy carriers may perceive as a threat now or in the future) would limit competition, choice and availability, and ultimately thwart growth in international visitation. Emirates is scheduled for non-stop service from Dubai to Orlando September 1st, and the estimated economic impact is $100 million annually.  Now THAT supports a lot of jobs.

Title: Patz Turner
Comment:
"Airport leaders are tapping a variety of sources to pay for everything, including winning state and federal grants, spending reserves of $56 million, agreeing to sell bonds and extending a $4.50 fee affixed to every passenger ticket and a $2.50 surcharge on cars rented within 48 hours of a traveler touching down at Orlando International."  Orlando Sentinel reporting from Frank Kruppenbacher regarding the financing of the OIA airport.

This is the same thing, and we are not confused that "state and federal grants" are taxpayer dollars, financed by the US government for the benefit of the airlines.  Do not stop international traffic to gift it to companies that benefit and a cost to the tourism marked.

Title: Dallas Larson
Comment: I am encouraging the U.S. government to address the Gulf carrier subsidies and other unfair benefits that are violating Open Skies policy and harming American jobs

Title: Comment from Jeff Strachan
Comment:
Dear Sirs,
Having observed the open skies debate and grievance submitted by the "Big 3" American carriers, I can only observe that their intentions are driven by the realization that they are and have well and truly missed an opportunity. They failed to effectively plan a strategy which took into account the emergence of a rapidly growing source market in Asia, Africa and the Middle East. They failed to effectively plan for route expansion and aircraft to compete on those routes and quite honestly the lack of strategy and planning is appaling. Now, having realised they missed a beat, they would like to enter those markets by asking for government intervention. Effectively they want government to shut down competition so that they can then move into the routes. 
Really, they should enter the markets and compete. They have had plenty of opportunity to do so. If they had had the market intelligence, the courage, the fleet, then they would have been able to gain first mover status on all of those routes. Fact is, they were so wrapped up in creating a commodity on their own domestic markets, that they failed to realise a growing middle class in India, China, South East Asia, East Africa and of course a youth bubble in the Middle East. Their lack  of understanding of potential source markets should embarrass them. Yet, they fail to admit to past strategic failures, they dream up a whole host of 'excuses' and rather than be held accountable for their strategic failures, they are asking for help!

This is and should not be the behaviour of what should be respectable CEO's. They should be pouring their energy into their businesses, focusing their teams on how to grow, how to bring a better fleet, how to drive service and how to drive prices up, not commoditise their offering. As great American leaders, they should not cry and bleet like children, they should step up to the plate, offer dynamic, brave strategies, designed to win market share and customers. 
Friends in Government, your Airline leaders are failing the people of America, the people should be embarrased of them. You are a country who should make things happen, you are the epitome of the capitalist system, you want to compete and you want to win. You cannot complain when you miss the boat, you have to take that on the chin, rise again and design strategies to win. These CEO's just don't like having one over them. Their predecessors are the guilty ones. They had no-one taking care of future forecasting back in 2002/3. When the GCC countries employed American futurists to map out the next 20 years, the American airlines couldn't see past their back garden. That's the real story of how this happened. 
The corporate world is littered with companies which failed to effectively plan for expansion. Your airlines fit into that area. 

Allow me to reiterate, this has nothing to do with open skies, this has to do with airlines wanting a slice of a huge Pie that they initially failed to identify as Huge. Now they are crying.

Title: Comment from Mohammed Elkaderi
Comment: I believe the open skies agreement should stay. Is the US trying to reduce globalization? If US carriers are facing difficulty getting customers due to Gulf carriers providing outstanding service, they might as well improve themselves. As for the fuel prices, I believe a fair compromise can be to make a unified global market for fuel that has a single volatile market price, therefore allowing all carriers to feel the same burden. As for the alleged startup aids by governments in the Middle East, there is no solid evidence that any financial aid has occurred. Once evidence on the fact that this has occurred arises, then I highly disregard my opposition to the banning of these airlines and tip my hat to you guys...

Title: Edward Hasbrouck
Comment: See attached file.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
American Airlines should be required to comply with 14 CFR 399.83, which states, in relevant part:

"It is the policy of the Board to consider the practice of an air carrier, foreign air carrier, or ticket agent, of stating to a prospective passenger by telephone or other means of communication that a reservation of space on a scheduled flight in air transportation is confirmed before a passenger has received a ticket specifying thereon his confirmed reserved space, to be an unfair or deceptive practice and an unfair method of competition in air transportation..."

American Airlines' own internal general rules define "ticket" as:

"The 'passenger ticket and baggage check,' including all flight, passenger, and other coupons therein, issued by carrier, which provide for the carriage of the passenger and his baggage."

When American Airlines (or any airline) issues an "electronic ticket" to a customer (an "other means of communication" from the perspective of 14 CFR 399.83), much of that information is missing, leaving the consumer at a disadvantage if the terms of the ticket are brought into question.

Allowing an airline to ignore this rule leads to a situation where one party to the contract of carriage (the airline) is able to set and enforce non-negotiable and undisclosed conditions against the other party (the passenger).  The airlines have historically been more than willing to enforce these terms when it is to their advantage, yet the passenger - to whom these conditions were never disclosed - is unable to enforce these same conditions against the airline, or even defend himself from the airline's enforcement.

This is not a new concern.  Indeed, 14 CFR 399.83 was put in place to protect consumers from exactly this sort of deceptive practice.  Airlines cannot be allowed to pick and choose which rules they will follow and which they will ignore -- doubly so if they cannot be relied upon to follow even their own rules.

Thank you

Title: Michael Gran
Comment:
I have followed with interest this complaint by Mike Borsetti where it appears that American Airlines has been charging an incorrect amount of tax, but, that the extent of the error is not discoverable by a consumer because their e-ticketing documents lack a complete pricing breakdown.

American Airlines has always been my preferred airline, and I fly it a few times a year.

It seems fair that their e-ticketing documents provide this pricing breakdown information, especially since it appears to both be required by existing rules and that providing that information is not burdensome, since it already exists in the Sabre system.

To be honest, I'd always had great faith in American Airlines ability to charge appropriate taxes and fees, but, now that mistakes seem to have occurred, I need enough information that I can double-check the specific taxes and fees on my tickets in future.

Thank you.

Title: Kevin Hawkins
Comment: If an airline creates a ticket for you within its computer system (specifying in detail the terms of the contract by which you are bound, and by which the airline should also be bound), you should be entitled to have a copy of it, as under current law.

Title: James Martin
Comment:
It is clearly an unfair, deceptive, and harmful practice for AA to claim that terms are binding on purchasers, when a 
copy of the ticket containing those terms is not accessible to the ticket purchaser. An airline's attempt to prevent essential  free-market information and trade by not providing the "ticket holder" with a reasonable break-down of what he is paying for should not be allowed to stand.

Title: Richard Segal
Comment:
Full ticket and tariff information is vital for consumers attempting to receive fair treatment from an airline.
Please enforce the existing rule and make clear to ALL carriers that this is an important set of information that they MUST provide.

Title: Sanjay Saigal
Comment: In a laws-based society, it makes no sense for an airline to sell me a service (often expensive) without the benefit of a legally-binding contract. As a 2+ million mile flyer, I strongly urge the DOT enforce its rules obliging airlines to provide an actual ticket (electronic is fine) with all terms spelled out.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: A virtual ticket is a ticket, and it is not ok for the airlines to say otherwise. It is essential that airlines must continue to provide the information in the ticket to passengers. When there is an issue, we need to have all the information tickets provide so that we can know what redress is possible. When airlines keep the information from us, it puts the customer at a tremendous disadvantage when something goes wrong.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Well, AA is my preferred flyer, but I would like to make informed decision about the taxes and fees so I won't be overcharged. If the airline creates a ticket for me in its computer system that specifies the terms by which the airline and I are bound by, I am supposed to have a copy of it. 

The information about taxes and fees seem to already exist in their system, so it won't be a big issue for the airlines to supply the information. Please think of us consumers!

Title: Antoine Bastien van der Meer
Comment:
Dear DOT,

In my opinion, airlines should follow the provisions contained in 14 CFR 399.83, and the DOT should enforce them.  Otherwise, the flying public has no recourse against airline fraud, misrepresentations, and mistakes regarding ticket terms (and pricing).

It is well known that U.S. airlines, notably American, United, and Delta routinely attempt to defraud (yes, defraud), or otherwise take advantage of their passengers.  Other than the tarmac rule, passengers have little, if no recourse against predatory carriers.

Based on the foregoing, I respectfully urge you to enforce the provisions of 14 CFR 399.83 against American Airlines in this case, and require that it provide a ticket to Mike Borsetti and all other passengers.

Sincerely,

Antoine J. Bastien van der Meer

Title: Benjamin Duffy
Comment: The ticket is the closest thing to a 'legally binding document' between the air carrier and the passenger. When a passenger is unable to view all of the details that they are entering into, it makes it difficult for them to confirm that the air carrier has issued the ticket according to their, and the government's, guidelines.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Airlines in the United States have lost the public's trust because they so often don't abide by regulations and are not transparent.  The passenger is at a disadvantage while traveling because they are away from home.  Please keep airlines from taking advantage of us!  I am a US citizen, have traveled on airlines since 1969, but don't want to post my name because, again, I have heard stories of the airlines punishing (illegally, perhaps) passengers for complaining (e.g. United Airlines had a passenger removed from a flight for tweeting a neg comment about a flight as it was leaving the gate).

Title: Anonymous
Comment: It is important that consumers be given paper tickets by airlines, so as to have all the ticketing information. Thank you.

Title: Douglas Rice
Comment:
While I am generally a fan and happy customer of American, It is completely unreasonable of them to suggest that a passenger should not receive a complete record of what they have purchased.  Many aspects of travel depend on information that is not disclosed on American's confirmations, and while I can usually get the information by calling them, this isn't useful when written proof is needed.  

The lack of fare basis codes makes it impossible to determine the refund rules, eligibility for upgrades, eligibility for premium seating, and eligibility for frequent flyer mileage accrual.  The baggage allowance is also important; under the rules of a ticket I once purchased from American I was entitled to three pieces of baggage on my entire itinerary (because a trans-Atlantic segment was ticketed in first class).  My return itinerary included an intra-Europe segment on British Airways that had no first class cabin, and I was permitted only two pieces at check-in.  While the website confirmed my entitlement to three, the agent was unwilling to check, and lacking documentation proving my entitlement to three, I was unable to check the third piece.  If I had had a paper ticket, it would have indicated the allowances for each segment.

I believe that all airlines should be required to provide as part of a ticket confirmation, all of the information that may be needed to prove what we have purchased.  For DOT to rule otherwise means that the carriers can change the rules at their whim without any knowledge on our part.

Title: David Finden
Comment: Please ensure that all airlines are required to show the entirety of information related to pricing breakdown by segment and other related information to any requesting passenger.  The airlines should not have any additional information advantage by storing of tickets on their systems.  As a reminder, e-tickets work well because they provide logistical advantages to both the air carrier and the passenger.  This works, however, only if both parties can view the entire terms and conditions of each ticket including its underlying makeup.

Title: Erik Glitman
Comment: Please require that all airlines fully disclose the terms and conditions of any ticket issued and provide a full copy of the ticker terms, rules, and conditions including all components of the final price in the electronic version of the ticket. Require that all airlines provide a full breakdown of all final price components, less add-ons made after purchase, in the electronic version of the ticket accessible to all ticket purchasers.

Title: Suzanne
Comment:
James Martin said it well: "It is clearly an unfair, deceptive, and harmful practice for AA to claim that terms are binding on
purchasers, when a copy of the ticket containing those terms is not accessible to the ticket purchaser. (Any) airline's attempt
to prevent essential free-market information and trade by not providing the "ticket holder" with a reasonable break-down
of what he is paying for should not be allowed to stand."

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
If I am held to the rules, restrictions and penalties associated with an airline ticket, I should also know what my rights are as well as the responsibilities of the airline in question in providing the transportation paid for.

It makes perfect sense that I should be able to get a complete document/ticket, if I request it, that outlines all rules, restrictions, fares, taxes, rights and responsibilities of both parties, etc. Otherwise, I am clearly at a disadvantage is anything out of the ordinary occurs.

The airline will exercise its rights and will quote the rules and restrictions of the ticket, so it should share all of that information at the time of ticketing, so we enter the contract at a level that is fair to both parties.

Title: David Morty
Comment: Make the airlines comply with the applicable federal regulations until such time as they are changed.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I support the right of passengers to receive a full and complete copy of their ticket. 
Thank you.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Why are airlines allowed to impose contract rules never fully disclosed to consumers?  Rules are routinely referred to only by reference, buried deep within internal documents (which may or may not be available online and when they are available online they are often included under tangential, irrelevant or illogical categories), vaguely worded, subject to discriminatory application and interpretation is left solely to the airlines' discretion.  "Rules" are also routinely made up by front line employees for their own convenience.  Even worse, airlines routinely hide (and often deny the existence of) Federal Government mandates from the flying public at the moment when airlines commit infractions; airlines often claim remedies contrary to Federal mandates are the "best they can do."  

When a passenger/customer requests an airline follow the law or its own rules, the passenger/customer runs the risk of being barred from contracted transportation or even banned for life--without recourse.

It's far past time that the Department of Transportation enforce its existing rules and impose rules that assure the equitable treatment of passenger/customers.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
This information is vital to ensure that taxes, fees, and relevant details such as fare class are easily available to customers. Not having this information prevents customers from being able to accurately verify transactions, add/collects, and other situations where calculations occur.

Finally, full names of tax codes, fee codes, and other charges need to be displayed so customers are aware of what's being charged.

Title: Arlene Lea
Comment:
Not just AA, but all airlines should comply with US Federal regulations (14 CFR 399.83)  which requires airlines to provide each ticket purchaser with a ticket,  It is not being done by American and may others.  If the airline creates a ticket within its computer system (specifying in detail the terms of the contract by which you are bound, and by which the airline should also be bound), I should be entitled to have a copy of it.   Airlines already make money on baggage charges, but without an actual ticket, the consumers can't tell if taxes and other charges or accurate.  Booking a flight is supposed to provide us with the cost information.  The ticket should show the necessary information too.

American Airlines should be sanctioned for failing to comply with the federal regulations AND required to comply immediately.

Title: Michael Collins
Comment:
It is clear that AA currently does not routinely provide their customers with the level of detail regarding the breakdown of fare, taxes and fees that was traditionally provided by a paper ticket, or by the e-ticket confirmations in use by most other airlines.  As a result, Mr. Borsetti and other passengers were unable to determine what the breakdown of taxes and fees they were being charged was, and were unable to verify their correctness.  There is no technical reason why this information cannot be provided to customers routinely, and the applicable regulation gives the department the authority to compel it.  It is in the public interest to improve transparency, as it helps prevent unfair and deceptive practices, such as the overcollection of taxes that occurred in this case.

The department should compel AA to provide, at a minimum, equivalent information to what would have been provided on a paper ticket.

Title: Amy Fey
Comment: When I fly, I expect that I will have the most complete information on my ticket, not an abridged version. When an airline creates a ticket (specifying in detail the terms of the contract by which you are bound, and by which the airline should also be bound), I am entitled to have a copy of it. This is the only way in which I can be assured that the contractual agreement which the ticket represents is carried out by the airline.

Title: Ken Lavender
Comment:
the law (14 CFR 399.83) states that AA *MUST* supply a ticket *MUST* follow the law.

they are not the congress.  if AA thinks the law is outdated, then they need to get congress to change the law.

you have a duty to uphold the law and this law is on  the books.

please do you job!

:)

Title: Mark Thompson
Comment: From the documents provided by the complainant, it is clear that American Airlines is willfully refuting the relevant regulations requiring it to provide its passengers with all the information spelled out when it issues its tickets. I encourage the Department of Transportation to rule in favor of Mr. Borsetti and refund him what he is rightly due, and to also require American Airlines to provide the required ticket information to all its passengers.

Title: James Gerber
Comment:
It is outrageous to allow airlines to hold the only copy of the ticket and not provide a ticket at required in the regulations.  In the event of a dispute, the traveler has no record of what they actually purchased and cannot provide evidence that they are due a refund for example.  

The ticket need not be a paper document.  All the DOT need do is require the airline to provide the customer with an electronic document containing all the information formerly provided on a paper ticket.  This could either be by email or on demand at the carrier's website.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Ticketing requirement should remain a requirement. A ticket contain all necessary information that both sides can reference.  A detail ticket presents a summary of the transactions that has occurred.  Without a detail ticket, the traveler really doesn't have the relevant information to know what they purchased.  By not providing a ticket, the airline is not proving proper disclosure of the transaction and therefore can hide non-relevant charges or exotic restriction unbeknownst to the traveler.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: If an airline ticket represents a binding contract for services rendered by an airline to a traveler, it is only right that both parties to which the contract binds have equal access to the terms of that contract. Obviously, the airlines already have this access; the traveler should have access also. The DOT should enforce the requirements set forth in 14 CFR 399.83.

Title: Lawrence Slavin
Comment: I think in today's electronic age it is necessary that customers have a right to see all the details of their ticket transaction as is required under 14 CFR 399.83.  I believe that while making the purchase the customer should be able to request a copy of the Virtual Coupon Record to be included in the email confirmation.  As well as after the transaction and even after the flight.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: As a frequent traveler, I want all airlines to supply all travelers with a complete copy of airline tickets purchased.  Often times, electronic tickets do not contain all of the details, which are required to be supplied by the airlines, as noted in US regulations.  Please require airlines to automatically provide that information to all who purchase tickets, no matter whether they purchase full fare tickets, discounted tickets, or tickets with accrued miles.

Title: Nathanael Wales
Comment: Airlines should be required to provide customers with a proper ticket, even if electronically, containing all flight coupons.  These coupons are available to airline employees serving customers and should also be available to customers themselves.  This would make all ticket terms for each flight segment transparently available to the customer.  Withholding this information is unfair and deceptive; much like other contracts, a customer may not read these coupons and their terms unless there is a problem--and that's precisely when and why the customer should have them readily available.

Title: D.L. Egan
Comment: If the airline creates a ticket for a passenger within its computer system (specifying in detail the terms of the contract by which one is bound, and by which the airline should also be bound), the passenger should also be entitled to have a copy of it. Since most tickets are now virtual, issuing an electronic ticket with all information should not actually cost the airline any additional monies.

Title: Bill Howard
Comment: It is important for our financial system to work with integrity that all fares and their relevant taxes be clearly displayed to consumers before any financial commitment by the consumer is made.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
Consumers have few rights with airlines anymore.  Airlines can and do whatever they want to schedule, reschedule, cancel, and otherwise mess with flights and the consumer just has to, literally, sit back and take it...then fight via endless email battles while the airlines claim "circumstances out of their control (when they usually aren't) to avoid compensating passengers for their negligence or incompetence let alone rudeness.

This case is even worse.  They are violating DOT regulations and attempting to change the regulations by stating they are archaic.  Ignorance of the law or refusal to abide by it does not make it any less obligatory.  Mass power the airlines have amassed due to government deregulation has afforded them an arrogance they are not entitled to.

Force American to comply with the requirement to disclose all "ticket" information to the passengers so that we can protect ourselves in this little way as intended by the DOT.  Then tighten the loopholes and reins around the airlines so they can't produce poor service that truly has an impact on a paying customer that, under current regs, has little recourse.  It's not like we can go to another car dealership who treats us better.  We're down to a few choices for air travel, especially in some locales, and the airlines know they have a 1 in 3 shot of getting our business no matter how they treat us.  If this is how they run their "customer service", think how shoddily they maintain their planes.

Title: Lynn Hamper
Comment:
As a previous travel agency owner, I am appalled by American Airlines' actions against providing relevant information for a passenger's ticket.

How can an airline not provide information for validity dates, prices paid, date the ticket was issued (this bears on future ticket reissue expiration) and faring?

This will be an immense accounting problem for corporations, and meeting and event planners with corporate discount codes and prices and meeting fares and code.

There is no business I am aware of that refuses to give the customer a receipt for which they will be held to on rights of the passengers.

Please, DOT, make this right and fair for the traveling public.  It's a travesty if American wins,.

Title: Nancy Weisberger
Comment: It is unjust of American Airlines to impose rules and regulations governing a purchased airline ticket without providing said rules and regulations in their entirety to the consumer.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Airlines are required by DOT regulation to provide passengers with complete ticket information, not just a little subset as they all do now. DOT's failure to enforce their own regulation demonstrates that (like so many other federal agencies) the DOT is in fact operating to protect and serve the airlines and not the public as it was created to do. I cannot imagine how unethical and immoral people like you can sleep at night, and go to church and claim to be Christians (or otherwise religious).

Title: Anonymous
Comment: In this day and age of e-[everything], it becomes even more imperative that consumers are provided in a verifiable method the T&Cs of their transaction.  Airlines should not be allowed to use omission of this information to their enrichment at the expense of said consumer.  The fact that the technology of today, and more so of the future, facilitates communication does not eliminate the original intent of the regulations that consumers be protected by receiving the details of their transactions.  In fact, progressive technology should make it even easier and not be used as an excuse to hide information or no longer provide it.  Only idiots and those with ulterior motives would argue otherwise.

Title: Carrie Johnson
Comment: If an airline creates a ticket for you within its computer system (specifying in detail the terms of the contract by which you are bound, and by which the airline should also be bound), you should be entitled to have a copy of it, as under current law.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: if the airline creates a ticket for you within its computer system (specifying in detail the terms of the contract by which you are bound, and by which the airline should also be bound), you are entitled to have a copy of it.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I wish the rules in place be enforced :

AA's violation of 14 CFR 399.83

We need clear information to travel safely and with ways to protect our self

Title: Rainer Waseem
Comment:
Please require all airlines to provide all the details included on the  Virtual Coupon Record (VCR), which contains all of the information previously included on paper tickets.
Also please impose significant penalties to encourage American Airlines and all other airlines to provide this information. I would suggest  a penalty of 10% of the cost of the ticket for all tickets issued without complete information be refunded to the ticket purchaser on any airline.

Title: Sam Linder
Comment:
Since an airline creates a ticket for me within its computer system (specifying in detail the terms of the contract by which I am bound, and by which the airline should also be bound), I am entitled to have a copy of it.

Please enforce 14 CFR 399.83!

Title: Stephen Cristofar
Comment: If we, the ticket-purchasing passengers, are entitled to fully-documented tickets, or copies thereof, then the airlines must be required, without exception, to provide them.

Title: Susan Burstad
Comment: I've read Mr. Borsetti's complaint, the American Airlines response to the complaint, and Mr. Borsetti's recent (6-12-2015) response to the American Airlines offer to refund the overcharged taxes collected from his flight in question in exchange for his releasing all further claims.  I've been a public school educator for 33 years, and I've always had the privilege of teaching young people (America's future caretakers) to meet the obligations of an agreement (contract) that they willingly enter into. On the flip side, I've always taught these same young people how to be stewards of the obligations they make to others.  Are these not the basic concepts of fairness and the equality of all parties concerned?  The most powerful teaching tool I have at my disposal to reinforce what I've taught is sincere and correct modeling of the concept.  It was with overwhelming astonishment that I realized that the broader picture of Mr. Borsetti's complaint is that when a person enters into a contract (CoC) with another entity and pays money to seal the contract, a copy of the contract (ticket) is refused him -- even after repeated requests are made to have his copy (ticket).  Imagine that, in deciding this case, you are modeling the most basic of concepts to a group of impressionable youngsters (America's future caretakers):  rules need to be followed by everyone for the beneficial outcome of everyone.  When one side or the other refuses to meet their obligations (contract) they are displaying bullying behavior.  As I understand the DOT rule in question, American Airlines (and how many others?) are blatantly ignoring the obligations (contract) set forth in the rule.  Can not their behavior be described as bullying to all concerned?

Title: Craig Folkedahl
Comment: When I purchase a ticket from an airline for travel on their equipment, I should have the right to a copy of the full ticket including information on fare class, price, taxes and fees charged, and any other legal requirements that may or may not have a direct impact on the contract of carriage.

Title: Loretta Martin-Halpine
Comment: Please require airlines to provide an exact copy if the information on each ticket to the passenger.

Title: Jeffrey Starrfield
Comment: As a citizen of the United States of America, and a consumer of airline services, I insist that my government protect my consumer rights and enforce its own regulations including 14 CFR 399.83 so that I may receive details of my airline ticket purchases so as to know my rights in case of a dispute.

Title: B. Elliott
Comment: I am requesting that DOT enforce its rules and mandate that airlines provide complete ticketing information for e-tickets including a breakdown of taxes, fare codes for all segments, and more.

Title: Teresita Barnett
Comment: I heartily support the enforcement of the regulation that requires ALL airlines to provide the complete ticket to all passengers.

Title: Bob Schou
Comment:
As a frequent flyer, I would like to see the enforcement of the current ticket regulation (14 CFR 399.83).  This could be accomplished by providing the ticketing information at the time the confirmation number is issued (either on the confirmation page or as a separate PDF download).

On the same page (of download) should be a customer summary of the cartage contract between the airline and myself along with a summary of government rules and regulations that are in force on my trip.

Title: Edie Hoffman
Comment: if an airline has information as to rules, regulations, taxes etc on the e-ticket which is now used the purchaser should also be entitled to a copy of same to review taxes and other details.

Title: Hazvinei Mugwagwa
Comment:
The complaint at hand is much the same as the situation I am currently experiencing with American Airlines (American). The unwillingness of American to provide all the information comprising my ticket have meant that when making changes to my ticket I am unable to ascertain if the applicable fare rules, collected taxes, and other charges have been properly calculated and applied. I purchased a Round-the-World ticket and the rules are quite complicated, that even American insists that these tickets be handled by a specialized desk. During the times of paper tickets, one had physical coupons that contained all the information necessary for a consumer to ascertain what they were paying for and the details of the contract between the carrier and passenger. However, with the move to e-tickets all that information is held by the airline and a passenger is forced to accept whatever is communicated over the phone, no written records to later review or challenge, it results in the airline holding all the power on a ticket. This means a passenger is beholden to whatever the whim of the agent on the other end of the phone despite what the applicable rules and regulations may be for their ticket.

Disclosing the details of the ticket as set forth in the applicable regulations should be a requirement of the airlines and should the Agency accept American's position in the answer it will result in diminution of passenger standing, increase the likelihood passengers do not receive the benefits of the ticket they purchase, and entrench the power of the airlines that already hold substantial positions vis-a-vis passengers. Airline tickets are already contracts of adhesion, with little bargaining power for passengers besides the power to purchase or not, which then disappears following purchase with the airline being both interpreting and enforcing the contract for transport. Providing passengers with the details of their contract and purchased travels at least allows a passenger to exercise what little rights they have under the contract of carriage and in law/regulation. 

The agency should not accept American's position that mere confirmations are sufficient enough disclosure and that the agency along with the traveling public should "trust them" to do always do the right thing. Besides, there is minimal cost burden to airlines to provide the full details of the ticket, including fare basis, individual taxes collected and tariff calculations in detail. The airlines already have this information in their systems as they use it to calculate the initial fare, manage remittance of taxes and other fare components to other carriers or their own accounting systems. The only additional requirement is disclosing the same to the purchaser. 

In my situation, American refuses or claims to be unable to tell me what individual taxes they have collected from me and what may have been remitted, they have repeatedly told me on the phone that they are collecting United Kingdom passenger duty at a time when my itinerary did not meet the requirements for collecting such tax (I had a connection not a stopover), and they could not tell me why I kept having to pay additional surcharges with each change beyond change fees and applicable taxes that are readily calculated. As I was traveling I have had little to no choice to pay their demands unless i lose my ticket or have to find alternative travel means. This is mostly caused because American has determined that it is under no obligation to share the details of the contract made and the fare, taxes and surcharges made, and the Agency has so far failed to enforce its rules in this respect. I have written and called into many of American's departments, including their executives without success, and indeed some of the departments have indicated that they cannot get answers from their colleagues. How can a consumer then be able to assert their rights?

Finally, to preempt any claims of hardship or burden as American suggests in its response, I am attaching a copy of a receipt I received recently from Delta. Note the complete detail on taxes and fare basis calculation.

The Department of Transport should not support American's position and should enforce its long standing and valid rules, Airlines should be required to provide full details of the ticket information as contained in the airlines records, they already have to have this information to operate, and any refusal to so disclose is to the detriment of the public.

Title: Susan Cheng
Comment: I think it's important that people purchasing the ticket should be able to have a copy of any ticket terms, fine print, etc associated with the ticket. The requirement to provide a complete VCR is important, and should be enforced. Especially now with electronic tickets, it costs the airlines almost nothing to provide an electronic copy of the ticket. Please enforce this standard. It is certainly NOT obsolete.

Title: James Hammett
Comment: I notice that I'm getting less and less details about my tickets when I purchases it.  Please make sure that the airlines continue/resume providing us with the required information, when we spend our hard earned money.

Title: Barbara Gideon
Comment: I cannot think of any other purchase I have made that did not have a complete receipt of all charges.

Title: Douglas Diehl
Comment:
DOT should follow its own regulations until such time as they are amended or rescinded.  Government agencies should not be allowed to selectively enforce regulations.  If the regulations are outdated, then fix them, but don't ignore them, particularly when it allows for potential fraud against consumers.  

The argument of American Airlines that that this requirement (for a ticket) is outdated is specious.  The form in which the ticket is issued, with all the required information, can keep up with the times and be in electronic format.  This protects both the consumer and the airline, and keeps everything above board, particularly with relation to taxes.

If the claims of Mr. Borsetti are accurate, then a much larger issue of fraudulent collection of taxes needs further investigation.

Title: Murray Reed Little Jr
Comment:
A complete ticket (or the VCR which constitutes the complete e-ticket) includes a variety of information which is important to purchasers but often omitted from e-mail confirmations by most airlines when dealing with electronic tickets.

Where this information is held by the airlines, and specifies the details of the contract between the airlines and the ticket purchaser, there are good consumer protection reasons to require the airlines to furnish a copy of this information to each ticket purchaser; just as there were (and are still) good consumer protection reasons that initially require the carriers to furnish this information to customers during the days of paper tickets.

The shift to e-tickets in no way should reduce the requirement for the airlines to provide all the necessary information to consumers in order for their rights to be understood and maintained.

14 CFR 399.83 should be retained and should be enforced.

Title: Adam Birecki
Comment:
It seems that if the airline has rules beyond what appears in the reservation they transmit to the ticketholder, they should be required to spell it out in detail. A ticket with an airline should include all the rules required to fully understand the rights of both parties to those rules.

Please make sure to have the airline issue full and complete tickets.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I fail to see why the airlines do not provide all the information I need to know what I have paid for and am entitled to when I buy an airline ticket.  They force me to print out what they say, using my own ink/paper/time - why can't they be forced to follow the law and at least give me full information?

Title: Anonymous
Comment: As a consumer, I need all information I am legally entitled to.  I cannot put forth my rights when an airline is illegally hiding that information from me.  With an e-ticket the required information can still be provided. In my opinion, Airlines that do not provide this information are intentionally being deceptive.  14 CFR 399.83 is there to protect my rights.  That the airline believes they should be the sole arbiter is illegal.  It is time for the DOT to enforce the law.

Title: Sandy Dmtry
Comment:
If an airline creates a ticket for you within its computer system (specifying in detail the terms of the contract by which you are bound, and by which the airline should also be bound), you are entitled to have a copy of it.

Why is this not currently being enforced?  The ticket specifies the terms of the contract between the airline and the client - and BOTH sides need to have ALL the information on the contract!

Title: Fortunato Stanziale
Comment:
Passengers should be on an equal footing with the Airlines when contesting whatever.  It is clearly unfair when one party sees the cards and the other party is kept in the dark.  We need a Passenger Bill of Rights to protect the passenger from unfair Airline practices.   Congress needs to step up and walk the talk when they profess doing their job for the American People.
Show your metal Congress!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Airlines should be required to provide the full ticket record and details -- whether electronic or physical. If, as passengers, we are held to terms and conditions, then we should have a copy of the full T&Cs to which we are being held.  To allow anything different is to create even more animosity between airlines and passengers than already exists. Please keep the playing field as level as possible by requiring airlines to provide the full ticket details and records to each passenger.

Title: James Glen
Comment: 399.84(a) applies to "advertising or solicitation", not e-tickets.  American's defense of their deceptive practice reads as a disingenuous attack on the Full Fare Advertising Rule.

Title: Jay Libove
Comment:
In re:  American Airlines ("AA) in its answer of May 22, 2015, to this complaint (document DOT-OST-2015-0087-0004):
14 CFR 399.83 should be retained and should be enforced.
Transparency in commerce, and particularly in e-commerce (which includes 'virtual' airline tickets) is key.
Without transparency, there cannot be real competition, and markets will necessarily become less competitive, less fair (unfair), more anti-consumer (deceptive), and ultimately less efficiency for the national economy (harmful).
All airline ticket purchases, no matter by what channel, must continue to generate a 'ticket' (which could be a classic Virtual Coupon Record, as long as it continues to retain the same full details as the old full paper tickets did), and these tickets must be provided in full to the purchaser by default - without the purchaser having to ask. Electrons are cheap. There is no excuse for not including the whole ticket record in the email (or other electronic) confirmation of every ticket purchase.

I urge DOT to uphold this complaint that AA has violated 14 CFR  399.83, and to impose sanctions commensurate with the consequent damages to consumers.

Title: Bert Nielson
Comment:
I believe that the airlines should still be held to the regulations requiring issuance of all relevant ticket information. 

I recently traveled to NYC and my return flights were both cancelled and delayed. 

The level of frustration encountered stemmed in no small part due to the this information not being available to me and my booking agent. 

Phone calls to the booking agent were quite long as they were unable to confirm anything without reaching out to the airline directly. Prior to e-ticketing, I know I was able to call my agent, have everything confirmed or changed without having to be put on hold and wait while they called the airlines.

Something is missing from the process, something that was there before and now isn't.

Title: Richard Weil
Comment: I respectfully point out that a ticket is required under 14 CFR 399.83.  Also, this is a contract and each party entering into it can reasonably expect both fully disclosed and written information from other participants.  This really shouldn't even be an issue; given what the airlines charge and their miserable levels of service the least they can do is be fully open on what they are delivering.

Title: Harold Burstyn
Comment: If the airline has a virtual ticket in its system, it MUST give me a copy or other access to it so that I have all the information I need to know about what I have allegedly agreed to in purchasing the trip.

Title: K. Saling
Comment: AA and other airlines must provide a full and complete ticket, in line with US Federal regulations (14 CFR 399.83).  The current practices of US carriers are anti-consumer.  Consumers have a right to the full details of their contract with the airline.

Title: Martin Crossland
Comment: If I purchase a non-refundable ticket, I should be allowed to reclaim taxes charged for services not provided, such as so called "airport taxes. In this case I should have access to all the items included in the ticket price.

Title: Charles Mattoon
Comment:
I am appalled that the law requiring airlines to provide customers with a copy of their full ticket information is neither being observed by most airlines nor enforced at all by the government. It is simply and obviously wrong for only the service provider to have a copy of what is essentially a contract, thus handicapping the consumer in event of any dispute. 

In addition, if the computer systems of the airlines break down or are hacked or for any reason the e-ticket is lost, the consumer is out in the cold without a paper copy and the situation becomes more problematic for all. 

Thank you for your time,

Charles Mattoon

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
If an airline creates a ticket for a customer within its computer system (specifying in detail the terms of the contract by which  the customer are bound, and by which the airline should also be bound), the customer is entitled to have a copy of it. 

This needs to be adhered to!

Title: Art Wolfe
Comment:
I'm amazed that the FCC does not enforce its rules which require tickets to contain full detailed information about the contract terms of the ticket when it is not a paper ticket but just a virtual ticket in the computer system.  It is unfair to passengers to be deprived of this basic information just because the ticket is no longer on paper.

Art Wolfe
Ann Arbor, MI

Title: Ervin Kalman
Comment:
I am struck by a sleight of hand in American Airline's answer to Mr. Borsetti.

They do not claim they provided Mr. Borsetti with a ticket per 14 CFR 399.83.  Their rebuttal focuses on Mr. Borsetti's request for a "'complete copy of the electronic ticket record' as stored in the carrier's electronic reservations system." 

I cannot comment on all what is stored in the carrier's electronic reservations system. But surely AA must provide passengers with what AA itself defines as a ticket in it's own published tariff, at least as of today:

"TICKET MEANS THE "PASSENGER TICKET AND BAGGAGE CHECK," INCLUDING ALL FLIGHT, PASSENGER AND OTHER COUPONS THEREIN, ISSUED BY CARRIER, WHICH PROVIDE FOR THE CARRIAGE OF THE PASSENGER AND HIS BAGGAGE"

Clearly those "flight coupons" (now Virtual Coupon Records as I understand it) would have the relevant fare breakdown -- which is necessary for verifying that rules of the fare (and rules of the tax authorities) are being followed correctly.

Title: Kaushik Shridharani
Comment:
Precisely to resolve consumer complaints, the DOT requires carriers (under 14 CFR 249.20 (8)) to retain "flight coupon" records for 1 year and "sales ticket reports" records for its offices for 2 years. 

By its own tariff (see Rule 71 in its international tariff), AA uses fare and tax information on a per-flight-coupon basis to calculate such things as denied-boarding compensation. So this information, at a minimum, must be there in AA's records structured by coupon.

It would seem that AA must make this information available to customers to resolve complaints, otherwise the DOT requirement would not have been placed under the "Consumer Complaints" heading.

Title: Logan Scott
Comment:
Interference tolerance masks developed using the methodologies of the ABC draft test plan may prove dangerously permissive. The GPS L1 C/A code signal used as the primary, and often sole, navigation and timing signal in most civil applications has numerous well known structural vulnerabilities that will not be stimulated under this test plan. Specifically, C/A codes are short and repeat themselves every 1 msec leading to a line spectrum vulnerability. Low level interference can cause sustained biases in measured pseudorange and carrier phase, often with no measurable change in observed C/No.

Interfering sources with structural components that are a multiple of 1 kHz or 1msec are of particular concern. LTE downlink signals have several structural components that fit this criterion:

1.	The underlying subcarrier symbol rate is 15 kHz
2.	Reference symbols have a 1 msec periodicity that can yield 1 kHz lines
3.	The RF frame length is 10 msec.
4.	LTE OFDM waveforms are not constant envelope. Periodicities in out of band interference can couple into a GPS receiver via AGC and nonlinear frontend effects.

The ABC draft test plan proposes using white noise as a stand-in for LTE signals. White noise is the most benign form of interference there is for a GPS L1 C/A code receiver. Waveforms 100 times weaker can cause larger errors in position and time and, without altering C/No. White noise has no periodicities and it is not capable of inducing measurement bias effects. 

Navigation and timing receivers have objectives that are fundamentally different from communications receivers. Testing for adjacent band compatibility should not rely solely on SNR / C/No depression, especially since C/No is often ill-defined in cases where waveform on waveform structural interaction dominates. Specific type compatibility testing is needed. If the objective is to measure adjacent band compatibility with LTE signals, you need to test with LTE signals. White noise is an inadequate and overly benign stand-in which can lead to overly permissive interference tolerance masks.

Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Greenwood Telecommunications Consultants LLC
Comment: On behalf of Greenwood Telecom, please see attached file.

Comment: Please see the attached Comments of the GPS Innovation Alliance.

Title: Louisiana State University
Comment:
We are interested in adopting decommissioned USCG CORS sites in the Gulf of Mexico area to integrate into our own GPS CORS site network operated by the Center for GeoInformatics of Louisiana State University.  That includes sites in Texas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama, and Florida.  If any sites are deemed to be decommissioned, please contact us at:

Clifford J. Mugnier
Chief of Geodesy
Center for GeoInformatics
LOUISIANA STATE UNIVERSITY
266 ERAD
Baton Rouge, LA 70803
cjmce@LSU.edu
(225) 578-4578 [225-LSU-4LSU]

Title: Ann Morrison
Comment: I think that reducing the number of ground stations verifying GPS coordinates is a bad idea.  I worked at the Weldon Spring Site Remedial Action Project at St. Charles, Missouri.  The engineers could not verify survey markers with GPS.  We need to make GPS more credible, not less.

Title: H. Alexander Huskey
Comment: Dear Staff, the Nationwide Differential Global Positioning System (NDGPS)should be considered a vital backup system to satellite GPS, and not shut down merely because of a decline in its use. The exception to this lack of use is by sites in coastal areas, and since the system helps navigate obstacles of that sort, it should go without saying that inland mountainous regions of the USA could likewise benefit, especially in case of emergency regarding orbiting satellites. Infrastructure like the NDGPS should actually be expanded with emergency use in mind, not cancelled because handheld GPS devices are suddenly affordable by everyone. Another point would be that NDGPS sites should be hardened to tampering and supplied with backup power for the sake of aforementioned emergency use. A "multilayered contingency plan" would include a certain number of portable or heliostat-deployable NDGPS units for use when fixed ground units are disabled for reasons of natural disaster or terrorism. It's important that government agencies charged with protecting the common good not be guided by market forces which are not structured to deal with emergencies. Thanks for your consideration. Sincerely, H. Alexander Huskey

Title: J. Robert Moore
Comment:
Concerning DGPS coverage,
I operate a vessel out of Mayport, Florida and am routinely tasked to work in close quarters and reduced visibility during adverse weather conditions
It concerns me to loose Savannah station due to the possibility of poor coverage in the area as defined by future coverage reference map.
This area has high maritime traffic and loss of DGPS signal would be detrimental to our safety.
Loss of DGPS would in fact reduce or capabilities and increase or operations risk factors.

Captain J. Robert Moore
Operator, USN 180' Research Vessel.

Title: John Doody
Comment:
I am writing to support the continuation of NDGPS.  I utilize these corrections in a class I teach at Central Connecticut State University, New Britain, CT.  Through the collection and checking of data collected using DGPS corrections, I have found an average accuracy of about 1.6' horizontally and 5' vertically, which is superior to the Space Based Augmentation System SBAC called WAAS which is operated by the FAA (about 3' Horizontally).

The Coast Guard Station in Moriches, NY  provides the signal up to 300km in all directions, so land based corrections are provided to Long Island, Connecticut, Rhode Island and parts of Southern Massachusetts, a densely populated region with lots of GIS mapping activity.  Using DGPS for GIS mapping means that a less expensive GPS receiver can be used ($9,000 vs. $20,000).

Title: Chris Brown
Comment: I am not objecting to decommissioning the Nationwide Differential Global Positioning System (NDGPS) service augments GPS, what I do object to is shutting down all the GNSS receivers at the proposed locations because they are in location which do not have good Continuing Operating Reference Station (CORS) coverage. We need ensure that we have good CORS at a spacing on not more than 50km, I have for many years been providing geodetic control for remote sensing projects, a number of the projects have been for life safety of the general public and government regulations. So please keep one of the GNSS receivers operating, if needed please work with PBO on a transition to the CORS system.

Title: Sidney D. Durham
Comment:
My name is Sid Durham, I am a life-long boater and a member of the
Venice (Fl) Sail and Power Squadron.  I currently own a 42 foot motor yacht with a Garmin GPS/Chart plotter at the helm.  I also have a GPS on my computer and both tablets and my smart phone.  All of the latter have various programs/apps which permit me to locate and track my boat with extreme accuracy, which is important to me after suffering a very expensive grounding.  Yes, I know it is redundant, but no different than all the redundancy systems on any modern Boeing airliner.  It is all there for our safety. Now I am not a physicist, but I do not believe it takes one  to know that when there are currently 84 DGPS sites, and they are cut back to 22 DGPS sites, which is a 78.57 per cent decrease, even I do know that to cut back to that level in not in the coastal boater's best interest.  The margins for error increase significantly, and for example a grounding at speed or other error GPS caused, with the potential loss of life and property is not worth the cutbacks.  I noted that many of the sites to be decommissioned are inland, I have no concern with those being decommissioned. Please leave the ones along our coasts and the Great Lakes fully operational.

Please register my objection to the proposed cutbacks in DGPS
sites as set forth above.  I thank you very much.

Sidney D. Durham
Luna~Sea II
Venice, Florida
269-217-7265

Title: Robert Childs
Comment: I am most interested in seeing the system remain functional as a whole.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am writing to support the continuation of NDGPS. My work for a private civil engineering firm utilizes the CORS data for differential correction of GPS data collected using an affordable GPS receiver ($8000) for a variety of projects handled by our GIS department. For instance, we use the Whitney CORS station data to improve the precision of positioning in remote locations around the Nebraska panhandle where access to base stations for post processing is very limited.  Indeed, we regularly differentially correct for improved horizontal precision using Whitney CORS station data. The CORS data from Whitney is also called upon for the only available nearest base data when other area base stations are not operating for a variety of reasons, which happens quite a bit.  Thank you for your consideration.

Title: Thomas Zacaroli
Comment: It works well.  Stop fiddling and move on to any of the thousands of government programs that do not work.  If you want meaningful comment provide meaningful information.  Use is declining?  How do you know?  What are the metrics?  Presumably this is to save money?  How much and where from?  What are the operational consequences? What re the unintended consequences - there always are some?

Title: Virginia Tech Transportation Institute
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: James Ebmeyer
Comment: Water craft, air craft and vehicles navigating our waterways and roadways, all need accurate position data - water and air craft are the most demanding of accurate and high level of detailed position data.  Any changes made via this proposal must not degrade the accuracy of the user's position.  As a boater, accuracy of position relative to underwater hazards is crucial.  Both lives and investments in vessels are at risk, on our waterways.  I have cruised the Great Lakes, St. Lawrence River, Atlantic and Gulf Coasts.  Please do not put the millions of us, who use digital global position system, at risk.

Title: Joe McCormick
Comment:
Dear Sirs,

Redundancy is key in natural disasters. My one concern especially in major metropolitan areas is the possibility for temporary and even permanent damage to antennas, hardware, software and infrastructure.

The Nationwide Differential Global Positioning System (DGPS) has accuracy that draws down positions from 45 feet to mere inches. When Mariners are making calculations in course corrections a 45 foot error in a starting point can lead to errors of miles at later waypoints. This can lead to near misses, collisions, fatalities and or bridge collisions.

In a natural disaster such as Earthquakes, Tsunamis and or Power grid failures this system (DGPS) and GPS networks can and will fail. The effort to repair and or rebuild is much more expensive and time consuming that simply shutting off the switch and turning off land point stations. If this is primarily a cost savings effort consider the cost of ship collisions causing transportation and environmental catastrophes. 

Vessels within inland waters are especially susceptible to groundings and or bridge collisions.

Please consider keeping in place sufficient network land stations DGPS and (backup stations) that can go back online in a moment's notice during station outages and failures.

What can happen will happen.

Sincerely,


Joe McCormick 

Master, Derrickboat Raccoon
Navigation & Structural Section
USACE-OR-O-NS

US ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS
San Francisco District
Operations Bldg.
2100 Bridgeway Blvd.
Sausalito Ca. 94965

415-699-1482 - M/V Raccoon

Title: Mitchell Tweedy
Comment:
DOT-OST-2015-0105
Decommissioning of a total of 62 DGPS sites is ok, however the receivers that are part of the NGS CORS program should stay operational as NGS Reference stations.
http://www.ngs.noaa.gov/CORS_Map/

If the NDGPS is unwilling or unable to maintain the reference stations as CORS, they should be turned over to organizations that will reinstall them and resubmit them to the NGS CORS program.

Title: Puerto Rico Seismic Network
Organization Name: Puerto Rico Seismic Network / University of Puerto Rico - Mayaguez Campus
Comment:
On behalf of the Puerto Rico Seismic Network (PRSN), I would like to notify the interest of keeping site PUR5 located in Isabela, Puerto Rico in operation.  The use given to the data from this important site is twofold: tectonic (monitor crustal deformation and its implication on earthquake occurrence and behaviour) and tsunami (to help estimate earthquake magnitudes in real-time and implications for tsunami genesis).  
PRSN currently operates and maintains 15 continuously operated GPS sites within Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands.  We have a system in place to collect the data in real-time, archive it and perform a series of post-processing routines.  We are interested and capable of adopting the site if the owners 
deem appropriate.  
Please refer to the attached official letter from the PRSN for more details.

Sincerely, 

Alberto M. Lpez-Venegas
Puerto Rico Seismic Network
Geology Dept. 
University of Puerto Rico- Mayaguez Campus

Title: Nationwide Differential Global Positioning System
