Title: Wayne Carnes
Comment:
I work as Captain aboard the High Speed Craft FAIRWEATHER that is operated by the Alaska Marine Highway System.  Our daily operation requires an accurate DGPS signal for position making in the narrow waterways of SE Alaska.  This is especially important during times of inclement weather when standard piloting methods and RADAR become limited.  

I'm requesting that the following Alaska DGPS stations be kept operational - Biorka, Gustavus, and Level Island.  My ship travels at 36kts while carrying 250 passengers and 40 vehicles - so an accurate position is critical.  The redundancy of these stations ensures that we get the needed accuracy at all times.

Title: John Mraz
Comment:
The US Army Corps of Engineers, Survey Section,  routinely operates 5 Survey vessels and  use the DGPS system for position, motion, and vessel attitude increased accuracy .    Elimination would mean:
- Increased costs of operation due to the need to install our own base station for every project.
- Slower response for emergency situations
- increased risk of navigation failures due to a single base not being integrity checked to SOLAS standards.
- increased operations costs due to the need to check geodetics 
- additional costs if we are forced to move to a private subscription-based service.

Title: Ed Sinclair
Comment:
I am writing to voice my opposition to the decommissioning of the dGPS sites in Southeast Alaska.  As a marine pilot, I see the reduction in this service counter to the demanding navigation challenges posed by operating some of the largest cruise ships afloat and cargo vessels with limited maneuverability (most often with electronic aids to navigation that are inferior to portable piloting aids carried aboard by the pilot) in these waterways.

Cruise ships are quickly moving to paperless chart rooms and navigation is reliant on electronic positioning.  Some cruise line companies are going as far as wanting to operate with track-keeping autopilots with system automation that reports deviations from an electronic track line to the home office.  Though I strongly oppose this method of navigation, the art of navigation is becoming more and more reliant on electronic navigation.

Reducing position accuracy in an area such as Southeast Alaska with narrow channels, inestimable number submerged hazards, waterways affected by extreme currents and dangerous winds, is counter to navigation safety.  The local Coast Guard has proposed reducing some of the fixed aids to navigation service which is further contradictory to the proposal to reduce dGPS.  Reducing aids to navigation service is the wrong direction to take.

That said, I was unable to locate any graphics that depicted WAAS coverage for Southeast Alaska.  It would have been informative to be provided a graphic of the other GPS augmentation systems to better understand what coverage is redundant in this area to put the Southeast Alaska dGPS sites on the decommissioning list.

Title: Michael Lombardi
Comment:
It would be worthwhile to at least consider re-purposing the decommissioned DGPS stations as a backup source of frequency for GPS disciplined clocks and oscillators.  For example, GPS disciplined clocks and oscillators are key components of critical infrastructure systems such as telecommunication networks and the electric power grid.  When they lose satellite reception, these GPS devices immediately go into "holdover" mode, and their performance is only as good as their local oscillator.

If the DGPS stations were re-purposed to perform a simple task, such as broadcasting a standard frequency signal, future GPS disciplined clocks and oscillators manufactured for use in the United States could be designed to receive that signal and switch over to the terrestrial radio signal to control the frequency of their local oscillators during a GPS outage. This would greatly improve their holdover capability, perhaps allowing them to maintain microsecond level time synchronization for multiple weeks in absence of GPS.

The redesign of the DGPS system would be straightforward, but it would probably be best to put all of the re-purposed transmitters on the same frequency, 300 kHz, for example.  GPS disciplined products would then simply receive the signal from the nearest station.  It would also be necessary, of course, to have cesium clocks or an equivalent reference at each of the sites.  Additional information (such as a time code) could be modulated on to the signal, but a standard carrier frequency would be sufficient for providing frequency holdover.

Note that a scheme similar to this was utilized by at least one telecommunications company with legacy LORAN-C, prior to that system being turned off in 2010, so some proof of concept already exists.

Title: Prince Riley
Comment:
(1) The commenter's usage of NDGPS for positioning, navigation, and timing;

Currently the commentator's use of the NDGPS system is as a system of systems component in a FAA NextGen proof of concept (POC) vehicle UAS flight management system. 

The basic operational scenarios for this POC vehicle is to provide highly accurate, real-time position, ground speed, direction of flight, and course navigational data within a 'weight restricted avionics payload to UAS commercial system owners/operators.

This POC system uses the NDGPS system and  the Real-Time Kinematic (RTK) procedures to provide highly accurate flight data using a fixed ground station equipped with a multi-channel software defined radio system (SDR) and open source GPS correction and correlation software to produce a positional value to a cloud-based information processing system which can then be accessed by FAA flight control systems and operators as well as commercial aviation aircraft.

After further system development and testing, this POC UAS system and its use of the NDGPS system will have applications to commercial UAS operations nationally and will provide a cost-effective COTS platform to integrate UAS vehicles into the nation's airspaces without increasing the FAA flight operation workloads or aircraft management infrastructure (control and radar towers). 

Further, we envision the NDGPS could play a pivotal and vital role in the emergence of the IoT to provide cost-effective GPS services. Again, an operational scenario is the NDGPS provides high-precision location data that can be used to match a location to a destination USPS nine digit zip-code address  in the national Address Correction System. 

The advantages of this system to logistic services providers and carriers such as UPS, FedExp, USPS, and others can be easily understood when one understands the limited payload and fuel duration of flight characteristics of UAS vehicles.  In fact, the USPS could use a variant of the POC GPS system now to provide commercially valuable highly accurate real-time, 'in route' transit times and locations of time sensitive, packages, letters, and parcels.  


(2) The impact on NDGPS users if NDGPS were discontinued;

After a two year development effort, we were unable to duplicate a GPS system with the necessary payload requirements and position accuracy measurements within a reasonable cost. The key element is this POS system use of the NDGPS is the SDR base station's link to several GPS satellite transmissions and the NDGPS as described in the RTK. 

Without such a highly accurate source of ground position reference data, the < 3 meter position accuracy cannot be achieved without purchasing more accurate survey GPS equipment which is both too expensive and has a unacceptable weight and risk of loss penalty. Also, the loss of the NDGPS would delay the advancement of the inclusion of commercial UAS flight operations into the FAA NextGen ATCS.       


(3) If NDGPS were discontinued, the possible alternatives for meeting users' positioning, navigation, and timing requirements; and

We do not know of any technically feasible alternatives which would be available tot the general public at a acceptable commercial cost. 

(4) Potential alternative uses for the existing NDGPS infrastructure.

It's our opinion, the NDGPS could provide the USPS an infrastructure to offer very attractive parcel, letter, and package tracking services at a nominal cost of operation and infrastructure investment. The USPS could license or provide such services to commercial logistic providers such as FedEx, Amazon, UPS, and other shipping and container services (roadway, rail, and air) that are not otherwise available.

Title: Jeff Freymueller
Comment:
Two separate issues need to be considered with regard to the proposed NDGPS site shutdown. The first is the real-time use of the broadcast NDGPS corrections. The second is the use of these sites within the CORS network. I have never used the real-time broadcast corrections and there would be no impact to me if the broadcasts were terminated. However, I have used every single day of data ever recorded at many of the sites proposed for shutdown, and the loss of the GPS receivers as CORS sites would be significant. The fact that these sites comprise only 5% of the CORS network is misleading, because in some places (particularly in Alaska) their removal would result in a significant loss of CORS coverage over large geographical areas. My strong recommendation is that the DGPS broadcasts can be terminated, but the receivers themselves maintained as CORS sites. Remaining as CORS-only sites, the sites could be simplified considerably. Only the primary receiver would need to be retained, as the redundancy requirement for CORS is lower.

When considering the impact of the loss of sites as CORS sites, it is not sufficient to consider only the number of sites or their fraction of the CORS network. The distribution of sites and existence (or not) of alternate sites within a few tens of kilometers distance must be considered. The Alaska sites in particular do not have replacements, and removal would create gaps of as much as hundreds of kilometers (miles) in the available CORS network. The same is true of many of the remaining sites in the lower 48 and Hawaii, because other CORS site operators did not locate sites close to the NDGPS sites, to avoid duplication of effort.

The largest user group for these sites as CORS is the land survey and GIS community. The NDGPS sites in Alaska are a vital resource for this community. They often need to make short duration surveys (a few minutes to an hour or two) of survey points, with an accuracy requirement of 1-2 cm level for survey applications and the sub-meter level for GIS/mapping applications. Reliably achieving that accuracy requires a nearby CORS base station, where the proximity requirement for the CORS station depends on the application and duration of measurements but is typically several tens of kilometers or shorter. If there is no base station close enough, then the time on site required to get the same accuracy using remote CORS jumps dramatically, in some cases to several hours on site (in that case the proximity requirement is only a several hundred kilometers or closer). Removal of the six Alaska sites will create large holes in the CORS network that will force users working in those areas to incur significantly larger time on site and larger expense to carry out work that for years they have been able to do using these sites. This problem is magnified by the recent removal of 3 other long-running CORS sites in Alaska and the potential for loss of funding to the remainder, which are part of the Plate Boundary Observatory supported by the National Science Foundation. The Alaska sites are absolutely needed as CORS.

I use data from about half of the sites on the list for research purposes on a daily basis. I analyze every day of data to study crustal motions, and to monitor Earth deformation caused by tectonics, earthquakes, and volcanism. Other CORS sites were sited to complement the NDGPS sites without duplication, so the NDGPS locations are not easily replaced. I use the six NDGPS sites in Alaska that are proposed for shutdown (Biorka, Cape Hinchinbrook, Cold Bay, Gustavus, Kodiak, and Level Island), plus several in the Lower 48. Near-real-time and ultimately real-time monitoring systems are being developed using these data, aimed at enhanced earthquake and tsunami monitoring and early warning systems. Removal of these sites would be a significant blow for these efforts.

Particularly in Alaska, many users and applications depend on their continued existence. Their removal would cause a substantial loss of capability and significantly increased expenses for many land survey/GIS/mapping users. Their removal would cause significant data gaps for research users and would impede the development of enhanced volcanic, earthquake and tsunami monitoring and early warning systems. The retention of the sites as CORS sites would not require the degree of physical redundancy currently used for the NDGPS sites. A single receiver and antenna at each location would be sufficient, without the second redundant unit and separate integrity monitors, and without the need for the DGPS broadcasts. CORS real-time data streams can be simply and cost-effectively disseminated by internet. The cost of maintaining the sites as CORS only should be considered, as it is likely to be substantially lower than the present cost, and it may be possible to operate the sites as CORS sites for a considerable period of time for less than the cost of decommissioning and removing the sites.

Title: Anne Vawser
Comment: I am writing to support the continuation of NDGPS. My work for the National Park Service utilizes the CORS data for differential correction of GPS data collected using affordable GPS receivers for a variety of projects. across 13 states, on a near daily basis. We often work in remote areas and the loss of only a few stations, such as the Whitney and Medora stations, will leave us with large gaps for correction thus making our data much less accurate. This seems like a large step backwards for what is a fast growing use of GPS for all kinds of resource, emergency, and navigation purposes. If the issue is funds, why not partner with more agencies? If the belief is that these services are duplicating others that are out there, I think that is a false assumption.

Title: Brinnen Carter
Comment: Decommissioning the Biorka and Gustavus DGPS stations will have a negative impact on the capability of local mariners to navigate in the waters in-and-around SE Alaska.  Moreover, other professionals such as foresters, archeologists, geologists, and hydrologists, will receive less precise location information if the two stations are decommissioned.  For the overall safety and professional capability of people working and navigating in SE Alaska and the Gulf of Alaska, please keep these to aids to navigation fully functioning.

Title: Michael Peterson
Comment: I oppose decommissioning the CORS stations. My archeological work at Redwood National Park depends on highly accurate GPS data for identifying and locating cultural resource locations, and also for identifying areas of concern for management of park resources and for assisting with law enforcement issues such as identifying illegal grow sites and associated illegal and other dangerous activities. Taking down some of these COR sites will lesson the accuracy of our GPS data and could result in poor quality data and ultimately result in misinformation. We depend upon accurate data plotted on maps derived from corrected GPS data by using existing CORS stations. This data is not only critical for park resource management, but is ultimately critical for insuring the good health and safety of park employees and park visitors. Please do not decommission the CORS stations!!! Thank you.

Title: Thomas Rutter
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: D. Gassaway
Comment: Docket DOT-OST-2015-0105 DGPS proposal: Solicited comment 1) current usage: I currently use or have used a battery powered hand held GPS system for the following: road travel, recreational boating, reporting weather hazards, hiking, reporting pollution incidents, and navigation aid (fixed and floating) confirmations for confirming my position. 2) The estimated impact of eliminating some DGPS sites will not affect my livelihood, but may be inconvenient during a transition. Discussion: In observing and reporting a hazardous or potentially hazardous situation in a remote coastal area, (waterspout or flooding for example) the reporter will want to  be able to answer the question "where is it?". The operator, (whether a 911 call center, NOAA weather station, public utility company, etc.) will likely be in another county or even another state. There are distinct dangers associated with activating communication devices in or around many hazards during many circumstances, so the reporter will need to answer "where was it?" with some degree of precision, because reports should only be submitted from a safe place. The operator will then need to notify the response team with precision where the location is or was, hours or days later. In aquatic environments, due to wind, currents, tides, dispersion, dissipation or other movement, the next question is "where will it be in an hour/day/week?". Telephone call centers will usually ask for a specific road or street address. This is not possible on the water. Inland navigation with my handheld GPS has proven reliable with regard to latitude and longitude, but the elevation measurements "above sea level" vary (more than 100 feet on the same day at times) due to barometric pressure changes or fluctuations. The marine sextant, in combination with a GPS, or other tools can provide an accurate position if the proper sea level is known. In summary, in a coastal environment, if waterway users are to report floods, MARPOL violations, accidents, gas leaks, oil spills, waterspouts, power lines down, or other phenomenon, then an accurate way of answering the questions :where is it? where was it? and where is it headed? will enhance prevention, response and recovery of potentially hazardous situations.

Title: Matt Yacubic
Comment:
Please do not decommission the 62 CORS stations listed in the federal register notice. As an archaeologist working for the BLM, I regularly depend on GPS for locating and monitoring cultural resources and use many of these stations to differentially correct my data for accuracy. Taking down these stations will leave  gaps in our GPS coverage across my district and the west.

Respectfully,
Dr. Matt Yacubic

Title: Robert Kautz
Comment: I am concerned regarding the proposed closing of the Austin, NV CORS (GPS) station.  I am an archaeologist with a small (veteran owned) business in Reno, NV.  We do a lot of work in central and eastern Nevada and accordingly, we use the facility to correct our GPS readings.  Please reconsider this closing - it will impact our work considerably!

Title: Keri Hicks
Comment: I am the Regional Heritage Program Leader for the Alaska Region, USDA Forest Service in Juneau, AK.  There are 6 CORS sites proposed to be closed in the state of AK and 4 of those sites are located on National Forest System (NFS) lands.  These CORS stations are invaluable to the Forest Service heritage program where precise and accurate GPS positioning data is needed and achieved through differential correction.  A robust CORS system facilitates precise position OPUS solutions, the development of an improved GEOID, and mapping of resource data.  Please reconsider closing the CORS located on NFS lands.  My program area depends on them to locate and re-locate significant cultural resources on a daily basis.  Closure of these sites will reduce spatial data accuracy and will make it more difficult for heritage staff to monitor and protect historic properties.

Title: Lisa Baldwin
Comment: Dinosaur National Monument is covered by a single CORS station at Myton, Utah.  If the Myton CORS station is decommissioned DINO will no longer be able to differential correct GPS data resulting in less accurate location information for paleontology, natural and cultural resources. Please reconsider closing the CORS stations as we rely on accurate GPS information on a daily basis to preserve these unique resources.  Thanks

Title: Erik Johnson
Comment: These CORS stations are invaluable to many of our Forest Service business areas in the Alaska Region where precise and accurate GPS positioning data is needed and achieved through differential correction.  A robust CORS system facilitates precise position OPUS solutions, the development of an improved GEOID, and mapping of resource data in most business areas.  These business area include but are not limited to Heritage, Forest Management, Engineering, Minerals, Lands, GIS and others.

Title: Steven Woods
Comment:
Columbia River Pilots currently use the AIS info provided by the vessel for our VTIS. The accuracy is dependent on the DGPS signals provided by the Fort Stevens #886; The Appelton #871 and Klamath Falls #791 Please consider keeping these stations open for the near future. 6 years maybe? Coos Bay/ Yaquina Bay could also benefit by having the DGPS signals that are relevant as well.

Capt. Steve Woods Pres.
Columbia River Pilots

Title: Dustin Wittwer
Comment:
In Alaska, maintaining the presence of existing CORS stations is paramount especially in a region of the US that is geographically data poor, both in quantity and quality.  For our agency and public customers, the utility of these stations as real-time DGPS is secondary to their use for post processing, development of geographic data and refinement of Geographic data models.  If the sites must be trimmed, I'd hope only the DGPS/radio beacon be decommissioned but leave the base station in place.  There is still some use of the DGPS signal because in many areas of operation, WASS and internet based correction signals are not available.  WASS is too low on the southern horizon and internet data service is quite limited.  I would hope some consideration be given to upgrading the receivers from GPS to GNSS capability.  In our agency, the USDA Forest Service, we are working to add new GNSS Base stations to serve National Forest System lands.  The need is great and we'd hate to see a reduction to the current system.  OPUS position solutions are invaluable for precise solutions for survey applications and mapping grade GIS.  However those OPUS solutions are heavily dependent on close proximity to existing CORS stations.  We need a higher density of CORS, rather than a reduced density.  

There are six maritime sites in the state of Alaska under consideration and four of those sites are on or in close proximity to national forest lands.  We have many business areas, including but are not limited to Heritage, Forest Management, Engineering, Minerals, Lands, GIS and others that will be impacted if the following Alaska sites are decommissioned:  

Biorka, Cape Hinchinbrook, Cold Bay, Gustavus, Kodiak, and Level Island. 
 
I urge you to support the continued operation of all the AK sites and especially the four on or near the national forest lands.  At the very least, I hope another agency or group such as UNAVCO to take these sites over.  Thank you for your consideration regarding this resource.

Dustin Wittwer, USFS Regional Geospatial and Remote Sensing Specialist

Title: Southeast Alaska Pilots' Association
Comment:
My name is Captain Paul F. Merrill and I am the President of the Southeast Alaska Pilots' Association. 

SEAPA is an association of Marine Pilots who frequently use the DGPS sites at Level Island, Biorka, and Gustavus, AK (which are slated for de-commissioning.)  Our Portable Pilot Units interface with foreign-flagged ship equipment, and we have no control over the GPS units used by these vessels.  Additionally, the World's commercial fleets (and the USCG) are rapidly embracing electronic charts, and de-emphasizing traditional means of terrestrial navigation and paper charts.  

Due to the navigational hazards in Alaska, extreme weather and sea conditions, occasional poor satellite coverage due to the fjords, and the extreme sensitivity to environmental issues here, we don't feel that any degradation of navigational accuracy is appropriate.  In these challenging conditions we move about a million passengers and hundreds of thousands of tons of cargo per year on ships that can exceed 1000 feet in length. 

Glacier Bay National Park and the Tongass National Forest are arguably the most environmentally sensitive maritime areas in North America and could be devastated by a navigation mishap.  Reducing the accuracy of the electronic navigation infrastructure in these areas is counter to the goals of protecting our pristine waters.

We strongly urge you to keep our DGPS sites operational.

Title: Detroit District US Army Corps of Engineers
Comment:
CELRE-OT-T

SUBJECT:  Review of Federal Register Notice:   Nationwide Differential Global Positioning System (NDGPS) - Docket number DOT-OST-2015-0105.

1. Reference Federal Register Notice dated 08/18/2015, subject as above, from the Coast Guard, Transportation Department, and the Engineers Corps.

2. Operations Office has the following comments/concerns regarding the Federal Register Notice in regards to decommissioning the proposed 62 locations across the United States.

a.	The decommissioning of NDGPS sites in the upper Great Lakes will have a major impact on hydrographic surveying in the Detroit District, Corps of Engineers. The Detroit District has numerous in-house and contractor hydrographic survey vessels operating out of offices in Duluth, MN, Kewaunee, WI, Sault Ste. Marie, MI Grand Haven, MI Traverse City, MI and Detroit, MI that currently use the NDGPS system for most basic hydrographic surveying operations. These survey operations are critical to support channel and harbor maintenance and dredging throughout the upper Great Lakes, including the connecting channels and numerous deep draft commercial harbors. Although some of these survey vessels have the capability to use RTK or cell phone corrections many do not. We also have many areas where cell phone coverage is weak or non-existent and setting up RTK base stations is problematic. At this time the six sites listed below for shut down are critical to our hydrographic surveying operations:   

Wisconsin Point, WI
Upper Keweenaw, MI
Sturgeon Bay, WI
Mequon, MI
Cheboygan, MI
Saginaw Bay, MI

b.	We strongly urge that this decision to close these sites be reconsidered or as a minimum postponed for two years to allow us time to obtain additional equipment and adjust our field operations. We also support leaving Pickford and Detroit fully operational as planned as they are also critical to our surveying operations.

c.	In addition to the District impacts listed above, we've had discussions with the commercial shipping industry, and they've expressed major concerns with the decommissioning plan. They plan to submit their own comments to the public notice. However, it should be noted that the Great Lakes Navigation System supports over 226,000 jobs and brings in a total of $33.5 billion in business revenue. Most of the iron ore shipped through the system originates in Lake Superior ports with over 53,800,000 tons of iron ore shipped in 2013. In addition, Saginaw is a major receiving port that ships/receives over 2.5 million tons a year. Abandoning the five sites listed above would have significant impacts and should be reconsidered.

3. If there are any questions please contact Derek Cusimano (313)226-3776 or Donald Holly (313)226-6816 in the  Technical Services Branch at 6-3776.


David L. Wright, P.E.
Chief, Operations Office
Detroit District
US Army Corps of Engineers

Title: Timothy Mullikin
Comment:
I am a professional surveyor practicing in Alaska.  Removing the GPS base stations, particularly in areas where there are few existing COORS will have a detrimental affect on field surveying in those areas, increasing survey costs significantly for both the private and government sectors.

In my practice, the removal of the RTK correction aspects of the stations would not affect me, and may be a cost savings measure.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
USACE Hydrograghic Surveyor.

In response to the CORS Stations being discontinued. We have surveyed or assisted on the inland river  waterways system that covers most of the Eastern have of the country. The topograghy is different within every river system which means there is not many locations for a base station or RTK. We rely on DGPS for the most accurate position we can get out on the river systems. With out this accuracy the hydro surveys that aid in commercial navigation's electronic navigation charting and updated shoaling conditions from the hydro surveys, commercial tows could end up with incorrect depth's resulting in major accidents within our inland rivers and waterways. Not having the DGPS could be the difference in having safe navigation or ripping a hole in the bottom of a coal or asphalt barge and sinking. Each would have dire consequence's to the system and was completely aviodable by leaving all DGPS functional up and working. Think about how much that would cost versus  maintaining the beacons. Who would get that bill.

Title: Dan Ignotov
Comment:
As the current Land Survey Supervisor for the Southcoast Region of the Alaska Dept. of Transportation and Public Facilities I must submit that the complete decommissioning of the 6 listed NDGPS stations along the coast of Alaska would be dramatically detrimental to our operations region wide.

AKDOT & PF Southcoast Region extends from the Dixon Entrance south of Ketchikan westerly along the coast of the Gulf of Alaska to Attu Island at end of the Aleutian chain. My group is responsible for the surveying and mapping of the State's transportation infrastructure to include airports, marine highway facilities, and roadways amongst other State interests. The 6 listed Alaskan NDGPS stations contain 6 GPS Continuously Operating Reference Stations (CORS) whose precise positions are maintained and published by the National Geodetic Survey (NGS). DOT uses the continuously received and published CORS GPS receiver data for post processing of locally collected survey grade positional GPS data so that we may reference our survey and mapping projects to the latest realization of the National Spatial Reference System (NSRS) as defined by NGS. The CORS network represents our only active tie to said reference system. This tie and reference is statutory as well as the spatial foundation of all of our projects. Our projects can be for establishment of geodetic control networks, aerial or bathymetric mapping, modelling of existing terrain and infrastructure, land boundary and rights-of-way determination, and tidal levels to name several.

DOT surveyors do not use the navigational correction broadcast supplied by the NDGPS site. However the loss of the entire NDGPS to include its CORS will leave gaps in the CORS network along the south coast of Alaska. This will cause extra time and expense for each project where these gaps exist. The rest of the CORS we count on are the National Science Foundations' Plate Boundary Observatory CORS. It is my understanding some of these are in jeopardy due to funding issues down the road. This will be disastrous to our spatial infrastructure in Alaska. We have difficulty relying on passive physical monuments set in the ground however robustly they may be constructed. The coastal areas of Alaska have too much crustal motion from frost heave, unsuitable soils, and glacial rebound.

In summary if the federal government finds it necessary to decommission the 6 listed Alaskan NDGPS stations then consideration should be given to keeping the CORS portion of the system operating as usual. This will save funding by eliminating the correction broadcast but keep the important link to the NSRS intact.

Title: Frances Biles
Comment:
I am a geographer with the U.S. Forest Service, Pacific Northwest Research Station (PNW) in Juneau, Alaska
and consider the USCG DGPS sites to be an essential part of the CORS network in southeast 
Alaska. At PNW we do not utilize the NDGPS broadcast signal, mainly because the GPS equipment we are 
currently using is not equipped to receive the signals. However, we are considering new equipment and 
we do have a very occasional need to navigate to precise locations in the field where having access to 
NDGPS real-time corrections would be useful.  Our primary use of the DGPS stations is for differentially 
correcting GPS data collected in the field. We and our cooperators depend on accurate positioning data 
for use in a variety of research projects (e.g., studying ecosystem processes, building landscape models, 
forest monitoring, inventories, and assessments, etc).

The panhandle of southeast Alaska (SEAK) covers an area roughly the size of Pennsylvania and has 12 
CORS stations available: 7 operated by UNAVCO, 4 by the USCG, and 1 by the FAA. Not a single site is 
equipped with a GNSS receiver. In comparison, Pennsylvania has at least 40 CORS stations, over half of 
which are GNSS-capable, and many more stations available near the borders of surrounding states.  
Decommissioning 3 of the 4 USCG NDGPS sites in SEAK (GUS5, BIS6, LEV6) would reduce the already 
sparse CORS network by 33%. If GUS5, BIS6 and LEV6 are decommissioned, and funding for the UNAVCO 
PBO base stations is not renewed in 2018, then SEAK will have only 2 CORS stations: one USCG DGPS 
(AIS6) station at the very south end of the area, and an FAA station towards the north in Juneau, a 
distance of over 400km.  If the 6 Alaska DGPS stations are decommissioned and the PBO network is not 
funded, there will be enormous CORS gaps throughout Alaska. 

I strongly advocate for keeping the Alaska USCG GPS stations operating as base stations on the CORS 
network even if the broadcast signal is eliminated. They are needed for redundancy and maintaining an 
adequate CORS network for differential correction. Furthermore, I would support replacing the Alaska 
USCG GPS sites with GNSS receivers. There may be opportunities to partner with the USFS in this regard.
The ability to collect GLONASS positions has significantly improved data collection in southeast Alaska where 
the GPS constellation is sparse, terrain is steep, and forest canopy is dense; however, the closest GNSS 
station on the CORS network available for differential correction is in Atlin, British Columbia.

Title: Renaker Parks
Comment: Please do not shut down the CORS sites. I am a forester on the Tongass NF and I depend on these sites for accurate GPS position reception. Removal of the sites will result in poor GPS performance for my work.

Title: Richard Preston
Comment:
I am a Marine Pilot in the southeastern region of Alaska with over 25 years experience navigating these waters aboard USCG vessels and Alaska State ferries.  I am writing in opposition to the premature proposed decommissioning of the dGPS sites at Biorka, Gustavus, and Level Island. This is 3 out of 4 presently available regional sites.  The proposal asserts to be leave dGPS in place where precise navigation is required - this will NOT be the case in our region - it will severely degrade the system's precision.  

The proposed action compromises the safety of millions of passengers, and millions of dollars of sea borne commerce - unless there is an equally precise, and equally accessible proven technology currently available to marine users

Glacier Bay National Park, Tracy Arm/Fords Terror Wilderness, and the Admiralty Island National Monument are among the most environmentally sensitive waters of our nation.  They are best protected by ensuring that maritime commerce passing thru or near them have the best navigational signal possible available.

If CORS/WAAS is redundant to the coverage from these dGPS sites - please publish the studies that prove the efficacy of said technology for surface users.  My research only revealed coverage charts for aviation users.  Have local trials been conducted to prove that the surface WAAS signal has not been degraded by our labyrinthine mountainous topography - as was experienced with Loran-C, GPS, and dGPS ? Lastly, are all shipboard GPS receivers able to utilize the CORS/WAAS signal? This should be ascertained before rushing to eliminate the proven dGPS system. 

As Pilots, we rely upon terrestrial navigation techniques; electronic navigation is a back-up, cross check method.  However, there are numerous areas in which we pilot where precise terrestrial navigation is not timely to allow large vessels to safely pass - the Tracy Arm Bar, Sitkaladik Narrows in Glacier Bay, Wrangell Narrows, and Hawk Inlet and we are forced to integrate "eNav" into our methodologies. Precision is vital.  We are hampered by the risk of severe weather and lack of visibility throughout the year. In addition, the local Coast Guard has proposed reducing some of the fixed aids to navigation in favor of "eNav" - this is directly contradictory to this proposal to reduce dGPS.  I agree with another commenter - "reducing aids to navigation is the wrong direction to take."

Please delay this proposed action until CORS/WAAS is proven equal or better to dGPS for surface users.

Title: Bradford Wheeler
Comment:
I request that the NDGPS system is maintain as is.  WAAS is not yet an IMO approved replacement for DGPS.  
The DGPS system is used by inland operating companies.  The Harbor Pilots have requested 22 of the beacons be maintained 
and operated.  I am a First Class Pilot and Unlimited Master and require the accuracy that DGPS provides without 
the shadow effect that can interrupt the WAAS signal in areas where high structures along the banks of river do not 
allow line of sight to the WAAS Satellite.

Title: Barry Vessels
Comment:
I have a six person team that runs 3 Government hydrographic survey vessels and one dredge to support 650 miles of the Lower Ohio River.  We primarily use DGPS from the Louisville or St. Louis towers for less than one meter accuracy with a high confidence level.   The surveys are used to layout dredge cuts and shared with the Coast Guard cutters for buoy placement.  We do not have any commercial services in the KY area that will cover our area of concern.  The WAAS is not a survey grade system that we can rely on for any certainty of accuracy.   

It appears there is not much use for differential as it is hard to find beacon radio modems and antennas.  The reason, it is so popular the Differential correction beacon is built into all survey grade systems as a standard product.  If you shut the towers down without us having an alternative, it will greatly degrade the accuracies of the base mapping and buoy placement supporting commercial navigation.  Being off 5 meters in a narrow winding river bar area will ground a towboat.  The surveys and buoy placement accuracy is critical.

Barry Vessels GISP
Lead Marine Information Specialist/
Navigation and Dredging Team Leader
Corps of Engineers - Louisville District

Title: Paul Chevalier
Comment:
My name is Paul Chevalier and I am a Captain/Pilot with the Hudson River Pilots Association.  I am writing to say that I am against the removal of DGPS stations especially the Hudson Falls, NY location.  The following reasons are why:

DGPS stations provide reliable terrestrial correction signal of the GPS signal.

The upper part of the Hudson River, including Albany is in a single coverage area, this coverage is provided by the Hudson Falls station.

Radio beacon DGPS correction is optimized for surface navigation, WAAS is intended for air navigation.

Redundant DGPS signals are important because a signal can be lost during maintenance of a station and in thunderstorms

As a New York State Licensed Pilot I am mandated to carry portable navigation computers that rely on the Hudson Falls DGPS signal.

I ask that these reasons be heavily considered and that the DGPS stations not be removed.  Hudson Falls DGPS station is not only used by State Licenses Pilots, it is also used by enrolled Tug and Barges transiting to and from the Port of Albany.  An accurate signal which is located near the port is very crucial and if the Hudson Falls location was removed the nearest station would be approximately 150 miles away.

Thank you for your time and consideration,
Captain Paul Chevalier
Vice President 
Hudson River Pilots Association

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am a professional marine surveyor practicing in New Jersey. Removing the GPS base stations, particularly in areas where there are few existing COORS will have a detrimental affect on marine surveying in those areas. Please do not remove these crucial stations - my small business relies on the service they provide.

Title: John Gustin
Comment: I am a Professional Surveyor and Mapper. Our company provides surveying and mapping services to the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers. These mapping services include hydrographic surveys of the Inland Waterways primarily for the determination of the 9 ft. depth contour for safe navigation. We also map features on the inland waterways which are pertinent to navigation such as bridges, docks, jetties, etc... The data from these surveys is used to create and update the Inland Electronic Navigational Charts (IENCs). The IENCs are used by the commercial Towing Industry Towboat Pilots to navigate the waterways safely. The IENCs are also used by a large number of recreational boaters. The Nationwide Differential Global Positioning System (NDGPS) has provided our survey crews with a very reliable and accurately corrected position for performing these surveys. Alternative means of position corrections are more costly and less reliable. These surveys and the resulting charts are a matter of public safety.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Differential correction is invaluable in survey applications and should not be decommisioned or degraded.

Comment: If these sites are shut down , it will put small farmers out of business, to have to buy replacement equipment

Title: J.B.
Comment: For both professional and recreational purposes, it would be a crying shame to see the DGPS crippled as is currently being proposed.  As a master mariner, a professional hydrographic surveyor and a recreational mariner, I kindly and emphatically request that the DGPS system be expanded and certainly not be systematically dismantled.  Both my livelihood and my safety while recreationally boating will be dramatically impacted should the proposed actions be followed through with.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I believe the DGPS stations are to instrumental for the security of or nations Ship Channels especially on the Gulf Coast. It is already a difficult enough job, without the DGPS stations for some agencies it will become impossible. Please do what you need to do to keep the DGPS stations up and running.

Title: Christian Shaw
Comment:
Please do not close all of these stations! I use them every day for boats and dredges that survey and dig our ports and harbors! 

Christian Shaw
HYPACK INC
Chrisitan@HYPACK.COM

Title: Sam Robinson
Comment: Please do not close these stations! We use them everyday on our dredging and surveying projects all over the country. Our work is all inland and we rely solely on these stations for our equipment guidance systems. This is not something that will be easily worked around and will cost our company a lot of time and money. Dredge America, Inc.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I am a surveyor and we use the CG beacons as the only means of correcting DGPS, without it we are dead in the water.  We need these to survive to keep working.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Don't do it! We need accurate GPS data to build America safely!

Title: William Kennedy
Comment:
To All party's concerned,
My name is William Kennedy and I am a pilot in South East Alaska. I feel the removal of the DGPS system in our area (SE Alaska) will greatly reduce navigation safety. We routinely encounter strong currents,wind and restricted visibility and frequently  transit narrow passes and channels where accurately monitoring the vessels position and movement is critical. 
The old mantra of not relying on one tool is as pertinent today as ever but the second part of this mantra is to use all your available tools and DGPS is an important one.
Please consider maintaining the DGPS system.
Thank you

Title: Garrett Johnson
Comment: Please  don't shut down these important sites.   I pilot cruise ships in Southeast Alaska with as many as 4000 people aboard and we rely on differential GPS and electronic charts as one of the primary means of navigation. Title: Lake Carriers Association
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Joan Sizemore
Comment:
My name is Captain Joan Sizemore and I am a member of the Southeast Alaska Pilots' Association.
 SEAPA is an association of Marine Pilots who frequently use the DGPS sites at Level Island, Biorka, and Gustavus, AK (which are slated for de-commissioning.)   The World's commercial fleets (and the USCG) are rapidly embracing electronic charts, and de-emphasizing traditional means of terrestrial navigation and paper charts. 
Due to the navigational hazards in Alaska, extreme weather and sea conditions, occasional poor satellite coverage due to the fjords, and the extreme sensitivity to environmental issues here, I don't feel that any degradation of navigational accuracy is appropriate.  Glacier Bay National Park and the Tongass National Forest are arguably the most environmentally sensitive maritime areas in North America and could be devastated by a navigation mishap.  Reducing the accuracy of the electronic navigation infrastructure in these areas is counter to the goals of protecting our pristine waters.
I strongly urge you to keep our DGPS sites operational."

Title: Kelly Bellis
Comment:
From what I've read, it sounds as if only the live broadcasts would be coming to an end on January 15, 2016. CORS data from those slated stations otherwise used in post-processing; e.g., OPUS, etc., also coming to an end wasn't clearly stated leading me to only wonder about their ultimate fate.

The pool of users negatively impacted by live broadcasts ceasing on January 15, 2016 will be considerably smaller than those users presently engaged in precise surveying and other scientific activities related to those 62 stations if these CORS are completely abandoned.

As a measure of the impact/ blowback, consider a trial period (not permanent) for their closure beginning on January 15, 2016. Extend the comment period until April 15, 2016 and thereby capture a more realistic metric in assessing the actual impact as there may be many users unaware of DOT's notice.

Title: Resilient Navigation and Timing Foundation
Comment:
Docket Number DOT-OST-2015-0105 
Nationwide Differential Global Positioning System

The Resilient Navigation and Timing Foundation is dedicated to reinforcing and protecting our nation's essential Position, Navigation, and Timing (PNT) services. PNT services are essential for virtually every technology. We must have multiple and robust sources of PNT so that a disruption to one will not threaten our nation's security and economy.

We understand and do not object to the administration's determination that the Nationwide Differential Global Positioning System (NDGPS) is sufficiently like the Wide Area Augmentation System (WAAS) in its phenomenology and services provided such that it does not provide significant incremental benefit to the nation's PNT architecture as a whole. We do not object to termination of the signals from the 62 sites.

However, we note that the nation's current PNT architecture, including NDGPS and WAAS, is almost entirely dependent upon the Global Positioning System (GPS). In fact, GPS has been identified by senior officials in the Department of Homeland Security as "...a single point of failure for critical infrastructure." 

Having a single, vulnerable source of primary PNT is a far cry from the multi-layered, multi-phenomenology architecture called for in the inter-department National PNT Architecture Study Final Report published in September of 2008. 

Some or all of the 62 NDGPS sites (and associated equipment) could play an important role in achieving the PNT architecture America needs.  Disposing of them before we are assured they are not useful in completing that architecture is against the national interest and would not be the best use of government assets and funds.

The RNT Foundation objects to decommissioning the sites and disposal of any real or personal property as proposed in the announcement until the administration decides upon and implements a resilient PNT architecture that supports national security and economic vitality.

Title: Scott Ireland
Comment:
Dear DOT,

My name is Captain Scott Ireland. I am the Senior River Pilot with the Hudson River Pilots Association. Myself and other professional mariners working on the Hudson River are charged with safely and efficiently moving commercial vessels of all sizes, with any cargo, on the Hudson River to ports as far north as Albany NY

I'm writing to register my dismay and strong opposition to the proposal to decommission the Hudson Falls DGPS site. 

By New York State regulation, pilots are required to carry on board and utilize a satellite based navigation system. The Hudson Falls radio beacon DPGS correction is an invaluable tool that allows us to accurately pinpoint our vessels position in a river that has an unusually long and narrow shipping channel ( 50 miles long  x 400ft wide ) from Kingston NY to Albany. 

Through this narrow channel, along with a myriad of other cargoes, ships and barges carry millions of barrels of diesel fuel oil and more millions of barrels of Bakken Crude Oil. The DGPS signal correction from Hudson Falls is a crucial tool in ensuring that the safe transport of cargo....including hazardous cargo.... is done in a manner that both protects the environment and safely keeps commerce flowing.

The idea that the only DGPS station available in the upper Hudson Valley, an area of single station coverage, is being considered for decommission is, in my humble opinion, an action of navigational malpractice and is exceedingly ill considered.

I most strongly urge that the DOT withdraw any such plan to decommission the Hudson Falls DGPS site.

Regards,

Capt. Scott Ireland
Hudson River Pilots Assoc.
36 Rolling Ridge Rd.
Hyde Park NY 12538
845-988-7318
rvrpilot@gmail.com

Title: U.S. Geological Survey
Comment:
The U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) is commenting on the Federal Register Notice about the proposed shutdown and decommissioning of 62 National Differential Global Positioning System (NDGPS) sites, some of which currently support the ability of the USGS to assess and monitor natural hazards, surface water flows, and groundwater resources.

The USGS is the lead federal agency responsible for providing assessments and warnings for volcanic eruptions, earthquakes, and landslides.  In support of that mission, the USGS processes data from various GPS networks, including some NDGPS sites.  We have assessed the potential impact of the decommissioning of 62 NDGPS stations and find that loss of the following stations would negatively impact USGS capabilities:

1.  In Alaska, the USGS is concerned about the potential loss of the Cold Bay NDGPS site, which would have a significant impact on monitoring volcanoes in the Aleutian island chain.  The Cold Bay site is used by the USGS Alaska Volcano Observatory as an off-volcano reference station for Unimak Island volcanoes (especially Shishaldin, one of the most active Aleutian volcanoes), enabling a clearer picture of the volcanic signal, which is especially important during a crisis.  Another site on the list to be decommissioned is Kenai/Nisiki, which was used for volcano monitoring until 2008, when its signal became too noisy due to an equipment change and was no longer of use.

2.  In California, the USGS is concerned about the potential loss of the Pigeon Point NDGPS site, which would negatively impact the USGS's ability to monitor earthquakes on the San Gregorio fault zone, since it is one of the few sites to the west of this fault.  The San Gregorio fault is located west of the San Andreas fault in northern California.  GPS data provide important information about the amount of motion accommodated on this fault, however because it is located largely offshore opportunities to collect such measurements are limited.  Paleoseismic evidence for earthquake offsets of 3 - >5 meters suggest that this fault is capable of producing earthquakes of magnitude 7 - 7.5.  A magnitude 7.5 earthquake on the San Gregorio fault between San Francisco and Monterey would produce very strong to severe shaking with moderate to heavy damage in San Francisco, the Peninsula, and coastal communities.

In support of its water mission, the USGS post-processes survey-grade GPS solutions using continually operating reference stations (CORS), partially composed of NDGPS sites, to establish datum among the cooperative streamgage network composed of nearly 8,000 gaging platforms.  These solutions are also used to inter-relate altitude among parts of the cooperative groundwater well network along with a significantly growing Short-Term network of storm-surge and event-based gage platforms.  Survey-grade GPS post-processed solutions are also used for a variety of interpretive investigations such as surface water modeling efforts and inundation mapping.  Effective flood-warnings and forecasts by the National Weather Service, flood-inundation maps of the USGS, all of which are derived from USGS streamgages, are all expressed in terms of elevations and the loss of precession and accuracy from these downgrades could have consequences on these services.

Longer-term (2+ hours) observations using the National Geodetic Survey's Online Position Users Service - Static (OPUS-S) required for post-processed solutions would still be permissible given the 62 NDGPS reduction; however, more expedient GPS work involving short-term observations (15 minute) using the National Geodetic Survey's - Online Position Users Service - Rapid Static (OPUS-RS) would have some degree of impact and solution degradation due to the 62 NDGPS reduction.  In terms of OPUS-RS, figure 1 identifies areas of solution degradation (0.5 - 1.0 cm.) in some parts of the U.S.; areas in black would lose the ability completely to provide these short-term observations for processing. Areas in Puerto Rico, islands of Oahu and Kauai, western Nevada, parts of Montana, and northwest Mississippi would likely be most impacted when attempting to conduct short-term GPS observations for post-processing.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Maintain the current system.

Title: Prentice Strong
Comment:
My name is Captain Prentice Strong III and I am a member of Penobscot Bay and River Pilots Association.  Our association
pilots all commercial vessels transiting the waters of Penobscot and Frenchman Bay's in the state of Maine.

For over 15 years we have carried PPU's (Pilot Portable Navigation Units) aboard the vessels we pilot.  These units use differential
GPS corrections from either the Penobscot or Brunswick differential stations to provide us with the most accurate position
fixing available for our area.  We do not believe we will continue to be able to utilize differential corrections for our PPU's if 
both stations in Maine are shut down and that accuracy of position fixing will be potentially degraded, especially in the 
Penobscot River.

We request that at least one DGPS station remain open in Maine, preferably Penobscot, and we can live with Brunswick.

Title: U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, St. Paul District
Comment:
SUBJECT: Review of Federal Register Notice: Nationwide Differential Global Positioning System (NDGPS) - Docket number DOT-OST-2015-0105.

The US Army Corps of Engineers, St. Paul District maintains 22 navigation projects throughout Minnesota, Wisconsin, and Iowa.  These projects include the Upper Mississippi River, Minnesota River, and several commercial and recreational harbors to name a few.  The District depends on the Alma DGPS tower for hydrographic survey and dredging operations.  The following units would be impacted: Survey Launch 21, Survey Launch 22, Portable Survey Systems, Dredge Goetz, Dredge Dubuque, Government Mechanical Dredge Plant, two Contract Mechanical Dredge Plants, plus any contractor working on placement site unloading contracts and Upper Mississippi River Restoration projects.  Shutting down the Alma tower without having an alternative will greatly degrade accuracies of the survey mapping and buoy placement supporting commercial navigation.  Accuracy is critical due narrow and winding river conditions.  Channel shoaling and underwater navigation control structures like wing dams need to be accurately marked.

Currently there are no reliable alternatives that would keep all users as productive as utilizing the Alma tower.  Alternatives would have a large upfront financial impact and would need to be tested to ensure that all survey areas within the district have corrected GPS accessibility.  We have many areas where cell phone coverage is weak or non-existent and setting up RTK base stations would be problematic.  Other alternatives would have a major negative impact to production and could jeopardize the 9 foot navigation channel mission.  

We strongly recommend reconsidering the decision to close the Alma tower site or at a minimum postpone closure for two years to allow us time to obtain additional equipment and adjust field operations.


Steve Tapp
Operations Manager
Channels & Harbors Project Office
St. Paul District Corps of Engineers

Title: Barry Olver
Comment:
As a Southeast Alaska (Marine) Pilot operating in Alaska's Region One I write to strongly urge the continued operation of the DGPS sites at Level Island, Biorka Island, and Gustavus, AK.  Decommissioning of these sites will seriously degrade the accuracy of positioning data available to marine traffic in the region thus also diminishing the safety of navigation.  

Although, in theory, there is duplicate coverage in WAAS/CORS this is unproven, and not approved by IMO, or APA.  The Southeast Alaska region is home to natural resource treasures that would suffer immeasurable damage from a marine incident.  DGPS is a reliable, proven resource of position data available to the myriad of users in a region of challenging weather conditions, and narrow fjords surrounded by high mountains whose bases frame the waterways.  WAAS signals are known to suffer from the shadow effect of high peaks, and coverage for surface (marine) users is unproven.

The trend in marine navigation, with the advances in technology and use of electronic chart systems,  is to stray ever farther from visual means of navigation.  Some of the larger cruise ships sailing the waters of the world visit Southeast Alaska waters and the push by industry is to navigate these vessels on a track-keeping autopilot linked to the DGPS.  As a pilot I oppose this means of navigation and pilot with visual means as a primary resource, but also carry a PPU as a secondary means of verification.  This portable pilot unit (ECS) obtains position, heading, course, speed, AIS data from the vessel (and also has an internal DGPS) providing a refined check on ship displays (ECDIS).  The vessel GPS units (as well as other electronics) are foreign-flag state chosen, and not under the control of the pilot.  It is unknown what percentage of these vessels can even utilize WAAS data.  Additionally the thousands of users of DGPS data, from recreational craft, commercial fishing, commercial cargo, and passengers vessels will operate on degraded GPS data.  It can not be expected that all of these users will be able to upgrade to WAAS capable units by January 2016, even if proven a reliable substitute for DGPS.

Again, I strongly urge you keep the Southeast Alaska DGPS sites operational.

Title: Tyler Lulich
Comment: NDGPS is part of the Continuously Operating Reference Stations (CORS) network, which is used with GPS data to improve the precision of positioning.  The value of long-term data from these CORS sites for science, land surveying, and mapping applications is of very high value.  Please do not shutdown these NDGPS sites, some of which have been operating continuously for almost 20 years.

Title: William Holt
Comment:
I am a Professor at Stony Brook University involved in research on continental dynamics and transient deformation processes. These CORS sites are providing the only long-term measurement of potential displacements in eastern North America. Such a data set is all we have to potentially quantify a signal that we have speculated about for decades: a tectonic loading signal. What makes this network important is its density of coverage. The network is turning out to be of fundamental importance for earthquake hazards estimates within eastern U.S.. The western U.S. has a large number of stations that were put into place to measure rapid tectonic strains. On the east coast, deformation is much slower. Measuring potential intraplate strains has proven very difficult because rates are very low. Because the coverage is dense, and the time period covered relatively long, it is possible to begin to measure this signal. Directly measuring a signal of internal intraplate strains is something never before achieved for an intraplate region. Given the importance for earthquake hazards estimates and the impact on planning for infrastracture,  nuclear facilities, etc., I would consider this network of primary national importance. Given the population density in the central and eastern U.S., this network is of high value to taxpayers. 

Secondly, we are now looking at this network of displacements during and following major storms. We have observed a large signal following Hurricane Sandy that may represent a new observation of solid Earth deformation in response to storm surge loading. We are currently writing this result up for publication. It is impossible to determine what signal or signals might be detected next with this network, but its coverage and placement as part of a national infrastructure is of critical importance.

Title: Jack Eggleston
Comment:
I strongly encourage the Coast Guard to continue operating the NDGPS sites that it has proposed to shut down.  These sites provide valuable data.

At the US Geological Survey we are using data from these sites to monitor land subsidence in the Hampton Roads region and elsewhere.  The loss of the NDGPS site in Driver, VA (CORS site DRV6) would be particularly harmful to our efforts to determine rates of land subsidence in Hampton Roads.

These long-term sites are particularly valuable because they provide uninterrupted description of vertical land motion.  The longer a site has been operating the more valuable it is.  The DRV6 site and others like it on the proposed list have been in operation longer that most other sites on the CORS network.

Please do not cease operation of these sites.

Title: US Army Corps of Engineers, Rock Island District
Organization Name: US Army Corps of Engineers, Rock Island District
Comment:
The US Army Corps of Engineers, Rock Island District depends on the Rock Island and St Louis DGPS towers for hydrographic survey and dredging operations. The district has 3 hydrographic survey vessels and utilizes 3 mechanical dredging plants, a government owned hydraulic dredge, and a contract dredge that rely on these towers for positioning.  Loss of these towers without having a reliable alternative will severely reduce accuracy of hydrographic surveys and dredging operations, increasing potential for marine casualties related to shoaling or other channel obstructions. 

Currently there are no alternatives to these towers that provide both the required accuracy and coverage area needed for our operations on the Illinois and Mississippi Rivers.  Alternatives such as subscription services that require internet access and/or cell coverage cannot be relied upon due to loss of signal in remote areas, and WAAS has not been demonstrated to provide sufficient accuracy.

We strongly recommend maintaining the Rock Island and St. Louis tower sites for at least two years to allow us time to establish a suitable alternative for positioning.

Jon A. Klingman
Chief, Channel Maintenance Section
Operations Division 
Clock Tower Building
Rock Island, IL 61204

Title: Roland Burgmann
Comment:
Researchers at the Berkeley Seismological Laboratory and the Active Tectonics group at UC Berkeley rely on data from continuous GPS stations for earthquake research and mitigation efforts. Data from stations considered for termination in California have played an important role in this work. For example, the station at Pigeon Pt. has provided valuable information for ongoing research by my group on slip rates on the San Gregorio and San Andreas faults in the San Francisco Bay Area, for almost 20 years. It is the continuous time series of daily positions spanning many years that make this and other CORS stations particularly valuable. 

Continuous GPS data are also used for rapid characterization of earthquake ruptures following major events, which informs community earthquake response efforts. Finally, GPS from continuously operating GPS stations is playing an integral role in the earthquake early warning (EEW) systems developed for the western United States. We hope that solutions can be developed that will ensure the continuation of these important stations. Continuous GPS networks represent a valuable national infrastructure for a increasingly diverse range of applications spanning many scientific and applied fields.  
Best regards,
Roland Burgmann
Professor, Earth and Planetary Science

Title: Thomas James
Comment: I would note that two of the sites that are being proposed to be shut down have been used to generate projections of relative sea-level change, based on the IPCC AR5 (Brunswick, ME, and Robinson Point, WA) (document attached).  There is great value to long-established GPS sites with stable (or relatively stable) time series for sea-level and earthquake hazard studies.

Title: Angela Jarding
Comment:
The Medora site in North Dakota and Whitney site in Nebraska are very beneficial to National Parks located in that region. I fear we would lose GPS position accuracy which is needed for research/monitoring in parks.  We need inland sites to be managed by a different agency, not discontinued.

Thank you.

Title: Robert McCaffrey
Comment:
The GPS sites to be removed are important sources of crustal deformation data that are used in the assessment of earthquake hazards. Some of them record transient (non-steady) motions that have revolutionized our understanding of the Earth and the earthquake cycle. I use the data for my research that is currently funded by the USGS and NSF.
Thank you.

Title: Thomas Lyman
Comment: I very strongly urge the Department of Transportation to maintain the DGPS system nationwide.  This has proven to be extremely useful to a wide variety of surveyors, farmers, wildlife biologists and many others who depend on cost-effective higher accuracy GPS positioning and location.  There are a great many DGPS receivers that are still in operation for mapping, location, travel, law enforcement, safety and search and rescue operations that depend on the Coast Guard and Corps of Engineers differential signals for better accuracy. To close down or abandon this system would be a huge disservice and is not justified.

Title: Nicholas Hazelton
Comment:
While the NDGPS is becoming less needed, largely because it has been superseded by WAAS and related services, the CORS themselves are critically important, especially in Alaska. Alaska has more coastline than the rest of the US combined, and relatively few CORS for its size. As there is relatively poor alternative control in Alaska, and our datums are completely dependent on GNSS positioning, we separately need more CORS, not fewer. Current estimates suggest as many as 100 more CORS are important to provide infrastructure support.

As far as the CORS themselves are concerned, their operation is relatively cheap, compared to their original establishment and the benefits that derive from having them in the CORS network. Before these sites are decommissioned, alternatives should be sought for operational support. Other agencies may be able to assist, as can private companies who use the services that CORS provide. Removal of the NDGPS service will significantly reduce costs, and as the CORS can send data direct to NGS, the main cost is the data connection and the power, both of which are small, and can usually be included in the cost of a small office without being noticed. So another party could easily take over the CORS operation as CORS without incurring significant cost.

I note that one of the CORS has already had a major technical failure and been switched off (Cape Hinchenbrook, CHI6), and some of the Coast Guard sites actually have two CORS. While it often seems that there are plenty of CORS available, many of the UNAVCO-PBO sites are not as reliable as we might like, as they were not necessarily established with a view to continuous data collection and uploading to the CORS system at NGS.

In summary, CORS are as critical a piece of infrastructure for a modern nation as roads, rail lines and power networks. It is unfortunate that they are designed to be unobtrusive, and the infrastructure to which they provide immediate support is not always obvious. However, that does not mean that this infrastructure is any less critical to the nation than roads. In Alaska, with a dearth of roads and high reliance on sea and air for transportation and the movement of goods, a high-reliability CORS network is critical to safe travel and continued development of the region.

As a working surveyor for the past 40 years across three continents, as well as having been heavily involved in infrastructure development and implementation, I know how critically important this infrastructure is, and what are the consequences of allowing it to run down. I therefore strongly urge you to reconsider decommissioning these CORS sites, looking at alternative means of keeping them operational, as a means of aiding the common good of Alaska and the nation.

Title: Eric Lindsey
Comment:
As a postdoctoral researcher at UC Berkeley, I use GPS observations to study tectonic deformation as well as land subsidence related to human activities. For both of these applications, the rate of motion of the ground is small (millimeters per year), and accurate measurements require a long time series. Thus, the most valuable asset in these types of earth-monitoring applications is a long-running GPS station.

Although I do not directly use the broadcast DGPS service, the archived data collected by these 62 long-running stations is critical to my research. If these sites are decommissioned, the continuity of the timeseries will be lost, and my research will be severely impacted in a way that cannot easily be repaired by establishing new sites. 

If budget constraints require a cutback of some kind, may I suggest that the real-time DGPS aspect of these sites could be curtailed while retaining the operability and archival of the GPS data. This would allow scientific use of the data to continue, and ensure these stations continue to become even more valuable to the scientific community.

Title: Joe Bergan
Comment:
There is no technology readily available to replace NDGPS.  I want the best accuracy for pilotage on the Great Lakes. There needs to be continued redundancy in GPS navigation. Presently our Receiver default is NDGPS for best 10 cm accuracy then Wide Area Augmentation System (WAAS) then standard GPS 30 meter accuracy.
I don't think it is fair that NDGPS accuracy should be only available for pilots on the East coast. The Great Lakes are a environmentally sensitive area that more harm could be done in the event of a worst case discharge from a grounding due to navigation error from a inaccurate GPS signal.
Please continue to operate NDGPS transmitters on the Great Lakes.

Title: Jim Harned
Comment: The value of the DGPS stations to OPUS and OPUS-RS users for daily commerce cannot be over-stated  particularly in Midwest and Plains states where GPS is the go to technology for a majority of the survey services provided.  Are there private services that can replace these stations in some areas, yes, but that fee would be passed along to the consumer in an already stressed market place.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Hi, I'm in the GPS line cutting business for forestry and development and if you do away with the DGPS sites in North Carolina it will impact my business tremendously.  We currently have three of these GPS systems that will require this correctional signal.  There are a lot more businesses that use this system than you realize.   Don't know why you would even consider doing away with this signal.  Please reconsider your decision in this matter for it will impact my business greatly.

Title: Tom Whidden
Comment: Please don not shut down these stations....we use them daily.

Title: Lee Hines
Comment:
I am the Vice President of a small survey company in Louisiana. We have contracts with the US Army Corps of Engineers that "require" 
that we use the Coast Guard Navigation Beacon. Our current contracts require us to use this positioning system in the Mississippi River 
from above Memphis, Tenn to the Gulf of Mexico. Without the Vicksburg tower we will not be able to meet the requirements of
our contract plus to provide a similar accuracy to the Government we will have to establish our own system at a huge cost increase to t
the Government. We need this system to stay alive on the Mississippi River system.

Title: Jason Croop
Comment: Please maintain the current system.  As a captain, hydrographer and surveyor that frequently works with private, state and federal entities these beacons are an important part of the work we do and the data we collect.  Disruption of this service would make this work impossible in many locations where accurate positioning is needed.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: All 82 DGPS sites currently in operation are used daily by numerous private and public groups engaged in recreational or commercial activities. This is good for the economy on so many levels and in so many places. I believe it would be a short-sighted mistake to decommision 62 of the sites leaving only 22 operational sites. I strongly object to this proposal to decommision these sites.

Title: Judith Powers
Comment:
:I am a journalist specializing in the dredging, hydrographic surveying and marine construction industries since 1977. I was on hand to cover the construction of the NDGPS towers, its purpose in providing an unbroken network of signals for what turned out to be sub-meter, real time kinematic (RTK) accuracy, and the evolution of GPS receivers. With the presence of this system, dredging and hydro survey vessels evolved to automate all functions. On dredges, the kinematic updates allowed x, y, z data on river and tidal stage and position of the cutting tool; estimating amounts already excavated and still to be excavated, and precise vessel location both for navigation and digging location -- all integrated by proprietary and purchased software to produce reports of unprecedented accuracy. Hydrographic survey boats using the system are also able to use the system in RTK mode for navigation, depths and sediment volumes for unprecedented accuracy in survey charts. 

A system that has had such an important effect on technology advancement, and which has provided sub-meter accuracy for so many for two decades cannot be judged to be "not used by anyone" with as little research as was done prior to making this decisison. 

Many users have progressed to other modes of position correction, but in conversations with people in the industry, I am finding that even those who are not using the NDGPS system as a primary source of position corrections believe that the system provides a necessary layer of redundancy in what could be life-threatening situations should another system fail, even briefly. I hope that for safety's sake and for the sake of the many making comments on this site who are using the system as a primary source of positioning, the agencies will see that shutting the system down would be a waste, if not a disaster for many users.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: I strongly encourage the Coast Guard to continue operating the NDGPS sites that it has proposed to shut down. These sites provide valuable data. Users of unmanned vehicles, such as my research group, rely on these sensors for vehicle navigation. While WAAS GPS works on some of our newer systems, our older vehicles still use DGPS. Please do not cease operation of these sites.

Title: Randy McFarland
Comment: Coast Guard GPS benchmark stations are critical for monitoring land subsidence along the U.S. east coast that is contributing to regional sea-level rise. Particularly important is station DRV6 in the Hampton Roads area of Virginia, where land subsidence is anomalously high compared to elsewhere. Monitoring of land subsidence that is enabled by Coast Guard GPS benchmark stations is fundamental to protecting critical infrastructure here that includes Norfolk Naval Base, numerous other military installations, and one of the most vital industrial complexes in the country.

Title: Kurt McCoy
Comment: Keep active DRV6 in the Hampton Roads area of Virginia.  The data from this station is very important to understanding land subsidence in the area.

Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Comment from Seth Johnson
Comment: Please do not shutdown these sites.  We use the Duluth, MN site for all our surveying the the Duluth/ Superior Harbor.

Title: Comment from David Olin
Comment: Very Bad Idea. The infrastructure is already in place. Thousands of surveyors and scientists depend on this data for mapping. Please keep them operational. Our very expensive DGPS receivers will be paperweights.

Title: Comment from Scott Kichman
Comment:
Please review the attached report for information regarding information on the use of CORS, DGPS and WAAS on the Big Island in Hawai'i.

 The loss of DGPS would adversely affect Real time correction for all the Hawaiian Islands.

Title: Comment from Patrick Burke
Comment: I am against the reduction in DGPS signal beacons around the US. I am an archaeological surveyor who relies on DGPS signal to accurately navigate on many types of waterways. Using base stations to establish what DGPS is already doing in many areas is not feasible. Losing these stations will degrade signal solution, and thereby the data we collect. Without current DGPS coverage, many operators like myself will not be able to operate as accurately, often on projects that involve critical national infrastructure. First we lost LORAN as a backup, and now we degrade our GPS accuracy? Lets move forward, not backward. Thank you.

Comment: See attached file

Title: Comment from Bruce Howe
Comment: Navigation, positioning and precise timing are essential elements of our modern civilization. Common sense dictates that one does not put all your critical infrastructure eggs in one basket - diversity is essential. Keeping DGPS services is one aspect of this. Related also is maintaining/implementing eLoran for the same reasons.
