Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment: Being a hydrographic surveyor for the last 40+ years, I am dumbfounded that an innovation like the Nationwide Differential GPS system, which in a lot of cases brought us out of the dark ages as far a surveying methodology goes, is being considered for decommision. We went from carrying marine batteries and setting up shore-based microwave sytems to receiving RTCM corrections from these sites and you would have thought there could be nothing better. I know a lot of surveyors still rely on this system. And removing the only one in Puerto Rico, you have to be kidding me. Please reconsider this proposal and continue to provide this most valuable service. Thank you.

Title: Comment from American Pilots' Association
Comment: The APA is of the view that terminating certain NDGPS sites at this time would be a mistake that would have a significantly negative impact on the safety of navigation in those areas.  Given the relatively small cost for the federal government to maintain individual NDGPS sites, combined with the enormous potential costs (both in dollars and damage to the environment) of a substantial reduction in navigation safety in near-coastal, harbor entrance and approach, and inland waters, it would be in the best interests of safety to retain certain NDGPS sites.  Accordingly, the APA requests those sites listed in the attached Annex, as well as sites that may be identified in separate comments by local pilots' associations be retained and remain operational.  See attached file(s)

Title: Comment from Jonathon Roder
Comment: The stations proposed to be commissioned by the Coast Guard are critical for GPS surveys in many mapping projects our small company performs. The stations enable surveyors and other specialists to access quality data to perform surveys which would be more costly and less efficient without them. In addition, the need is critical in Alaska where we have less CORS stations per land area than any other state in the nation.

Title: Comment from Karen Anderson
Comment:
At Acadia National Park, we depend on submeter navigation accuracy to relocate certain long-term research plots which are marked mimimalistically to reduce both hazards to and disturbance by park visitors.   WAAS not a viable option for this purpose in most areas here due to vegetation canopy (WAAS use required a direct line of sight).   And while internet streaming services are available for DGPS, cellular coverage in our area, and many other remote areas, is poor, so it is not a good field navigation option either.  The other alternatives for realtime submeter navigation for plot relocation require significant monetary investments or recurring costs for services.  We still have and use GPS equipment that will receive the NDGPS signal.

Of additional concern is the possibility of losing the CORS stations that are currently providing data for the NDGPS broadcast.  The Penobscot, ME CORS site is the closest CORS to some parts of Acadia National Park and for other parts of the park, we have used it when BARH data is unavailable;  the next closest sites beyond that are almost twice as far away.

Our preference would be to see the Penobscot NDGPS and underlying CORS remain functioning.

Title: Comment from Captain Clint Winegar
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Comment from Robert Goldman
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Comment from Lara Bender
Comment: I am a hydrographic surveyor for the Midwest Region of the National Park Service and conduct benthic mapping operations at three Lake Superior National Parks.  We use multibeam sonar for mapping, which relies on high-accuracy GPS data to spatially orient bathymetric data.  Our data is post-processed to improve positioning.  Closure of two of the NDGPS sites, Upper Keweenaw and Wisconsin Point, would impact our ability to provide high quality data to our National Parks.  This bathymetric data is used for a variety of restoration and research projects critical to the long-term health of these areas.  We request that these sites remain in operation to maintain high quality GPS data in the Great Lakes region.

Title: Comment from Lindsey  Williams
Comment: The attached commentary, related to Docket DOT-OST-2015-0105 (NDGPS), is hereby submitted by Delphi Automotive.

Title: Comment from Robert Markle
Organization Name: Radio Technical Commission for Maritime Services

Title: Comment from Joel Viers
Comment:
These sites are still quite useful. First as a student then as an instructor these sites provided great data and instructional opportunities, and of course useful scientific data.. 
For the minimal cost involved I urge these not be closed for now; perhaps in the future a revaluation would be helpful.

Title: Comment from Samuel Greenaway
Comment: The NOAA Office of Coast Survey has relied on NDGPS to meet our horizontal positioning requirements for hydrographic surveys for decades.  We have found the system to be reliable, easy to implement in the field and robust.  With the growing difficulty of sourcing commercial DGPS receivers and the expansion of alternatives, we have been exploring alternative approaches to precision positioning.  We now have hardware and procedures in place to transition away from reliance on the NDGPS systems and have no objection to the planned decommissioning of 62 NDGPS sites.

Title: Comment from Robert Rich
Comment:
Hello,
I am commenting on behalf of the Columbia River Towboat Association, representing the multiple tug and barge lines that operate on the Columbia Snake River system.  We account for approximately 1400 to 1500 commercial barge tows transiting from the deep draft lower Columbia River Ports of Longview, Kalama, Vancouver and Portland, destined to the 28 upriver ports as far away as Lewiston Idaho, 365 miles east thru 8 Navlocks.  Our members strongly support the continuation of the DGPS system of enhanced accuracy for just that: enhanced accuracy in navigation. As the Columbia transitions into the narrow twisting Snake River canyons, bridge transits, shallow channels, and general navigation are dependent on the tightest of margins for safety and reliability. In particular, the Spokane and Appleton stations in WA, and Seneca in OR are of significant value to the system, as they provide the safety net of system coverage for our area of operation.  We well understand that with advances in satellite navigational technology, some earlier systems become obsolete, such as Loran.  But in this case, the extra margin of accuracy, placing a vessel and tow accurate to within 1 to 2 meters, rather than the 12 to 15 that un-enhanced GPS can sometimes give, is critical.  We strongly urge you to maintain these stations in order to continue to ensure the significantly enhanced margin of safety and accuracy they now provide.  we will be glad to revisit this proposal in the future as further gains in GPS accuracy are made.
best regards, Rob Rich, CRTA President.

Title: Comment from Michael Dennis
Comment:
My recommendation is that these sites only be partially decommissioned.  By that I mean terminating the real-time differential service and removing the secondary GNSS antenna and receiver.  The primary antenna and receiver should remain in place as an existing part of the NGS CORS network.  In that capacity they should continue to log GNSS data without interruption, and the data should continue to be publicly accessible through the NGS CORS website.

I believe all the sites proposed for decommission have existed for many years.  In fact, some of the oldest NGS CORS are NDGPS stations.  As such they represent valuable continuous monitoring sites valuable for scientific, engineering, and positioning applications.  I have personally made heavy use of one of the sites (Flagstaff) since it was installed in 2000.

Most of the sites at risk also form the foundation of the national network of geodetic control stations.  These stations were held as constraints in the 2007 and 2011 national adjustments.  Continuity of use helps maintain network integrity.

In addition, in some areas (such as Alaska), the NDGPS CORS are the only CORS available for very large geographic regions.  Their removal would significantly compromise the existing CORS network in those areas, and thus negatively impact users of those CORS.  Moreover, much of Alaska is tectonically active, and removal of such CORS would be a major data loss in what is already sparse coverage.  A similar thing can be for the tectonically active areas of the western coterminous US.

In summary, I am hopeful those responsible for deciding the fate of these sites will consider leaving the existing primary antenna and receiver in place.  These represent a substantial investment in existing spatial infrastructure, and the replacement costs would be far greater than the costs of continued operation.  So I believe the savings gained by entirely decommissioning the sites is false economy.

Title: Comment from Larry Pullin
Comment:
I am a 20+ year pilot in the SE region of Alaska.  I rely on a portable navigation unit that interfaces with ship board GPS receivers for enhanced information regarding ship position, conflicting traffic location, and location of current USCG search and rescue operations.  Electronic charting as a component of GPS navigation is currenly replacing traditional paper charts, without accurate GPS positioning the need for this advanced techonoly becomes mute. 
Alaska has many sensitive and navigationaly difficult areas that are frequented by passenger vessels that are up to 1000 ft in length.  These very areas are in fjords and near high mountain ranges that affect the accuracy of normal GPS signals.  I do not believe that a reduction in navigational positioning accuracy is prudent not only from a mariners standpoint but from a safety and environmental standpoint.

Title: Comment from Christopher Wright
Comment: The majority of my work as a Certified Hydrographer and environmental scientist occurs within regions where real-time position accuracy would be impacted by the proposed closures. We would be forced to pass along the substantial costs of alternative subscription-based correction services to our clients, predominantly US Government Agencies. Please reevaluate the economic consequences associated with this proposal.

Title: Comment from Christina  Lee
Comment:
To Whom it may concern:

 

I am reaching out to your company today to let you know the importance of your satellite signal, and what it means to my husbands company. We have been blessed to have this capability to better increased exact pinpoints and productivity with our machines for our customers.
I'm sure your company did quality research on the importance of what the satellite signal means to each state.
My question is who was part of the survey? Was it land surveyors? If the answer is yes, then you should know 
that all land surveyors don't know the importance of this. These companies contract us (mulching businesses) to cut precise lines with the comfort of knowing our work will be accurate. However, they don't always know how that 
is done. 
What you should know is fifty percent of his business is because of the signal you send. Yes, I did mention land surveyors is a part of that, but it also includes government contracts. Having this taking down will be detrimental in meeting the needs of these establishments.
His company is located in eastern North Carolina. As I look over the map of states that will be affected, I'm confused of why NC would be cut out completely. NC is close to several military bases and still is overwhelmed  by the growing population. As you know, the growth of any state will need lines cut and clearing done to help sustain influx of the growing population.

 

I will appreciate your consideration in leaving at least one operational site in our state.  The great state of NC. 

 

Thanks, 

Christina Lee

Title: Comment from Capt. Michael Siepert
Comment:
I would strongly recommend that the NDGPS stations in Brunswick, ME and Penobscot, ME be removed from the list of the NDGPS stations for disestablishment starting Jan. 15, 2016. As a pilot in Portland, ME, we are seeing more and more vessels which are ECDIS only class ships, and they rely heavily on accurate DGPS data in order to perform well. With the increase in size of vessels, deep draft vessels, and restricted visibility that we regularly see, accurate positioning is critical to safe port operations.

In addition to the navigational needs, the bottom surveys that are performed as part of different dredging projects, requires accurate positioning data. We have Federal channels and anchorages that are regularly maintained by dredging, and accurate positioning for this is a must.

Title: Comment from Michael Deane
Comment: This proposed shut down of the "inland station" Hudson Falls will SEVERELY HINDER our ability to SAFELY utilize the corrected DGPS signal while we transit the Hudson River. I am captain of a 490' LOA  ATB that makes regular runs on the river with drafts running from 16.5' thru 23.5'. Since the charts for the river have NOT been updated with recent survey data, we rely on the DGPS signal for accurate placement within the navigable waters and channels while on the Hudson.Please reconsider shutting down the inland station "Hudson Falls" for this reason. This will place our corrected signals being sent from Montauk NY, which would allow for to much error within the confined channels we run. Thanks for your time

Title: Comment from Lou Nash
Comment:
Our company has provided marine positioning, guidance and underwater imaging systems and solutions for the past 18 years.
I consider myself diligent in staying informed of what's going on within our industry.  After seeing an initial reference to the 
proposed DGPS shutdown issue in an on-line news article in early October, I made a number of calls to customers and 
colleagues to see what they knew about the issue.  To a person, no one knew of the proposed shut down.  Concerned by this
seeming lack of knowledge regarding the proposed shutdown, throughout what I see as a fairly large user base, I formed an 
informal "round table" group in an effort to identify concerns of our customer / NDGPS user base as a whole. 

I got together a small group of colleagues, each at the apex of their positions within their given industry or discipline.  These 
persons represent marine contractors and dredgers, GPS hardware manufacturers, ship's captain and harbor pilot associations
as well as the US Army Corps of Engineers and are fairly representative of our customer base.  As a whole, this group uses
100's of DGPS receivers on a daily basis, relying on USCG supplied corrections for their navigation and positioning needs.

Our discussions and findings are summarized below:

-	The DGPS user base relies on the accuracy and dependability delivered by the NDGPS network but does not frequent 
the listings within the Federal Register and hence does not know of the proposed shut down.

-	The NDGPS network performs so well, it's taken for granted by its users.  This adds to the overall problem of what
would be experienced if the system were shut down in a "turn-key" fashion in January, 2016.

-	The fallout from a turnkey shutdown of 62 stations in January, 2016 is incalculable at this point and should be studied
 further prior to any such broad-based decommissioning of the system.

-	There seems to be quite a bit of "misinformation" amongst the small group of proponents that our group contacted that 
needs to be addressed, to include a number of technical issues and the true size of the user base itself. 

-	The NDGPS network is a key component of our nation's infrastructure that needs to remain largely intact.  This includes
both the DGPS broadcasts and the Continuous Operating Reference Stations (CORS) stations within each site that form the 
national Geospatial network for NOAA-NGS. 

My personal opinion, as a tax payer and small business owner,  is that the NDGPS network is truly a national resource and a 
key component to our nation's infrastructure.  You don't need to look far or long to find reference to the deterioration of our 
country's infrastructure and its effect on our status of leadership as a nation and a driver of our nation's economic engine.  Our
inland waterways are a key to the President's stated goal of increasing exports.  The NDGPS network plays a key role in 
servicing these same waterways.  To intentionally degrade this network can only have a negative impact on our nation as a 
whole.

Based on the feedback and responses of our small round table group, (representative of only the customer base I have a 
working relationship with and not including other groups such as GIS practitioners, agricultural users, First Responders, etc.,)
I respectfully request that this issue receive further and more complete due diligence prior to any "turn-key" shut down of the
system.

Title: Comment from Matt King
Comment:
Re proposal to shutdown and discontinue NDGPS sites DOT-OST-2015-0105

GPS located near to tide gauges provide critical control on their stability and vertical land movement. Several of the sites proposed for decommissioning are near to important tide gauges used for climate related work - both in terms of long-term (multi-decadal) sea level measurements and in terms of validation of satellite altimeter missions such as the NASA Topex/Jason series. King (2014) reported to the UN Global Sea Level Observing System (GLOSS) program detailing areas of need for new GPS/GNSS deployments, highlighting the need for expansion of such networks. I urge the US Coast Guard to not decommission a site where no alternative continuous GPS/GNSS site is available, at least of similar quality, and equally close proximity to a tide gauge. Before any decommissioning I encourage the Coast Guard to seek advice from the NASA JPL Ocean Surface Topography Mission/Jason Science Team, GLOSS and the International GNSS Service TIGA program .

King, M.A. 2014. Priorities for installation of continuous Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) near to tide gauges. Global Sea Level Observing System (GLOSS). http://dx.doi.org/10.13140/RG.2.1.1781.7049

Matt King
University of Tasmania

Title: Comment from Eric Johansson
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Comment from Nigel Shaw
Comment: Please see comments in attached file.

Title: Comment from Lawrence Vose
Comment:
As a current licensed State of Alaska Marine Pilot and former Chief of the USCG Aids to Navigation Branch in Alaska, this proposal does not enhance safety of navigation in Southeast Alaska.  Specifically, the recommendation to decommission the dGPS sites at Gustavus, Alaska; Biorka, Alaska and Level Island, Alaska is detrimental for the following reasons. 
The dGPS site at Gustavus, Alaska supports the safe navigation of Hawk Inlet Alaska.  The local USCG COTP has stated that a vessel grounding in Hawk Inlet would be devastating to the surrounding environment and severely restrict mining operations.  Recently, the USCG COTP reduced the underkeel clearance requirements in this waterway with rational that included the constant risk assessment by the Southeast Alaska Pilots and the improved navigation capabilities (including electronic navigation systems) for this waterway.  The Pilots are not on record endorsing this decision and eliminating dGPS coverage for this waterway is not consistent with local USCG rationale (for reducing the underkeel clearance).
The dGPS site at Level Island Alaska supports the safe navigation of ships within Wrangell Narrows.  Transits of this waterway by larger cruise ships are increasing, resulting in reduced navigation tolerances and increased emphasis on electronic navigation systems.  
The dGPS site at Biorka, Alaska supports safe navigation into Sitka and Peril Straits.  Cruise ship transits are expanding into previously unused waterways in this area and again, result in increased reliance on accurate and reliable electronic navigation systems. 
The USCG has encouraged industry partnerships that include investment by Pilots in Pilot Portable Units (PPU's) that are dependent on the navigation infrastructure (which includes dGPS). Degrading the accuracy and reliability of the electronic navigation infrastructure as proposed is a step in the wrong direction and is not recommended.

Title: Comment from Brian Busey
Comment:
As a hydrographic survey company, TerraSond makes extensive use of the USCG DGPS network to provide GPS corrections for seafloor surveys. Alternatives include deployment of a local GPS base station and SBAS. However, setting up a local base station can have substantial cost associated with it, and SBAS is frequently unavailable due to terrain.

	The majority of Alaska's coastline is not covered by DGPS. In areas without coverage we frequently need to install GPS base stations on shore, which can drive up the cost for our clients considerably. The proposed reduction in DGPS coverage would greatly decrease the area of coverage and increase costs of providing hydrographic services in those areas for our client, the US government.

	Our clients seeking hydrographic surveys frequently have limited budgets available. The increased costs associated with installation of GPS base stations to support hydrographic projects in areas without DGPS coverage will inevitably result in reconsideration of marginal projects and elimination of future projects, and reduce associated economic activity.

	TerraSond has found that SBAS is often not an option for hydrographic surveys in Alaska. SBAS satellites are low on the southern horizon and are easily masked by terrain. USCG DGPS signals, at approximately 300 kHz, tend to wrap around terrain and be available even in the steep fiord environments of southern coastal Alaska.

Title: Comment from Victor Zlotnicki
Comment: I cannot believe that the proposed closure of dhps sites at tidebgage stations is even being considered.  Tide gages are an rssential complement to sayellitr radar altimetey.to study sea level rise, a problem of greatbsocietal consequence for coastal populations. Simply stated, without the dgps station it is not possible to separate sea level rise from land subsidence at the tide gage station. While few of us download the dgps fata directly, a community of at least hundreds and probably thousands use the data after a handful off experienced scientists process the combined tidegage dgps combined dataset. So, please dont shutter these essential instruments

Title: Comment from Martin Bransby
Comment: Please see attached document.

Title: Comment from Jill Halchin
Comment: If decommissioning the NDGPS stations includes shutting down CORS at the same locations, then mission-critical projects in two national parks in the Southeast will be affected - specifically, Ocmulgee National Monument in Macon GA and Fort Pulaski National Monument in Savannah GA.  The nearest remaining stations are more than 50km away. The Great Smoky Mountains and Gulf Islands National Seashore would experience problems if backups are down.  The staff of the Southeast Archeological Center of the NPS rely daily on accurate GPS to record locations of significant cultural resources and areas that have been surveyed.  At a minimum, please convert the stations to broadcasting WAAS.

Title: Comment from Stephen  Doherty
Comment:
As a Hudson River Maritime Pilot in training I am asking that you strongly reconsider the decommissioning 
of the Hudson Falls DGPS. This station is of vital importance for myself and all other mariners on the Hudson River in that the upper part of the Hudson River, including Albany is in a single coverage area. This coverage is provided by the Hudson Falls station. Once a New York State Licensed Pilot I will be mandated to carry portable navigation computers that rely on the Hudson Falls DGPS signal. With out this radio beacon marine traffic on the Hudson River must resort to WAAS, a signal intended for air navigation, while the DGPS correction is optimized for surface navigation. The Hudson Falls DGPS station provides reliable terrestrial correction signal of the GPS signal. The redundant DGPS signals are important to the safety of marine transportation, because a signal can be lost during maintenance of a station and in thunderstorms.

I ask that these reasons be heavily considered and that the DGPS stations not be removed. Hudson Falls DGPS station is not only used by State Licenses Pilots, it is also used by enrolled Tug and Barges transiting to and from the Port of Albany. An accurate signal which is located near the port is very crucial and if the Hudson Falls location was removed the nearest station would be approximately 150 miles away.

Respectfully, 
 Stephen Doherty

Title: Comment from Pascal Bonnefond (for OSTST)
Comment:
In the coming century, rising seas will threaten coastal areas containing hundreds of millions of people and trillions of dollars of infrastructure worldwide. Covering more than two-thirds of Earth's surface, the rising oceans tell the story of human caused warming and its impact on the planet. To understand and project these changes, scientists require global observing systems to measure ocean warming, the melting glaciers and ice sheets and sea level rise itself. The Ocean Surface Topography Science Team (OSTST) is an international body of more than 200 Earth scientists studying the oceans, the ice and even lakes and rivers.

The ongoing accuracy of globally averaged sea level as observed by the Jason series of altimeters is partly maintained and verified by the global tide gauge network. The Ocean Surface Topography Science Team supports efforts to maintain the global tide gauge network and co-located GPS stations to detect ground motion at many key tide gauges.  The OSTST relies on continuous monitoring of vertical land motion estimates from the maritime NDGPS sites in conjunction with tide gauges from the National Water Level Observation Network (NWLON) maintained by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's Center for Operational Oceanographic Products and Services (CO-OPS). The proposed shutdown of maritime NDGPS sites will have a detrimental effect on the sea level community's ability to demonstrate the stability of altimetry measurements of sea level rise.

Because a relative sea level trend measured by a water level station includes both land motion and absolute sea level changes, there are often major differences in the trend from station to station. Although there are some small regional differences in the absolute sea level trends, most of the variation in the relative sea level trends is due to differential vertical land motion caused by glacial isostatic adjustment (GIA), tectonic movement (seismic and interseismic), sedimentary basin subsidence, soil compaction, and fluid withdrawal.

Land motion changes resulting from a variety of regional geophysical phenomena need to be monitored continuously by the NDGPS sites. Tectonic activity produces both an instantaneous seismic displacement, as well as long-term interseismic deformation after the greatest magnitude earthquakes. Therefore, offsets and differing pre- and post-seismic rates may be possible at NWLON stations near plate boundaries in California, Oregon, Washington, and Alaska. Subsidence, soil compaction, and fluid withdrawal can all have varying effects on relative sea level trends in coastal Louisiana and Texas. Volcanic activity at the Big Island of Hawaiian can also change vertical land motion rates.

As the chairs of Ocean Surface Topography Science Team, we strongly recommend not shutting down maritime NDGPS sites without consulting the OSTST, NOAA, and the Global Sea Level Observing System (GLOSS) at least for specific sites that are very important for altimetry/tide gauge comparisons (e.g., Key West, Kodiak, Annapolis, Upolu Point, and Fort Stevens).

The project scientists of Jason missions and chairs of the OSTST:
Pascal Bonnefond (Observatoire de la Cote d'Azur/Geoazur), Pascal.Bonnefond@obs-azur.fr

John Lillibridge (NOAA), John.Lillibridge@noaa.gov

Remko Scharroo (EUMETSAT), Remko.Scharroo@eumetsat.int

Josh Willis (NASA/JPL), Joshua.K.Willis@jpl.nasa.gov

Title: Comment from Sam Zapadinsky
Comment:
Dear Sir or Madam,

My name is Captain Sam Zapadinsky and I am a member of the Hudson River Pilots' Association. In piloting ships and tug/barge units serving ports along the river between Yonkers, NY and Troy, NY, I carry a New York State mandated portable navigation computer. This system utilizes differential signals from the Sandy Hook, NJ station and Hudson Falls, NY station. Most commercial traffic using the Hudson River call on the vital port of Albany, NY. The decommissioning of Hudson Falls, NY station will leave the upper portions of the Hudson River without a means to correct the GPS signal. 

Our navigation systems cannot utilize WAAS corrections due to the nature of the topography and the loss of signal on many courses along the route.

It is my opinion that without a redundant signal in the NY Harbor area or any differential signal in the upper portions of the Hudson River and Port of Albany, we will be compromising safe navigation on the river. As a result, I ask that you reconsider the shutdown and decommissioning of the Hudson Falls, NY NDGPS Station.

Title: Comment from Julian Heilman
Comment: The Arizona Science Center of the U.S> geological Survey depends on CORS stations for vertical land-surface measurements for a number of long-term projects located along the Colorado River and within the Colorado Plateau area in north-central Arizona. The discontinuation of the Flagstaff and Albuquerque stations would leave much of that area without coverage, and necessitate either relying on WAAS-only DGPS or building base-stations of sufficient vertical reliability. We'd like to see the Flagstaff and Albuquerque stations remain in place. Thank you.

Title: Comment from Craig Clouet
Comment: Closing the Kokole Point NDGPS site negatively affects the State of Hawaii, and especially the mapping and survey community. Hawaii has two stations, one at each end of the island chain. The Kokole Point one is the closet on to Honolulu city and county with nearly a million residents live and work. The stations need to be considered as part of a network. Closing this one would leave half the state of Hawaii with no service and degraded positional accuracy for infrastructure mapping needs.

Title: Comment from Fritz Klasner
Comment:
The proposed priorities for decommissioning do not support National or local needs.  Please consider decommissioning stations based on where RISK of accident is greatest and RISK to resources is greatest (distance from response support, previously unimpacted resources present [i.e. natural vs disturbed habitat], lack of alternatives for precise navigation support [few local pilots for example]) and value as a scientific/monitoring tool is identified. In this context, removing AK, HI, and other stations with extensive 'single coverage' areas makes little sense as the risk is extremely high with few to no alternatives, scientific/monitoring uses are extensive, etc.; while in populated and high use areas multiple options for addressing accuracy exist and risk of uncontrolled or unmitigated damages are less due to extensive response resources available.

In addition, decommissioning should only be recommended for public comment only after alternative data collection agencies have been contacted and explicitly declined interest in assuming operations (i.e. this should be a 2-step process 1. public comment on proposed transitions from NDGPS to an alternative network, and then 2. proposed decommissioning due to lack of risk and existing mitigation solutions exist along with little scientific/monitoring interest).

Thank you.

Title: Comment from Bob Thompson
Comment: Please do not close the Kokole Point station, as it is utilized for numerous GPS surveying projects. Thank you.

Title: Comment from John Anderson
Comment: The Blue Ridge Parkway being an inland unit of the National Park Service currently uses several sites in North Carolina, Virginia, and Tenn. that are planed for decommissioning.  The use of differential correction to obtain sub-meter accuracy in the monitoring of federally listed plant species is very important.  Loss of this resource will require the park to invest in new hardware and operation protocols.  Park employees also rely on sub meter mapping with our equipment to inventory and locate boundary markers and other small park assets.

Title: Comment from Gene Dashiell
Comment:
In Hawaii I use and totally depend on the two DGPS sites, including Kolekole for my field work which requires real-time accuracy. I depend on these for the following reasons:
a) WAAS in Hawaii is not accurate or precise, as it is on the continent. We all know this, and are constantly advised so by NGS.
b) there are many locations in Hawaii with deep and steep valley walls, and in such cases DGPS corrections can be a virtual life-saver in terms of getting my work done.

I use DGPS weekly.

I use Trimble gear including their GPS beacon, along with my GeoXH 6000.

I am an environmental planning consultant, I write environmental assessments and I do a lot of my own field work related to archaeology and historic sites. I have been using DGPS since the early 2000's, and was disappointed that it was shut down in the CNMI and Guam.

This year I have been working on a hydropower plant location in Makaweli Valley, in the Waimea River Basin on Kauai, about 5 miles inland. I found that I was getting great DGPS corrected positioning at about the 2 meter RMS level. Whereas, with WAAS I could not get a corrected position.

I don't have the time, training or financial resources to invest in an RTK system, and the gear would be too cumbersome anyway for my type of work, which is often in remote locations, not accessible by vehicle.

Please keep the Hawaii DGPS stations operational until WAAS can effectively supersede them.

Please contact me if you have questions.

Aloha,
Gene

Title: Comment from Todd Beers
Comment:
De-commissioning NDGPS Site Pueblo 2

I am Professional Land Surveyor in Colorado (and currently serving as the President of the Professional Land Surveyors of Colorado) who utilizes GPS technology on a daily basis and I would not like to see the CORS portion of the station go away for the following reasons:

NDGPS is not the concern, but the station operating as a CORS is. NDPS provides a corrector. CORS provides much more - a resource that data can be pulled for post processing. Surveyors and mappers in Colorado as well as across the nation rely upon these sites.

Here in Colorado we are limited in the CORS coverage. In the area of PUB5, there are 2 stations 60 and 70 kms away, three 150- 200 kms away and the rest are well over 200 kms.

This site has been operating as a CORS for since 2012 originally as PUB1 and PUB 2, now PUB 5 and PUB6.

Loosing PUB5 and PUB6 would be detrimental to the State of Colorado, in particular, the area around Pueblo, CO. 

We would like to cooperate with USCG to see if this site could be re-established as a CORS at a nearby area. There are resources such as the technology transit center, Colorado Department of Transportation, City and County of Pueblo, ..


The general consensus from our user-community has been that, while the broadcast signal may be on its way out in terms of usefulness, the underlying CORS serve as highly stable (operationally) stations with long-term records in our active geodetic control network that is sorely lacking in redundancy.

Please consider relocating the CORS station in the vicinity of the existing station.

Title: Comment from Darrell Stewart
Comment: Please do not discontinue this service as our dredging firm relies on these beacons for positioning on both private and pubic contracts across the entire United States including the United States Army Corp of Engineers.

Title: Comment from Elise Leroux
Comment: Please do not close the Kokole Point NDGPS site. This site is one of only two in Hawaii, and both are critical to the State, as they cover different geographic areas. The negative affect of closing one site would be degraded accuracy, which would affect environmental, mapping, surveying, and infrastructure projects. Many of the companies who work in the environmental and surveying fields are small, local business that do not have the resources to set up a similar service on their own. Furthermore, Hawaii's topography is such that non-line-of-sight systems are critical. Closing either Hawaii station would negatively impact Statewide GIS layers; two of our four counties; and, in the case of the Kokole Point site, several military bases.

Title: Comment from Kamehameha Schools Land Information Systems
Comment:
Aloha,
Kamehameha Schools doesn't use the NDGPS broadcast signal anymore, though we do have the required beacon.  We more commonly now use the GPS data recorded from this and other CORS sites increase the accuracy of our data collection for land surveying and mapping applications.  Without these CORS corrections, the accuracy of our data will be degraded greatly.
Mahalo,
Kamehameha Schools Land Information Systems

Title: Comment from St. Louis District Corp. of Engineers
Comment:
The USCG Differential Beacon Towers (DGPS) provide local correction for more accurate GPS positioning that support channel maintenance activities on Federal Navigation Channels within St. Louis District; which includes 300 miles of the Upper Mississippi River, 80 miles of the Illinois Waterway, and 36 miles of the Kaskaskia River.  

DGPS provides sub meter accuracy for GPS positioning for on water activities to include detailed hydrographic surveys, and vessel positioning. Accurately identifying obstructions in the waterway, and positioning dredge operations near Locks, entrance channels, or other structures is critical.  DGPS positioning is used by the Dredge Potter, M/V Pathfinder, M/V Grand Tower, Dredge Tenders Kimmswick and Prairie Durocher, Survey Boat SkyII and at least three other Government survey boats have DGPS capability.

DGPS correction service by radio frequency performs very well throughout the District.  Oppositely, we are concerned about the less accurate satellite based augmentation service (WAAS) or other commercially available products and how consistent those products will perform throughout the District. Also, switching to a commercially provided correction service will require purchasing new GPS receivers and contractual arrangements to pay for such services.  

Based on the above, St. Louis District request to keep the St. Louis DGPS Tower operational for 1 to 2 years to identify alternatives and procure new equipment.

Title: Comment from Peter Douglas
Comment:
I write as a former Chairman of the Position, Navigation & Timing Working Group of the IALA e-Navigation Committee.
 
The US Coast Guard led the way in developing DGPS and in engineering and modernizing the system, and are to be congratulated for their efforts in improving the integrity and accuracy of marine navigation. It is therefore extremely disappointing that the USCG consider the prime function of DGPS is to support buoy operations, and do not recognize a mandate to provide DGPS for the benefit of mariners, both national and international.
 
Provision of a high quality service to mariners requires dual coverage DGPS in areas of high traffic volumes and risk, which surely includes the Pacific, Gulf and Atlantic coasts. Alaska may have lower traffic volumes but arguably higher risk factors. 

Furthermore, maintenance of dual coverage sites and their infrastructure offers options in the development of Resilient PNT solutions such as Ranging-Mode or eLoran - solutions to problems the marine world is belatedly becoming aware of.

I strongly recommend that the USCG reconsider any plans which may degrade maritime coverage of DGPS.

Title: Comment from Ulf Gafvert
Comment:
I work with the Great Lakes Network of the National Park Service.
We conduct ecological monitoring of natural resources in and around nine National Parks in the Great Lakes region, and collect GPS location information regularly while doing field work. Accurate position information is critical for such applications as forest plots, water quality site locations, or in collecting ground control in support of aerial photography or lidar collection projects.
We regularly use the National CORS network along with various state DOT CORS stations for post-processing GPS data. Losing Wisconsin Point, WI and Upper Keweenaw Point, MI will hamper our ability to post-process our data. We typically use Trimble equipment, often requiring a set of 3 stations for accurate post-processing (H-Star), and these stations are essential for good triangulation. We also use POSPac software in post-processing multibeam sonar data, again having multiple stations is critical to achieving the best accuracy possible. Redundancy is also important as there are fairly frequent data drop-outs creating gaps in correction files. 
It is surprising to hear of these stations being decommissioned at a time when more and more applications of location information are being developed. I urge you to reconsider this decision.

Ulf Gafvert
GIS Coordinator
Great Lakes Network
National Park Service

Title: Comment from Taylor Luke
Comment:
As a Marine Contractor working on the Upper Mississippi River System, we are 100% reliant on the St. Paul (Alma) and Rock Island DGPS towers for our work with the Federal/State/Local Governments, Utility Providers and Private Industry.  We rely on the positioning provided by the DGPS towers for hydrographic surveying, dredging operations, marine construction, pipeline safety zone identification and location of additional known and targeted hazards.  Loss of these towers without a reliable alternative will severely reduce accuracy, efficiency and safety of our work operations putting further strain on the movement of public and private goods and resources throughout the inland navigation system. 

Currently there are no viable alternatives to the towers that provide both the coverage area and accuracy needed for our operations on the Upper Mississippi River system. Alternatives that require internet access and/or cell coverage cannot be relied upon due to limited coverage and weak signals in both remote and obstructed areas.

We strongly recommend maintaining St. Paul (Alma) and Rock Island sites, at a minimum, until an alternative with both the accuracy and reliability of the DGPS tower system is established.

Title: Comment from Barry Phillips
Comment:
Please consider keeping the Albuquerque cord station alive. 
This station is important in our GPS work in the state of NM.

Title: Comment from Mark Bourassa
Comment:
Changing sea levels relative to land elevation will likely be one of the greatest threat modifiers to coastal communities. The impacts of such changes on infrastructure and property are profound in low lying areas (i.e., most coastal regions), with a much greater risk of water damage when the sea level rises relative to the community. And rising seas are only one part of the change in sea level; the changes in the elevation of land are typically just as great as the changes in sea level. NDGPS sites monitor these changes in sea elevation, and hence play a very important role in the monitoring of sea level. Changes in elevation happen as a result of glacial isostatic adjustment (GIA), tectonic movement, sedimentary subsidence, compacting of soil, and the withdrawal of fluids from the ground. Consequently, the rate of change of land elevation is quite varied across the US coasts. The observations proposed to be cut play a critical role in understanding sea level change from the perspective of management of that change. 

The Ocean Observation Panel for Climate (OOPC) has already recommended, in our contribution to a report of the status of climate observations, that the number of stations with this capability be increased. This will help in understanding how changes in land and sea combine to modify sea level in the coastal regions where people will experience the impacts of these changes. The recommendation is based on input from broad research communities as well as from communities impacted by these changes. If some sites must be cut, we recommend that the selection of sites be done in consultation with the Global Sea Level Observing System (GLOSS), which can recommend a subset of the coastal sites that are of higher priority. 

Mark Bourassa
Florida State University
Co-Chair, Ocean Observation Panel for Climate
mbourassa@fsu.edu

Title: Comment from National Park Service Inventory and Monitoring
Comment:
Docket Management Facility (M-30) 					November 16, 2015 
U.S. Department of Transportation 
West Building Ground Floor, Room W12-140 
1200 New Jersey Avenue 
Washington, DC 20590-0001 

Re: Public Comments on Docket Number DOT-OST-2015-0105 Decommissioning of Nationwide Differential Global Positioning System (NDGPS) Transmitter Sites

The National Park Service Vegetation Inventory program coordinates and collaborates with all the territories of the Pacific Rim, Hawaiian Islands, the Caribbean, CONUS, and Alaska to serve over 300 Parks, Monuments, and Preserves.  These resources of the American public are remote, rugged, and loved by them.  Many of these resources are monitored and mapped by many remote sensing technologies, and GPS is the primary basis of sample point location, re-survey of sites, and support of GIS and digital mapping efforts.  The use of CORS as a tool to support and manage these public assets is a non-replaceable tool, provides the only free NAD83 tie to the National Spatial Reference Frame, and serves these remote locations without backup.  A typical mapping effort will collect several hundred points for ecological study, and several thousand for map verification and accuracy assessment. In over 300 Park units, this represents a significant and irreplaceable public investment.   Positioning and resurvey of these areas using the GPS as a utility demands the accuracy of CORS for post processing.

The Department of Transportation serves the American Public and the Federal Agencies as a liaison and representative of agency needs related to GPS.  The collection of this input is the second time the Department of Transportation has asked for this survey, with similar results.  The evidence from the field, the known loss of functionality and safety in the Great Lakes and northern tier regions across to the Dakotas and Montana, and the common dependence on CORS in all regions of the US (CONUS and all other Regions) for post processing and data management all direct the Department of Transportation to a currently irreplaceable utility used by industry, the public, and public servants alike.

A credible cross-funded process exists to continue these services. Dropping NDGPS and retaining CORS retains the post-processing functionality, at a minimum.  The resources and the public deserve to have an adequate positioning tool, and the CORS has proven that capability for post processed positions to the NAD83 reference frame and the future datums that will follow.  The land management agencies of this county and our sister nations and First Nations all use GPS positioning to serve and protect the public lands.  You have an overwhelming response of the need for NDGPS and CORS to serve those needs.   Once again, make the decision to continue what is now a common utility and as a minimum retain the CORS capability for science and public lands protection and management.

Karl E. Brown, PhD
Vegetation Inventory Program Leader
National Park Service Inventory and Monitoring 
Karl_brown@nps.gov

Title: Comment from Joel Cusick
Comment: I write in support for retaining all of the NDGPS sites in Alaska including retention of the radio beacon broadcast and CORS.

Title: Comment from Great Smoky Mountains National Park
Comment: Great Smoky Mountains National Park relies on DGPS provided either through beacon devices (e.g. "Beacon on a Belt") and/or VRS (Virtual Reference System) service providers. Loss of this service would either require the reduction of precision in GPS data utilized in regulatory or public safety applications, or deployment of more expensive GPS equipment capable of greater precision. Both work-arounds would result in greater cost to the government for many of this units location-based service dependencies.

Title: Comment from Gregg Kneipp
Comment: While the site that I normally use, the Corbin facility, is not being shut down, I think it is a bad idea to shut down any other sites as they serve the purpose for deferentially correcting GPS data to improve its accuracy, places that do not have access to the coastal sites that are being shut down.

Title: Comment from Glacier Bay National Park and Preserve
Organization Name: Glacier Bay National Park and Preserve
Comment:
Dear Sirs,

As the Superintendent of Glacier Bay National Park and Preserve (GBNPP), I would like to share our deep concerns with your proposal to decommission the Nationwide Differential Global Positioning System (NDGPS) site in Gustavus Alaska.  GBNPP relies heavily on the Gustavus NDGPS site, both for post-processed differential correction of essential resource and maintenance features, as well as serving vital corrections to the navigation systems of large cruise ships and other vessels in park waters.

GBNPP has five Trimble professional GPS mapping units all capable of post-processing.  Since 2001, the park has differentially corrected thousands of files using the Gustavus station.  These files have contained data for mapping natural and cultural resources as well as utilities, infrastructure, trails, and boundaries.  Differential correction using the reliable Gustavus site allows enhancing accuracy from 10 meters to sub-meter.  This type of accuracy is essential to re-locate broken water pipes under snow cover, revisit remote campsites, or to re-survey cryptic archeological features.  The Gustavus site has been our most reliable base station since the late 1990's.  Although a recent map shows Plate Boundary Observatory (PBO) sites surrounding our park, these have not been as reliable as the U.S. Coast Guard station and have had gaps in data availability.   Additionally, if the Gustavus station is lost, the distance from northern Glacier Bay to a differential correction base station will increase 20 km (from 80km to 100km) and the distance from the majority of our park's infrastructure in southern Glacier Bay to a base station will increase from 10 km to 55km, a 5 fold increase.

Additionally, the loss of the Gustavus NDGPS station will seriously compromise the integrity of marine navigation systems within the park. In the comments for this Federal Registry Notice, please refer to the Southeast Alaska Pilots Association recommendation for retaining NDGPS for electronic navigation.   GBNPP is a marine park and our 500,000+ yearly visitors rely heavily on large ships up to 1000 feet in length navigating narrow fjords.  Reliance on Wide Area Augmentation System (WAAS) may be suitable in lower latitudes or above 1000 feet elevation, but not at sea level in steep narrow fjords in northern Glacier Bay.   NDGPS remains an important redundant and park-wide augmentation for navigation in Glacier Bay, and is therefore vital to the protection of one of the most environmentally sensitive maritime areas in the country.      

The Gustavus NDGPS station has been a reliable and highly valued site since its inception.  We strongly urge you to continue this much needed service.     

Sincerely,

Philip N. Hooge, Ph.D.
Superintendent
Glacier Bay National Park and Preserve

DOT-OST-2015-0105

Title: Comment from Alaska Geospatial Council
Government Agency: AK DNR, DOT, DEC, DCCED, F&G, DMVA, & UA
Comment:
The Alaska Geospatial Council represents six state government Departments (Natural Resources, Transportation, Fish & Game, Community & Economic Development, Environmental Conservation, Military & Veteran's Affairs) and the University of Alaska. The Alaska Geospatial Council strongly advocates maintaining the Alaska USCG NDGPS stations. 

The USCG DGPS sites proposed for decommissioning in Alaska are a critical component of state's already precariously sparse GPS CORS network. Currently there are just over 100 operating CORS for an area comprising over 20% of the Nation.  If these sites are decommissioned and funding for the UNAVCO Plate Boundary Observatory base stations is not renewed in 2018, less than 1/3 of the state will be left with adequate CORS coverage. BAY5 and GUS5 are especially critical for CORS coverage in Alaska.

Southeastern Alaska is characterized by steep, thickly forested terrain and narrow channels with strong currents. Dense cloud cover and strong winds are common occurrences in this area where there are also several critical marine habitat areas. The NDGPS broadcast signal is used for navigation by marine vessels and aircraft as an augmentation to unreliable or insufficient GPS reception. 

Because accurate positioning data is used for a variety of purposes, including navigation, land management decisions, land use planning, research, forest monitoring, inventories, and assessments, the Alaska Geospatial Council strongly advocates maintaining the Alaska USCG NDGPS stations. Cost of removal of these sites has been estimated at up to $30M per site, whereas the annual cost of operations of all NDGPS sites nationally is less than $6M. At the very minimum, Alaska's USCG NDGPS stations need to continue to operate as part of the CORS network even if the broadcast signal is eliminated. They are needed for redundancy and maintaining an adequate CORS network for differential correction. 

If the USCG is unable to continue maintenance of these sites, please provide maintenance costs, site agreements, and any other requirements to allow continued operations by an alternate entity as an alternative to decommissioning.

Title: Comment from Timothy Smith
Comment:
NDGPS has been a long standing, reliable service that I feel should continue for the following reasons:

- It should continue at least until the issue of a backup to GPS is settled. The existing hardware and infrastructure at these sites may be an asset that the government will find very helpful in the near future.
- The associated CORS are very important to the overall CORS network in the Inter-mountain West, Alaska and Hawaii. CORS sites are spread out already to the point that it limits the capabilities of the government to meet its mission. If the sites are removed this will get worse. The result will be that government personnel will have to stay on a point much longer costing more money. Additionally, some operations to not lend themselves to static occupation of a single point. This issue will increase for coastal areas when fewer CORS are available such as in Assateague Island, MD. We need accurate elevations to respond to sea level rise and climate change. See attachments.
-  When the Reference Network becomes completely virtual it is important that we have real time access to the reference frame. NDGPS provides this now for code-phase corrections. If the CORS portion of the NDGPS sites remained and streamed differential data on the internet then this would extend to carrier and code for greater accuracy. We require greater accuracy of our elevation surveys to respond to climate change. This is one example of many that carrier-phase corrections coming from the NDGPS CORS would go a long way towards fulfilling.
- O and M of the NDGPS system is about $5.5 million dollars annually. I would say that is a pretty good return on the governments investment. This could be even less if the broadcast portion were shut down and the streaming of the CORS differential data was extended to the internet.

Title: Comment from Dennis Pirtle
Comment:
Attention: De-commissioning NDGPS site Pueblo CO


NDGPS is not the concern, but rather the station operating as a CORS station. CORS stations provides much more of a resource for Surveyors and Mappers in Colorado as well as across the nation.

In Colorado we are limited in the number of CORS  stations operating. In the area of PUB5, there are 2 stations 60 and 70 kms away, three 150- 200 kms away and the rest are well over 200 kms.

This site has been operating as a CORS site since 2012, originally as PUB1 and PUB 2, now PUB 5 and PUB6.

Loosing PUB5 and PUB6 would be detrimental to the State of Colorado, in particular, the area around Pueblo, CO. 

We would like to cooperate with USCG to see if this site could be re-established as a CORS station at a nearby area. There are resources such as the technology transit center, Colorado Department of Transportation, City and County of Pueblo, ..

The general consensus from our user-community has been that, while the broadcast signal may be on its way out in terms of usefulness, the underlying CORS station serves as highly stable stations adding long-term records to our active geodetic control network that is lacking in redundancy.

Please consider this request to support the Surveying and Mapping community.

Title: Comment from Gregory Johnson
Comment: I believe that it is short-sighted to decommission all of the inland DGPS sites. The DGPS system is an important piece of infrastructure that could be utilized in many other ways in addition to broadcasting DGPS corrections. I was co-author of a study for the PNT EXCOM in 2011 titled "Evaluating the Potential for New Civil User Services That Could Be Provided From NDGPS Sites" that laid out many additional uses of the sites and infrastructure. In addition, the DGPS sites could be used as transmitters for a ranging signal (R-Mode) for alternative PNT. The feasibility of this has been discussed in reports done for the German Waterways and Shipping Administration as part of the ACCSEAS Project - the reports can be found online at http://www.accseas.eu/publications/r-mode-feasibility-study/. Including R-Mode signals as part of an Alternative PNT system would improve performance and reduce costs over that of an eLoran-ony system and this combination should be considered.

Title: Comment from Karyn Nolan
Comment:
Pacific GPS is a small business that specializes in geospatial services and GNSS equipment and software sales. Please keep these base stations online and functional. I am commenting on behalf of our client base in the Hawaii and Pacific region as well as DoD end users nationally. 
The base stations are critical infrastructure to correct GNSS/GPS data to increase accuracy of mapping grade and survey grade receivers. This affects a wide range of end users including: local, state and federal government, utilities, emergency management, natural resource managers, engineering, construction, etc. 
In addition to maintaining the base stations for post processing, please consider broadcasting the corrections via IP. This would be valuable as a single base broadcast or can potentially be connected to a network of base stations for a real time network. Feel free to contact me for further input.
Best regards,
Karyn Nolan
President
Pacific GPS, LLC

Title: Comment from Canadian Coast Guard
Comment:
Good Day,

Please refer to the attached document as the Canadian Coast Guard's official response to this notification. It is intended to replace a draft version of comments which were submitted by my colleague, Nadia Lahyane, earlier today. This version reflects changes that were made at the request of senior officials within the Canadian Coast Guard. Your consideration of our input on this matter is much appreciated. 

I invite you to contact me should you have any questions or concerns.

John R. Festarini
Manager, Marine Navigation |
Gestionnaire, Navigation maritime
National Strategies | Stratgies nationales
Canadian Coast Guard | Garde ctire canadienne

Title: Comment from Clarence Young
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Comment from USFWS Arctic Refuge and Alaska Refuge's Inventory and Monitoring Program
Organization Name: USFWS Arctic Refuge and Alaska Refuge's Inventory and Monitoring Program
Comment:
Decommissioning sites in the existing network could have a negative impact on the US Fish and Wildlife Service's National Wildlife Refuges. Decreased stations in remote areas could increase the probability of catastrophic events associated with navigational errors and decrease scientific capacity as location accuracy is lost. To reduce potential impacts there must be alternative solutions:  

1. Alternative solutions must improve navigation capabilities in areas currently covered by the stations proposed for decommissioning. Doing so could improve human safety and prevent catastrophic events. According to the current DOT notice (DOT-OST-2015-0105), in response to the 2013 notice on station decommissioning "ship pilots in particular noted that DGPS can be critical in confined waterways for precise ship handling maneuvers." This statement indicates stations could be detrimental or harmful when ships are operating in confined waterways where non-line-of-sight navigation is necessary. 

These waterways are particularly prevalent along Alaska's complex coastlines. These coastlines are not only dramatically underrepresented in the current network of sites, but have limited bathymetric maps, elevation datasets, and satellite coverage. Removing stations would further decrease navigational capabilities along these coastlines and could increase the probability of catastrophic accidents in these vulnerable habitats. These coastlines provide habitat for threatened and endangered species and one of the largest and most sustainable fisheries in the world. Loss of threatened and endangered species would compromise international treaties and impact biodiversity at a global-scale. Negative impacts on these coastal habitats and fisheries would affect subsistence fisheries in Native communities, the commercial fisheries and tourism industries, and the availability of a healthy food resource that is globally distributed.

The current notice states that sites selected for decommissioning are in areas that are not "generally used". In Alaska, areas that are not "generally used" as major shipping routes have extremely poor communication and emergency response capabilities. The probability for catastrophic events to occur in these in confined waterways where navigational and response capabilities are hindered is relatively high and release of fuel, oil, invasive shipboard species (e.g. rats) can have much greater impacts than they would in less remote areas. These impacts could devastate terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems, subsistence resources, local communities, and the safety of USFWS staff, partners, local community members, and others. 

These same areas will likely experience increasing traffic with changes in climate, fisheries regulations, oil prices, and development. In the future, climate change, loss of sea-ice, and increased frequency and severity of storm events will increase the need for improved navigation in these areas. The focus should be on making these areas safer and less prone to major catastrophes. Not demobilizing.     

Coverage of the current DGPS network is already limited to less than 50% of Alaska's coast. Much of this coast is complex, confined, and remote; satellite coverage is poor throughout the entire state; and response capabilities are marginal at best. Yet these shorelines are some of the world's most important and productive habitats for fish and wildlife. Assisted by ocean and wind currents, water, fish, and wildlife along these coastlines migrate to habitats across the globe. They support unique subsistence communities and commercial fisheries with cultures that don't exist anywhere else in the world. A reduction in the already gross navigational capabilities along these vulnerable, remote coastlines would be absurd. The entire Aleutian Chain would be completely unrepresented. Places like Kodiak Alaska would not be covered. Fifty percent of Southeast Alaska would not be covered.   

2. If coastal and inland sites are decommissioned there must be alternative solutions that maintain or improve GPS location accuracy in these regions. Loss of stations and associated location accuracy could be a major setback for scientific efforts, land managers, communities, and others assessing the impacts of and planning for the effects of climate change at local, regional, and global scales. This would be particularly harmful in Alaska which lacks a high-resolution elevation dataset and where satellite coverage is extremely poor. 

3. Work with NOAA, USFWS, and others to co-locate climate reference network stations, or something similar to improve navigation and emergency response capabilities, GPS location accuracy, and our understanding of and ability to forecast the effects of climate change. In addition to existing sites, coverage in Alaska must be improved and include sites in Northern Alaska. Partnering with others in Japan, Russia, and Canada to create similar sites should also be considered.

Title: Comment from James  Blanchar
Comment:
The system has developed users far beyond the navigation industries. As the former Chief of Operations for Rock Island District, my channel maintenance depending tremendously on the NDGPS System. The cost reductions of our channel maintenance were much more than significant and improved accuracy of channel surveys. Prior to the NDGPS to perform a survey the survey team would sut transponders on the shore to establish horizantal locations. This was a very time consuming effort with a lower degree of accuracy. Many times the surveys were required to determine the locations of shoals. With the NDGPS system the hydrotrafic survel boat could commence surveys could start immediately on arrival at the shoal site. Installation of tarnsponders may have been delayed due to weather  daylight and other causes. Every minute the shoal caused a closure was costing the tows $400.00 per hour in delays. The time to start dredging could result in a backup of many tows. 

The farm interests have become very heavy users of the system in controlling, feritlizing and harvesting crops. Tractors are equipped with GPS systems. The system can control plowing patterns. The harvest can be closely monitored for yiealds as crops are are harvested. at the next season that data is used to control fertilize applications  to save fertilizer costs and more uniform yields. 

I don't know about the automotive, cell phone and other system use of the NDGPS System, but I feel my use  in navigation while driving on streets and highways provides accurate data on tmy location to make accurate turnes.

The advantages are way beyond the initial floating navigation purposes. As Chief of Operations I fully supported the partnership between the Corps and Coast Guard to establish the Upper Mississippi River System. Rock Island had communication towars the fit the requirement of the NDGPS equipment. We entered into a partneship agreement for the usage of the towers. I still believe the system is a great benefit to the navigation requirements and has become a national assess the must be maintained.

Title: Joe Citizen
Comment:
Lack of Enforcement or Focus on Knowing Violators of Lithium battery Regulations.
I am a concerned citizen that believes DOT is not doing enough to protect the public.
The lithium battery regulations have changed every two years for at least the last 10 years. 
 ICAO and US DOT have gone to great lengths to produce more onerous and restrictive regulations but little to address
 the unscrupulous shippers that knowingly do not comply with regulations to avoid the costs associated with compliance.  
Introducing further restrictions, complicated requirements and high cost packaging will only exasperate the prevalence of 
non-compliant shipments from these shippers.  The non-compliant shipments are difficult to detect and are typically only 
discovered when a carrier experiences a situation where the package is damaged in transport in which case it may be 
reported to an appropriate enforcement agency.  Generally there is a lack of enforcement authority over shippers in certain 
parts of the world especially in jurisdictions where there is the highest likelihood of non-compliance.  As a concerned citizen I do 
not believe that ICAO or the US DOT have focused on this issue which is the most critical factor to reducing the risk of 
incidents aboard aircraft.  Compliant US companies are being penalized with more onerous and expensive requirements while those 
that deliberately violate the regulations continue to do so without being held accountable.  

The agenda for the public meeting should include the enforcement issue and DOT should explain what they are doing to address it.

Title: Mike Eskra
Comment:
What is the DOT already aware of?
As a chemical engineer with over 30 years in the battery field and a certified fire and explosion investigator (CFEI), as well as a pilot, what I see:
-Lithium batteries shipped charged beyond regulations
-Lithium batteries labeled as other chemistries, such as NiMH, to avoid the more stringent lithium regulations
-Lithium batteries sold as new, but actually refurbished
-OEM, refurbished and counterfeit batteries are manufactured into packs, packaged, sold, and shipped, full state of charge, without enough safety mechanisms, and poorly manufactured, for use in all types of battery powered toys, electric bikes, scooters, computers etc.
-Counterfeited batteries are entering viable supply chains.
-Chinese manufacturers pop up then disappear at a moment's notice.
-Foreign batteries have cost millions of dollars of property loss, but worse, loss of lives
Prime offenders: China, China and China, as well as Taiwan and some outliers 

What inspection is in place before customs signs off and allows a shipment to be loaded? Perhaps a program of more stringent quality inspections with the cost put back on the manufacturer or the country of origin is in order? After all, what's the worst that can happen? The cost of foreign batteries will go up?

Comment: Attached please find comments submitted by Underwriters Laboratories (UL) on Lithium Battery Aviation Safety (DOT-OST-2015-0169).

Title: Advanced Medical Technology Association (AdvaMed)
Comment: Please see the attached comments.

Title: Paula Ralston
Comment:
I attended the meeting today and would first like to say thank you to the the DOT and all presenters and attendees for their inputs. I have major concerns though, that the main concern seems to be the regulations that are already in place. It would seem more sensible to put a huge effort into identifying and penalizing the manufacturers that do not comply with the regulations. Moving forward with changing the regulations to make lithium battery shipments safer, will do nothing to improve safety unless offenders are first identified, and prosecuted. Stronger regulations will effectively "punish" the "good guys", making their products more expensive, while allowing the "bad guys" to continue with their bad practices, enabling them to keep their costs down. To add insult, the US Government, will then insist, in many cases, that contractors purchase the lowest price item. There is something drastically wrong with this scenario. While I am certainly on board with any regulation change that improves safety, while allowing continued delivery of quality products, I would implore the DOT to look at options to ensure regulations are followed by all, before changing them. 

I am not educated on what processes are in place already to ensure quality of products being shipped to the US from foreign nations, however, I know, in cases such as Chinese manufacturers, unless they are caught immediately, they disappear, and pop up as a different name within days. Inspection has to happen at the point of shipment. In some cases, it is easy to identify non-compliant product, however, an in depth inspection is warranted, with destructive physical analysis included on a percentage of parts. Of course, there will be a cost to this, which should be absorbed by the manufacturer, or country of origin, in the form of a penalty. I would think, shutting the door on these manufacturers would not take long and send a strong message.

Besides the safety issues of shipping by air, these products are getting through to the commercial stream, and while they may not have caused a catastrophic air issue, they have and are causing destruction of US citizen property and in some cases have caused loss of life. We owe it to all, to look at the real issue and stop the import of non-compliant product to the US. Then, and only then, can you look sensibly at changing the regulations that exist.

We have presented at many government conferences on the issues of safety and counterfeit issues, and have managed government battery testing facilities. We would gladly share these presentations, and any useful knowledge if there is interest.

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
During the public meeting several participants expressed concern that the FAA tests and conclusions that are published on public web sites and shared at meetings such as the ICAO DGP are not subject to public comment or peer reviewed. 
In particular concern was expressed with the validity of the FAA "balloon test".  FAA said that the results which indicate that as few as 2.6 lithium cells could damage a cargo liner and compromise the fire suppression capabilities of an aircraft would not be used to justify further regulatory restrictions.  WP29 that was submitted to the ICAO DGP meeting uses the FAA data to justify removing the small battery and cell exceptions.  WP29 states:

1.3 Considering that Section II of Packing Instructions 965 and 968 only permits a small
quantity of cells or batteries to be carried in the same package (except for lithium ion batteries not
exceeding 2.7 Wh and lithium metal batteries not exceeding 0.3 g of lithium, for which there is a weight
limit not a limit in numbers) and taking into consideration that this allowance exceeds the safe limits
established by the tests for the number of lithium batteries in a single cargo compartment of an aircraft
commonly used in air transport, there is no reason for maintaining the provisions of Section II in the
Technical Instructions.

This paper substantiates the concerns raised by participants of the public meeting.  The FAA test and conclusions are being used to justify a change to the regulations that will have serious, costly and overly burdensome implications to companies that are shipping their batteries safely while doing nothing if not incentivizing those companies that intentionally fail to comply and put the public at risk.  

 The Information Quality Act (IQA), sometimes referred to as the Data Quality Act, was enacted in December 2000 as Section 515 of the Treasury and General Government Appropriations Act for Fiscal Year 2001 (Public Law 106-554). The act required the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) to issue guidance to federal agencies designed to ensure the "quality, objectivity, utility, and integrity" of information disseminated to the public. It also required agencies to establish administrative mechanisms that allow affected persons to seek correction of information maintained and disseminated by the agencies that does not comply with the OMB guidance.  FAA has not followed DOT's established guidelines from a quality, objectivity, utility, or integrity basis.  You can view DOT's guidelines at:

http://www.rita.dot.gov/bts/sites/rita.dot.gov.bts/files/subject_areas/statistical_policy_and_research/data_quality_guidelines/html/guidelines.html 

The OMB/DOT guidelines define "influential" information as information that the agency reasonably can determine "will have or does have a clear and substantial impact on important public policies or important private sector decisions." The guidelines assign to DOT the task of defining this term in ways appropriate to the agency and its various programs. The Department emphasizes that to be influential; information must have a clear and substantial impact. In rulemaking, influential information is scientific, financial, or statistical information that can reasonably be regarded as being one of the major factors in the resolution of one or more key issues in a significant rulemaking, as that term is defined in Executive Order 12866. These reports are certainly influential and are driving regulations that will cost Americans and US companies hundreds of millions of dollars.

Title: Comment from Steven Holman
Comment:
I don't see how this policy can override Section 336 of Public Law 112-95, which states:
"(a) IN GENERAL.Notwithstanding any other provision of law
relating to the incorporation of unmanned aircraft systems into
Federal Aviation Administration plans and policies, including this
subtitle, the Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration
may not promulgate any rule or regulation regarding a model
aircraft, or an aircraft being developed as a model aircraft, if
(1) the aircraft is flown strictly for hobby or recreational
use;
(2) the aircraft is operated in accordance with a communitybased
set of safety guidelines and within the programming
of a nationwide community-based organization;
(3) the aircraft is limited to not more than 55 pounds
unless otherwise certified through a design, construction,
inspection, flight test, and operational safety program administered
by a community-based organization;
(4) the aircraft is operated in a manner that does not
interfere with and gives way to any manned aircraft; and
(5) when flown within 5 miles of an airport, the operator
of the aircraft provides the airport operator and the airport
air traffic control tower (when an air traffic facility is located
at the airport) with prior notice of the operation (model aircraft
operators flying from a permanent location within 5 miles of
an airport should establish a mutually-agreed upon operating
procedure with the airport operator and the airport air traffic
control tower (when an air traffic facility is located at the
airport)). "
As long as people operate within these guidelines, why should they need to register?
