Title: Comment from Philip Knieper
Comment:
My concern is primarily directed towards the privacy issues surrounding the information which will be made public through the new sUAS registration system.   

As a long term RC (remote control) hobbyist / operator (cars, planes, now multi-rotors), I have been safely participating in this hobby for over 30 years.  I recognize that the careless actions of some have created an environment where a registration requirement such as this is necessary.  

However, as a father of a minor who also participates in this hobby, I am greatly concerned about protecting my child. He will soon be 13 years old and thus required to register.  If an unfortunate accident occurs (even with my direct supervision) and he has a fly-away model loss, anyone who finds that model (regardless of whether there are negative consequences of the loss or not) will have direct access to his information and have the potential of exploiting him in the situation(1).  The same thing can be said of myself (45 year old male), and even though I am an adult and better prepared for such events, there remains significant risk.  

So, because of: 
A) the previously mentioned careless and foolish actions of others
B) press sensationalism within our nation
C) the ubiquitous association of all things RC flight (sUAS = RC planes, helicopters, multi-rotors, etc.) with the term drone
D) our nation's legitimate use of military drones - 
we now face an American public which is uneducated, paranoid, and openly hostile to a long established hobby.  Examples of this are the numerous cases of 'drones' shot down by the public (2a-2c), unjustified assaults against RC fliers (3), marketing of anti-drone ammo (4), and the marketing of (illegal) drone jammers (5).  I'm sure you can understand how having law enforcement agents between my son (or myself) and a hostile member of the public is a highly desirable outcome.  

You have taken appropriate actions to help protect the public from careless sUAS operators by enacting this registration system and driving further education for sUAS operators.   Please take into consideration that sUAS / RC operators (especially minors) may also need to be protected from a careless, uneducated, and increasingly paranoid public.  Ensure that the sUAS database is not publicly available, but instead reflects the statement in the UAS registration FAQ (6): "The FAA will be able to see the data that you enter. The FAA is using a contractor to maintain the website and database, and that contractor also will be able to see the data that you enter. Like the FAA, the contractor is required to comply with strict legal requirements to protect the confidentiality of the personal data you provide. Under certain circumstances, law enforcement officers might also be able to see the data."

Thank you for your consideration of my concerns.

------References:
(1) from current proposed update of Privacy Act of 1974, DOT/FAA-801: " Additionally, the public may only retrieve model aircraft owners' name and address in the publicly available Aircraft Registry by the aircraft registration number (i.e., the public may not retrieve data by an owner's name or address)"
(2a) http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2015/07/31/428156902/dispute-emerges-over-drone-shot-down-by-kentucky-man 
(2b) http://www.wbrz.com/news/drone-shot-down-in-ascension-parish-feud/ 
(2c) http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/man-shoots-down-drone-over-property-receives-850-fine/article/2567254 
(3) http://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2014/06/quadrocopter-pilot-gets-attacked-by-drone-hating-woman/ 
(4) http://www.popularmechanics.com/technology/a16967/drone-munitions-shotgun-shells/ 
(5) http://www.digitaltrends.com/cool-tech/anti-drone-death-ray/ 
(6) http://www.faa.gov/uas/registration/faqs/#priv

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment:
Applies to Docket No. DOT-OST-2015-0246

At some point, a reasonable balance needs to be achieved between the rights of a tiny percentage of airline passengers whose disabilities currently give them priority over other passengers, and the majority of the people on the airplane.  The current expectation is that those latter passengers' rights have less priority, and consequently they must yield space, convenience, and absorb the cost (passed on indirectly by the airline) of special accommodation for the disabled people.  

It is not fair or reasonable to airline, or to the majority of the population, for example, to require a special, accessible lavatory in an aircraft with only one or two lavatories, nor to mandate special seat design, seat pitch, aisle width, etc., to serve a few passengers who may not even be aboard the majority of flights.  Similarly, it is not fair to the passengers or cabin crew to allow an unaccompanied (or even, in some cases, accompanied) passenger so severely disabled as to be unable to attend to his/her personal hygiene, is malodorous, unable to evacuate the airplane without blocking or delaying other passengers, unable to use a standard seat belt or fit into a standard aircraft seat or requires other significant special accommodations.  Safety issues as well as convenience for the majority of the passengers need to be considered here.      

"Service animals" were also addressed in this document.  It is widely known that "service animals" -- many of which generate significant discomfort and inconvenience for other passengers -- are being allowed in aircraft passenger cabins under circumstances where the associated passengers' real need for those animals' presence is questionable at best, and the animals' eligibility to be there is equally questionable.  Few people would object to a blind person's seeing-eye dog.  Many people would object to an obnoxious, yapping "companion" dog allowed aboard on the basis of a bogus note from a doctor.  The process for identifying which service animals are eligible for transportation in the passenger cabin obviously needs to be made more stringent.    

As these requirements are evolving, they become an increasingly unreasonable economic burden upon the airlines, and infringe the individual liberties of other passengers on the airplane . . . and consequently, I believe that applicable rules and policies need to be adjusted to establish a fair balance between the rights of disabled people and other passengers. 

I am a retired airline pilot and frequent airline traveler.

Title: Comment from Thida Cornes
Comment:
I'd like the definition of a service animal to be the same as the Department of Justice's. http://www.ada.gov/regs2010/service_animal_qa.html "Under the ADA, a service animal is defined as a dog that has been individually trained to do work or perform tasks for an individual with a disability.  The task(s) performed by the dog must be directly related to the person's disability."

I'd like inflight entertainment to include the option of closed captions on all programming.

Title: Comment from JoAnn Amann
Comment:
SERVICE ANIMALS
The FAA rules and regulations for service animals should reflect those of the Justice Department as defined in the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA). Emotional support animals I have observed on flights have appeared to be more frightened of flying and/or being on an airplane than their handlers - who supposedly need them. I've seen emotional support dogs wearing anti-anxiety jackets that are manufactured specifically for reducing stress in canines. The dogs more often than not bark at everyone and everything on the plane, including my hearing dog. 

ACCESSIBLE RESTROOMS
I believe that at least one (1) accessible restroom should be available on every airplane. When someone who needs one IS aboard a flight and unable to use the inaccessible restrooms, THAT is a definite hardship. If no one who "needs" the accessible restroom is on a flight, it would be available for anyone on board.

CAPTIONS
Airlines SHOULD provide captions for movies / entertainment on flights. Being unable to hear what's being said should NOT prevent those of us with hearing loss and/or deafness from enjoying the in-flight provided entertainment.

Title: Comment from Greg Bawden
Comment:
I encourage the federal government to take seriously the issue of accommodation in air travel.  I have a moderate-severe to severe hearing loss. I frequently travel by air for my work, pleasure, and service as an elected official.  

As a person with hearing loss, I dread all aspects of air travel because of the industry's  general disregard for people with this hidden disability.  On the planes, I cannot understand many cabin announcements (they are usually loud enough, sometimes painfully so, but often unintelligible).  I regularly get passed by for beverage and food service because I can't hear or understand the flight attendant's announcements/requests as they pass down the aisle.  Some planes have videos with captions showing the emergency procedures.  Most passenger aircraft do not.   I do not request any digi-players or other onboard video entertainment because it is generally not captioned.  And I am fortunate - my hearing loss fluctuates - I have some days/weeks/months when I hear quite well, others when I cannot.  I imagine that air travel is even more frustrating for my friends with consistently severe hearing loss.

While this is beyond the scope of this rule making, I find the entire process of navigating the airport frustrating, embarrassing, and insulting.  Going through the TSA checkpoint, there are very very few written instructions.  As I recently passed through a checkpoint, apparently there was a change in procedure.  When the TSA official called out an instruction to me, I didn't understand and said I have a hearing loss (and gestured towards my ears while saying this.)  The response was the same as it always is - they just repeat the instruction in the same voice, apparently at the same volume, only this time with a look of irritation. They NEVER offer any additional explanation or offer to write up a note or point to a written instruction.    (I have written to TSA and asked how to proceed and they said I can contact any TSA agent outside the checkpoint and ask for assistance.  This hasn't been successful yet.)  Airline boarding instructions - pretty much garbled.  Airport announcements.  Often loud and hard to make out.  

I urge the Dept. of Transportation to adopt the proposed rule making for assisting passengers on aircraft. It may seem like a big step for the airlines, but for people with hearing loss or mobility challenges, these are long overdue and welcome steps towards what (I hope will be) further changes to make travel fully accessible.

Title: Comment from Bark  Busters
Comment:
These accommodations are necessary! If all service dogs passed the programs out there, and their owners were put on a list, along with the prescribing Doctor's name, maybe we could stop the fraud!
The Autistic girl in this photo would not have been able to attend her H.S. graduation without her service dog, since fear of a meltdown would have typically caused her to stay home! Now she attends Jr. College without needing her dog. "It's too crazy for the dog!"

Title: Comment from Michele Erwin
Comment:
We are writing to you today to introduce our organization, All Wheels Up, Inc., a non for profit organization, which was created to solely advocate for the crash testing of wheelchairs for commercial flight purposes by the FAA.   Our Organization would like to work with you, as well as with airline manufacturers, on the future designs of new airplanes to be wheelchair accessible. We are specifically concerned about power chairs, in which the passenger is unable to transfer themselves, or in which traveling in a standard airline seat would risk their physical health and safety.
Currently, neither the Department of Transportation's Air Carrier Access Act nor the ADA resolves the needs for those who are dependent on wheelchairs and commercial flight.  The ADAs requirements for public transportation providers are generally the same whether they are public agencies or private contractors.  Standards apply to facilities and vehicles.  Unfortunately the airline industry has been excluded from having to make revisions to existing aircraft or from having to currently make any advancement in designs for future planes going into production.  We are requesting that the airline industry as a whole come together to address the lack of progress in this area and address the needs of the disabled flyer who uses  a wheelchair and can not be transferred or travel safely in a regular seat.
All Wheels Up, Inc.is here to be liaisons of information from the wheelchair industry, rehabilitation regulations industry, as well as providing financial data, to show you how safe and profitable it will be for wheelchair users to travel commercially.    We are also a professional organization that understands things do not change overnight. The reality is that at the end of the day a big business like yours wants to know the dollars and cents. 
So, what is the big picture, and how do you benefit?   First of all, we are not asking you to retrofit existing planes. This would be a huge expense. What we are asking is for you to look to the future and set the ground work for the future of aviation accessibility. And secondly, with the increasing number of people using wheelchairs each year, the airline industry will realize significant revenue exponential. 
As an industry, you are not just excluding the one person who is disabled from flying , but you are losing the revenue of the approximately four additional seat sales.  A disabled person rarely flies alone. They travel with their families, as well as, and in many cases with a care taker or nurse.  Do you want this this family of four, plus one care taker driving, to their next destination due to how difficult it is to fly?  if you get just half of the population that are in power chairs that currently does not fly to fly  your revenue would increase in the multi million dollar range. 
In 2008, one particular airline spent over $1 Million in wheelchair repairs.   This figure also does not include the expenses that airlines outlay every year to disabled travelers in lawsuits, free tickets, and additional items to prevent lawsuits.
Solution
The next step:  All Wheels Up has raised the funds and has done the research and will be conducting the first ever crash test of wheelchairs for commercial flight at an FAA approved Crash test facility.  We would like you to request the major aircraft manufacturers (Boeing and Airbus) to consider a design for wheel chair accessible cabins.  With this request, the FAA has confirmed they will act upon our request to crash test wheelchairs.  Take note, a large majority of the work and reports have already been conducted.  The FAA would only need to expand on the research already done from the company Q'straint, whose restraining systems have passed the 20 G crash test, while all air craft passenger seats have only passed a 16 G crash test. Due to this study alone, the FAA is excited to work on the crash testing wheelchairs for commercial flight.  In addition, hundreds of wheelchair models have already undergone extensive crash testing by the RERC  WTS (Rehabilitation Engineering Research Center on Wheelchair Transportation Safety) due to the WC18 regulation funded by the NIDRR (National Institute on Disability and Rehabilitation Research).  These tests conducted show all wheelchairs have also passes a 20 G frontal crash test, again surpassing the 16G crash test standard for commercial airline seats.
All Wheels up, and like minded companies, have the solution. All we need is you to take the next step with us. We look forward to you having further conversations with us regarding crash testing wheelchairs for commercial flight.

Michele Erwin
All Wheels Up Founder and President
917-414-0897

Title: Comment from Terry Babineau
Comment:
I am in a power (electric) wheelchair and I like to travel, especially by air.  Allowing a person such as myself to stay seated in my specially designed chair would make flying so much easier as well as much more comfortable.  I feel like a second-class citizen when I have to be transferred (lifted) from my wheelchair onto an aisle chair to be transferred into the airplane and then transferred (lifted) into the seat on the plane.  I worry about being dropped.  Most importantly, I worry that the people helping me might hurt themselves while transferring me.  Most often it has been the baggage handlers who have been assisting in my lifts, but I have also had firemen help as well.  I also worry about damage to my wheelchair while it is stored with the other luggage.  My wheelchair is rather expensive, approximately $25,000, and it's not easy to replace any specialized pieces that may get broken.  If I was allowed to board an airplane and then stay seated in my wheelchair during the flight, it would save a lot of time boarding, allow me to stay comfortable during the flight, keep people from becoming injured, and allow everyone to enjoy the flight.

Thank you for your time,

Terry Babineau.

Title: Comment from Denise Wetzler
Comment:
The ADA has been a benchmark for disability rights and inclusion since 1990. The ADA defines a service animal as: "...any dog that is individually trained to do work or perform tasks for the benefit of an individual with a disability, including a physical, sensory, psychiatric, intellectual, or other mental disability... The work or tasks performed by a service animal must be directly related to the handler's disability. Examples of work or tasks include, but are not limited to, assisting individuals who are blind or have low vision with navigation and other tasks, alerting individuals who are deaf or hard of hearing to the presence of people or sounds, providing non-violent protection or rescue work, pulling a wheelchair, assisting an individual during a seizure, alerting individuals to the presence of allergens, retrieving items such as medicine or the telephone, providing physical support and assistance with balance and stability to individuals with mobility disabilities, and helping persons with psychiatric and neurological disabilities by preventing or interrupting impulsive or destructive behaviors." 

This notion that there are a lot of passengers falsely claiming their pets as service animals is unfounded. This premise has not been borne out by research. The rationale has been that passengers have tried to say their dog is for a psychiatric disability. Given the stigma surrounding mental illness, very few people are going to fake a service dog for a psychiatric disability. 

First, although it is not specifically addressed in the proposed rulemaking, individuals with psychiatric disabilities are currently treated differently than individuals with other disabilities. They are the only class of individuals with a disability that must provide documentation for their disability. I propose that the requirements for individuals using a service dog for a psychiatric disability be removed, and those individuals treated the same as any other passenger with a disability. A service dog for an individual with a psychiatric disability is trained to the same standard as for other disabilities. By imposing the 48 hours advance notice and the letter from a mental health professional, the ACAA places an undue burden on this class of individuals, especially if last minute travel for an emergency or death in the family must be arranged. It further stigmatizes this population. I support leaving in place the requirements for passengers flying with an emotional support animal. These are pets, not highly trained service animals.

The ADA goes on to state: Inquiries. A public accommodation shall not ask about the nature or extent of a person's disability, but may make two inquiries to determine whether an animal qualifies as a service animal. A public accommodation may ask if the animal is required because of a disability and what work or task the animal has been trained to perform. A public accommodation shall not require documentation, such as proof that the animal has been certified, trained, or licensed as a service animal. Generally, a public accommodation may not make these inquiries about a service animal when it is readily apparent that an animal is trained to do work or perform tasks for an individual with a disability (e.g., the dog is observed guiding an individual who is blind or has low vision, pulling a person's wheelchair, or providing assistance with stability or balance to an individual with an observable mobility disability)." Note that the ADA states that when it is readily apparent that an animal is trained to do work or perform tasks, generally the public accommodation may not inquire whether it is a service dog and what work or tasks the dog is trained to do. A non disabled individual can easily be ferreted out by asking what work or task the dog is trained to do.  A service dog can be identified by its training and behavior. Granted, even service dogs have off days, but they are far better behaved than pets.

The ACAA is currently at odds with the ADA on both of these counts. By aligning the definition of service animal with the ADA, it reduces the confusion between the myriad of laws out there that pertain to service animals. Adopting a uniform definition of a service animals helps everyone, not just the service dog handler. Asking the handler to name the work or tasks the dog has been trained to do (if it is not readily apparent) is yet another way to determine if the handler is truly disabled. The ADA also states that a service dog may be properly excluded: "A public accommodation may ask an individual with a disability to remove a service animal from the premises if: (i) The animal is out of control and the animal's handler does not take effective action to control it; or (ii) The animal is not housebroken." Again, the ADA has safeguards in place to protect the public accommodation.

I strongly encourage changing the definition of service animal to align with the definition in the ADA.

Title: Comment from Zoey Hicks
Comment: Making the ACAA congruent with DOJ and ADA when comes to psychiatric service dogs and PTSD. IE: ACAA requires doctors letter for PTSD and psychiatric trained service dogs are still tasked  trained service dogs and should not require a letter. Only ESA are required note only. Also would be nice to have more protection for bulk head seating for service dogs. Zoey

Title: Comment from Carrie Andrews
Comment:
My service dog and I have always been treated well on flights.  Recently, I've moved to a small town which is near a small airport.  Because of the airport's size, the smaller planes are used; ones with no first class, and the bulkhead is the exit row.  The seats on these planes are smaller than ones found on larger planes. At this time, I have a German Shepherd service dog who will be flying with me in February.  On these smaller planes, it is difficult (if not impossible) to adhere to the requirement that she fit in front of my legs in the smaller rows.  Thankfully the agent at Alaska Air agreed to try to keep the seat next to us so that my dog has the ability to fit while still staying out of the isle.  Since more and more disabled people are flying with their service dogs, I would propose that one of the rows be removed, making a second bulkhead-sized seating area.  That way every flight is capable of carrying up to 4 people with service dogs or conditions where a person is unable to bend their knees.

In addition, I propose that there be an accessible bathroom on all flights.  People like me are unable to walk more than a few steps without an assistive device or my harnessed service dog.  When traveling alone, I would not be able to use the facilities because my service animal will not fit in the lavatory with me. While my upcoming trip is only a 2 hour flight, we do have trips planned which would include flight legs 5 hours or longer.  For both me and my service dog, that is just too long to wait.

Thank you for considering the concerns of disabled people such as myself.

Title: Comment from Darlene Shaw
Comment:
Help is DESPARATELY needed for the disabled passengers on air flights. Traveling has become increasingly difficult since 9-11 and airlines increasingly greedy in turning the planes into human stables. My family is very reluctant to travel anywhere that requires air planes because past trips have been so difficult. The leg room is completely inadequate for the mobility challenged and the bathrooms are ridiculous for anyone.
Boarding and unboarding has been very difficult in many places either because the airline was not properly prepared (like on the Big Island of Hawaii) or because the flight is on a small plane. Security is also difficult. My family member is 77 and has a knee replacement in one leg and a steel plate in the other, so she always has to experience the extended search. Cards should be issued to disabled travelers so they are not subjected to this procedure every time they fly. It's tiring and humiliating for them.

Title: Comment from Laurren Storck
Comment:
For the DOT concerning Air Carrier Access Act Implementation - Docket No. DOT OST 2015-0246

We were pleased to see the announcement https://cms.dot.gov/briefing-room/dot-explores-consensus-based-initiative-make-flying-easier-individuals-disabilities and also the notice of intent http://www.regulations.gov/#!documentDetail;D=DOT-OST-2015-0246-0001 pertaining to Air Travel Access. 

For the membership of the CCAC (CCACaptioning.org) and many others, we submit these concerns: 

IFE must become accessible with quality captioning that offers reasonable choices to all airline passengers since, as paying passengers, we and the airlines benefit from accessible in-flight entertainments. However, IFE seems a too-narrow focus for this Negotiated Rulemaking Process. 
 
Importantly and in addition to IFE concerns, we strongly suggest two other areas that are vital for access and inclusion of people with hearing loss and deafness who use captioning for understanding speech - (1) airport announcements and also (2) in-flight announcements.
 
Safety in airports and in-flight also are surely major concerns for everyone. Announcements in the airport, always considered essential for air travel, need to become visible with quality speech-to-text (live captioning). Sudden emergencies of any sort, gate changes after arriving at gates (not to miss the flight), and any other airport announcements can use existing technologies to create access with live captioning, not only for deaf and hard of hearing people, but also for so many with different fist languages or other conditions that use captioning for comprehension (e.g. autism, tinnitus, auditory perceptual differences). 

Similarly, we ague that in-flight announcements are vital for safety and equal communication access in-flight. Information access of any and all announcements is required. Not only people who are deaf or have a hearing loss need this information, live and real-time; there are many others in-flight (hearing also) who do not understand these announcements, and safety and calm environments in-flight are just as important as always, for everyone.  

We hope that the DOT agrees and finds ways to include these concerns along with IFE matters. 
Respectfully,
Lauren E. Storck (PhD). 
President, Collaborative for Communication Access via Captioning (CCACaptioning.org) - Volunteer Citizen Captioning Advocates, Official 501(c)3 Non-Profit Organization.  
 
CCACAPTIONING@GMAIL.COM
twitter.com/CCACaptioning
www.facebook.com/ccac.captioning
www.youtube.com/user/CCACORG/videos

Title: Comment from Owen Kent
Comment: It's very important that restrooms on airplanes become accessible. Anything less is discrimination.

Title: Comment from Dave Gaines
Comment:
I support the reg neg process here. It is collaborative and provides significant influential power to the stakeholders impacted by the regulation. The reg neg process has been previously utilized specifically for this airline disability access issue. It has resulted in regulations being enacted. However, I am unfamiliar with the details of the previous reg neg process for this specific issue, so I am unable to determine what, if any, problems were encountered previously that may indicate potential problems for another reg neg process. While a determination on whether or not to use reg neg this time around should not be made solely on the basis of the success or problems of the previous reg neg process, the current determination should take previous reg negs for airline disability access into consideration.

In deciding to utilize the reg neg process again, a key factor to examine is whether the potential members of an advisory committee can engage in the reg neg process with good faith. Committee members must possess a genuine interest in working collaboratively, hearing all sides of the issue, operating with honesty and transparency, and supporting statements and claims with verifiable facts and information.

Also, the reg neg process may require time and patience. Negotiations, particularly where participants are initially far from a consensus, require a back-and-forth process to be successful. Sometimes this back-and-forth can be tedious and time-extensive. The more that the back-and-forth can occur - meaning, the more time that is available for the negotiations - the higher the likelihood of the reg neg process resulting in success. As such, one factor to consider in whether to use the reg neg process, is the amount of time available for the process. This examination of available time must include the time that potential committee members have to commit to the process, the time the federal agency has available to allow the process, the time that is available according to available resources, such as money, that are needed to support the reg neg process, and the urgency of need for regulations to be enacted.

In conclusion, I wish to point out that technology and creative-thinking will assist in overcoming any logistic barriers to the reg neg process and will also allow for more diverse committee members, particularly in the case of committee members with disabilities (disabilities can include physical disabilities and mental disabilities). The reg neg process itself needs to be accessible to all stakeholders.

Title: Comment from Psychiatric Service Dog Partners
Comment:
Psychiatric Service Dog Partners' comment is attached, and is also available through our advocacy page:

     http://www.psychdogpartners.org/board-of-directors/board-activities/advocacy

Thank you for this opportunity to have a dialogue and hopefully reach meaningful consensus on the important issued raised in this proposed Reg Neg.

Title: Comment from Deborah Stai
Comment:
Good day.
I am writing today to share my support that PSDP (Psychiatric Service Dog Partners) represents my interest in the proposal negotiated rule making (docket DOT-OST-2015-0246).

PSDP is a peer advocacy group that represents myself and so many more that deal with mental illness, psychiatric disabilities daily, most for life.  Many take an active role in their recovery to lead a "normal" life by the use of a service dog. So that we might enjoy life day to day, as described by ADA.  

If it were not for PSDP, I'd be alone, in my home.  It was through finding this group, that allowed me to approach my Primary care Doctor and discuss my need for a service dog.  My Doctor and my therapist agree a service dog is required for my illness.  I have a letter. 

Please include PSDP in your dialogue that pertains to this most important rule that will affect so very many lives. Please speak to those that walk in my shoes.  

Thank you.

Title: Comment from J. S.
Comment: As someone who needs a psychiatric service dog, I believe that Psychiatric Service Dog Partners should be part of the negotiated rulemaking process.

Title: Comment from Carol F. King
Comment:
I am strongly in favor of non-discrimination of types of Service Dogs on Air Lines (type of disability the dog assist.)  I am now a member of Psychiatric Service Dog Partners (PSDP).
A number of years ago while I was on the Board of Directors for IAADP, I personally worked with DOT on some of these same issues.  Katherine Blank will still remember me.  In a national transportation publication I (Carol F. King) was named as the single most helpful voice, for the Air Line Companies involved, explaining the difference between Service Dogs for Mental Illness and Emotional Support Dogs.
At this time my Service Dog does Hearing Work, and Medical Alert for me, as well as helps me with Mental Illness.
In 2005 I worked with Homeland Security and FEMA on writing new guidelines for people with disabilities in disasters.  Up until that time, people with disabilities were not invited to the table to form policies for their own needs.
Because of my work on the Board of IAADP, I have worked with people with all types of disabilities, and their Service Dogs, so I was/am a good well rounded advocate for all types of disabilities, and not just "one group" which we ran into allot of on the committee.  Each group wanted "their" needs to take center stage and be most important in policy making.  I was able to see and work to get the best treatment for all disabled with compromise and lots of communication.  I would love to be of assistance again.

Title: Comment from Linden Gue
Comment:
I use a Service Dog to mitigate psychiatric disabilities.  I have been greatly disturbed by the current ACAA rules regarding people with psychiatric disabilities who travel with Service Dogs.  I have family distant to me and may need to fly suddenly.  Current rules don't allow me to do that if accompanied by my Service Dog.

I support including Psychiatric Service Dog Partners (PSDP) in the process of reviewing the current rules.  I believe there can be safe, fair and reasonable regulations for all Service Dog handlers to fly on available carriers.

Title: Comment from Roberta Newlin
Comment:
I have CMT, a form of MD. At this stage I'm confined to a wheelchair. So air travel is challenging to say the least. My husband and I love to take cruises and would love to travel over seas to see the rest of the world but about the longest airplane ride my bladder can stand is 5 hours. Plus the act of not eating or drinking anything for many hours before we start our trip and up to arriving at our destination. ADA restroom on the plane would be a wonderful help but getting to the restroom would also need to be a consideration. If you've ever had the experience of using an aisle chair you understand what I'm saying, in an empty plane it's tough but trying to use it with people already seated not sure how that would work out. If passengers like me could be placed close to the ADA restroom it would be wonderful. 
My family and I would love to travel more and greater distances and being able to use the restroom would enable me to do so. 
Thank you,
Roberta Newlin

Title: Comment from Dena Gassner
Comment:
My name is Dena Gassner and I am a wife, mother, grandmother, parent to an autistic son, and an autistic. I fly frequently. I find the inconsistency that I endure in soliciting and obtaining accommodations when traveling. 
My necessary accommodations include expedited TSA screening (crowds cause incapacitating anxiety), pre-boarding and seating near the front of the plane as possible. My limited income disallows me from paying for premium seating, but again, anxiety makes it so I ask for this option.
Due to the invisible nature of my disability, again and again I find myself challenged and doubted by personnel throughout the process. I carry a card from my doctor. I notify the airline. But I continue to have difficulty.
My son, on the other hand, is more externally manifesting in his autism. He rarely deals with this kind of discrimination. However, this process is no less challenging for me than it is for him. 
I serve on two national boards (GRASP and the Arc) and as an advisory board member for the Autism Society. I am seeking my PhD while living in the dorm at age 56. I am not easily discouraged or defeated.  Yet, I continue to endure increasing anxiety when traveling because this happens.
Please let me know if there is any way I can provide testimony or provide my experiences which have at times, left me incapacitated upon arrival. One such experience is noted as attached.

Title: Comment from Monica McClain
Comment:
My name is Monica McClain. I am 60 yrs. old, and have been disabled for many years. I use a Service dog for Mobility/Balance Assistance. I am on my third Service Dog now. My first two dogs were trained by me and because of my states law I had to have them tested and certified by a Service dog organization at that time.  By the time my current Service dog came along, my states laws had changed. I trained this dog as I did my first two, but since I no longer under Federal Law needed certification, I employed a trainer to test my present dog and make sure that she like my first two dogs was able to work in public and remain unobtrusive, and able to do the tasks I required of her. In addition to that I did some additional, but not required testing with my trainer. My present Service Dog , as my last two Service Dogs is a well mannered and focused dog. We are always welcome in places of business where we live and travel as well as Public Transportation, and Greyhound. My Service dog was recommended by my Doctors to help me with my Mobility issues. I have been around many Service dogs over the years. I have seen program trained dogs that were both good and bad.  I have also seen Owner Trained Service dogs who were good and bad.  Being an owner trainer myself. I want to stand up for those who have task trained Service Dogs they have trained themselves or with the help of a private trainer. This is not something that is easy to do. Like program dogs. Many hours of training go into these dogs. You don't just slap on a vest and go. It is more involved. It takes at least 18 mos. to 2 years to fully train a puppy from the ground up to be a Service Dog. It involves hard work on your part as well as the Dogs part. As an owner trainer, I am dedicated to presenting the public with a well behaved Service Dog. I keep my Service dogs training sharp for the working life of that Dog.  In recent years we have seen the increase of people who use Service Dogs and we have also seen the Emotional Support animals.
I believe that in regards to that later type of animal, I have seen too much that was ridiculous. But, the Air lines need to shoulder some of this blame for allowing untrained animals like Pigs, parrots, barking yapping unhousebroken dogs and cats, and finally that Turkey on an Air plane as an Emotional Support Animal. I am one who well knows the comfort an animal can bring. But that said I believe that only dogs and the miniature horses can and should be Service Animals. As for ESA's they should be completely done away with. Only task trained Service dogs and Psychiatric Service dogs should be allowed to fly. I don't believe a person needs to be forced to show any one their doctors letter in order to travel. Ones disability is their business. But that brings us to a need to separate the Fake service dogs from the real. I don't know how that can be done fairly. Id's aren't a good way because anyone can go on line and pay money and get a fake ID and vests. The airlines may have to set up a program within to stop these fakers. But please stop these things like Turkeys from flying. In setting up a program for Air travel and persons with disabilities who use a Service Dog Please do not exclude Owner Trainers, and the Psychiatric Service Dog community.

Sincerely, 

Monica McClain

Title: Comment from Alan Bates
Comment:
Over the past decade, several private vendors have attempted to bring anti-idling services to the heavy duty trucking market. Over that time, data has shown that Truck Stop Electrification ("TSE") significantly reduces fuel use, fuel costs, engine wear, and noise. The data and customer feedback confirmed that TSE is desirable and affordable, and the service earned many devoted customers.  The drawbacks:  too few TSE facilities to meet the need; limited truck parking spaces (which discouraged non-customers from leaving TSE parking spaces open for plug-in customers);  lack of driver awareness of the service; dependence on truck stop staff to promote the service; and lack of interest on the part of national truck fleets due to limited availability. 

Recently completed DOE-funded projects stimulated the economy by returning 250% of the original grant monies; reducing diesel fuel consumption and exhaust emissions; adding 66,268 FTE labor hours to the economy; and doubling the number of truck stop electrification sites in the nation.  The stimulus had a ripple effect within the trucking industry which continues. During the project period, major truck manufacturers such as Daimler-Freightliner began installing idle reduction equipment as standard on their production models.  The idle reduction equipment manufacturers (of APUs and eTRUs) increased their sales, improved their technology, set up brokers, and increased sales staff.  Fleets installed private electrification installations in their yards and staging areas.  

For more information, please see "Interstate Electrification Improvement Project             Final Report." 

Shore power is now a more common term in the trucking industry (and no longer only associated with marine vessels).  It is a well-known alternative power source thats cheaper than idling, and tangible not a concept or experiment. Industry spokespeople state its only a matter of time before shore power is available everywhere, and they see it coming. 

The current 115 TSE sites (both on-board and off-board technology) are an insufficient number to serve the long haul trucking industry and earn enough to support an enterprise without heavy education and outreach efforts.

Lack of open parking spaces next to power pedestals is a very significant barrier to TSE.  Users of crowded truck stops will not leave a space open for a customer because they may not get any other space otherwise.  Sites with consistent utilization always had adequate parking for overnight customers. Limited truck parking is a serious national problem that is challenging to solve, however, other options should be considered immediately including reserved paid parking at the power outlets; an idle-free zone at the connection points that is enforced; and parking priority given to major fleets and regular customers. Existing customers state they are willing to pay between $12 and $25 per night for a reserved space at a power pedestal.  

Any current or future highway funding or legislation should include concessions for Truck Stop Electrification infrastructure and encourage uptake through outreach and education campaigns.  Any new parking facilities should be required to install a minimum percentage of electrified parking spaces, allowing drivers to save fuel and emissions. 

It is estimated that there should be at least another 200 well-sited facilities to meet the operational needs of the truck drivers and fleets, and reach the critical mass needed to foster widespread adoption by large fleets.  Future study might determine the best strategy for expansion: 1) Concentrate sites on a very busy corridor and space them 100 to 150 miles apart, or 2) Space sites no more than 500 mile intervals on Interstates nationwide, along routes used by large trucking fleets.
